ARTICLE IV. - RENTAL FACILITIES USED FOR PUBLIC ADMISSION EVENTS[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 80-703, § 1, adopted June 26, 2012, amended art. IV in its entirety, in effect repealing and reenacting said article to read as herein set out. The former art. IV, §§ 6-76 and 6-91—6-94, pertained to public dance halls and derived from § 3-406 of the 1967 Code. 
 
DIVISION 1. - PURPOSE 
 
Sec. 6-76. - Purpose. 
It is the intent and purpose of this article to provide regulations to ensure the preservation of order and decorum and to protect the public peace when rental facilities are used for general admission events that are open to the general public. 
(Ord. No. 80-703, § 1, 6-26-12)  
DIVISION 2. - DEFINITIONS 
 
Sec. 6-77. - Definitions. 
For purposes of this article, the following words and phrases shall be defined as follows: 
Capacity. The maximum number of persons allowed to occupy a room or floor area of a place of assembly. 
Net floor area . The floor area of a building or room intended for occupancy, excluding ancillary areas such as kitchens, washrooms, service rooms, janitor closets, cloakrooms, structural elements and fixtures permanently affixed to the floor. Net floor area is an assembly space where the public is expected to or may assemble. Seating, either affixed or unattached, and tables incidental to seating are included in net floor area. Areas that may be deducted from the gross floor area of a building or room to calculate the net floor area include: 
(1)  Bar fixtures and areas behind the bar; 
(2)  Items permanently affixed to the floor, or deemed by their nature to not be easily moved such as pool and gaming tables and gaming devices; 
(3)  Stages and platforms which are intended for performance only; 
(4)  Fixed counter tops; 
(5)  Fountains, aquariums and other large decorative items. 
Private event . A banquet, luncheon, entertainment, dance, party, sports event or other event or activity held at a place of assembly where guests are invited and admission is limited to the invited guests without any fee or charge required. 
Public admission event . Is an event held at a place of assembly for entertainment, dance, party, sports or other event or activity open to the public who may gain admission by paying a fee, payment of an admission charge or the rental of the premises to conduct an activity where the public generally may gain access with or without payment of a fee. 
Rental facility. Is a place of assembly such as any hall, room, building, portion of a building or other place of assembly available for rent, lease or loan for the purpose of public assembly, banquets, luncheons, entertainment, dances or sports events including facilities operated as a commercial establishment, a noncommercial establishment, or a private hall as defined as follows: 
(1)  Commercial rental facility . A rental facility operated for profit. 
(2)  Noncommercial rental facility. A rental facility operated by a nonprofit organization, such as a union, religious organization, fraternal organization, school. 
(3)  Private hall. The hall is available only to members and their invited guests who are not required to pay an admission charge or any fee. Includes social clubs and residential community buildings as follows: 
a.  Private social club . A private facility operated by a social organization which limits use to its members and invited guests. 
b.  Residential community building/clubhouse. Private facilities provided to the residents of a residential community and which limits use of the facilities to its residents. 
(Ord. No. 80-703, § 1, 6-26-12)  
DIVISION 3. - PERMIT REQUIRED FOR PUBLIC ADMISSION EVENTS HELD AT RENTAL FACILITIES 
 
Sec. 6-78. - Permit required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to use a rental facility for a public admission event, as defined herein, without first obtaining a permit from the city clerk as provided in this division. 
(b)  The owner/operator of a rental facility is required to give written notice to any person renting the facility for a public admission event that a permit is required to hold the public admission event at the rental facility, and that the renter shall limit admission to the capacity number for the facility as specified on the permit. 
(Ord. No. 80-703, § 1, 6-26-12)  
Sec. 6-79. - Permit exemptions. 
Exempt from the provisions of this article are: 
(1)  Private events; 
(2)  Events held at private halls such as social clubs and residential community buildings where use of the facility is limited to its membership and their invited guests who are not required to pay an admission charge or any fee; and 
(3)  Dances and events sponsored by public or private schools, civic clubs, charitable organizations under IRS Code 501(c)(3), veterans' groups, fraternal societies, political and campaign action committees, church or religious societies and the chamber of commerce; 
(4)  Catering and banquet facilities where the owner provides entertainment and sells tickets or charges an admission, such as a dinner theatre; and 
(5)  Events held at auditoriums and exposition centers which are multipurpose facilities designed specifically for public admission events. 
(Ord. No. 80-703, § 1, 6-26-12)  
Sec. 6-80. - Application for a public admission event permit. 
Applicants for a public admission event permit shall file a completed application with the city clerk at least thirty (30) days prior to the date of the event. The application shall be signed as required by this section and notarized. An application is considered complete when it contains all information required by this section and is accompanied by the required fee. 
(1)  The applicant's full name, business address, and if different, applicant's mailing address. 
(2)  The business name, location, address, and phone number, and if a corporation under the laws of what state the corporation is incorporated. 
(3)  The name of the person who will manage or supervise the public admission event, the local address and permanent address of such individual, the capacity in which such person will act, whether as promoter, agent or otherwise. 
(4)  The fingerprints of the applicant and the person who will manage or supervise the public admission event. 
(5)  A statement as to whether the person who will manage or supervise the public admission event has been convicted of any crime or violation of any city ordinance including the nature of the offense(s) and the punishment imposed. 
(6)  Proof of insurance policies in amounts as required by section 6-83. 
(7)  Submission of a cash bond as required by section 6-84. 
(8)  A statement as to the number of parking spaces required by the ordinance and the number of parking spaces provided. 
(9)  If alcohol will be served or permitted on the premises, a copy of the license issued by the liquor control commission. 
(10)  Any other information the city clerk may deem necessary to protect the public good relating to the identity or character of the person who will manage or supervise the business or the method or plan of doing such business. 
(11)  The application shall be signed by the applicant, if an individual; by all the partners, if a partnership; or by the authorized officers, if a corporation. 
(Ord. No. 80-703, § 1, 6-26-12)  
Sec. 6-81. - Permit fee. 
A permit fee shall be required for each public admission event permit as prescribed in section 18-18. 
(Ord. No. 80-703, § 1, 6-26-12)  
Sec. 6-82. - Local agent. 
If the applicant is acting as agent for another, or the applicant will have an agent performing the applicant's duties, the applicant shall be required to file with the application an instrument acknowledging the agent as the true and lawful agent with full power and authority to acknowledge service of process on behalf of the principal in respect to any matters arising out of the public admission event. 
(Ord. No. 80-703, § 1, 6-26-12)  
Sec. 6-83. - Insurance required; certificate of insurance. 
As a condition precedent to the issuance of a public admission event permit, the applicant shall file with the city clerk proof of a general liability insurance policy issued by a company licensed to do business in the state for premise and public liability covering injuries to persons and wrongful deaths from the negligence or willfulness of the permit holder, his or her agents, servants or employees in an amount not less than one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) each occurrence. The policy shall also include a provision that the insurer shall notify the City of Warren of any modification or cancellation of the insurance policy. 
(Ord. No. 80-703, § 1, 6-26-12)  
Sec. 6-84. - Bond required. 
To ensure the preservation of order and decorum and to protect the public peace, a cash bond in the amount of one thousand five hundred dollars ($1,500.00) shall be posted with the city treasurer. The bond shall be returned to the permit holder after the event, unless the police and/or fire department is dispatched to the event to respond to a breach of the peace, a civil disobedience or disorderly premises. In the event the police and/or fire department are dispatched to the event, the bond shall be applied to the costs incurred for the police and/or fire response. 
(Ord. No. 80-703, § 1, 6-26-12)  
Sec. 6-85. - Investigation and approval. 
No permit shall be issued without the required investigation and approvals. The city clerk shall forward the application to the following officials for investigation and approval: 
(1)  The police commissioner shall conduct an investigation of the applicant's moral character pursuant to the standards and procedures set forth in section 18-8 of this Code. After such investigation, the police commissioner shall endorse upon the application his or her approval or disapproval and forward the application to the city clerk. 
(2)  In the event alcohol will be served, the liquor and licensing officer of the city police department shall conduct an investigation of the liquor control commission records related to the applicant and this location. After investigation, the officer shall endorse upon the application his or her approval or disapproval and forward the application to the city clerk. 
(3)  The fire inspection division shall conduct an inspection of the premises to determine the capacity of the facility, and if the rental facility complies with all applicable provisions of the International Fire Code and State Construction Code, as amended. After such investigation, the fire commissioner shall endorse upon the application his or her approval or disapproval and the capacity number for the facility, and forward the application to the city clerk. No permit shall be issued until an inspection has been conducted and the fire commissioner has approved, in writing, such issuance. 
(4)  the zoning official who shall review the application to determine whether the property is properly zoned for the proposed use; the required off site parking is provided; and if located within a residential district or within two hundred (200) feet of a residential district. The zoning official shall endorse upon the application his or her approval or disapproval and forward the application to the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 80-703, § 1, 6-26-12)  
Sec. 6-86. - Issuance of permit. 
The city clerk shall issue the public admission event permit for the date and location specified upon: 
(1)  Demonstrated compliance with all applicable regulations contained in this Code; and 
(2)  Receipt of all the following approvals: police commissioner, fire commissioner, zoning official, and if applicable, by the liquor and licensing officer. 
(Ord. No. 80-703, § 1, 6-26-12)  
Sec. 6-87. - Permit contents. 
The permit shall contain the permit number, the date the permit is issued, the date of the event, the hours of the event, the address where the public admission event will be held, the capacity of the rental facility, the name of the person authorized to conduct the event, and the name of the local agent. 
(Ord. No. 80-703, § 1, 6-26-12)  
Sec. 6-88. - Display of permit; nontransferable. 
The permit issued under this article shall be posted conspicuously on the premises. If the person applying for the permit shall desire to hold events in more than one (1) place within the city, or on more than one (1) date, a separate permit shall be required for each location and each date the event is held. The permit shall be posted conspicuously in each place. Any permit issued pursuant to this article is nontransferable. 
(Ord. No. 80-703, § 1, 6-26-12)  
Sec. 6-89. - Denial, revocation, suspension. 
Any permit issued pursuant to this article may be denied, revoked or suspended pursuant to the standards and procedures set forth in section 18-12. 
(Ord. No. 80-703, § 1, 6-26-12)  
Secs. 6-90—6-94. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - REGULATIONS 
 
Sec. 6-95. - Capacity. 
The capacity shall be the lesser number of: 
(1)  The design occupant load, as defined in Section 1004.1 of the International Fire Code; or 
(2)  An alternative occupant load calculated by dividing the net floor area, in units of square feet, by the pertinent occupant per unit of area factor in Table 1004.1.1 of the International Fire Code. In all cases, the means of egress of the room or space shall be sufficient to handle the calculated occupant load. The capacity shall never exceed one (1) occupant per seven (7) square feet of net floor area as defined in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 80-703, § 1, 6-26-12)  
Sec. 6-96. - Alcohol. 
No person, including the permit holder, shall sell, offer for sale, trade, provide, allow, possess, consume or attempt to consume any alcoholic liquor on premises of the rental facility unless the operator of the facility or the permit holder has obtained the appropriate permit from the liquor control commission pursuant to MCL 436.1101 et seq., as amended. 
(Ord. No. 80-703, § 1, 6-26-12)  
Sec. 6-97. - Hours of operation. 
(a)  The hours of operation a public admission event held at a rental facility located in a residential district or within two hundred (200) feet of a residential district, shall be 7:00 a.m. to 12:00 midnight. 
(b)  The hours of operation of a public admission event at a rental facility located further than two hundred (200) feet of a residential district shall be 7:00 a.m. to 2:00 a.m. 
(Ord. No. 80-703, § 1, 6-26-12)  
Sec. 6-98. - Outdoor events. 
There shall not be any outdoor activities or outdoor public admission events at the rental facility unless it complies with Section 4.35 of the Zoning Ordinance and approval was granted by the zoning board of appeals, and if required, pursuant to site plan approval by the planning commission. In no event shall an approved outdoor event/activity take place in any area required and designated for on-site parking. 
(Ord. No. 80-703, § 1, 6-26-12)  
Sec. 6-99. - Parking lot. 
Adequate on-site parking for passenger vehicles shall be provided as required by the zoning ordinance and pursuant to an approved site plan. 
(Ord. No. 80-703, § 1, 6-26-12)  
Sec. 6-100. - Outdoor lighting required. 
The permit proposed for the public admission event shall not be approved unless the applicant demonstrates there is outdoor lighting on the premises and in the parking lot for security purposes. 
(Ord. No. 80-703, § 1, 6-26-12)  
Sec. 6-101. - Local agent on premises; capacity. 
The permit holder, or the local agent named on the application, shall remain on the premises for the duration of the public admission event to supervise the activities and shall be responsible to ensure the capacity does not exceed the number specified on the permit. 
(Ord. No. 80-703, § 1, 6-26-12)  
Sec. 6-102. - Disorderly premises/disturbing the peace. 
The permit holder, or the local agent named on the application, shall be responsible to maintain the public admission event to ensure there is not a violation of either section 22-113 of this Code for disorderly premises; or section 22-107 for disturbing the public peace. A conviction for disorderly premises or disturbing the peace shall be grounds for revocation, denial or suspension of a permit. 
(Ord. No. 80-703, § 1, 6-26-12)  
Sec. 6-103. - Minors. 
In the event there is possession or consumption of alcohol on the premises, a permit holder shall not allow the admission or attendance of any person who is under the age of twenty-one (21) to any public admission event. 
(Ord. No. 80-703, § 1, 6-26-12)  
Secs. 6-104—6-108. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 5. - PENALTY 
 
Sec. 6-109. - Penalty. 
The violation of any provision of Article IV is a misdemeanor which shall, upon conviction, be punishable by a fine not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisonment for a term not exceeding ninety (90) days or both, plus costs and other sanctions for each violation. 
(Ord. No. 80-703, § 1, 6-26-12)  
Sec. 6-110. - Permit eligibility. 
A permit holder convicted of violating any of the provisions of this Article IV shall not be eligible to apply for another permit for a period of three (3) years. 
(Ord. No. 80-703, § 1, 6-26-12)

(Code 1967, § 3-412)  
Sec. 6-137. - Posting of prices. 
The scale of prices for admission to any theater shall be framed and hung at some conspicuous place at the entrance of the theater. 
(Code 1967, § 3-408)

The applicant shall file a surety bond with a company authorized to do business in this state in an amount of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) indemnifying and agreeing to pay the city all damages, indebtedness or loss to the city arising from any acts or omissions of the licensee, his or her agents, servants, employees or his or her lessees or licensees, in the operation of such business. 
(Code 1967, § 3-125(10); Ord. No. 80-320, § 1(10), 5-13-86)

ARTICLE VIII. - AMUSEMENT PARKS AND RIDING DEVICES

Sec. 6-211. - Required.

Sec. 6-212. - Fee.

Sec. 6-213. - Insurance and bond requirement. 
(a)  As a condition precedent to the issuance of any license for amusement parks or places, the applicant shall file with the city proof of a standard liability insurance policy or policies issued by a company licensed to do business in the state for public liability covering injuries to persons and wrongful deaths from the negligence or willfulness of the licensee, his or her agents, servants or employees in an amount not less than two hundred fifty thousand dollars ($250,000.00) for any one (1) person and not less than five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) for more than one (1) person and property damage of not less than one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00). The applicant shall file a surety bond with a company authorized to do business, in this state in an amount of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00), indemnifying and agreeing to pay the city all damages, indebtedness or loss to the city arising from any acts or omissions of the licensee, his or her agents, servants, employees or his or her lessees or licensees, in the operation of the business. 
(b)  As a condition precedent to the issuance of any license for amusement riding or moving devices, the applicant shall file with the city proof of a standard liability insurance policy or policies issued by a company licensed to do business in the state for public liability covering injuries to persons and wrongful deaths from the negligence or willfulness of the licensee, his or her agents, servants or employees in an amount not less than two hundred fifty thousand dollars ($250,000.00) for any one (1) person and not less than five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) for more than one (1) person and property damage of not less than one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00). The applicant shall file a surety bond with a company authorized to do business in this state in an amount of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) indemnifying and agreeing to pay the city all damages, indebtedness or loss to the city arising from any acts or omissions of the licensee, his or her agents, servants, employees, or his or her lessees or licensees, in the operation of the business. 
(Code 1967, § 3-125(3), (4); Ord. No. 80-320, § 1(3), (4), 5-13-86)  
Secs. 6-214—6-225. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IX. - AMUSEMENT MACHINES[9] 
Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
Cross reference— Vending machines, Ch. 40. 
State Law reference— Pinball machines permitted in liquor establishments, MCL 436.28a; offense concerning coin operated devices, MCL 752.811. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 6-226. - Definitions. 
The following words and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them: 
Aisle means a passageway providing for traverse of pedestrian traffic. 
Amusement machine means any mechanically or electronically operated device or video device requiring the insertion of a coin or token for commencement of its operation and which is offered for use by the public as a game, entertainment or amusement, including children's rides but excluding shuffleboards, electronic dart boards, pool tables, billiard tables, or juke boxes as licensed under other applicable Code provisions. 
Amusement machine center means a commercial establishment where five (5) or more amusement machines, not including music vending machines or jukeboxes, are offered for use by the public. 
Amusement machine center owner means an owner of an amusement machine center. 
Distributor means any person who places any amusement machine, in any place or establishment for operation and for the purpose of receiving any type of compensation. 
Exitway means an entranceway or exitway doorway providing for entrance into the building or premises from a public way. 
Owner means any person, including an agent or employee, who operates, conducts or has charge or control of any place or establishment in which an amusement machine is available for operation by the public. 
(Code 1967, § 3-501; Ord. No. 80-281, §§ 2, 3, 4-26-83; Ord. No. 80-436, § 1, 8-10-93; Ord. No. 80-543, § 1, 4-13-99) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 6-227. - Location of machines. 
(a)  Amusement machines may not be located within nine (9) feet of any exitway. 
(b)  That side or sides of the machine from which it is intended that the machine be operated must be located so that the operating side has the following minimum aisle width: 
Minimum Width 
(inches) 
(1)  Amusement machine on one (1) side of aisle ..... 72 
(2)  Amusement machine on both sides of aisle ..... 96 
(Code 1967, § 3-505(4); Ord. No. 80-281, § 6, 4-26-83)  
Sec. 6-228. - Closing hours. 
It is unlawful for any person holding a license under this article to permit the operation of an amusement machine between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 7:00 a.m. of any day. 
(Code 1967, § 3-505(3))  
Sec. 6-229. - Prohibited conduct on premises. 
No licensee, owner or attendant, directly or indirectly by any agent or employee shall: 
(1)  Permit any person to loiter so as to cause an obstruction within or immediately outside the licensed premises; 
(2)  Permit any intoxicated person on the premises; 
(3)  Permit the possession or use of any alcoholic liquors on the premises nor shall the premises be accessible to any place where alcoholic liquors are kept, sold, distributed or given away unless the licensed premise possesses a valid license from the state liquor control commission; 
(4)  Permit on the premises, the possession or use of any controlled substance as defined in Public Act No. 368 of 1978; MCL 333.7101 et seq.; 
(5)  Permit noise or music to emerge from the licensed premise, which is disturbing to persons in the surrounding area; 
(6)  Permit the premises to become a nuisance; 
(7)  Permit any gambling or gambling paraphernalia on the premises. For purposes of this subsection, gambling shall mean the acceptance or payment of anything of value contingent upon the result of a race, contest, happening of an event not known to be certain or a game in which winning depends upon fortuitous or accidental circumstances beyond the control of the player. Gambling does not include the winning of free games or a prize in connection with a scheduled tournament not exceeding one hundred dollars ($100.00) in value, or the use of redemption game devices as defined in chapter 40. 
(Code 1967, § 3-505(1), (2); Ord. No. 80-287, § 1, 6-28-83; Ord. No. 80-554, § 1, 3-28-00)  
Sec. 6-230. - Routine inspections. 
It shall be the duty of police officers to make routine inspections of all amusement machines, and if any unlawful practices are observed in connection therewith, they shall report the same to the police commissioner for such action as the commissioner may deem proper. 
(Code 1967, § 3-511(c))  
Secs. 6-231—6-245. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE[10] 

Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
Cross reference— Licensing generally, Ch. 18. 
 
Sec. 6-246. - Required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person, either in the capacity as a distributor or owner, to allow the maintenance and/or distribution for the purpose of operating any amusement machine without having first procured a license for the device pursuant to the provisions of this division. 
(Code 1967, § 3-502(1))  
Sec. 6-247. - Application. 
(a)  License applications for amusement machines shall be made to the city clerk in the form and manner required by the clerk and in accordance with the provisions of this Code, and the application shall state, among other things: 
(1)  The number of amusement machines intended to be operated on the premises; 
(2)  The type of amusement machine; 
(3)  The name, address and location of the amusement machine center; 
(4)  The name and address of the owner of the amusement machine center; 
(5)  The name and address of the person responsible for operating or managing the amusement machines; 
(6)  The name and address of the distributor; 
(7)  The location and description of motor vehicle parking facilities provided for patrons utilizing the amusement machines; 
(8)  A scale diagram of the business floor plan, showing the permanent location of each amusement machine, including electrical outlets, all aisleways, exitway discharges and doorways. 
(a)  If, after the issuance of the license, the licensee desires to operate other amusement machines, in addition to the number stated in the application for a license, the licensee shall make a new application to the city clerk in the same form and manner as the original application for a license. 
(b)  Each and every application under this division shall be in writing and made out in duplicate, one (1) copy being referred to the director of the division of buildings and safety engineering, and one (1) copy to the city clerk. The application shall include two (2) copies of a scaled site plan showing the property with the size of the building indicated, all parking spaces and maneuvering lanes and type of business. 
(Code 1967, § 3-503(1)—(4); Ord. No. 80-543, § 2, 4-13-99)  
Sec. 6-248. - Investigation by police commissioner. 
The police commissioner shall investigate the location wherein it is proposed to operate the amusement machine to determine whether it violates any prohibition of this article, shall ascertain if the owner and/or distributor has been convicted of any felony or has been convicted of a misdemeanor involving moral turpitude and in the case of renewals, shall investigate and report all violations of ordinances or statutes at the premises for the preceding licensing year, and on the basis of aforesaid investigation shall file his or her recommendation and report with the city clerk within twenty (20) days of the request. 
(Code 1967, § 3-503(4)(a); Ord. No. 80-292, § 2, 8-30-83)  
Sec. 6-249. - Inspection by division of buildings and safety engineering. 
The director of the division of buildings and safety engineering shall: 
(1)  Assign an electrical inspector to inspect all wiring and connections to the amusement machines listed in the application and determine if the same complies with the city electrical code; 
(2)  Assign a zoning inspector to inspect the location to see if same complies with the pertinent sections of the city zoning ordinance; 
(3)  Determine whether the applicant's designated building has a proper certificate of occupancy and complies with all applicable health and safety ordinances and statutes of the city and state; 
(4)  For renewals, assign inspections for any new locations, new machines or relocated machines; 
(5)  File his or her recommendation and report with the city clerk within twenty (20) days of the request. 
(Code 1967, § 3-503(4)(b); Ord. No. 80-292, §§ 3, 4, 8-30-83)  
Sec. 6-250. - Approval or disapproval. 
(a)  Within forty-five (45) days after the filing of the application and the required fees under this division, the city clerk shall approve or disapprove the application. 
(b)  If the city clerk disapproves an application for a license, the reasons for the disapproval shall be stated in writing. The city clerk shall have full and absolute power to disapprove such an application for either a new license or renewal of a previous license for any of the following specified reasons: 
(1)  Applicant makes a false or fraudulent statement of material fact in the application, or has made a false or fraudulent statement in any application previously submitted to the city; 
(2)  Applicant has violated any provision of this article; 
(3)  Applicant is delinquent in taxes owed to a municipality. 
(Code 1967, § 3-503(5), (6); Ord. No. 80-292, § 6, 8-30-83)  
Sec. 6-251. - Insurance required. 
The city clerk shall require a licensee under this division to furnish proof of public liability insurance in an amount not less than one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for each person and four hundred thousand dollars ($400,000.00) for each accident, covering any damages arising out of the use or operation of any facilities operated in connection with the amusement machine center. Evidence of insurance in the form of a certificate or policy from the insurance carrier shall be filed with the clerk's office. The certificate shall stipulate that the insurance shall not be cancelled except upon ten (10) days prior written notice to the city clerk. 
(Code 1967, § 3-503(7); Ord. No. 80-543, § 3, 4-13-99)  
Sec. 6-252. - Fee. 
The applicant for a license under this division shall pay a fee as provided in section 18-18. 
(Code 1967, § 3-504; Ord. No. 80-281, § 5, 4-26-83)  
Sec. 6-253. - Issuance. 
Upon meeting the requirements of this division, the city clerk is authorized to issue a license. 
(Code 1967, § 3-503(10))  
Sec. 6-254. - Display. 
It shall be the joint and several duty of the owner and/or distributor to post the license permanently and conspicuously at the location of the machine in the premises wherein the amusement machine is to be operated and maintained. 
(Code 1967, § 3-502(1)(a))  
Sec. 6-255. - Transfer. 
Licenses may be transferred from one (1) amusement machine to another amusement machine upon application to the city clerk to such effect, giving the description and serial number of the new machines and upon payment of the transfer fee. 
(Code 1967, § 3-503(9); Ord. No. 80-281, § 4, 4-26-83)  
Sec. 6-256. - Renewal. 
A license may be renewed upon submission of a renewal application and upon payment of the renewal fee. The application shall be considered in the manner provided in section 6-247(a), except if the application is for the same location as the previous year, then no electrical inspection is required. One scaled drawing will be required with the application. 
(Code 1967, § 3-503(10); Ord. No. 80-303, § 2, 9-11-84; Ord. No. 80-543, § 4, 4-13-99)  
Sec. 6-257. - Expiration. 
A license issued pursuant to this division shall be valid for one (1) year, expiring annually on the thirty-first day of August. 
(Code 1967, § 3-503(8))  
Sec. 6-258. - Seizure and destruction of machines. 
Police officers shall have the power to issue citations for any violation of this article. Upon the issuance of a citation for a violation of section 6-246, the owner shall apply for a license in accordance with the requirements of section 6-247 for the amusement machine within three (3) business days from the date of the citation. If the application is not made within three (3) business days, the police officer shall obtain a warrant authorizing the seizure of the machine and confiscate the machine which shall be returned only after the owner has secured the proper license and paid the additional fee of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) per machine. 
(Code 1967, § 3-514)  
Secs. 6-259—6-275. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE X. - SEXUALLY ORIENTED BUSINESSES[11] 
Footnotes: 
--- (11) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 80-621, § 1, adopted Oct. 11, 2005, amended Art. X, in its entirety, to read as herein set out. Prior to inclusion of said ordinance, Art. X pertained to similar subject matter. See also the Code Comparative Table. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 6-276. - Purpose and findings. 
(a)  Purpose. It is the purpose of this article to regulate sexually oriented businesses in order to promote the health, safety, and general welfare of the citizens of the city, and to establish reasonable and uniform regulations to prevent the deleterious secondary effects of sexually oriented businesses within the city. The provisions of this article have neither the purpose nor effect of imposing a limitation or restriction on the content or reasonable access to any communicative materials, including sexually oriented materials. Similarly, it is neither the intent nor effect of this article to deny access by adults to sexually oriented materials protected by the First Amendment of the United Constitution and/or Michigan Constitution, or to deny access by the distributors and exhibitors of sexually oriented entertainment to their intended market. Neither is it the intent nor effect of this article to condone or legitimize the distribution of obscene material. 
(b)  Findings and rationale. Based on evidence of the adverse secondary effects of sexually oriented businesses presented in hearings and in reports made available to the city council, and on findings, interpretations, and narrowing constructions incorporated in the cases of City of Littleton v. Z.J. Gifts D-4, L.L.C. , 541 U.S. 774 (2004); City of Los Angeles v. Alameda Books, Inc. , 535 U.S. 425 (2002); City of Erie v. Pap's A.M., 529 U.S. 277 (2000); City of Renton v. Playtime Theatres, Inc. , 475 U.S. 41 (1986); Young v. American Mini Theatres , 427 U.S. 50 (1976); Barnes v. Glen Theatre, Inc. , 501 U.S. 560 (1991); California v. LaRue , 409 U.S. 109 (1972); N.Y. State Liquor Authority v. Bellanca , 452 U.S. 714 (1981); and 
East Brooks Books, Inc. v. Shelby County , 588 F.3d 360 (6th Cir. 2009); Entm't Prods., Inc. v. Shelby County , 588 F.3d 372 (6th Cir. 2009); Richland Bookmart, Inc. v. Knox County , 555 F.3d 512 (6th Cir. 2009); Sensations, Inc. v. City of Grand Rapids , 526 F.3d 291 (6th Cir. 2008); Deja Vu of Nashville, Inc. v. Metropolitan Gov't of Nashville and Davidson County , 466 F.3d 391 (6th Cir. 2006); Big Dipper Entm't, LLC v. City of Warren , 658 F. Supp. 2d 831 (E.D. Mich. 2009); Flanigan's Enters., Inc. v. Fulton County , 596 F.3d 1265 (11th Cir. 2010); Deja Vu of Cincinnati, L.L.C. v. Union Township Bd. Of Trustees , 411 F.3d 777 (6th Cir. 2005) (en banc); Little Mack Entm't II, Inc. v. Twp. of Marengo , 2008 WL 2783252 (W.D. Mich. July 17, 2008); Fantasy Ranch, Inc. v. City of Arlington , 459 F.3d 546 (5th Cir. 2006); City of Chicago v. Pooh Bah Enterprises, Inc. , 865 N.E.2d 133 (Ill. 2006); Andy's Restaurant & Lounge, Inc. v. City of Gary , 466 F.3d 550 (7th Cir. 2006); 181 South, Inc. v. Fischer , 454 F.3d 228 (3rd Cir. 2006); Bronco's Entm't, Ltd. v. Charter Twp. of Van Buren , 421 F.3d 440 (6th Cir. 2005); Charter Twp. of Van Buren v. Garter Belt, Inc. , 258 Mich. App. 594 (2003); Jott, Inc. v. Clinton Twp. , 224 Mich. App. 513 (1997); Michigan ex rel. Wayne County Prosecutor v. Dizzy Duck , 449 Mich. 353 (1995); Gora v.
