(5)  Willful departure from or disregard of plans or specifications in any material respect and prejudicial to another, without consent of the owner or his or her duly authorized representative and without the consent of the person entitled to have the particular construction project or operation completed in accordance with such plans and specifications; 
(6)  Willful or deliberate disregard and violation of the building or other ordinances or regulations of the city or the building laws of the state; 
(7)  Misrepresentation of a material fact by an applicant in obtaining a registration certificate; 
(8)  Making any substantial misrepresentation, or making any false promise of a character likely to influence, persuade or induce; 
(9)  Advertising in any manner whatsoever that said residential builder or residential maintenance and/or alteration contractor is registered under this article; 
(10)  Changing business location without notification to the director of buildings and safety engineering within thirty (30) days from the date of change; 
(11)  Any conduct, whether of the same or of a different character than hereinbefore specified, which constitutes dishonesty or unfair dealings. 
(b)  The builder's registration commission may consider only those complaints which are presented to it in writing and verified under oath, and which are made within eighteen (18) months after completion, occupancy or purchase of a residential structure; provided, however, that complaints presented by the proper authorities charged with enforcement of the city ordinances, codes and regulations governing construction of residential structures shall be considered by the commission only if made by written verified complaint within sixty (60) days after completion, occupancy or purchase of the structure. 
(c)  The builder's registration commission shall, before refusing to issue or to renew, or before suspending or revoking, a registration certificate, and at least ten (10) days prior to the date set for the hearing, notify in writing the applicant or registrant of any charge made, and shall furnish the applicant or registrant with a copy of the complaint and afford the applicant or registrant an opportunity to be heard in person or by counsel in reference thereto. Such written notice shall be served by delivery of same personally to the applicant or registrant or by mailing the same by certified mail to the last known business address of such applicant or registrant. The hearing on such charges shall be at such time and place as the commission shall prescribe. The commission shall bring before it and take the testimony of any person in the same manner as in judicial proceedings in the civil courts. If the commission shall find that the applicant or registrant is guilty of any violation of any of the provisions of this article, the commission shall, as the case may be, refuse to issue or to renew the registration certificate of the applicant or registrant, or shall suspend or revoke same for such period of time as shall be determined by the commission. 
(d)  Any person whose registration certificate is suspended or revoked, or any person whose application for issuance or renewal of a registration certificate is refused, shall have the right of appeal to the city council, provide that a written request therefor is filed with the secretary or deputy secretary of the council within ten (10) days following such refusal, suspension or revocation by the builder's registration commission. The city council shall grant a hearing on such appeal and may affirm or reverse any action of the commission, and the decision of the city council shall be final. 
(Code 1967, § 6-407)  
Sec. 9-323. - Administration and enforcement; rules and regulations, copies. 
It shall be the duty of the builder's registration commission to administer and provide for the enforcement of all the provisions of this article. The commission is hereby expressly vested with the power and authority to make and enforce any and all rules and regulations not inconsistent with the provisions of this article. Copies of all rules and regulations of the commission shall be sent to all registrants when the license or renewal thereof is delivered to the registrants. 
(Code 1967, § 6-408)  
Secs. 9-324—9-340. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VIII. - MOVING BUILDINGS[10] 
Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
Cross reference— Streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 34; traffic and motor vehicles, Ch. 37. 
State Law reference— Moving buildings or obstruction, MCL 247.188 et seq. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 9-341. - Compliance with building code and zoning ordinance required. 
The foundations and all other new portions or alterations to a building or structure being moved under this article shall be constructed in conformity with the terms and provisions of the building code, and the building or structure shall be located in a zone and placed upon a lot or parcel of land in conformity with the zoning ordinance; furthermore, all inspections required on a new building shall be made on any house which is to be moved onto any lot within the city prior to the time a permit is issued to move the house. 
(Code 1967, § 6-810)  
Sec. 9-342. - Water service. 
Every person who shall move any building or structure under a permit issued pursuant to this article shall, prior to the moving of the building or structure, cause all public water to the building or structure to be shut off at either the curb stop or the corporation stop by notification to the division of water supply and causing the public water to such building or structure to be shut off. Such person shall, prior to the moving of the building or structure, cause all water pipes in the building or structure to be disconnected and removed to a depth of at least four (4) feet below the grade level of the land or premises from which the building or structure is to be moved, and shall deliver or cause to be delivered to the division of water supply any water meter located in the building and removed as a result of disconnecting of the water pipes pursuant to the provisions of this section. 
(Code 1967, § 6-811) 
Cross reference— Water generally, § 41-21 et seq.  
Sec. 9-343. - Sewer service. 
Every person who shall move any building or structure under a permit issued pursuant to this article shall, prior to the moving of the building or structure, cause all sewer pipes in the building or structure below the ground level to be disconnected and removed to a depth of at least four (4) feet below the grade level of the land or premises from which the building or structure is to be moved, and shall cap all sewer lines left upon the lands and premises with a concrete cap not less than one (1) foot in thickness. The concrete cap shall be installed in such manner as to prevent any sand or debris from entering into the sewer line remaining upon the land or premises after the removal of the building or structure therefrom, all of which shall be done as prescribed and approved by the division of buildings and safety engineering. 
(Code 1967, § 6-812) 
Cross reference— Sewers generally, § 41-56 et seq.  
Sec. 9-344. - Filling excavations, etc. 
Every person who shall move any building or structure under a permit issued pursuant to this article shall, within seven (7) days after the removal of the building or structure, remove or cause to be removed all equipment and to clean all refuse, debris and waste of any kind or description from the land or premises from which the building or structure is moved, and shall within such period of time fill or cause to be filled any excavation left upon the land or premises after the removal of the building or structure unless such excavation shall be used for the erection of a new building commencing within thirty (30) days of the moving of the old building or structure. Any excavation required to be filled hereunder shall be filled even with the grade of such land or premises with earth, clay, sand or other solid filler. Until any excavation shall be filled or used for the erection of a new building in accordance with this section, any person who shall move any building or structure under a permit issued pursuant to this article shall erect or cause to be erected substantial barricades at least three (3) feet in height around any such excavation. 
(Code 1967, § 6-813) 
Cross reference— Sewer dumping and regrading, Ch. 32.  
Sec. 9-345. - Routes, barricades, watchmen. 
The police commissioner shall specify the route over which the structure is to be moved and the time allowed for such moving. All reasonable effort shall be made in the moving so as to least obstruct any street, alley, boulevard or other public place, and if it becomes necessary to leave the structure thereon, or the moving is being made after sundown, there shall be erected around the structure and all equipment a safe and sufficient barrier amply provided with red lanterns or flares. Also, a watchman shall be on duty from sundown until sunrise. Further, the applicant shall submit to the director of buildings and safety engineering proof of notification to any utility company having wires or lines over or along the proposed route to be affected by such move and that arrangements have been made with such utility companies on or along the proposed route during the time of moving. 
(Code 1967, § 6-809)  
Secs. 9-346—9-360. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - HOUSE MOVING BOARD[11] 

Footnotes: 
--- (11) --- 
Cross reference— Administration, Ch. 2; boards and commissions generally, § 2-91 et seq. 
 
Sec. 9-361. - Created. 
There is hereby created a house moving board of the city. 
(Code 1967, § 6-801)  
Sec. 9-362. - Composition. 
The house moving board shall consist of three (3) members: the director of buildings and safety engineering, who shall be chairperson; the director of buildings and safety engineering; and the planning director. Any member is hereby authorized to designate the assistant director in their respective departments to act for and in their stead on such board. 
(Code 1967, § 6-801)  
Sec. 9-363. - Meetings; purpose. 
The house moving board shall hold meetings, at the call of its chairperson, at such time and place as shall be designated by him or her for the purpose of considering applications for permits for the moving of houses or other residential structures as provided herein. Such meeting shall be called without an unreasonable delay after the application for such permit is made. 
(Code 1967, § 6-803)  
Sec. 9-364. - Procedure. 
The house moving board shall adopt rules and regulations relating to its procedure. 
(Code 1967, § 6-802)  
Secs. 9-365—9-375. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - LICENSE[12] 

Footnotes: 
--- (12) --- 
Cross reference— Licensing generally, Ch. 18. 
 
Sec. 9-376. - Required. 
No person shall engage in the business of moving houses or other residential structures into, upon or across any street, alley, boulevard or other public place without first having obtained a license as provided in this division. 
(Code 1967, § 6-804)  
Sec. 9-377. - Application. 
Application for a license to engage in the business of moving houses or other residential structures shall be made to the city clerk on a form furnished for that purpose. 
(Code 1967, § 6-805)  
Sec. 9-378. - Fee. 
The fee for a license under this division shall be as prescribed in section 18-18. 
(Code 1967, § 6-805)  
Sec. 9-379. - Investigation; approval; revocation. 
The city clerk shall refer the application to the division of buildings and safety engineering for the purpose of investigating the training, experience and qualifications of the applicants to determine their fitness to take part in any of the operations of the business, and shall certify his or her recommendations to the city clerk who may issue, or refuse to issue, such license, or revoke any license issued, if he or she finds the party is not fit or qualified or is not a suitable person to engage in such operation. 
(Code 1967, § 6-805)  
Sec. 9-380. - Insurance. 
The applicant under this division shall file with the city clerk a public liability and property damage insurance policy, with form approved by the city attorney, naming the applicant and city as the assured and providing for the payment of any liability imposed by law upon such applicant and/or city to the extent of two hundred fifty thousand dollars ($250,000.00) for injury to or death of any one (1) person and five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) for injuries to or death of more than one (1) person, and for damages to property in the amount of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00). 
(Code 1967, § 6-805)  
Secs. 9-381—9-400. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - PERMIT 
 
Sec. 9-401. - Required. 
No person shall move or cause to be moved any house or other residential structure of a larger size than fifty (50) square feet into, upon or across any street, alley, boulevard or other public place in the city without first having secured a permit therefor in the manner prescribed in this division. 
(Code 1967, § 6-806)  
Sec. 9-402. - Application. 
Application for a permit to move a house or other residential structure shall be made by a licensed mover to the division of buildings and safety engineering as provided in the building code of the city. If approved as complying with all the ordinances applicable thereto, and if the division finds that under the facts the applicant has sufficient knowledge, experience, equipment and facilities to properly conduct such moving, such application shall be forwarded to the board forthwith. 
(Code 1967, § 6-807)  
Sec. 9-403. - Investigation; action by council. 
(a)  The house moving board shall make, or cause to be made, such investigation as it deems necessary in regard to any application for a permit to move a house or other residential structure. The investigation shall include, but shall not be limited to, a thorough physical inspection of the structure, consideration as to whether the structure complies with the building code, the housing code, the zoning ordinance, and all other applicable codes and ordinances of the city, and whether its relocation will be injurious to the contiguous property and surrounding neighborhood. In an effort to avoid undue damage or injury to trees along the designated route, the house moving board shall also obtain a report from the division of forestry to determine whether there are trees along the route that may be affected. After conducting the hearing as hereinbefore provided, the house moving board shall, within a period of seven (7) days, forward to the city council, through the mayor, its written recommendations as to whether a permit shall be issued. The city council, at its next regular meeting, shall consider the recommendation and shall either approve or disapprove the permit applied for. 
(b)  All houses or other residential structures which are proposed to be moved to a location within the city shall conform, insofar as is possible, to the general type, age, construction and architectural style of the majority of the residential buildings in the area adjacent to, and in the neighborhood of, the site upon which the house or residential structure is proposed to be moved. 
(Code 1967, § 6-808)  
Sec. 9-404. - Issuance; fee. 
Upon the approval of the application for a permit, the designation of the route and proof of notification of any utility company, the division of buildings and safety engineering, upon the payment by the applicant of a permit fee of fifty dollars ($50.00), shall issue such permit. The permit shall designate the route to be used in such moving and the time in which such move shall be contemplated. 
(Code 1967, § 6-809)  
Secs. 9-405—9-415. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IX. - WRECKING BUILDINGS  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 9-416. - Water service. 
Every person who shall wreck any building or structure under a permit issued pursuant to this article shall, prior to the completion of such wrecking operation, cause all public water to the building or structure to be shut off at either the curb stop or the corporation stop by notification to the division of water supply and causing the public water to the building or structure to be shut off as aforesaid by the employees of the division. Such person shall, prior to the completion of such wrecking operation, cause all water pipes in the building or structure to be disconnected and removed to a depth of at least four (4) feet below the grade level of the land or premises upon which the building or structure is being wrecked, and shall deliver or cause to be delivered to the division of water supply any water meter located in the building and removed as a result of disconnecting of the water pipes pursuant to the provisions of this section. 
(Code 1967, § 6-820) 
Cross reference— Water generally, § 41-21 et seq.  
Sec. 9-417. - Sewer service. 
Every person who shall wreck any building or structure under a permit issued pursuant to this article shall, prior to the completion of such wrecking operation, cause all sewer pipes in the building or structure below the ground level to be disconnected and removed to a depth of at least four (4) feet below the grade level of the land or premises upon which the building or structure is to be wrecked, and shall cap all sewer lines left upon the lands and premises with a concrete cap not less than one (1) foot in thickness. The concrete cap shall be installed in such manner as to prevent any sand or debris from entering into the sewer line remaining upon the land or premises after the completion of the building or structure thereon, all of which shall be done as prescribed and approved by the division of buildings and safety engineering. 
(Code 1967, § 6-821) 
Cross reference— Sewers generally, § 41-56 et seq.  
Sec. 9-418. - Refuse, debris, excavations. 
Every person who shall wreck any building or structure under a permit issued pursuant to this article shall, within the period of time specified for the completion of the wrecking operation, remove or cause to be removed all equipment, refuse, debris and waste of any kind or description from the land or premises upon which the wrecking operation was carried on, and shall within such period of time fill or cause to be filled any excavation left upon the land or premises after the wrecking of the building or structure unless the excavation shall be used for the erection of a new building or structure within thirty (30) days from the actual completion of such wrecking operation. Any excavation required to be filled hereunder shall be filled even with the grade of such land or premises with earth, clay, sand or other solid filler. Until any excavation shall be filled or used for the erection of a new building in accordance with this section, any person who shall wreck any building or structure under a permit issued pursuant to this article shall erect or cause to be erected substantial barricades at least three (3) feet in height around any such excavation. 
(Code 1967, § 6-822) 
Cross reference— Garbage and rubbish generally, Ch. 16.  
Secs. 9-419—9-430. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE[13] 

Footnotes: 
--- (13) --- 
Cross reference— Licensing generally, Ch. 18. 
 
Sec. 9-431. - Required. 
No person shall engage in the business of wrecking buildings or structures in the city without first having obtained a license as provided in this division and having complied with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1967, § 6-814)  
Sec. 9-432. - Application. 
Application for a license to engage in the business of wrecking buildings or structures shall be made to the city clerk on a form of application furnished for such purpose. 
(Code 1967, § 6-815)  
Sec. 9-433. - Fee. 
The fee for a license under this division shall be as prescribed in section 18-18. 
(Code 1967, § 6-815)  
Sec. 9-434. - Investigation; approval; revocation. 
The city clerk shall refer the application under this division to the director of buildings and safety engineering who shall make an investigation of the training, knowledge, experience and equipment of any applicant to determine the fitness of such applicant to engage in the business of wrecking buildings or structures. The director of buildings and safety engineering may approve the issuance of such license if he or she shall determine that the applicant is fit and qualified to engage in such operations or may disapprove the issuance of such license, or revoke any license issued, if he or she shall determine that the applicant is not fit or qualified to engage in such operation. Upon the refusal to issue a license or the revocation of a license after issuance, the applicant or former licensee shall have the right of appeal to the license appeal board. 
(Code 1967, § 6-815)  
Sec. 9-435. - Insurance. 
(a)  Before the issuance of any license under this division, the applicant shall file in the office of the city clerk the following: 
(1)  Due proof of the issuance of public liability and property damage insurance naming applicant and the city as the assured and providing for the payment of any liability imposed by law upon such applicant and/or the city arising from the wrecking of any buildings or structures under applicant's license from the city in an amount of not less than two hundred fifty thousand dollars ($250,000.00) for injury or death to one (1) person and five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) for injury or death to more than one (1) person and for damage to property in the amount of not less than one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00). 
(2)  Due proof that applicant is covered by workers' compensation insurance. 
(b)  Such policy or policies of insurance required in subsection (a)(1) shall expire concurrently with the applicant's license and new proof of such insurance and also of workers' compensation insurance shall be filed when making application for any renewal of the license. The policy or policies of insurance required in subsection (a) shall contain a provision for continuing liability thereunder to the full amount thereof, notwithstanding any recovery thereon. Any insurance company whose policy has been filed pursuant to this section may file written notice in the office of the city clerk of its intention to terminate and cancel such insurance and give notice thereof to the licensee, whereupon the license of such licensee shall be deemed cancelled and null and void until such time as due proof of the issuance of a new policy or policies of insurance as required by this section shall have been filed in the office of the city clerk. 
(Code 1967, § 6-816)  
Secs. 9-436—9-450. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - PERMIT 
 
Sec. 9-451. - Required; prohibitions. 
No person shall engage in the business of wrecking any building or structure under the name of any other person licensed under the provisions of this article. No licensee under this article shall obtain a permit for the wrecking of any building or structure for the benefit or use of any person not licensed under this article, nor shall any licensee utilize or accept the services of any person not licensed under this article as an independent contractor in the wrecking of any building or structure. The wrecking of any building or structure shall be carried on only by the licensee or his or her employee to whom the permit for wrecking a building or structure has been issued and no person shall conduct or carry on wrecking operations under a permit issued to some other person. 
(Code 1967, § 6-817)  
Sec. 9-452. - Application. 
Application for a permit to wreck a building or structure shall be made by any licensee under this article or by any other person hereinafter defined as an owner, prior to the commencement of wrecking operations to the city clerk upon forms provided therefor who shall forthwith refer such application to the director of buildings and safety engineering for approval. 
(Code 1967, § 6-818)  
Sec. 9-453. - Investigation; approval. 
(a)  The director of buildings and safety engineering shall investigate the location of the building or structure to be wrecked, the method of wrecking proposed to be used by applicant, and determine that applicant proposes to take proper and adequate safeguards for adjoining properties and the public, for the removal of the salvage materials. The director of buildings and safety engineering may, if he or she shall determine from such investigation that applicant shall and will satisfactorily perform such wrecking operations under the requirements of this section, approve the issuance of such permit. The director of buildings and safety engineering may, if he or she shall determine that applicant will not satisfactorily perform such wrecking operation under the requirements of this section, refuse the issuance of such permit. The applicant shall have the right of appeal to the license appeal board for the granting of such permit, and if the board shall approve, then the permit shall be issued. 
(b)  Upon the approval of the application for such permit, the director of buildings and safety engineering shall specify the time within which such wrecking operation shall be completed and shall notify the city clerk of such approval. The permit shall specify the time within which such wrecking operation shall be completed. 
(Code 1967, § 6-818)  
Sec. 9-454. - Fee. 
The fee for a permit under this division shall be prescribed in Chapter 18, section 18-18, regulating license fees. 
(Code 1967, § 6-818; Ord. No. 80-521, § 1, 10-14-97)  
Sec. 9-455. - Exceptions for minor buildings. 
No permit for the wrecking of any building or structure shall be issued to any person not licensed under the provisions of this article, except that a permit may be issued for the wrecking of a minor building or structure to the owners of the premises upon which such minor building or structure shall be located. The work or operation of wrecking under a permit issued to an owner shall be performed or executed by the employees or members of the owner's family acting under his or her supervision and direction and shall not be done by any independent contractor unless such independent contractor shall be licensed to carry on the business of wrecking buildings or structures under this article. For the purpose of this article, a minor building or structure shall be defined as any masonry building not over one (1) story in height and five thousand (5,000) cubic feet in volume above the grade line, or any frame or veneer building not over two (2) stories in height and twenty-five thousand (25,000) cubic feet in volume above the grade line. For the purposes of this article, an owner means any person holding legal title to the land upon which such building or structure to be wrecked is located by deed or by land contract. 
(Code 1967, § 6-819)  
Chapter 10 - CABLE AND TELECOMMUNICATIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference— Public utility services, Ch. 15; public utility franchises, § 15.6; limitations on the granting of franchises, § 15.7. 
State Law reference— Consent for construction in rights-of-way by cable television companies required from municipalities, MCL 247.183. 
 
ARTICLE I. - CABLE FRANCHISE REGULATORY ORDINANCE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— It should be noted that Ord. No. 80-583, adopted March 12, 2002, provides, "Section 1. Comcast Cablevision of Warren ("Grantee") requested to renew its cable franchise in the City of Warren. 
Section 2. Comcast Cablevision of Warren has demonstrated the legal, technical and financial qualifications, during the prior franchise period, to maintain and operate a cable television business. 
Section 3. The City of Warren determined that the public interest would be served by maintaining competition in the City and providing residents with a choice of cable providers. 
Section 4. The City of Warren therefore renews Grantee's non-exclusive franchise to operate a local cable television business within the City of Warren for no longer than 15 years ("Franchise"). 
Section 5. This franchise shall encompass and Grantee shall be subject to the provisions of Chapter 10, Article I of the Warren Code of Ordinances, Ordinance No. 80-512, entitled the Cable Franchise Regulatory Ordinance ("the Ordinance") and the Cable Television Franchise Agreement made between Grantee and the City of Warren ("the Agreement"). The Ordinance and the Agreement are incorporated by reference and made a part of the Franchise. 
Section 6. The Mayor and City Clerk are authorized to execute the Cable Television Franchise Agreement on behalf of the City of Warren. 
Section 7. By executing the Agreement by Grantee, Grantee will accept the Franchise, including provisions of the Ordinance and the Agreement, and all exhibits attached thereto. 
Section 8. This Ordinance shall take effect on April 4, 2002, and shall constitute a contract between the City of Warren and Grantee." 
 
Sec. 10-1. - Intent. 
The city is authorized to grant one or more non-exclusive franchises to construct, operate, maintain and reconstruct cable television systems within the city. This article is intended to encourage competition in cable television, promote the growth and development of cable systems which are responsive to the needs and interests of the community, and to provide for the orderly and systematic development of cable systems within the public rights-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 80-512, § 1, 6-24-97)  
Sec. 10-2. - Definitions. 
The following terms, phrases, words and their derivations shall have the meaning given herein, unless otherwise clearly apparent from the context. Words used in the present tense include the future, words in the plural include the singular, and vice-versa. Words not defined shall be given their common and ordinary meaning or the meaning assigned by the U. S. Cable Communications Policy Act, as amended, 47 U.S.C. 521, et. seq. ("the Federal Cable Act"), or by the Federal Communications Commission, as may be amended from time to time. 
Cable service shall mean the total of the following: 
(1)  The transmission to or from subscribers of video programming, or other programming service; and 
(2)  Subscriber interaction, if any, which is required for the selection and use of such video programming or other programming service. 
Cable system means a facility consisting of a set of transmission paths which may include associated signal generation reception, signal transmission, reception and control equipment that is designed to provide cable service which includes video programming and which is provided to multiple subscribers within a community, but such term does not include: 
(1)  A facility that serves only to retransmit the television signals on one (1) or more television broadcast signals. 
(2)  A facility that services subscribers without using any public rights-of-way. 
(3)  A facility of a common carrier which is subject, in whole or in part, to the provisions of Title II of the Federal Cable Act, except that such facility shall be considered a cable system (other than for purposes of section 621(c) of the Federal Cable Act) to the extent such facility is used in the transmission of video programming directly to subscribers, unless the extent of such use is solely to provide interactive on-demand services. 
(4)  Any facilities of any electric utility used solely for operating its electric utility system. 
Cable cast means the distribution of programs (both from broadcasting sources and original programs) through the cable system by means of coaxial cable or other electrical conductors or fiber optical transmitters. 
Channel or cable channel means a portion of the electromagnetic frequency spectrum which is used in a cable system, or as otherwise defined by the FCC or federal or state law. 
City or grantor shall mean the City of Warren, Michigan and reference to the city in the franchise shall include its authorized officer, employee or commission acting within the scope of apparent authority on behalf of the city. 
Drop or cable drop means the cable that connects the subscriber terminal to the nearest feeder cable of a cable system. 
Facilities shall mean any part or whole of the plant, works, systems, improvements or equipment of a grantee, including poles, guys, anchors, fiber, wires, underground conduits, circuits and other property used or installed in connection with the cable system or cable services. 
FCC shall mean the Federal Communications Commission, and shall include any successor or additional Federal governmental body with authority superior to the city with regard to the regulation of any activity authorized by the franchise. 
Franchise means a non-exclusive authorization awarded by ordinance for the construction, maintenance, and operation of a cable system and related cable system equipment for the purpose of providing cable service as provided for in this article and in the franchise agreement. 
Franchise agreement or agreement means a contractual agreement, containing the specific provisions of the franchise granted, including references, specifications, requirements and other related matters. 
Franchise fee means a fee as specified in the franchise to be paid by grantee to the city. The term "franchise fee" shall exclude: 
(1)  Any tax, fee or assessment of general applicability imposed on both utilities and cable operators or their services or upon businesses or their services, but not including a tax, fee or assessment which is unduly discriminatory against cable operators; 
(2)  Capital costs required by the franchise to be incurred by grantee for system expansion, upgrade, improvement, maintenance, and repair, or payments or costs required by the franchise to support public, educational or governmental programming; 
(3)  Requirements or charges incidental to awarding or enforcement of the franchise, including payments for bonds, securities, funds, letters of credit, insurance indemnification, penalties or liquidated damages. 
Grantee means any and every holder of a franchise granted pursuant to this article, under a granting ordinance, and its lawful successors, transferees or assignees. 
Gross revenue shall mean revenues derived from the operation of the cable system to provide cable service as more specifically set forth in the franchise agreement. 
Headend means the equipment at the antenna site in a master antenna or cable system. The point of origination that collects all the signals and sends them to the subscribers. 
Installation means the connection of the cable system to subscriber's terminal. 
Person means any individual, firm, partnership, association, joint stock company, trust, limited liability company, corporation or governmental entity. 
Public, Governmental or Educational (PEG) programming or local programming means the total of: 
(1)  Channel capacity as may be designated at the discretion of the city for noncommercial public, educational or governmental programming; and 
(2)  Facilities and equipment for the use of such channel capacity. 
Rights-of-way means each of the following which have been dedicated to the public or are hereafter dedicated to the public authority or by others and located within the city limits; streets, roads, roadways, highways, avenues, lanes, alleys, sidewalks, easements, rights-of-way and similar public property and areas that the city shall permit to be included within the definitions of street from time to time. 
Service area or franchise area means the entire geographic area within the city as it is now constituted or may in the future be constituted, unless otherwise specified in the franchise agreement. 
Signal means any transmission of radio frequency energy or of optical information. 
Subscriber or user means any person who pays for service and who is provided the use of a grantee's cable system, channels, equipment or facilities. 
Trunk or trunk line means the main line of the cable system that carries signals from the headend to other extremities of the cable system. 
(Ord. No. 80-512, § 1, 6-24-97; Ord. No. 80-561, § 2, 7-25-00)  
Sec. 10-3. - Franchise required. 
(a)  No person shall install, construct, maintain, operate or transact local business on a cable system in the city nor shall any person provide cable service or acquire ownership or control of a cable company in the city without such person having first obtained a franchise from the city in the form of an ordinance granting a franchise to the person, which shall include, at a minimum, compliance with the specifications of this article. 
(b)  No person shall use, occupy or traverse the rights-of-way or any extensions thereof or additions thereto, whether on, above, or under the surface of the ground, for the purposes of installing, constructing, maintaining or operating a cable system or facilities therefor or for the purpose of furnishing a cable service without such person having first obtained a franchise from the city in the form of an ordinance granting a franchise, which shall include, at a minimum, compliance with all the specifications of this article. 
(c)  The provisions of this article are minimum requirements of a franchise. A grantee must enter into a franchise agreement with the city, which may establish other specifications or requirements, including, but not limited to, billing, customer service standards, security fund, interconnections, studios or other signal origination facilities, channels to be equipped, construction timetable, and support for local programming as deemed adequate to meet community interests and desires. 
(d)  This article shall apply to any existing cable system operating pursuant to a franchise awarded by the city which the grantee uses to transact local business as a cable system, except as otherwise provided. 
(e)  Any franchise granted shall be nonexclusive, and the city specifically reserves the right to grant, at any time, such additional franchises for a cable system or any component thereof, as it deems appropriate, subject to applicable state and federal law. The grant of authority for use of the city public rights-of-way does not establish priority for use over other franchise holders, permit holders and the city's own use of the property. 
(Ord. No. 80-512, § 1, 6-24-97)  
Sec. 10-4. - Extent of grant of franchise. 
A franchise granted by the city shall encompass the following purposes: 
(1)  To erect, install, construct, repair, rebuild, reconstruct, replace, maintain and remove cable facilities in, on, over, under, upon, along, and across public rights-of-way within the city for the delivery of cable services. If necessary, the responsibility of obtaining easements for private property shall be that of the grantee. 
(2)  To maintain and operate the franchise properties for the origination, reception, transmission, amplification, and distribution of television and radio signals and for the delivery of cable services within the city. 
(3)  To set forth the obligations of the grantee. 
(Ord. No. 80-512, § 1, 6-24-97)  
Sec. 10-5. - Construction with franchise and other laws. 
(a)  Any grantee shall comply with all rules, regulations, or provisions of law applicable to the provision of cable service as may be set forth in, and from time to time amended, the regulations or statutes of the United States, FCC, or State of Michigan. 
(b)  This article shall be construed in a manner consistent with all applicable federal and state and local laws. Whenever any duly authorized federal or state agency shall hereafter exercise any paramount jurisdiction over any specific provisions of this article, such paramount jurisdiction shall preempt or preclude the exercise of like jurisdiction by the city. 
(c)  The city reserves the right to amend this article or to adopt and enforce such other ordinances, rules and regulations as it shall find necessary in the exercise of its police powers, so long as such amendments are reasonable. 
(d)  If any provision of the franchise is held by any court of competent jurisdiction to be invalid as conflicting with any federal or state law, rule or regulation now or hereafter in effect, or is held by such court to be modified in any way in order to conform to the requirements of any law, rule or regulations, said provision may be considered a separate, distinct and independent part of the franchise, and such holding shall not affect the validity and enforcement of all other provisions. In the event that such law, rule or regulation is subsequently repealed, rescinded, amended or otherwise changed, so that the provision which had been held invalid or modified is no longer in conflict with the law, rule or regulations said provision shall return to full force and effect and shall be binding on the parties. 
(Ord. No. 80-512, § 1, 6-24-97)  
Sec. 10-6. - Franchisee application process. 
(a)  Any request for an initial franchise must be submitted on an application in such form as may be prescribed by the city. The application must be submitted by a non-refundable application fee in the amount established by the city. 
(b)  The application shall include information as the city may deem necessary to evaluate the legal, financial, technical, and other qualifications of the applicant to provide cable service in the city. 
(c)  Any untrue or misleading statement of material fact or omission of a material fact shall be grounds for rejection of an application 
(d)  In determining whether a franchise shall be issued, the city shall take into consideration the criteria set forth below, together with such other factors as the city may deem relevant: 
(1)  Capacity of the rights-of-way to accommodate equipment and fixtures. 
(2)  Benefits that may accrue to subscribers as a result of competition such as lower rates and improved service. 
(3)  The aesthetic effect of the installation of further above-ground fixtures. 
(4)  The demonstrated legal, financial, technical and business capability of the applicant to erect, maintain and operate the proposed system for the duration of the franchise term. 
(5)  Level of service and frequency of complaints in other communities served by the applicant. 
(6)  The proposed system design including channel capacity and ability to provide a broad range of services in conformity with the highest quality of standards of the cable industry. 
(7)  The applicant will satisfy the city's local regulatory requirements and the community's cable interests and needs. 
(e)  The franchise shall be granted or denied only after the council has held a public hearing on such request after due notice of the time and place of such hearing has been given to the applicant and the public. 
(f)  The city may require any new grantee to be responsible for underground trenching and costs associated therewith if, in the city's sole discretion, the right-of-way in a particular area cannot accommodate above-ground facilities. 
(g)  The applicant shall be responsible for all costs incurred by the city in connection with the proposed franchise, including, without limitation, the technical, legal, and financial evaluation, administrative review, and document preparation. 
(Ord. No. 80-512, § 1, 6-24-97)  
Sec. 10-7. - Term and effective date of franchise. 
A franchise granted hereunder shall be for a term of years not to exceed fifteen (15) years, commencing on the effective date set forth in the franchise agreement. 
(Ord. No. 80-512, § 1, 6-24-97)  
Sec. 10-8. - Franchise territory; geographical coverage. 
(a)  Any franchise shall be valid within all the territorial limits of the city, and within any area added to the city during the term of the franchise. 
(b)  A grantee shall serve the entire franchise area and shall offer service to all residences in the franchise area, within a reasonable time and in accordance with construction plans and service schedules acceptable to the city. 
(c)  After service has been established by activating trunk and/or distribution cables for any service areas, the grantee shall provide service to any requesting subscriber within that service area within at least seven (7) business days from the date of request provided that the grantee is able to secure all rights-of-way necessary to extend service to the subscriber within such period on reasonable terms and conditions, the installation is located within one hundred fifty (150) feet from the existing distribution system. 
(Ord. No. 80-512, § 1, 6-24-97)  
Sec. 10-9. - Franchise fee. 
(a)  The grantee shall pay a franchise fee in the amount of five (5) percent of its gross revenues, as defined in the franchise agreement. Franchise fees shall be in addition to any other tax, charge, fee, or payment due to the city by the grantee. 
(b)  All payments due from grantee to the city shall be made quarterly. 
(c)  Each payment shall be accompanied by a financial statement setting forth the basis for the computation and specifically showing the gross revenues to support the period covered by the payment, and for the year. 
(d)  The city shall have the right, upon thirty (30) days written notice, to inspect the grantee's records to verify the accuracy of the amounts payable under the franchise. The right of audit and re-computation of any and all amounts payable under the franchise shall always be accorded to the city. The grantee shall provide to the city only those records and reports which pertain specifically to the cable system and facilities and operations under this franchise and only the financial records of the revenues earned by the grantee from the facilities and operation of the cable system within the city. The books and records shall be made available to the city at its offices. 
(e)  Except as otherwise provided by law, no acceptance of any payment by the city shall be construed as a release or as an accord and satisfaction of any claim the city may have for further or additional sums payable as a franchise fee under this article or for the performance of any other obligations of the grantee, provided, however, that a payment shall be considered final upon completion of any audit. 
(f)  In the event that any franchise payment or re-computed amount is not made on or before the dates specified in the article or franchise agreement, grantee shall pay as additional compensation an interest charge, computed from such due date, at an annual rate equal to the then-current prime interest rate as publicly announced by the Detroit office of the NBD Bank, or its successor, in effect on the due date, plus one percent for the period the payment was due. 
(Ord. No. 80-512, § 1, 6-24-97)  
Sec. 10-10. - Franchise non-transferable. 
(a)  The grantee shall manage the cable system and the provision of cable services within the city. It shall not directly or indirectly contract for, subcontract or assign in whole or in part, the management of the cable system or the provision of cable services, except for construction as noted elsewhere. 
(b)  There shall be no sale, transfer, lease, assignment, sublet or disposal, in whole or in part, either by forced or involuntary sale, or by ordinary sale, contract, consolidation or otherwise, or change in control in or of the franchise or cable system, or any of the rights or privileges granted, without the prior consent of the city. 
(c)  A change in control, transfer, sale, lease, assignment, sublet or disposal, for purposes of this section ("transfer"), includes any merger, consolidation and/or the formation of a joint venture or limited or general partnership of the grantee, the sale, assignment or transfer of any shares or interest in the grantee which results in a change in the control of the day-to-day operation of the cable system, change in the ownership of more than twenty-five (25) percent of the voting stock is acquired by another person or persons acting in concert, or change in ownership or control of a majority interest. 
(d)  The parties to the transfer shall make a written request to the city for its approval of the transfer. The written request shall be accompanied by information required by FCC rules and shall be presented on a form as prescribed by the FCC. 
(e)  The city shall have one hundred twenty (120) days from receipt of the information referred to in this section to act upon the request for approval, unless otherwise provided by federal law or the parties agree to an extension. If the city fails to render a final decision on the request within that time, the request shall be deemed granted, unless the presumption of approval is no longer required by federal law at the time of the request. 
(f)  During the review period, the city may hold a public hearing for purposes of considering public comments on the proposed transfer. Grantee and the prospective transferee shall have at least fourteen (14) days advance written notice of such hearing, and shall have the opportunity to participate fully in the hearing. 
(g)  A decision of the city upon request for a transfer shall be in writing and subject to review and appeal as may be provided under federal law. 
(h)  In reviewing a request for a transfer, the city may request additional information as deemed necessary to inquire into the technical, legal, and financial qualifications of the prospective transferee, and the grantee shall assist the city in so inquiring. Any delay in providing the city with such material shall extend the one hundred twenty (120) days or other agreed-upon period for reviewing the transfer by the period of such delay. The city shall not unreasonably withhold its approval. However, the foregoing shall not require the city to consent to any transfer or change in control where it does not find adequate evidence that the prospective transferee has the necessary legal, technical or financial requirements to carry out the terms of the franchise. 
(i)  Any prospective transferee shall execute an undertaking that it will assume and be bound by all the provisions, terms, and conditions of the franchise and all applicable federal, state and local laws and, further, that the transferee shall be liable and obligated under this article and the agreement. 
(j)  The grantee shall comply (where applicable) with any other of the Federal Cable Act's provisions and the FCC rules and regulations concerning the sale or transfer of a cable system. 
(k)  Notwithstanding anything to the contrary, no consent or approval by the city shall be required for a transfer or assignment to any person or entity controlling, controlled by or under the same control as the grantee; provided, however, that the grantee gives the city at least fifteen (15) days advance notice of such transfer or assignment, and such person or entity executes an undertaking as provided under section 10-10(i) above. 
(l)  The occurrence of an unauthorized transfer or assignment may, at the option of the council, terminate the franchise and accelerate all of the obligations and rights thereunder. The franchise may be terminated without further proceedings as provided in this article, subject to the continuity of service and purchase rights as noted elsewhere in this article or the agreement. 
(m)  The prospective transferee shall submit an initial, non-refundable deposit in an amount determined by the city with any request for a transfer, and shall reimburse the city for all of the city's reasonable processing and review expenses in connection with the transfer which exceed the deposit, including but not limited to the costs of administrative review, financial, legal, and technical evaluation of the prospective transferee, consultants, notice and publication cost, and document preparation expenses. 
(Ord. No. 80-512, § 1, 6-24-97)  
Sec. 10-11. - System design and requirements 
(a)  Grantee shall construct, maintain, operate and improve its cable system in accordance with the accepted standards of the cable industry, and in conformity with the performance standards which may be established by the FCC. 
(b)  Grantee shall provide subscribers with high quality video and audio signals which are free from distortion or interference. 
(c)  Grantee shall maintain as a minimum throughout the term of the franchise the number of channels and broad programming categories specified to be initially activated in the franchise agreement. Grantee shall identify and respond to changing community interests and desires in programming and services, where economically and technically feasible. 
(d)  A grantee shall at all times provide cable television services as defined by the Federal Cable Act. 
(e)  The cable system shall transmit or distribute to all television and radio receivers of all subscribers without causing cross-modulation in the cables or interfering with other electrical or electronic systems or the reception of other television or radio receivers. 
(f)  The cable system shall be designed for and operated on a twenty-four (24) hour basis. 
(g)  The franchise agreement shall set forth the design and construction standards for the system, the construction timetable, location of all facilities, including headends, hubs and wiring. The grantee shall provide in its timetable a construction schedule that will allow the activation of service to the greatest number of residents in the shortest period of time. 
(h)  In the event that grantor shall annex further territory as authorized by law, then the grantee shall extend energized trunk cable to the portions of the annexed territory within the time feasible to make such extension. 
(Ord. No. 80-512, § 1, 6-24-97)  
Sec. 10-12. - Construction requirements. 
(a)  Prior to the commencement of any construction of the cable system or facilities, including the erection or installation of towers, poles, guys, anchors, underground conduits, manholes, or fixtures, the grantee shall first submit to the city engineer, for review and written approval, a concise description of the facilities proposed to be erected or installed, including engineering drawings, if requested or required, together with a map indicating the proposed location of such facilities. Grantee shall not commence construction nor erect or install any tower, pole, guy, anchor, underground conduit, manhole, or fixture until approval therefore has been received from the city engineer. Such approval shall not be unreasonably withheld. 
(b)  Grantee shall construct the cable system and facilities using material of good and durable quality and all work involved in the construction, installation, maintenance and repair of the cable system and facilities shall be performed in a safe, orderly, thorough and reliable manner. 
(c)  Grantee shall construct, install, operate and maintain the cable system and facilities in compliance with and in a manner consistent with all applicable federal, state, and local laws, ordinances, construction standards, governmental requirements, and technical standards. 
(d)  Grantee shall at all times comply with the National Electrical Safety Code (National Bureau of Standards); National Electrical Code (National Bureau of Fire Underwriters); the Michigan Occupations Safety and Health Administration, any standards issued by the FCC or other federal or state regulatory agencies in relation thereto, and applicable regulations of public utilities operating in the city. 
(e)  The cable system and facilities shall be constructed, maintained, and operated in the city as not to endanger or interfere with the safety of persons or property within the city. 
(f)  All cable and facilities shall be installed, where possible, parallel with electric and telephone lines, and multiple cable configurations shall be arranged in parallel and bundled with due respect for engineering and safety considerations. 
(g)  All cable, wires and other facilities shall be installed at a depth or in such manner so as not to interfere with water or main, gas, sewer pipe, traffic signal, street light, and all such poles or other fixtures placed in any street, and other cables or wires occupying the rights-of-way, and shall be placed at the outer edge of the sidewalk and inside the curb line, and those placed in alleys shall be placed close to the line of the lot abutting on said alley. 
(h)  Grantee shall provide adequate barriers, lights, signals and warnings to properly guard any opening or obstruction in, or disturbance of any property to prevent danger to any person or vehicle using such rights-of-way and shall be properly and promptly repaired, all in a manner specified and approved by the city engineer. 
(i)  Grantee shall identify the cable system and facilities by color code, stamping, engraving, tags, stickers, or other appropriate method approved by the city engineer to distinguish the facilities from other systems, utilities, and facilities, or otherwise visibly indicate and alert others to the location of its cable and wires before the cables and wires are installed, and to distinguish grantee's facilities from that of other facilities within the rights-of-way. 
(j)  The grantee shall participate in and have all facilities marked by the Miss Dig Program. 
(k)  The grantee shall provide the city with the name and phone number of a representative the city may contact on a 24-hour basis in the event of an emergency or problem. 
(l)  In areas where transmission or distribution facilities of public utilities providing telephone and electric service are underground, any grantee shall likewise install, construct, maintain and operate its transmission and distribution facilities in like manner underground, to the maximum extent feasible and permitted by existing technology and conditions, subject to the approval of the city engineer. 
(m)  In the event the utilities subsequently relocate their facilities underground, or the city provides notice to the utilities and other cable providers to relocate facilities underground, grantee shall likewise reconstruct, operate and maintain its transmission and distribution facilities underground at grantee's cost, within 60 days of such notice or relocation. Any cable provider granted an initial franchise after the adoption of this article may be required to locate underground pursuant to section 10-6(f). 
(Ord. No. 80-512, § 1, 6-24-97)  
Sec. 10-13. - Conditions of street occupancy. 
(a)  All wires, conduits, cable (coaxial, fiber, or functional equivalent), and other property and facilities of the grantee shall be so located, constructed, installed, and maintained so as not to endanger or unnecessarily interfere with the usual and customary use, traffic and travel upon streets, easements and other public rights-of-way or upon private property. 
(b)  Grantee shall remove any part of the facilities creating a hazardous or unsafe condition or an unreasonable interference with property. 
(c)  Grantee shall make a diligent effort to co-locate by obtaining space in existing conduit and on existing utility poles and to make joint installation of new fiber optic cable and conduit with other cable or facilities occupying the rights-of-way, for the purpose of minimizing disruption of the public rights-of-way. Any joint use or interconnection of fiber optics, conduits or other facilities shall not relieve any person from its franchise fee or other financial obligations. Grantee shall provide the city with notice of such co-located facilities. 
(d)  The grantee shall, at its own cost, protect, support, temporarily disconnect, relocate, remove, raise, or lower from the rights-of-way, any of its property or facilities when required to do so by the city because of street or other public excavation, construction, repair, traffic conditions, public safety, street closing; street construction or resurfacing, installation of sewers, water pipes, power or signal lines, traffic signal, or any other improvement, construction or repair related to the public health, safety, or welfare. 
(e)  The grantee shall, on the request of any person other than the city holding a building moving permit issued by the city, temporarily raise or lower its wires to permit the moving of buildings. The expense of such temporary removal, raising or lowering of wires shall be paid by the person requesting the same, and the grantee shall have the authority to require such payment in advance. The grantee shall be given not less than seven (7) days advance notice to arrange for such temporary wire changes. Any interruption in service occasioned by the temporary removal, raising or lowering of the grantee's facilities in accordance with this section shall not subject the grantee to any penalty provided under the franchise. Any interruption in service occasioned under this subsection shall be done, as far as is practicable, outside of prime time (i.e. 7 to 11 p.m.). 
(Ord. No. 80-512, § 1, 6-24-97)  
Sec. 10-14. - Conditions of pole use. 
(a)  The grantee shall not place, or cause to be placed, poles or other equipment in such a manner as to interfere with the rights of adjoining property owners without securing their written approval in advance, or with any gas, electric or telephone utilities fixtures or property, nor shall the grantee place, or cause to be placed, said poles or equipment in the rights-of-way except with the written approval of the city engineer, which shall not be unreasonably withheld. 
(b)  Nothing in the franchise shall be construed as authorizing the grantee to erect or maintain new poles in areas serviced by existing poles. The grantee shall obtain written approval from the city engineer, which approval shall not be unreasonably withheld before erecting any new poles or installing underground conduits where none exist at the time the grantee seeks to install its cable system. 
(c)  The grantee agrees to enter into only non-exclusive agreements for the use of utility poles with all utility companies whose poles shall be used in or affected by the construction of the cable system. 
(d)  The city shall have the right to install and maintain at no charge upon the poles of grantee, any wire and pole fixtures, including traffic control or police and fire alarm devices, that do not interfere or compete with the cable operations of the grantee. 
(Ord. No. 80-512, § 1, 6-24-97)  
Sec. 10-15. - Restoration of property. 
(a)  The grantee shall, at its own cost, restore and replace any private or public property disturbed, damaged or in any way injured by or on account of its activities to as good as the condition said property was in immediately prior to the said disturbance, damage or injury. If any such property cannot be restored, replaced or reconstructed, the grantee shall reasonably compensate the property owner for any damages caused by grantee. 
(b)  In the event of a failure by the grantee to complete any repair or restoration work required herein or in the franchise agreement, after written notice thereof by the city, or if the grantee does not diligently proceed to commence work within such period, and diligently complete the work within a reasonable period thereafter, or if the work must be completed in less than the required period in cases of emergency constituting a threat to public health, safety and welfare, the city, at its option, may cause such work to be done. Grantee shall reimburse the city for the costs of any work done within thirty (30) days after receipt of such itemized list of such administrative and overhead costs. At its option, the city may pursue remedies in accordance with section 10-27(a)(2) through (6) herein. 
(c)  The grantee may trim trees and other vegetation to prevent their branches from coming in contact with the wires and cables of the grantee. All trimming shall be done at the expense of grantee in the manner consistent with arborist practices and the rules and regulations of the department of parks and recreation. The grantee shall obtain the permission of the owner to trim trees outside of easements. 
(d)  Grantee shall remove and clean on a daily basis any debris caused by construction, tree or vegetation trimming, or by any of its other operations as a grantee. 
(Ord. No. 80-512, § 1, 6-24-97)  
Sec. 10-16. - Technical standards. 
(a)  The system shall at all times meet not less than minimum FCC Technical Standards established by the FCC under Subpart K, Part 76 of Title 47 of the Code of Federal Regulations, as from time to time revised or amended. 
(b)  Upon request, grantee shall provide to the city written reports of the grantee's annual proof of performance tests conducted pursuant to the FCC standards and requirements. 
(c)  RF leakage shall be monitored according to FCC regulations and shall meet FCC requirements. 
(d)  Grantee shall develop and adhere to a preventive maintenance policy directed toward maximizing the reliability (mean-time between malfunctions) and maintainability (mean-time to repair) of the cable system to subscribers at or above the performance standards set forth herein. 
(e)  Grantee shall maintain in constant readiness equipment capable of providing standby-power for the headend and trunk amplifiers for a minimum of four (4) hours. 
(1)  Said equipment shall be constructed so as to revert automatically to a standby mode when alternating current power returns. 
(2)  Grantee shall comply with all utility and other safety regulations to prevent a standby generator from powering the utility line. 
(f)  Antenna structures, if any, used in the cable system shall comply with construction, marking and lighting of antenna structures, required by the Federal Aviation Administration. 
(Ord. No. 80-512, § 1, 6-24-97)  
Sec. 10-17. - Emergency alert system. 
(a)  Grantee shall install as part of its cable system, and shall operate through the franchise term, an emergency alert system (EAS). The EAS shall be in accordance with the requirements imposed by the FCC, if any, including, without limitation, the requirements that cable systems transmit a visual EAS message on at least one channel (47 C.F.R. sec. 11.51 (g)(3)) and that cable systems also provide video interruption and an audio EAS message on all channels, with the audio message further stating which channel is carrying the visual message (47 CFR Sec. 11.51 (g)(2)). 
(b)  In establishing the EAS system pursuant to this section, the grantee shall: 
(1)  Designate a channel (which may be the government channel) which will be used for emergency broadcasts of both audio and video; 
(2)  Inform customers of the designated emergency channel at least daily on at least one channel (which may be the government channel) of the multi-channel system; 
(3)  Maintain all channel video blanking capability able to be activated remotely by security measures deemed mutually agreeable by the city and the grantee; 
(4)  Test the emergency override system not less than every three (3) months; 
(5)  Cooperate with the city on the use and operation of the emergency alert override system; and 
(6)  Maintain the capacity to permit the city in time of emergency to override by remote control all channels simultaneously consistent with the federal regulations as stated in 47 CFR sec. 11.55. 
(Ord. No. 80-512, § 1, 6-24-97)  
Sec. 10-18. - Standard of service; local re- quirements. 
(a)  Grantee shall comply with the consumer protection and customer service standards established by the FCC, as from time to time amended, and any additional standards set forth in the franchise agreement with such grantee or this article. 
(b)  Grantee shall maintain a reasonably convenient customer service office or bill payment location which shall be open during all usual business hours. Grantee shall have a publicly listed local telephone number or toll-free number and be so operated to receive subscriber complaints and requests for repairs or adjustments on a twenty-four (24) hour basis. Grantee shall render efficient service, make repairs promptly, and interrupt service only for good cause and for the shortest time possible. Such interruptions, insofar as possible, shall be preceded by notice and shall be brief and shall occur during periods of minimum use of the system (preferably between midnight and 6 a.m.). A written log shall be maintained listing all complaints resulting in service calls their disposition, and all service interruptions. 
(c)  The grantee shall maintain a suitable repair force of technicians in order to respond to subscriber complaints or requests for service within twenty-four (24) hours after receipt of the complaint or request. 
(d)  There shall be no charge for disconnection or discontinuation of service. 
(e)  Grantee shall promptly disconnect any subscriber who requests disconnection. No period of notice prior to requested termination of service may be required of subscribers by the grantee. The subscriber must be asked when the disconnecting is to become effective. 
(f)  If any subscriber terminates any monthly service prior to the end of a prepaid period, a proportionate portion of any prepared subscriber service fee, using the number of days as a basis, shall be refunded to the subscriber. 
(Ord. No. 80-512, § 1, 6-24-97)  
Sec. 10-19. - Interconnection. 
Grantee shall, if economically and technically feasible, interconnect with any other cable system located within the city and in any adjacent community under reasonable terms and conditions, upon request of the city. The intent of such interconnection is to enable each cable system to carry and cable cast the governmental or educational programming of the other cable system. 
(Ord. No. 80-512, § 1, 6-24-97)  
Sec. 10-20. - Parental lock-out. 
The grantee shall make available to all subscribers, upon written request, a "parental guidance" or "lock-out" device which shall permit the subscriber, at his or her option, to eliminate reception of any or all channels. 
(Ord. No. 80-512, § 1, 6-24-97)  
Sec. 10-21. - Rates and charges. 
The city may regulate rates for the provision of cable services and service charges to the extent permitted by law. If subject to rate regulations, the grantee and city shall comply with the following: 
(1)  No rates or charges for cable service that are subject to rate regulation shall be effective until grantee files the rates and charges with the city clerk. 
(2)  The city shall comply with the rules of the Federal Communications Commission regarding the regulation of rates and the procedures regarding confidential business information. 
(3)  After the grantee submits its existing rates for the or proposed increase in these rates, the clerk shall publish a public notice of these rates and costs giving interested parties, including the grantee an opportunity to file written comments which shall be available in the office of the clerk for public inspection and copying during normal business hours. 
(4)  Any grantee that willfully or repeatedly fails to comply with a rate decision or refund order directed at the grantee shall be subject to a monetary forfeiture of up to two hundred and fifty dollars ($250.00) per day up to ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) for any single act as determined by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 80-512, § 1, 6-24-97)  
Sec. 10-22. - Program content restrictions. 
In addition to providing basic cable television service consisting of broadcast, locally originated, access and character-generated signals, the grantee may offer subscribers optional services on a per-program or per-channel basis (pay cable). The grantee may not, however, program or in any way display material not protected by the U.S. Constitution such as obscene programming. 
(Ord. No. 80-512, § 1, 6-24-97)  
Sec. 10-23. - Insurance. 
(a)  On or before the commencement of operations, grantee and any contractor hired by grantee, shall obtain and shall keep effective during the term a franchise, policies of liability, worker's compensation, property and automotive insurance from companies authorized to do business in Michigan and with an A or better rating by A.M. Best Company. The franchise agreement shall state the form, amounts and further conditions of insurance coverage. 
(b)  All required insurance coverage shall provide for thirty (30) days notice to the city in the event of material alteration or cancellations of such coverage prior to the effective date of such material alteration or cancellation. 
(c)  Grantee shall file with the city prior to the commencement of construction either certified copies of these insurance policies or a certificate of insurance for each of the required policies executed by the company issuing the policy or by a broker authorized to issue such a certificate, certifying that the policy is in force providing the policy number; effective and expiration dates, names of insured and additional insured, type and amount of coverage limits. 
(Ord. No. 80-512, § 1, 6-24-97)  
Sec. 10-24. - Construction, performance bonds, security fund; letter of credit. 
Grantee shall, within sixty (60) days of the effective date of the franchise, file the requisite corporate surety bonds, security fund and/or letter of credit in form acceptable to the city attorney and as deemed necessary to guarantee the faithful performance of grantee's obligations under the franchise, and for the purpose of recovering damages, losses or costs incurred from the failure of grantee to perform its obligations. The form, amounts and conditions of such instruments shall be established in the agreement. 
(Ord. No. 80-512, § 1, 6-24-97)  
Sec. 10-25. - Records required and grantor's right to inspect. 
(a)  Grantee shall keep complete and accurate book of accounts and records of the business and operation under and in connection with the cable system and the franchise. 
(b)  The city shall have the right to review all records pertaining to the grantee's operation within the city of Warren at grantee's local business office or by mail; provided, however that financial audits are subject to section 10-99(d). 
(c)  The city shall, upon request, be provided with a copy of any report relating to the construction, maintenance or operation of the cable system, facilities or the city's regulatory responsibilities under the agreement or ordinance, including, but not limited to any report, statement or data submitted to the FCC or another Federal or State agency. 
(d)  Grantee shall file with the city engineer a current "as built" map showing the location of the transmission and distribution facilities and equipment in the city used by it in providing cable in a standardized format compatible with the city's computerized data system. The map shall be submitted each year unless no changes have occurred in the previously submitted map. 
(e)  An accurate and comprehensive file shall be kept by grantee of all subscriber complaints regarding the grantee. Complete records of grantee's actions in response to complaints shall be kept for three (3) years, and shall be made available to the city upon request. 
(f)  Upon request, grantee shall submit to the city such information and reports as deemed reasonably necessary to monitor compliance with the franchise agreement and ordinance, and in such form as the city may reasonably request. 
(g)  Upon request, grantee shall provide to the city copies of all documents, pleadings, and applications, and any responses thereto, filed by grantee with federal or state agencies or courts, which relate to the franchise. 
(h)  The city shall protect the confidentiality of any information constituting proprietary information and so designated by grantee as confidential or proprietary, and shall withhold such information from public disclosure to the extent permitted under the Michigan Freedom of Information Act, M.C.L.A. sec. 15.243(1). To the extent possible, grantee will provide the city with summaries of any required documents or copies thereof with trade secrets and proprietary matters deleted therefrom. The burden of proof shall be on the grantee to establish the confidential nature of any information submitted. 
(i)  Upon reasonable demand, grantee shall permit the city to make inspections of any of the grantee's facilities situated within or outside of the city during normal business hours upon seventy-two (72) hours notice or, in the event of an emergency, at any time. 
(j)  All reports and records required under the franchise shall be furnished at the sole expense of grantee and within thirty (30) days of the request. Records shall be maintained for a period of not less than three years preceding the date of any request, except as otherwise provided in this article or the agreement. 
(k)  Any materially false or misleading statement or representation knowingly made by the grantee in any report required under the franchise or in any notices to subscribers and users shall be deemed a material breach of the franchise, and shall subject the grantee to all penalties and remedies available at law. 
(Ord. No. 80-512, § 1, 6-24-97)  
Sec. 10-26. - Hearing and determination of complaints. 
(a)  Grantee shall establish written procedures for receiving, acting upon and resolving subscriber complaints without the intervention of the city. The written procedures shall prescribe the manner in which a subscriber may submit a complaint, either orally or in writing. Grantee shall file a copy of these procedures with the city. 
(b)  In the event the intervention of the city is requested, the city, shall upon its own motion or upon complaint of any person or subscriber of a grantee, have authority to hear and determine all complaints concerning the charges, rules, regulations, practices, quality of service, reception, construction, and operation of the cable system. The grantee shall cooperate with the city in resolving any complaint informally, to the extent such complaint may be resolved without formal hearing. 
(c)  In the event a complaint is not resolved informally, the city may conduct a hearing on the complaint. The city shall give all interested parties, including grantee, at least twenty (20) days notice of the time and place of the hearing. grantee shall comply with the decision of the city to resolve the complaint, so long as the decision is reasonable. 
(d)  In the event the parties are unable to reach a resolution, the city and grantee may, by mutual agreement (both as to whether to hire and whom to hire), employ the services of technical, financial or legal consultants, as arbitrators. All reasonable fees of the consultants shall be borne equally. 
(Ord. No. 80-512, § 1, 6-24-97)  
Sec. 10-27. - Procedures to remedy franchise violations. 
(a)  In the event.that the city determines that the grantee has violated any provision of the franchise, or any rule or regulation promulgated hereunder, the city may require the violation be remedied in the following manner: 
(1)  The city shall first notify grantee of the violation in writing by personal delivery or first-class mail, and demand correction within a reasonable time, which shall not be less than five (5) days in the case of construction delay or problem, or the failure of grantee to pay any sum or other amount due the city or deliver an instrument required under the franchise. In the event of a system outage involving ten (10) percent or more of subscribers, correction shall occur within ten (10) days. In all other cases, correction shall occur within thirty (30) days.
