Employee means any person who handles food or drink during preparation or serving, or who comes in contact with any eating or cooking utensils, or who is employed in a room in which food or drink is prepared or served. 
Itinerant restaurant means a restaurant operating for a temporary period in connection with a fair, carnival, circus, public exhibition, or other similar gathering. 
Restaurant means a restaurant, coffee shop, cafeteria, short order cafe, luncheonette, tavern, sandwich stand/shop, soda fountain, coffee house, fast-service, drive-in and all other eating or drinking establishments in which food and drink is prepared for direct consumption through service on the premises or elsewhere, as well as any other eating or drinking establishment or operation where food is served or provided for the public. It does not include those establishments exempted by MCL 333.12901(c) as amended. 
Utensils means any kitchenware, tableware, glassware, cutlery, utensils, containers, or other equipment with which food or drink comes in contact during storage, preparation or serving. 
(Code 1967, § 3-801; Ord. No. 80-517, § 1, 8-26-97) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 14-17. - License required. 
No person shall operate, conduct or maintain a restaurant or an itinerant restaurant in the city without first procuring a license and paying the required fee. 
(Code 1967, § 3-802) 
Cross reference— Licensing generally, Ch. 18.  
Sec. 14-18. - Application for license; fee. 
Application for a license shall be made to the city clerk in the form and manner required by the clerk in accordance with the provisions of this article and Code. The fee shall be as prescribed in section 18-18. 
(Code 1967, § 3-803)  
Sec. 14-19. - Fire and health inspection required. 
No license shall be issued by the clerk under this article without an investigation of the premises where the proposed business is to be operated, conducted or maintained, by the fire commissioner or any inspector designated by him or her and the health officer, and unless these officials signify their approval of the application, in writing, upon the face thereof. 
(Code 1967, § 3-804)  
Sec. 14-20. - Sanitary requirements. 
All restaurants shall comply with the following items of sanitation: 
(1)  Floors. The floors of all rooms in which food or drink is stored, prepared or served, or in which utensils are washed, shall be of such construction as to be easily cleaned, shall be smooth, and shall be kept clean and in good repair. 
(2)  Walls and ceilings. Walls and ceilings of all rooms shall be kept clean and in good repair. All walls and ceilings of any room in which food or drink is stored or prepared shall be finished in light color. The walls of all rooms in which food or drink is prepared or utensils are washed shall have a smooth, washable surface up to the level reached by splash or spray. 
(3)  Doors and windows. When flies are prevalent, all openings into the outer air shall be effectively screened and doors shall be self-closing, unless other effective means are provided to prevent the entrance of flies. 
(4)  Lighting. All rooms in which food or drink is stored or prepared or in which utensils are washed shall be well lighted. 
(5)  Ventilation. All rooms in which food or drink is stored, prepared or served, or in which utensils are washed, shall be well ventilated. 
(6)  Toilet facilities. Each restaurant shall be provided with adequate and conveniently located toilet facilities for its employees, conforming with the laws and regulations of the state. In restaurants hereafter constructed, toilet rooms shall not open directly into any room in which food, drink or utensils are handled or stored. The doors of all toilet rooms shall be self-closing. Toilet rooms shall be kept in a clean condition, in good repair, and well lighted and ventilated. Handwashing signs shall be posted in each toilet room used by employees. 
(7)  Water supply. Running water under pressure shall be easily accessible to all rooms in which food is prepared or utensils are washed, and the water supply shall be adequate, and of a safe, sanitary quality. 
(8)  Lavatory facilities. Adequate and convenient hand-washing facilities shall be provided, including hot and cold running water, soap, and sanitary towels. The use of a common towel is prohibited. No employee shall resume work after using the toilet room without first washing his or her hands. 
(9)  Construction of utensils and equipment. All multi-use utensils and all show and display cases or windows, counters, shelves, tables, refrigerating equipment, sinks, and other equipment or utensils used in connection with the operation of a restaurant shall be so constructed as to be easily cleaned and shall be kept in good repair. Utensils containing or plated with cadmium or lead shall not be used; provided, that solder containing lead may be used for jointing. 
(10)  Cleaning and bactericidal treatment of utensils and equipment. All equipment, including display cases or windows, counters, shelves, tables, refrigerators, stoves, hoods, and sinks, shall be kept clean and free from dust, dirt, insects, and other contaminating material. All cloths used by waiters, chefs and other employees shall be clean. Single-service containers shall be used only once. 
All multi-use eating and drinking utensils shall be thoroughly cleaned and effectively subjected to an approved bactericidal process after each usage. All multi-use utensils used in the preparation or serving of food and drink shall be thoroughly cleaned and effectively subjected to an approved bactericidal process immediately following the day's operation. Drying cloths, if used, shall be clean and shall be used for no other purpose. 
No article, polish or other substance containing any cyanide preparation or other poisonous substance shall be used for the cleaning or polishing of utensils. 
(11)  Storage and handling of utensils and equipment. After bactericidal treatment, utensils shall be stored in a clean, dry place protected from flies, dust and other contamination, and shall be handled in such a manner as to prevent contamination as far as practicable. Single-service utensils shall be purchased only in sanitary containers, shall be stored therein in a clean dry place until used, and shall be handled in a sanitary manner. 
(12)  Disposal of wastes. All wastes shall be properly disposed of, and all garbage and trash shall be kept in suitable receptacles, in such manner as not to constitute a nuisance. Garbage and trash shall be placed in plastic bags prior to being placed in receptacles. The plastic bags must be sealed and must be airtight. Receptacles shall be covered and kept free of flies and rodents. 
(13)  Refrigeration. All readily perishable food and drink shall be kept at or below fifty (50) degrees Fahrenheit except when being prepared or served. Waste water from refrigeration equipment shall be properly disposed of. 
(14)  Wholesomeness of food and drink. All food and drink shall be clean, wholesome, free from spoilage, and so prepared as to be safe for human consumption. All milk, fluid milk products, ice cream and frozen desserts served shall be from approved sources. Milk and fluid milk products shall be served in the individual original containers in which they were received from the distributor or from a bulk container equipped with an approved dispensing device, provided that this requirement shall not apply to cream, which may be served from the original bottle or from a dispenser approved for such service. All oysters, clams and mussels shall be from approved sources, and if shucked shall be kept until used in the containers in which they were placed at the shucking plant. 
(15)  Storage, display and serving of food and drink. All food and drink shall be stored, displayed and served as to be protected from dust, flies, vermin, depredation and pollution by rodents, unnecessary handling, droplet infection, overhead leakage, and other contamination. No animals or fowl shall be kept or allowed in any room in which food or drink is prepared or stored. All means necessary for the elimination of flies, roaches and rodents shall be used. 
(16)  Cleanliness of employees. All employees shall wear clean outer garments and shall keep their hands clean at all times while engaged in handling food, drink, utensils or equipment. Employees shall not expectorate or use tobacco in any form in rooms in which food is prepared. 
(17)  Linens, lockers, premises, etc. The premises of all restaurants shall be kept clean and free of litter or rubbish. None of the operations connected with a restaurant shall be conducted in any room used as living or sleeping quarters. Adequate lockers or dressing rooms shall be provided for employees' clothing and shall be kept clean. Soiled linens, coats and aprons shall be kept in containers provided for this purpose. 
(Code 1967, § 3-805; Ord. No. 80-324, § 1, 7-22-86)  
Sec. 14-21. - Unwholesome food or drink; examination, condemnation. 
Samples of food, drink and other substances may be taken and examined by the health officer as often as may be necessary for the detection of unwholesomeness or adulteration. The health officer may condemn and forbid the sale of, or cause to be removed or destroyed, any food or drink which is unwholesome or adulterated. 
(Code 1967, § 3-806)  
Sec. 14-22. - Inspection of restaurants. 
At least once every six (6) months the health officer shall inspect every restaurant located in the city. The person operating the restaurant shall upon request of the health officer permit access to all parts of the establishment and shall permit copying any or all records of food purchased. 
(Code 1967, § 3-807)  
Sec. 14-23. - Food handlers permit required. 
No person who is affected with, or is a carrier of, any infectious disease in a communicable form shall be employed in handling food or food utensils in any restaurant or itinerant restaurant. No person shall employ any person to handle food or food utensils in any restaurant unless such employee shall first procure a food handlers permit from the health officer and file same with his employer before entering upon his or her duties. The health officer shall not issue such permit to any person unless the permittee has been examined by a duly licensed physician who shall report his or her findings on the form and in the manner prescribed by the health officer. No permit shall be valid for more than one (1) year; no permit shall be renewed without submitting to another medical examination as aforesaid. Such permit shall be revoked by the health officer at any time the holder thereof could not qualify for a new permit if requested so to do. Refusal to submit to another medical examination, if requested by the health officer for good cause, shall constitute adequate reason to revoke any permit. 
(Code 1967, § 3-808)  
Sec. 14-24. - Duty to report to health officer. 
(a)  If any licensee has any reason to believe that any employee has contracted an infectious, contagious or communicable disease, it shall be his or her duty to exclude such employee from the licensed premises and immediately notify the health officer of this fact. If any employee has reason to believe he or she has contracted any infectious, contagious or communicable disease, or if the employee suffers a cough or skin eruption or other suspicious symptom which persists for more than fourteen (14) days, it shall be his or her duty to immediately notify his or her employer and the health officer. 
(b)  The health officer shall immediately exclude such employee from the premises until an investigation is made and shall in addition take such other action as he or she may deem necessary for the protection of the health and welfare of the public. 
(Code 1967, § 3-809)  
Sec. 14-25. - Suspension of license; reinstatement, revocation. 
After any inspection of the licensed premises as herein provided, the health officer shall suspend any license if it is found that any of the provisions of this article have not been complied with or have been violated. Written notice of such suspension and the reason therefor shall be delivered to the licensee either in person or by mail addressed to the licensed premises. Any suspended license shall be revoked at the expiration of ten (10) days unless the licensee shall file with the health officer an application for reinstatement of the license. Upon the filing of such application, the health officer shall make another inspection and, if it is found that the condition causing the suspension of license has been cured or rectified, the license shall be reinstated. 
(Code 1967, § 3-810)  
Secs. 14-26—14-35. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - FAST SERVICE AND DRIVE-IN RESTAURANTS 
 
Sec. 14-36. - Definitions. 
The following words and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them: 
Drive in restaurant shall mean any establishment where food, frozen desserts and/or beverages are sold to the consumer and where motor vehicle parking space is provided and where such food, frozen desserts and/or beverages are intended to be consumed in the motor vehicle parked upon the premises or anywhere on the premises outside of the building as well as in the building. 
Fast service or drive-in restaurant shall mean any establishment where food, desserts, and/or beverages of any kind is/are sold and/or served to the public and where such food, desserts, and/or beverages is/are served to the public directly over a counter and/or exterior or interior convenience window or other opening or both, for consumption by the public within the premises and/or in or around vehicles parked on or passing through the restaurant premises. It does not include those establishments exempted by MCL 333.12901(c) as amended. 
Waste material shall mean paper cups, straws, napkins, garbage, beverages and all other waste matter intended for disposal which, if not placed in a proper receptacle, tends to create a nuisance by rendering property unclean, unsafe and unsightly. 
(Code 1967, § 3-811; Ord. No. 80-517, § 2, 8-26-97) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 14-37. - Disposal of waste materials. 
(a)  The owner and/or manager of any fast-service and/or drive-in restaurant shall at least once every twenty-four (24) hours dispose if waste materials deposited by customers on the premises. It shall be the duty of the fast-service or drive-in restaurant, or any person in charge of said restaurant, to keep the restaurant premises, parking area and contiguous property free from all rubbish, waste products and debris, including napkins, straws, paper cups and plates and other waste material at all times, provided; however, that no private property shall be entered without consent of the owner or the owner's agent. 
(b)  The owner or manager shall provide the fast service and/or drive-in restaurant with a sufficient number of adequate refuse containers. 
(c)  In addition to the other penalties provided by this article, the proprietor of any fast-service or drive-in restaurant may be charged with the costs of cleaning up or removing debris found on the premises and on the public highway or highways adjacent to said premises. The enforcement officer shall have the right, if s/he sees debris on the premises occupied by the fast-service or drive-in restaurant and the highways adjacent thereto to cause the same to be cleaned up and removed from the premises and shall certify the costs of cleaning up and removal to the public service director. If the proprietor of any fast-service or drive-in restaurant fails to pay the costs of clean up and/or removal, such costs may be recovered by the city in the appropriate court of law. The costs when collected, shall be paid into the general fund of the city. 
(Code 1967, § 3-812; Ord. No. 80-517, § 2, 8-26-97) 
Cross reference— Garbage and rubbish generally, Ch. 16.  
Sec. 14-38. - Unlawful conduct on premises. 
(a)  No owner or operator of any fast-service or drive-in restaurant shall operate or permit any loudspeakers or shall make or permit to be made any other loud sound or shall permit any show or exhibit on the premises occupied by such fast-service or drive-in restaurant; provided, however, that the owner or operator of such restaurant may use an intercom address system solely for the purpose of taking orders from customers on the premises. No public address, loud speaker or other sound produced on the premises shall exceed the limits and standards set forth in the Warren Code of Ordinances relating to sound and to noise levels and its measurement and monitoring. It shall be a violation of this section for any customer or other person on the premises to produce any prohibited sound. 
(b)  The owner and/or manager of any fast-service and/or drive-in restaurant shall not knowingly permit disorderly conduct or loitering upon the premises. 
(c)  No person on the premises of any fast-service and/or drive-in restaurant, whether in or out of a motor vehicle, shall consume, have in his or her possession or under his or her control, any alcoholic liquor; provided, however, that this provision shall not apply to any person when served inside the building by a fast-service or drive-in restaurant duly licensed to serve such beverages. 
(d)  No person on the premises of any fast-service and/or drive-in restaurant, shall race the motor of any motor vehicle, needlessly bring to a sudden start or stop any motor vehicle, blow any horn or make or cause to be made any other loud or unseemly noise, nuisance or disturbance whereby the quiet and good order of the premises or of the neighborhood is disturbed. 
(e)  No person shall place, throw or deposit any waste materials upon the outside premises or parking areas of any fast-service and/or drive-in restaurant or on any street, alley or adjoining property, except in adequate receptacles provided for that purpose. 
(f)  It shall be unlawful for any number of persons to congregate for any time whatsoever at any location on the premises of any fast-service and/or drive-in restaurant other than in the restaurant building, or in a legally parked motor vehicle. Any persons so congregating shall be deemed guilty of loitering. 
(g)  It shall be the duty of the owner and/or manager of any fast-service and/or drive-in restaurant to post on the premises, in a conspicuous location, one (1) or more signs bearing the following legend: "Cruising and Gathering Outside of Vehicle Unlawful." 
(Ord. No. 1967, § 3-813; Ord. No. 80-517, § 2, 8-26-97)  
Sec. 14-39. - Paving, parking and lighting. 
All fast-service and drive-in restaurants shall have adequate paving, parking and lighting as required by the City of Warren Zoning Ordinances. 
(Code 1967, § 3-814; Ord. No. 80-517, § 2, 8-26-97)  
Sec. 14-40. - Violations and penalties. 
Any person found guilty of violating the provisions of this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, shall be fined not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisoned for not more than ninety (90) days, or both such fine and imprisonment, in the discretion of the court. 
(Ord. No. 80-517, § 2, 8-26-97)  
Chapter 15 - FRANCHISES  
PREAMBLE 
The city has the authority to grant one or more non-exclusive franchises for the use of streets, alleys, bridges, and other public places of the city for the furnishing of any public utility service to the city and its inhabitants. This chapter is intended to encourage customer choice and competition among electric utilities and other electric generators to reduce electric rates. Any grant of franchise in this chapter excludes a franchise to construct, lay, maintain, or operate facilities, including but not limited to, electric lines, towers, masts, poles, crossarms, guys, braces, feeders, transmission and distribution wires, transformers and other electrical appliances in, along, over or under highways, streets, alleys, and other public places in the City of Warren, Michigan.  
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 15-1. - Definitions. 
For the purposes of this chapter, the following terms, phrases, and words shall have the meanings respectfully ascribed to them: 
City or grantor shall mean the City of Warren, Michigan or its designee. 
Facilities/electric system shall mean any plants, works, systems, improvements and equipment owned, leased or used by grantee, including, anchors, wires, fixtures, underground conduits, circuits, electric lines consisting of towers, masts, poles, crossarms, braces, feeders, transmission/distribution wires, transformers, other electrical appliances and other property used or installed in the public right-of-way, which is necessary or convenient for the sale, transmission and/or distribution of electricity to a customer or customers. 
Public right-of-way means all public rights-of-way within the city which are owned by the city, either as an easement or in fee simple, and all other public places, including but not limited to the public rights-of-way used for streets, highways, sidewalks and alleys. 
(Ord. No. 80-549, 12-28-99)  
Sec. 15-2. - Franchise required. 
No person or utility may transport, deliver, or sell electricity to one or more customers through the use of facilities located in the public rights-of-way, and may not otherwise transact business in the city for the transportation and/or delivery of electricity unless the person or utility has been granted a franchise. 
(Ord. No. 80-549, 12-28-99)  
Sec. 15-3. - Franchise application process. 
(a)  Any request for a franchise must be submitted on an application in such form as may be prescribed by the city. The application must be submitted by a non-refundable application fee in the amount established by the city. 
(b)  Any untrue or misleading statement of material fact or omission of a material fact shall be grounds for rejection of an application. 
(c)  The applicant shall be responsible for all costs incurred by the city in connection with the proposed franchise, including but not limited to, any technical, legal, and financial evaluation, administrative review, and document preparation. 
(Ord. No. 80-549, 12-28-99)  
Secs. 15-4—15-23. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - ELECTRIC 
 
15-24. - Grant of non-exclusive electric utility franchise. 
Subject to all the terms and conditions set forth in article I and II, the City of Warren grants to Nordic Electric, L.L.C., a Michigan limited liability company ("grantee"), a franchise to supply electricity and electrical services as part of a program approved or authorized by the Michigan Public Service Commission or successor agency having similar jurisdiction, or by a federal agency, and to transact related local business in the City of Warren. This grant of a franchise excludes a franchise to construct, lay, maintain or operate facilities, including but not limited to electric lines, towers, masts, poles, crossarms, guys, braces, feeders, transmission and distribution wires, transformers and other electrical appliances in, along, over or under the highways, streets, alleys, and other public places in the City of Warren, Macomb County, Michigan; and further provided that grantee shall supply electricity and electrical services solely through facilities presently owned and maintained by the Detroit Edison Company, by agreement with the Detroit Edison Company or as otherwise provided by law. This grant of franchise also includes a franchise for grantee to own, operate and maintain metering and telemetry equipment for the purpose of serving its customers, provided that such equipment will not be used to bill services provided by the Detroit Edison Company. 
(Ord. No. 80-549, 12-28-99)  
Sec. 15-25. - Term of franchise. 
The term of the franchise granted under article I and II is for two (2) years after it takes effect, subject to revocation at the will of the City of Warren at any time during the two-year period. 
(Ord. No. 80-549, 12-28-99)  
Sec. 15-26. - Electric service and extension of system. 
(a)  If grantee accepts all terms and conditions set forth in this franchise, then the grantee may furnish electricity to customers located in the city under a program approved or authorized by the Michigan Public Service Commission or successor agency having similar jurisdiction, or by a federal agency, and in accordance with applicable laws, rules, and regulations. Subject to the terms of article I and II, the grantee may from time to time extend its services and furnish electricity to any and all residents within the city in accordance with applicable laws, rules, and regulations. There are no limitations on the number of customers, which the grantee may serve hereunder. However, the prohibition pertaining to construction set forth in the preamble and section 15-4 shall remain effective. 
(b)  Notwithstanding this grant, the grantee must comply with all provisions of the Code of Ordinance and rules and regulations of the city which regulate the use of public rights-of-way in the City of Warren, including but not limited to all permit requirements, to the extent applicable. 
(Ord. No. 80-549, 12-28-99)  
Sec. 15-27. - Sale/lease/successors/assigns. 
Grantee shall not sell, lease or sublease, assign, or allow another to use the franchise granted in article II without the consent of the city. If the grantee intends to transfer or assign this franchise, written application for such transfer or assignment shall first be made to the city. In reviewing a request for a transfer, the city may request additional information as deemed necessary to inquire into the technical, legal, and financial qualifications of the prospective transferee, and the grantee shall assist the city in so inquiring. 
(Ord. No. 80-549, 12-28-99)  
Sec. 15-28. - Consideration; costs. 
(a)  In consideration of the rights, power, and authority granted by the city, the grantee shall faithfully perform all duties required by the terms of this chapter. 
(b)  In further consideration of the rights, power and authority granted by the city, grantee agrees: 
(1)  To pay to the city a non-refundable application fee in the amount of four thousand dollars ($4,000.00); and 
(2)  To compensate the city: 
a.  For the amount of its actual expenses incurred by the city in the drafting and preparation of this ordinance, including reasonable actual attorney fees; and 
b.  For the amount of its actual expenses resulting from the process of adopting this ordinance. Grantee's total obligation to compensate the city for its actual expenses under this subsection (b) shall not exceed four thousand dollars ($4,000.00). 
(Ord. No. 80-549, 12-28-99)  
Sec. 15-29. - Use of public rights-of-way and other public places by grantee. 
(a)  No burden on public ways. No highway, street, alley, bridge, waterway or other public place used by the grantee shall be obstructed by the grantee. 
(Ord. No. 80-549, 12-28-99)  
Sec. 15-30. - Public emergency. 
The city shall have the right to sever, disrupt, dig up or otherwise destroy facilities of grantee, or used by grantee's customers, without any prior notice, if such action is deemed necessary by the appropriate city official or employee because of a public emergency. Public emergency shall be any condition which, in the opinion of the city, poses an immediate threat to the lives or property of the citizens of the city, caused by any natural or manmade disaster, including, but not limited to, storms, floods, fire, accidents, explosions, major water main breaks, hazardous material spills, etc. The owner of the facilities shall be responsible for repair at its sole expense of any of its facilities damage pursuant to any such action taken by the city. 
(Ord. No. 80-549, 12-28-99)  
Sec. 15-31. - License and employee identification. 
(a)  If at any time any personnel of grantee or any of its agents, as part of their duties, call upon residences in the city with the intention of offering electric customers a choice of alternative electric supply and/or services, grantee and/or its agents shall be required to obtain a license as required in chapter 24, article V of the Warren Code of Ordinances. 
(b)  All personnel of grantee or any of its agents who have as part of their duties contact with the general public shall wear on their clothing a clearly visible identification card bearing their name and photograph. Grantee shall account for all identification cards at all times. Every service vehicle of grantee or its agents shall be clearly identified as such to the public. 
(Ord. No. 80-549, 12-28-99)  
Sec. 15-32. - No city liability; indemnification. 
(a)  City not liable. The city, its officials, employees, and agents, shall not be liable for: 
(1)  Any injury that may occur to any person, or for any damage that may occur to any person, or for any damage that may occur to any property, as a result of any act, decision, or other consequence or occurrence arising out of the discharge of duties and responsibilities pursuant to this article. 
(2)  Any injury or damage occurring to any person or property from any cause whatsoever arising out of the construction, maintenance, repair, use operation, condition, or dismantling of any electric system owned or used by grantee, or used by grantee's customers, and due to the act or omission of any person or entity other that the city. 
(3)  For any interference with or disruption of the operation of any electric system owned or used by grantee or used by grantee's customers, or for any damage arising out of grantee's use of the public rights-of-way. 
(b)  Indemnification. As part of the consideration for this article, grantee shall defend, indemnify, protect and hold harmless the city, its officers, agents, employees, departments, boards, and commissions from any and all claims, losses, liabilities, causes of action, demands, judgments, decrees, proceedings, and reasonable expenses of any nature (including, without limitation, actual fees and expenses of attorneys, expert witnesses and consultants), arising out of or resulting from the acts or omissions of grantee, its officers, agents, employees, contractors, successors, or assigns which may arise as a result of the franchise. 
(c)  Assumption of risk. Grantee undertakes and assumes for its officers, agents and employees, all risk of dangerous conditions, if any, on or about any city-owned or controlled property, including public ways, and grantee hereby agrees to indemnify and hold harmless the city against and from any claim asserted or liability imposed upon the city for personal injury or property damage to any person arising out of the condition of the electric system or grantee's failure to comply with any federal, state, or local statute, ordinance, or regulation. 
(d)  Notice, cooperation, and expenses. The city shall give grantee prompt notice of the making of any claim or the commencement of any actions, suits, or other proceeding covered by this article. 
(1)  Grantee shall pay all expenses incurred by city in defending itself with regard to any such actions, suits, or proceedings. These expenses shall include all out-of-pocket expenses such as attorney fees and shall also include the reasonable value of any services rendered by or on behalf of the city's attorney, and the actual expenses of city's agents, employees or expert witnesses, and disbursements and liability assumed by city in connection with such suits, actions, or proceedings. 
(Ord. No. 80-549, 12-28-99)  
Sec. 15-33. - Insurance. 
(a)  During the term of this franchise, grantee shall maintain or cause to be maintained in full force and effect, and at its sole cost and expense, the following types and limits of insurance: 
(1)  Worker's compensation insurance with Michigan statutory limits, including employers' liability coverage. 
(2)  Automobile liability insurance to cover any vehicles used by anyone in connection with its activities under this article, with personal protection insurance and property protection insurance to comply with the provisions of the Michigan no fault insurance law including residual liability insurance with minimum limits of one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) as to the combined single limit for each occurrence for bodily injury and property damage. 
(3)  Comprehensive general liability insurance with the minimum limits of two million dollars ($2,000,000.00) as the combined single limit for each occurrence of bodily injury, personal injury, and property damage. The policy shall provide blanket contractual liability insurance for all written contracts, and shall include coverage for products and completed operations liability, independent contractors liability, broad general form liability extensions or equivalent, and coverage for property damage from perils of explosion, collapse or damage to underground utilities, commonly known as XCU coverage. 
(b)  The city, its elected officials, appointed officials, employees, agents, board members, committees, and commissions shall be named as an additional insured in all applicable policies. All insurance policies shall provide that they shall not be canceled or modified unless sixty (60) days prior written notice is given to the city. Grantee shall provide the city with a certificate of insurance evidencing such coverage as a condition of this article, and shall maintain on file with the city a current certificate along with written evidence of payment of required premiums. All insurance shall be issued by insurance carrier licensed to do business by the State of Michigan or by surplus line carriers on the Michigan Insurance Commission approved list of companies qualified to do business in Michigan. All insurance and surplus line carriers shall be rated A+ or better by A.M. Best Company. 
(c)  Each policy which is to be endorsed to add the city as an additional insured hereunder, shall contain cross-liability wording, as follows: 
In the event of a claim being made hereunder by one insured for which another insured is or may be liable, then this policy shall cover such insured against whom a claim is or may be made in the same manner as if separate policies had been issued to each insured hereunder. 
(d)  If the insurance policies required by this article are written with deductibles, the deductibles shall be approved in advance by the city. Grantee agrees to indemnify and hold harmless the city from and against the payment of any deductible and from the payment of any premium on any insurance policy required to be furnished by this article. 
(e)  Grantee shall require each and every one of its contractors and subcontractors carry, in full force and effect, workers' compensation, comprehensive public liability and automobile liability insurance coverage of the type which grantee is required to obtain under the terms of this article with appropriate limits of insurance. 
(Ord. No. 80-549, 12-28-99)  
Sec. 15-34. - Franchise not exclusive. 
The rights, power and authority granted are not exclusive. 
(Ord. No. 80-549, 12-28-99)  
Sec. 15-35. - Annual performance report. 
On or before March 31 of each year, grantee shall submit to the city clerk's office an annual report, which describes grantee's activity in the city for the preceding calendar year (January 1 —December 31). The report must include the following information: 
(1)  Total Energy sales quantities, revenues and number of customers, separated into industrial, commercial and residential classes. 
(Ord. No. 80-549, 12-28-99)  
Sec. 15-36. - Information to be provided to customers. 
Grantee shall provide to its customers in the city the following information: 
(1)  Price information, including average annualized cents per kilowatt hour measured at the customer's meter, price variability information by time of use and volume, and all charges, fees and penalties; 
(2)  Terms of service, including length and kind of contract, billing policies, warranties and notice procedures; 
(3)  Customer service information, including a contact address, telephone number and procedures for obtaining and maintaining service for making complaints; and 
(4)  Fuel and emissions characteristics, information on the fuel mix and emissions characteristics associated with the grantee's load-serving resource portfolio. 
(Ord. No. 80-549, 12-28-99)  
Sec. 15-37. - Cooperation with the city energy committee and/or commission. 
Grantee agrees to cooperate with the city in any energy plan created by the energy committee/commission by participating in projects and programs mutually agreed upon by the city and grantee. 
(Ord. No. 80-549, 12-28-99)  
Sec. 15-38. - Revocation. 
The franchise granted by this article is subject to revocation at the will of the city upon thirty (30) days' written notice to the grantee. 
(Ord. No. 80-549, 12-28-99)  
Sec. 15-39. - Jurisdiction. 
Grantee shall be and remain subject to all ordinances, rules and regulations of the city now in effect or which might subsequently be adopted for the regulation of land uses or for the protection of the health, safety, and general welfare of the residents of the city. 
(Ord. No. 80-549, 12-28-99)  
Sec. 15-40. - State and federal regulatory agencies. 
(a)  Jurisdiction. Grantee shall, as to all other conditions and elements of service not addressed or fixed by this chapter, remain subject to the rules and regulations applicable to electric service by the Michigan Public Service Commission, its successor bodies or any federal agency. 
(b)  Filing. Grantee shall provide the city with copies of all documents which grantee sends to the Michigan Public Service Commission or applicable agency and copies of all orders, decisions, or correspondence grantee receives from the public service commission related to services provided under this franchise. Grantee shall permit city to inspect and examine all records it is required to maintain or file under Michigan Public Service Commission rules and regulations. 
(Ord. No. 80-549, 12-28-99)  
Sec. 15-41. - Effective date. 
This chapter shall take effect twenty (20) days from the date of adoption by the city council and shall continue in effect for a period of two (2) years subject to revocation at the will of the city at any time during said two-year period; provided, however, it shall cease and be of no effect unless and until within fifteen (15) days after adoption the grantee shall file its written acceptance of the same with the clerk, and pay to the city the sum required by section 15-8. 
(Ord. No. 80-549, 12-28-99)  
Chapter 16 - GARBAGE AND RUBBISH[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 80-449, § 1, adopted Feb. 22, 1994, amended former Ch. 16, §§ 16-1—16-10, relating to garbage and rubbish, in its entirety to read as herein set out. The provisions of former Ch. 16 derived from Code 1967, §§ 4-1201—4-1207 and Ord. No. 80-409, § 1, adopted June 9, 1992. 
Charter reference— Authority to collect and dispose of garbage and rubbish, § 3.1(b)(2)(c). 
Cross reference— Refuse and debris at excavations for wrecked buildings, § 9-418; disposal of waste materials at drive-in restaurants, § 14-37; garbage and rubbish storage facilities in mobile homes, § 20-45; garbage and rubbish disposal for mobile homes, § 20-46; nuisances, Ch. 21; disposal of rubbish, garbage and waste materials in parks, § 23-10; regulation of soil, refuse or fuel carrying vehicles, § 37-631 et seq., water and sewers, Ch. 41. 
State Law reference— Authority to regulate disposal of garbage and rubbish, MCL 123.241 et seq., 123.361 et seq. 
 
Sec. 16-1. - Purpose. 
The City of Warren finds that the reduction of the amount of solid waste and conservation of recyclable materials is an important public purpose. 
The separation and collection of paper, cardboard, glass, cans and vegetative yard waste for recycling from the residential establishments in this municipality will minimize the adverse environmental effects of landfilling by reducing the need for landfills and conserving existing landfill capacity, facilitate the implementation and operation of other forms of resource recovery, conserve natural resources and reduce the cost of solid waste disposal in general. The promotion and use of recyclable materials, goods produced from recyclable materials and goods which facilitate recycling will further serve the same purposes by encouraging and facilitating recycling. 
(Ord. No. 80-449, § 1, 2-22-94)  
Sec. 16-2. - Definitions. 
As used in this article, the following terms shall have the respective meanings ascribed to them: 
City designated disposal facility: A facility or facilities which the city has identified from time to time as an approved location for the disposal of municipal solid waste, compost material, and/or recyclable materials. 
City recyclable container: A container provided by the City of Warren as a suitable container for the purpose of residential recyclable collection. 
Comingled: Source-separated, nonputrescible recyclable materials that have been mixed at the source of generation (i.e., placed in the same container). 
Compost material: Grass, leaves, weeds, garden waste which may include vegetable waste, and light brush less than two (2) inches in diameter and four (4) feet in length. 
Newspaper: All newsprint and materials that are a part of a newspaper only. 
Recyclable material: Glass bottles and jars without caps; tin and aluminum cans; plastic containers marked "1" (PETE) or "2" (HDPE); newspapers, newspaper inserts, telephone books, magazines, catalogs, all size brown paper bags, white paper, colored paper, computer paper, stationery, glossy and non-glossy advertisement flyers, index cards, post cards, and paper envelopes. 
Recycling drop off: Any facility designed and operated solely for the receiving and storing of source separated, nonputrescible metal, glass, paper, plastic containers and cardboard. 
Site of generation: Any premises in the City of Warren in or on which solid waste, compost or recyclable materials is generated by any person. 
Solid waste: Garbage, refuse and other discarded materials resulting from domestic and community activities, and shall include all other waste materials, including non-hazardous liquids. 
Source separate: To separate recyclable and compost material from the solid waste stream at the point of waste generation. 
Yard waste: All grass, weeds, leaves, small twigs and shrub clippings, flowers and basic waste materials resulting from landscaping. 
Yard waste collection season: A period each year as scheduled by the Department of Public Service during which a yard waste collection service is provided in specified areas of the city. 
(Ord. No. 80-449, § 1, 2-22-94) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 16-3. - Curbside program established; preparation for collection; collection schedule. 
(a)  Curbside program established; collection schedule. There is hereby established within the city a program ("curbside program") for the separate collection of municipal solid waste compostables and recyclable materials from all residents of the City. 
Separate collections of compostables and recyclable material shall occur in the manner and on the schedule as set forth by the director of public service. 
Such schedules shall be published by the city and shall define the area and dates of collection and the material designated for recycling. 
All residents and other persons in charge of any premises located within the city areas serviced by the curbside program, established by this article, shall source separate all designated recyclables and compostables from solid waste and place them between curb and sidewalk where possible at the side of the public right-of-way fronting their premises in the manner designated by this article on the dates specified for collection. 
(b)  Preparation of solid waste, compostables and recyclables for curbside collection. All solid waste, compostables and recyclables placed at the curbside for collection shall be prepared for collection in accordance with the requirements of this chapter and article together with the special requirements as may be set by the director of public service. 
a.  All newspapers shall be placed in paper bags or tied in bundles not exceeding thirty-five (35) pounds in weight nor exceeding one (1) foot in thickness. 
b.  All brush shall be cut into four-foot lengths or less and tied into bundles weighing not more than thirty-five (35) pounds in weight. No individual piece of brush may exceed two (2) inches in diameter. 
c.  All compostables must be placed in a clear plastic bag. Compostables not so bagged will not be picked up. The gross weight of compost bags, placed for collection shall not exceed forty (40) pounds in weight. Compostables not so contained will not be picked up. 
d.  All recyclables must be placed in a recyclable material container provided by the City of Warren. Recyclables not so contained will not be picked up. 
e.  Solid waste must be thoroughly drained of liquids and be wrapped in several thicknesses of paper before being placed in receptacles for collection. 
Items too large to fit into regular containers such as discarded rugs, appliances, furniture, mattresses, etc., should be set neatly next to the waste receptacles. Appliances with a latching door must have the door removed for safety purposes. Mattresses, rugs and similar items must be rolled up and tied securely whenever possible. Motor vehicle air conditioners, household refrigerators and freezers and room air conditioners must have affixed to it, documentation or certification, that the refrigerant has been removed by a certified contractor, before it will be collected at curbside. 
f.  NO SOLID WASTE, COMPOSTABLE, OR RECYCLABLE MATERIAL SHALL BE PLACED AT THE CURB OR STREET FOR COLLECTION PRIOR TO 6:00 P.M. OF THE CALENDAR DAY PRIOR TO THE RESIDENTS SCHEDULED PICK-UP DAY. 
g.  After the collection of the container contents has been made, the empty container shall be removed from the curb or street and replaced on the owner's storage area as soon as possible, but in no case later than ten (10) hours after collection of the refuse has been made. 
(Ord. No. 80-449, § 1, 2-22-94)  
Sec. 16-4. - Separation of brush, leaves, yard waste and other compostables or recyclables. 
(a)  No person shall dispose of leaves, yard waste, compostables, or designated recyclables, nor arrange for the disposal of the same or cause the same, to be disposed of in any manner inconsistent with this ordinance. 
(b)  All persons who gather leaves, yard waste, compostables or designated recyclables, shall source separate the items and place them for collection at the times and in the manner heretofore or hereafter specified by this ordinance or the director of public service. 
(c)  Nothing herein shall prevent any person from gathering leaves for compost, mulch or other gardening purposes. 
(d)  The city, or any other person collecting solid waste generated within the City Limits, may refuse to collect solid waste from any person who has failed to source separate designated recyclables or compostables. 
(Ord. No. 80-449, § 1, 2-22-94)  
Sec. 16-5. - Unlawful activities, scavenging, littering. 
(a)  Designated recyclable materials and compostable materials placed at curbside in accordance with this ordinance shall become the exclusive property of the city or the city's authorized agent. There shall be a presumption that the occupier or owner of the premises intended to recycle or compost the material under this ordinance if the material is placed at curbside. It shall be unlawful for any person not duly authorized by the city, to collect, remove, pick up, or cause to be collected, removed, or picked up, any such material. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to violate, cause to be violated, or assist in the violation of any of the provisions of this ordinance. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to place or to cause to be placed any material other than compostable or designated recyclable material in or near any recycling drop off or city designated disposal facility. 
(d)  The term "litter" as used in this section means all solid waste, compost material, paper, glass, cans, bottles, trash, debris or other foreign substances of every kind and description. 
It is unlawful for a person knowingly, without the consent of the public authority having supervision of public property or the owner of private property, to dump, deposit, place, throw, or leave, or cause or permit the dumping, depositing, placing, throwing, or leaving of, litter on public or private property or water other than property designated and set aside for such purposes. The phrase "public or private property or water" includes, but is not limited to, the right-of-way of a road or highway, a body of water or watercourse or the shore or beach thereof, including the ice above the water; a park, playground, building, refuge, or conservation or recreation area; and residential or farm properties or timberlands. It is unlawful for a person who removes a vehicle, wrecked or damaged in an accident on a highway, road, or street, to fail to remove all glass and other injurious substances dropped on the highway, road, or street as a result of the accident. 
(Ord. No. 80-449, § 1, 2-22-94)  
Sec. 16-6. - Authority, costs, notice to remove solid waste. 
(a)  The director of public service is hereby authorized and empowered to notify, in writing, the owner of any premises to remove solid waste found to be not in compliance with this ordinance on such premises (unless the same is on the abutting public right-of-way in which case no notice is required). Such notice shall be by hand delivery or certified mail, addressed to the said owner at the last known address. 
(b)  If solid wastes are not removed from the premises within six (6) days after the date of mailing such notice, or if the solid waste is on abutting public right-of-way, the owner and/or tenant(s) of the premises shall be subject to penalties as set forth in section 16-10(b) of this ordinance. The director of public service is also hereby authorized and empowered to pay for the removal of the solid waste or to order the removal by the city. 
(c)  When the city has effected the removal of such solid waste or has paid for its removal, the actual cost thereof, plus accrued interest at the rate of one (1) percent per month from the date of removal, shall be charged to the owner of the premises on the next regular tax bill forwarded to such owner by the city, and said charge shall be due and payable at the time of payment of such tax bill. 
(d)  Where cost of removal is not paid by the owner within sixty (60) days after the removal of such solid waste as set forth in parts (b) and (c) of this section, then the director of public service shall cause to be recorded in the treasurer's office the date and premises on which removal was done. The recording of such statement shall constitute a lien on the property and shall remain in full force and effect for the amount due in principal and interest until final payment has been made and shall be collected in the manner provided by law for collection of taxes; further, the total amount shall be subject to a delinquent penalty of one (1) percent per month in the event same is not paid in full on or before the date of the tax bill upon which said charge appears becomes delinquent; said sworn statements recorded in accordance with the provisions hereof shall be notice to every person concerned that the amount of the statement, plus interest, constitutes a charge against the premises described in the statement that the same is due. 
(e)  Any owner (as indicated in the current assessment roll of the city) of a condominium complex which does not meet city specification may request curbside solid waste, compost and recyclable material pick up by the city. The request and waiver of city liability must be made in writing with the director of public service. Upon said request the city will perform curbside pick up and the city will not be held liable for damage or alterations to any and all surface areas, subsurface areas or subsurface structures of any street not meeting city specification. The signed waiver of liability must be approved by the director of public service and filed with the city clerk's office. 
(f)  Commercial waste of any kind will not be collected by the department of public service. Commercial enterprises include industrial, office, medical and commercial businesses. 
(Ord. No. 80-449, § 1, 2-22-94)  
Sec. 16-7. - Other remedies. 
(a)  In addition to any other remedy provided in this article, this municipality may institute a suit in equity where unlawful conduct or public nuisance exists as defined in this article for an injunction to restrain a violation of this article. In addition to an injunction, the court may impose penalties as authorized by section 16-10. 
(b)  The penalties and remedies prescribed by this ordinance shall be deemed concurrent. The existence or exercise of any remedy shall not prevent this municipality from exercising any other remedy provided by this ordinance or otherwise provided at law or equity. 
(Ord. No. 80-449, § 1, 2-22-94)  
Sec. 16-8. - Recyclable container specifications. 
(a)  City recyclable container shall be of a distinctive color or material and printed with the city seal or other appropriate words which indicate to refuse collectors that the container is intended for residential recyclable collection service. 
Specifications for city recyclable containers and its use, and any future changes to those specifications shall be developed in accordance with this ordinance. Those specifications shall include, but shall not be limited to, the materials used and the content of printed information. 
(b)  At the inception of the mandatory recyclable material program, the City of Warren will provide to every residence a recyclable material container free of charge. Additional recyclable material containers that must be provided to a residence shall be sold to the residence at a price to be determined by resolution of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 80-449, § 1, 2-22-94)  
Sec. 16-9. - Compost bag specifications. 
(a)  Compost material bags shall be clear in order to indicate to compost material collectors that the bags are intended for residential compost collection service. 
(b)  Specifications for city compost material bags and their use and any future changes to those specifications shall be developed in accordance with this ordinance. These specifications shall include, but shall not be limited to, the materials used for such bags. 
(Ord. No. 80-449, § 1, 2-22-94)  
Sec. 16-10. - Penalty. 
Except if there is an administrative hearings officer vacancy as described in chapter 2.5, section 2.5-4(d), the violation of a provision of this chapter is a blight violation. The administrative hearings bureau shall punish a violator found responsible for a blight violation as provided in Warren Code of Ordinances, chapter 2.5, section 2.5-7. 
(Ord. No. 80-449, § 1, 2-22-94; Ord. No. 80-527, § 13, 1-13-98; Ord. No. 80-630, § 1, 3-28-06; Ord. No. 80-651, § 1, 4-24-07; Ord. No. 80-731, § 4, 8-11-15; Ord. No. 80-750, § 2, 2-14-17)  
Chapter 17 - HOTELS/MOTELS, LAUNDRIES AND SELF-SERVICE CAR WASHES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference— Authority to regulate trades and occupations, § 3.1(b)(2)(a). 
State Law reference— Cleaning agents, MCL 323.231 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 17-1. - Penalty. 
The violation of any provision of this chapter is a municipal civil infraction which shall result in the assessment of a fine of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) or not more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per violation, plus costs and other sanctions for each infraction. 
(Ord. No. 80-527, § 14, 1-13-98)  
Secs. 17-2—17-15. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - SELF-SERVICE LAUNDRIES  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 17-16. - Defined. 
For purposes of this article, a "self-service laundry" shall be deemed to be any place of business, whether or not customarily attended by the operator or employees of the operator thereof, available to the general public for the purpose of washing, drying, ironing, and/or extracting moisture from garments, linens, rugs, blankets, and other commonly laundered articles through the use of coin-operated machines or devices operated by the patrons of such business. 
(Code 1967, § 3-1802) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 17-17. - Requirements. 
All self-service laundries for which a license shall have been issued under this article shall comply with the following requirements: 
(1)  All provisions of building, electrical, plumbing, heating, ventilation, health and fire codes, rules or regulations applicable to self-service laundries shall be complied with by the licensee. 
(2)  The water heating and/or softening system shall be installed and maintained so as to be inaccessible to the general public. 
(3)  Washers shall be installed and maintained so that such moving parts and electrical components thereof as need not be accessible to the operator thereof in the usual and customary operation of such machines, shall not be readily accessible to the general public. 
(4)  Dryers shall be so installed and maintained that the backs and tops thereof shall not be readily accessible to the general public. 
(5)  All dryers installed or maintained in a self-service laundry shall be so designed as to be inoperable when the door thereof is open, and all such dryers shall be capable of having their doors opened from the interior thereof upon the application of outward pressure against such doors. 
(6)  All automatic washers or combination washer-extractor units installed in any location after May 1, 1970, shall be so manufactured or equipped that the doors or lids thereto cannot be opened during any portion of the operating cycle of such machine, or so that if the door or lid thereto is opened during any portion of the operating cycle thereof, such machine will be automatically caused to cease operating; provided, however, that this subsection (6) shall be deemed to have been complied with if such machines are equipped with a device, mechanism or means readily accessible to the user thereof, whereby the operation of such machine may be stopped, which such device, mechanism or means shall be identified by an appropriate label or sign prominently displayed upon such machine. 
(7)  Separate extractor machines shall be securely anchored to the floor and shall be so manufactured or equipped that the doors thereof cannot be opened during any portion of the operating cycle thereof. 
(8)  The minimum level of illumination in self-service laundries shall be not less than fifteen (15) foot-candles throughout the entire area accessible to the public, measured at a height of four (4) feet above the floor. All switches for control of illumination shall not be accessible to the public. All self-service laundries shall be kept in good repair and maintained in a clean and sanitary condition and shall be so installed and maintained that the area therein accessible to the general public shall be reasonably visible to the exterior thereof either by direct or indirect view. 
(9)  An appropriate refuse receptacle shall be furnished in all self-service laundries for the convenient use of the patrons thereof. 
(10)  All self-service laundries shall be prohibited from having amusement devices or mechanical music devices commonly known as juke boxes; provided, that this shall not prohibit the placing of AM or FM radios for the enjoyment of patrons, provided, however, that the controls thereof shall not be accessible to the public; and provided further, that where the establishment provides an attendant, a juke box may be allowed during such time as the attendant is on duty. 
(Code 1967, § 3-1806)  
Secs. 17-18—17-30. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Licensing generally, Ch. 18. 
 
Sec. 17-31. - Required. 
(a)  Every person operating a self-service laundry within the city shall obtain a license as provided in this division. 
(b)  The license prescribed in this division shall be in addition to any other license required by virtue of the operation of any business other than the business of a self-service laundry. 
(Code 1967, §§ 3-1801, 3-1804)  
Sec. 17-32. - Application. 
Application for a license under this division shall be made to the city clerk on forms provided by the clerk. 
(Code 1967, § 3-1803; Ord. No. 80-274, § 1, 2-22-83)  
Sec. 17-33. - Fee. 
The fee for a license under this division shall be as prescribed in section 18-18. 
(Code 1967, § 3-1803; Ord. No. 80-274, § 1, 2-22-83)  
Sec. 17-34. - Investigation; approval. 
Application for a license under this division shall be referred to the fire department, the division of buildings and safety engineering, the health department and the police department, and each of the departments shall certify to the city clerk whether the location concerned in such application complies with all laws, ordinances, rules and regulations applicable thereto. 
(Code 1967, § 3-1805)  
Secs. 17-35—17-45. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - SELF-SERVICE CAR WASHES[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 80-505, § 1, adopted January 14, 1997, amended the Code by the addition of §§ 17-35—17-37 and 17-38—17-41; however, said provisions have been redesignated as §§ 17-46—17-48 and 17-60—17-63, at the editor's discretion, for purposes of maintaining Code format. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 17-46. - Defined. 
For purposes of this article, a "self-service" car wash shall be deemed to be any place of business, whether customarily attended by the operator or employees of the operator, available to the public for the purpose of washing, vacuuming, and cleaning automobiles through the use of coin-operated machines or devices operated by the patrons of such business. 
(Ord. No. 80-505, § 1, 1-14-97)  
Sec. 17-47. - Requirements. 
All self-service car washes for which a license shall have been issued under this article shall comply with the following requirements: 
(1)  All provisions of building, electrical, plumbing, heating, ventilation, health and fire code, rules or regulations applicable to self-service car washes shall be complied with by the owner, licensee, manager, or person in charge of any self-service car wash. 
(2)  It shall be the duty of the owner, licensee, manager, or person in charge of any self-service car wash, to keep the premises together with the parking area and any adjacent area, free from rubbish, waste products and debris. An appropriate refuse receptacle shall be furnished in all self-service car washes for the convenient use of the patrons. 
(3)  All liquid wastes created from the operation of the self-service car wash shall be intercepted before entering a sewer by a suitable catch basin properly trapped and vented. Such wastes shall not drain over or into any street, sidewalk, courtyard, or paved approach, and no person shall throw or discharge from any lot or building any water, fluid or liquid substance so as to affect injuriously the surface of the street or sidewalk or so as to make it unsafe for travel. 
(4)  All self-service car washes shall be kept in good repair and maintained in a clean and sanitary condition. 
(5)  All equipment used for the operation of the self-service car wash shall be properly installed and maintained so as not to cause a danger to the general public. 
(6)  All lights used in connection with auto washes shall be shaded so as not to project upon or become a nuisance to adjacent properties. 
(Ord. No. 80-505, § 1, 1-14-97)  
Sec. 17-48. - Unlawful conduct on premises. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to congregate for any time whatsoever at any location on the premises of a self-service car wash if they are not using the self-service car wash for the purpose it was designed for. Any person so congregating shall be deemed guilty of loitering. 
(Ord. No. 80-505, § 1, 1-14-97)  
Secs. 17-49—17-59. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 
 
Sec. 17-60. - Required. 
(a)  Every person operating a self-service car wash within the city shall obtain a license as provided in this division. 
(b)  The license prescribed in this division shall be in addition to any other license required by virtue of the operation of any business other than the business of a self-service car wash. 
(Ord. No. 80-505, § 1, 1-14-97)  
Sec. 17-61. - Application. 
Application for a license under this division shall be made to the city clerk on forms provided by the clerk. 
(Ord. No. 80-505, § 1, 1-14-97)  
Sec. 17-62. - Fee. 
The fee for a license under this division shall be as prescribed in section 18-18. 
(Ord. No. 80-505, § 1, 1-14-97)  
Sec. 17-63. - Investigation; approval. 
Application for a license under this division shall be deferred to the fire department, the division of building and safety engineering, the health department and the police department, and each of the departments shall certify to the city clerk whether the location concerned in such application complies with all laws, ordinances, rules and regulations applicable thereto. 
(Ord. No. 80-505, § 1, 1-14-97)  
Secs. 17-64—17-75. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - HOTELS AND MOTELS[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 80-509, adopted May 13, 1997 added a new art. IV, §§ 17-42—17-54, relative to motels and hotels to read as herein set out. Sections 17-42—17-54 of said Ord. No. 80-509 have been redesignated at the direction of the city as §§ 17-76—17-83 and 17-96—17-100. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 17-76. - Defined. 
For the purpose of this article, a "hotel" or "motel" is defined as any building or part thereof kept, used or maintained as or held out to the public to be an inn, hotel or motel where travelers or members of the public (including gratuitous guests) are furnished with sleeping accommodations and which may include individual or general kitchen facilities, or a public dining room where the guests and general public may be served with food and drink. 
(Ord. No. 80-509, § 1, 5-13-97)  
Sec. 17-77. - Word "hotel" or "motel" to be displayed at entrance and on outside of building. 
Licensees under this article shall display the word "hotel" or "motel" in letters not less than two (2) inches high in a conspicuous place at the entrance thereof and on the outside of the building. 
(Ord. No. 80-509, § 1, 5-13-97)  
Sec. 17-78. - Register required; use of fictitious names prohibited. 
(a)  Every licensee or his agent, servant or employee, under this article shall provide and maintain a register in which shall be inscribed, in ink, at the time of arrival, the correct name of every guest renting or occupying a room, together with the home street and city address of each such guest, and the number of the space assigned, together with the time when such was rented. When any guest shall terminate his stay, it shall be the duty of the licensee or his agent, servant or employee, to see to it that the time thereof is entered in the register. Such register shall be open to inspection to police and fire officers on official business. 
(b)  Whenever a licensee or his agent, servant or employee knows or has reasonable cause for believing that any person has inscribed a false name or given false information in such register, it shall be his duty to forthwith notify the police department of such fact. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to write or cause or permit to be written in any hotel or motel register any other or different name or designation than the true name of the person so registered. 
(Ord. No. 80-509, § 1, 5-13-97)  
Sec. 17-79. - Responsible person required to notify fire department of fires occurring in hotel or motel. 
In all establishments licensed under this article, the licensee shall at all times have a person (who may also be the licensee) at this place of registration, who shall be charged with the duty of immediately notifying the fire department when a fire occurs therein. Any person therein who discovers such a fire shall immediately notify the person on duty at the place of registration. 
(Ord. No. 80-509, § 1, 5-13-97)  
Sec. 17-80. - Liability of hotel or motel for loss of valuables. 
Each licensee under this article who provides a safe or suitable vault for the custody of money, bank notes, jewelry, articles of gold and silver manufacture, precious stones, personal ornaments, railroad mileage books or tickets, negotiable or valuable papers, shall keep the same in good order and shall not be liable for the loss of or injury of any such property belonging to any guest unless such guest has offered to deliver the same, for custody in such safe or vault; provided that the licensee shall not be obliged to receive from any one guest for deposit in such safe or vault any properties hereinbefore described exceeding a total value of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00). 
(Ord. No. 80-509, § 1, 5-13-97)  
Sec. 17-81. - Locks, etc., required on doors, windows and transoms. 
Each licensee under this article shall keep on the doors of the sleeping rooms used by the guests suitable locks and bolts and on the transoms and windows of rooms suitable fastenings. 
(Ord. No. 80-509, § 1, 5-13-97)  
Sec. 17-82. - Occupancy of rooms by minors. 
It shall be unlawful for any licensee under this article or his agent, servant or employee to permit any minor under seventeen (17) years of age to be housed in any establishment licensed under this article, unless such presence is with the consent or knowledge of the parent, guardian or adult lawfully in charge of such minor, unless such licensee, his agent, servant or employee forthwith notifies the police department of the presence of such minor. 
(Ord. No. 80-509, § 1, 5-13-97)  
Sec. 17-83. - Hotels and motels to comply with housing act of state and other rules and regulations. 
Every hotel and motel and every part thereof shall comply with the housing act of the state, this code and other ordinances of the city, and all rules and regulations lawfully promulgated under this article. 
(Ord. No. 80-509, § 1, 5-13-97)  
Secs. 17-84—17-95. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 
 
Sec. 17-96. - Required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of conducting or maintaining a hotel or motel within the city without a license in compliance with the provisions of this division. 
(Ord. No. 80-509, § 1, 5-13-97)  
Sec. 17-97. - Fee; expiration date. 
The fees for licensee under this division shall be as established pursuant to chapter 18 of this code. All licenses shall expire on the thirty-first day of March of each year. 
(Ord. No. 80-509, § 1, 5-13-97)  
Sec. 17-98. - Application; agreements by licensee. 
(a)  Application for a license under this division shall be made to the city clerk on forms furnished for such purpose by the city clerk. The application shall contain, in addition to other required information, the following: 
(1)  The name, age and address of the applicant; 
(2)  If applicant is a corporation: 
a.  The full and accurate corporation name; 
b.  When and where incorporated; 
c.  Full names and addresses of the officers of the corporation. 
(3)  If applicant is a partnership, the names and addresses of members thereof; 
(4)  If the applicant conducts business under a trade or assumed name: 
a.  The complete and full trade name. The name and address of the persons doing business under such trade or assumed name. 
b.  Such application shall also contain an agreement upon the part of the applicant that he will comply with the provisions of this article and that he will forthwith notify the police department as to the presence of any minors under seventeen (17) years of age housed in any such licensed establishment, unless with consent or knowledge of the parent, guardian or adult lawfully in charge of such minor. 
(Ord. No. 80-509, § 1, 5-13-97)  
Sec. 17-99. - Investigation of applicant. 
The city clerk shall refer all applications for license under this article to the police commissioner, who shall cause each application to be investigated to determine whether the applicant or licensee has been convicted of violating any of the laws of this state, the United States or this code or other ordinances of the city involving moral turpitude, and to determine whether there are any facts which would tend to show that such applicant or licensee is not a suitable person to conduct or maintain such a business. The police commissioner shall furnish to the city clerk, in writing, the information obtained from such investigation, accompanied by a recommendation as to whether the license should be granted, refused, revoked or renewed, as the case may be. The police commissioner may conduct any further investigation which it deems advisable for the purpose of showing whether or not the applicant is a suitable person to conduct the business. 
(Ord. No. 80-509, § 1, 5-13-97)  
Sec. 17-100. - Inspections. 
Each application for a license or renewal thereof shall be referred by the police commissioner to the building department and the fire department. No license shall be issued until after an inspection has been made by the aforesaid agencies and it has been found that the premise comply in all respects with the housing act of the state and the provisions of this code and other ordinances of the city and a certificate to that effect shall have been issued by the building department. 
(Ord. No. 80-509, § 1, 5-13-97)  
Chapter 18 - LICENSING[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference— Authority to regulate trades and occupations, § 3.1(b)(2)(a). 
Cross reference— Administration, Ch. 2; handbill distributors license, § 3-24; license for ambulances, § 5-16 et seq.; license for pool and billiard establishments, § 6-31 et seq.; license for bowling alleys, § 6-61 et seq.; license for public dance halls, § 6-91 et seq.; license for skating rinks, § 6-121 et seq.; license for theaters and concerts, § 6-151 et seq.; license for circuses, carnivals and exhibitions, § 6-186 et seq.; license for amusement parks and riding devices, § 6-211 et seq.; license for amusement machines, § 6-246 et seq.; license for auctions and auctioneers, § 8-21 et seq.; license for moving buildings, § 9-376 et seq.; license for wrecking buildings, § 9-431 et seq.; license required for restaurants, § 14-17; license for self-service laundries, § 17-31 et seq.; massage establishments license, § 19-21 et seq.; myomassologist license, § 19-29 et seq.; license required to sell paraphernalia for controlled substances, § 22-206; license for peddlers, § 24-31 et seq.; licensing of ice cream vendors, § 24-53; license for transient merchants, § 24-91 et.seq.; license for route salesperson, § 24-126 et seq.; license for junk yards, § 30-21 et seq.; sidewalk contractors license, § 34-71 et seq.; license for tattoo parlors, § 36-26 et seq.; license for wreckers, § 37-571 et seq.; license for parking lots and stations, § 37-611 et seq.; license for soil refuse or fuel carrying vehicles, § 37-646 et seq.; business license for taxicabs and minibuses, § 39-41 et seq.; license for trailer rentals, § 39-106 et seq.; license for motorcycle rentals, § 39-151 et seq.; license for vending machines, § 40-26 et seq. 
 
Sec. 18-1. - License required. 
No person shall, directly or indirectly, operate, conduct, maintain or manage any business, trade, occupation or premises for which any license is required by this chapter or any other ordinance of the city without first procuring the license in the manner prescribed in this chapter. 
(Code 1967, § 3-101)  
Sec. 18-2. - Penalty. 
The violation of any provision of this chapter is a municipal civil infraction which shall result in the assessment of a fine of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) or not more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per violation, plus costs and other sanctions for each infraction. 
(Ord. No. 80-527, § 15, 1-13-98)  
Sec. 18-3. - Evidence of doing business. 
The fact that any person represents himself or herself as being engaged in any business, trade or occupation for the transaction of which a license is required, or that such person exhibited a sign or advertisement indicating that he or she is engaged in such business, trade or occupation, shall be prima facie evidence of the liability of such person to pay the required license fee. 
(Code 1967, § 3-119)  
Sec. 18-4. - State license or permit not exemption. 
The fact that a license or permit has been granted to any person by the state to engage in the operation, conduct, maintenance or management of any business, trade, occupation or premises shall not exempt such person from the necessity of procuring a license from the city, if such license is required by this chapter or any other ordinance of the city. 
(Code 1967, § 3-103)  
Sec. 18-5. - Application. 
Each person required to procure a license from the city shall make application for such license to the city clerk in the form and manner prescribed by the clerk and shall state, under oath, such facts as may be required for, or applicable to, the granting of such license, including the following: 
(1)  The full names, business addresses and residence addresses of all owners, proprietors, officers, managers and local employees of applicant's business; the names and addresses of each officer, if the applicant is a corporation; 
(2)  The place or places in the city where it is proposed to maintain applicant's business, and the length of time during which it is proposed that such business be conducted; 
(3)  The nature, character and quality of the goods, wares, merchandise or services to be sold or offered for sale by applicant; 
(4)  The nature and kind of business which applicant proposes to conduct and the manner of operating same; 
(5)  A list of all assumed, trade or firm names under which applicant intends to do business; 
(6)  The nature and character of advertising done or proposed to be done in order to attract customers; 
(7)  Whether or not the applicant or person conducting or managing applicant's business has been convicted of a crime, misdemeanor or the violation of any municipal ordinance, and, if so, full particulars in connection therewith. 
(Code 1967, § 3-104)  
Sec. 18-6. - Compliance with state law prerequisite to issuance. 
No license required by this chapter or any other ordinance of the city shall be issued to any person who is required to procure a license or permit from the state until such person shall submit evidence that the required state license or permit has been issued and that all fees pertaining thereto have been paid. 
(Code 1967, § 3-106)
