(10)  Proof of insurance in policies an amounts as required by section 24-97. 
(11)  Proof of worker's compensation insurance or if applicable a M-D 337 form. 
(12)  Obtain and show proof of the issuance of a certificate of occupancy pursuant to section 22.10 of the Zoning Ordinance. 
(13)  Any other information the city clerk may deem necessary to protect the public good relating to the identity or character of the person who will manage or supervise the business or the method or plan of doing such business. 
(Ord. No. 80-450, § 3, 2-22-94; Ord. No. 80-493, § 3, 2-13-96)  
Sec. 24-93. - Agents. 
If the applicant is acting as agent for another person, or the applicant will have an agent performing the applicant's duties, the applicant shall be required to file with the application an instrument acknowledging the agent as the true and lawful agent with full power and authority to acknowledge service of notice of process on behalf of the principal in respect to any matters arising out of the business transacted under the license and the bond given pursuant to this article. The instrument shall also contain recitals that the principal consents and agrees that service of any notice or process may be made upon the agent, and when made shall be considered valid as if personally served upon the principle and shall further waive any claim or right of error by reason of such acknowledgement of service or manner of service. 
(Ord. No. 80-450, § 3, 2-22-94)  
Sec. 24-94. - Investigation. 
No license shall be issued without the required investigation and approvals. The city clerk shall forward the application for investigation and approval as follows: 
(a)  To the police commissioner who shall cause an investigation to be made of the applicant's moral character pursuant to the standards and procedures set forth in section 18-8 of the Code of Ordinances. After such investigation, the police commissioner shall endorse upon the application his or her approval or disapproval and forward the application to the city clerk. 
(b)  To the zoning official who shall review the application to determine whether the property is properly zoned for the proposed use. The zoning official shall endorse upon the application his or her approval or disapproval and forward the application to the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 80-450, § 3, 2-22-94)  
Sec. 24-95. - Outdoor retail sales. 
In addition to the licensing requirements contained in this article, applicants proposing to conduct outdoor retail sales must obtain an outdoor retail sales permit pursuant to sections 4.44—4.55 of the Zoning Ordinance prior to the issuance of a transient merchant license. 
(Ord. No. 80-450, § 3, 2-22-94; Ord. No. 80-493, § 4, 2-13-96)  
Sec. 24-96. - Fee. 
Every applicant for a transient merchant license shall at the time of filing application, pay a fee based on the length of time the applicant requests to conduct business in the city as specified in section 18-18. 
(Ord. No. 80-450, § 3, 2-22-94; Ord. No. 80-493, § 4, 2-13-96)  
Sec. 24-97. - Insurance required. 
As a condition precedent to the issuance of a transient merchant license, the applicant shall file with the city proof of a general liability insurance policy or policies issued by a company licensed to do business in this state for public liability covering injuries to persons and wrongful deaths from the negligence or wilfulness of the licensee, his or her agents, servants or employees in an amount not less than $1,000,000.00 each occurrence. In addition, the policy shall name the City of Warren as an additional insured and shall state that the first named insured shall indemnify and hold harmless the City of Warren for any and all liability arising out of said operations. The policy shall also include a provision that the insurer shall notify the City of Warren of any modifications or cancellation of the insurance policy or policies. 
(Ord. No. 80-493, § 4, 2-13-96)  
Sec. 24-98. - License issuance. 
Whenever the applicant has received police commissioner approval, zoning approval, and otherwise fulfilled the requirements of this article and is further in compliance with all other regulations contained in the Code of Ordinances for the City of Warren, the city clerk shall issue the transient merchant license for the time period and location specified. 
(Ord. No. 80-450, § 3, 2-22-94; Ord. No. 80-493, § 4, 2-13-96)  
Sec. 24-99. - License contents. 
The license shall contain the number of the license, the date the license is issued, the nature of the business authorized to be carried on, the amount of the license fee paid, the expiration date of the license, the place where the business may be carried on under the license and the name of the person authorized to conduct the business. 
(Ord. No. 80-450, § 3, 2-22-94; Ord. No. 80-493, § 4, 2-13-96)  
Sec. 24-100. - Display of license. 
The license issued under this article shall be posted conspicuously on the licensed premises. If the person applying for the license shall desire to do business in more than one (1) place within the city, separate licenses may be issued for each place of business and shall be posted conspicuously in each place of business. Any license issued pursuant to this article is non-transferable. 
(Ord. No. 80-450, § 3, 2-22-94; Ord. No. 80-493, § 4, 2-13-96)  
Sec. 24-101. - Records required. 
The city clerk shall deposit the fingerprint records together with the license number with the police commissioner. The police commissioner shall report to the city clerk any complaints received against the licensee and any conviction(s) for violation of this article. In addition, the city clerk shall keep a record of all licenses issued, of all complaints received and of any violations. 
(Ord. No. 80-450, § 3, 2-22-94; Ord. No. 80-493, § 4, 2-13-96)  
Sec. 24-102. - Denial, revocation and suspension. 
Any license issued pursuant to this article may be denied, revoked or suspended pursuant to the standards and procedures set forth in Chapter 18, section 18-12. 
(Ord. No. 80-450, § 3, 2-22-94; Ord. No. 80-493, § 4, 2-13-96)  
Secs. 24-103—24-110. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - ROUTE SALESPERSONS  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 24-111. - Defined. 
In this article, "route salesperson" means any person whether self-employed or employed by another, who travels by any vehicle on a regularly established route, from time to time in the city calling at various residences with the intention of offering for sale any goods, wares or merchandise, or offering any service, for immediate or future delivery. 
(Code 1967, § 3-1201; Ord. No. 80-427, § 1, 3-23-93) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 24-112. - Council determination. 
The city council having determined that route salespersons call at various residences in the city, and for the protection of the occupants of such residences the city council finds that it is a matter of public welfare and safety to determine the moral character of such route salespersons and to achieve this purpose finds regulation of route salespersons is required and necessary. The city council having further determined that route salespersons generally sell items of food or services which may affect the health and welfare of the people of the city, and that regulation of route salespersons and the vehicle they use is necessary and desirable to protect and promote the public welfare, therefore to achieve this purpose, the city council adopts this article. 
(Code 1967, § 3-1202; Ord. No. 80-427, § 2, 3-23-93)  
Sec. 24-113. - Enforcement. 
It shall be the duty of any police officer to require any person seen route selling, and who is not known by such officer to be duly licensed, to produce his or her route selling license and to enforce the provisions of this article against any person found to be violating the same. 
(Code 1967, § 3-1209)  
Secs. 24-114—24-125. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference— Licensing generally, Ch. 18. 
 
Sec. 24-126. - Required. 
It shall be unlawful for any route salesperson to engage in such business within the city without first obtaining a license therefor as provided in this division. 
(Code 1967, § 3-1203)  
Sec. 24-127. - Application. 
Applicants for a license under this division shall file with the city clerk a sworn application in the form and manner required by the city clerk, which shall state the following information: 
(1)  Name and description of the applicant; 
(2)  Permanent home address and full local address of the applicant; 
(3)  A brief description of the nature of the business and the goods to be sold; 
(4)  If employed, the name and address of the employer, together with credentials establishing the exact relationship; 
(5)  The length of time for which the right to do business is desired; 
(6)  The place where the goods or property proposed to be sold, or orders taken for the sale thereof, are manufactured or produced, where such goods or products are located at the time the application is filed, and the proposed method of delivery; 
(7)  A photograph of the applicant, taken within sixty (60) days immediately prior to the date of filing of the application, which picture shall be two (2) inches by two (2) inches showing the head and shoulders of the applicant in a clear and distinguishing manner; 
(8)  The fingerprints of the applicant; 
(9)  A statement as to whether or not the applicant has been convicted of any crime, misdemeanor, or violation of any municipal ordinance, the nature of the offense and the punishment or penalty assessed therefor; 
(10)  If the applicant proposes to engage in the sale of food or foodstuffs, a certificate from a doctor of medicine, duly licensed to practice in the state, to the effect that the applicant is free from any contagious or infectious disease. 
(Code 1967, § 3-1204)  
Sec. 24-128. - Investigation; issuance. 
(a)  Upon receipt of an application under this division, the original shall be referred to the police commissioner, who shall cause such investigation of the applicant's moral character to be made as he or she deems necessary for the protection of the public welfare. 
(b)  If as a result of such investigation the moral character of the applicant is found to be satisfactory, the police commissioner shall endorse on the application his or her approval, and return the application to the city clerk, who shall issue a license to the applicant. The license shall contain the signature and seal of the issuing officer and shall show the name, address and photograph of the licensee, the class of license issued, and the kind of goods to be sold thereunder, the amount of fee paid, the date of issuance, and the length of time the same shall be operative, as well as the license number and other identifying description of any vehicle used in such route selling. 
(c)  If as a result of the investigation the applicant's moral character appears to be unsatisfactory, the police commissioner shall endorse on the application his or her disapproval, which shall be submitted, along with the results of his or her investigation, to the city clerk who shall not issue the license. 
(Code 1967, § 3-1207)  
Sec. 24-129. - Fees; exemption. 
(a)  Each applicant for a license under this division shall, at the time of making the application, pay the license fee specified in section 18-18. 
(b)  Any honorably discharged member of the coast guard, soldier, sailor or marine of the military or naval service of the United States, who is a resident of the state and a veteran of any war in which the United States of America has been or shall be a participant, shall have the right to take orders for, or sell, his or her own goods, wares and merchandise within the city by procuring a license therefor as herein prescribed. Application for such license shall be made to the city clerk in the form and manner prescribed in this division and, upon presentation to the city clerk of a certificate of honorable discharge from the coast guard, army, navy or marine corps of the United States, which certificate shall show that the applicant is a veteran of any war in which the United States has been or shall be a participant, a veteran's license shall be issued to the applicant without cost. Any person exempt by law from the payment of license fees as prescribed herein, shall comply with all other provisions of this article and upon submission of satisfactory evidence to the city clerk of such exemption, the city clerk shall issue to such applicant a license without requiring the payment of any fee, and the city clerk shall indicate upon the face of the license that same was issued, pursuant to such exemption without any fee being paid therefor. 
(Code 1967, § 3-1206) 
State Law reference— Exemption for a veteran's license, MCL 35.441.  
Sec. 24-130. - Bond required. 
Every applicant under this division shall file with the city clerk a surety bond, running to the city in the amount of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), with surety acceptable and approved by the city attorney, conditioned that the applicant shall comply fully with all the provisions of the ordinances of the city and the statutes of the state regulating and concerning the business of route salespersons and guaranteeing to any citizen of the city that all money paid as a down payment will be accounted for and applied according to the representations of the route salesperson and further guaranteeing to any citizen of the city doing business with the route salesperson, that the property purchased will be delivered according to the representations of the route salesperson. Action on such bond may be brought in the name of the city to the use or benefit of the aggrieved person. 
(Code 1967, § 3-1208)  
Sec. 24-131. - Records required. 
The police commissioner shall report to the city clerk all convictions for violation of this article and the city clerk shall maintain a record for each license issued and record the reports of violations therein. 
(Code 1967, § 3-1210)  
Secs. 24-132—24-145. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - CHARITABLE SOLICITATIONS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 80-465, § 1, adopted Sept. 13, 1994, amended former Art. VI, relative to charitable solicitations, in its entirety to read as herein set out. The provisions of former Art. VI derived from Code 1967, §§ 3-2201—3-2208 and Ord. No. 80-458, adopted June 28, 1994. 
State Law reference— Charitable organizations and solicitations, MCL 400.271 et seq. 
 
Sec. 24-146. - Definitions. 
The following words and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them: 
Canvass means to go about to seek orders, contributions, support, subscriptions, or aid on behalf of charitable organizations, religious organizations and community action groups. 
Canvasser means a person who canvasses on behalf of a charitable organization, religious organization or community action group. 
Charitable organization means a benevolent, educational, philanthropic, humane, patriotic or eleemosynary organization of persons which solicits or obtains contributions solicited from the public for charitable purposes. A person, chapter, branch, area office, or similar affiliate or person soliciting contributions within the state for a charitable organization which has its principal place of business outside the state is a charitable organization. This definition does include duly constituted religious organizations no part of the net income of which inures to the direct benefit of any individual if it has received a declaration of current tax exempt status from the United States. 
Community action group means a nonprofit organization of persons whose purpose it is to canvass, solicit or obtain contributions solicited from the public for projects sponsored by that organization. 
Religious organization means any number of persons brought together for the purpose of establishing any church organization for the purpose of teaching and spreading their religious beliefs and principles. 
Solicit means the door-to-door, building-to-building, or person-to-person request for money, credit, property, financial assistance or other thing of value including the sale or offer to sell of any thing whether of value or not, on the representation that such money, credit, property, financial assistance or other thing of value or any part thereof, will be used for a charitable, religious, political, patriotic, civic, educational or philanthropic purpose. 
Solicitor means a person who solicits on behalf of a charitable organization, religious organization or community action group. 
(Ord. No. 80-465, § 1, 9-13-94) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 24-147. - Identification required. 
Solicitors or canvassers for religious organizations, charitable organizations or community action groups are required to identify themselves and the organizations they represent, in writing to the city council twenty (20) days in advance of any solicitation or canvassing for any religious organization, charitable organization or community action group. Such identification form shall be filed with the city clerk and shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The name and address of the applicant, as well as, the charitable organization, religious organization or community action group seeking permission to solicit or canvass in the city; 
(2)  The names and addresses of the person or persons who will be in direct charge of conducting the solicitations; 
(3)  The names and addresses of all persons who will be soliciting or canvassing; 
(4)  A statement as to whether the applicant is a charitable organization, religious organization or community action group; 
(5)  The length of time of the solicitation or canvassing, including the specific dates and times of the proposed solicitation or canvassing. 
(Ord. No. 80-465, § 1, 9-13-94)  
Sec. 24-148. - Authorization. 
(a)  Upon receipt of an identification form seeking permission to solicit or canvass in the City of Warren, the city clerk shall immediately forward the form onto the city council for their consideration. The city council shall place the matter on the agenda to be considered within twenty (20) days of the date the identification form was filed and notify the applicant of the date set for consideration. The applicant shall appear at the council meeting to address any concerns and questions the council may have. If the city council determines that the requirements of section 24-147 have been met, the city council shall endorse its approval upon the application and forward the identification form to the city clerk. 
(b)  If the city council determines that the requirements of section 24-147 have not been met, the application shall be returned disapproved to the applicant. 
(c)  If an approval or denial is not issued by the city council within twenty (20) days of the submission of an application, it shall be presumed that the application has been approved by the city council and the city clerk shall immediately thereupon notify the applicant by letter of the authorization from the city council. 
(d)  The city clerk shall keep on file such identification form and shall notify the applicant immediately by letter of the action of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 80-465, § 1, 9-13-94)  
Sec. 24-149. - Authorization and licensing exemptions. 
(a)  The authorization and licensing requirements of this article do not apply to any charitable organization determined by the Attorney General to be exempt under section 13 of the Charitable Organizations and Solicitations Act, MCL § 400.271 et seq. upon the production of a certification of exemption from the state. 
(b)  The authorization and licensing requirements of this article do not apply to any minors who reside within the city that are engaged in soliciting for an educational, religious or youth organization. 
(Ord. No. 80-465, § 1, 9-13-94)  
Sec. 24-150. - License contents. 
The license issued under this article shall bear the name and address of the person by whom the solicitation is made, the date issued, the dates within which the license holder may solicit, the name of the organization or group the person is soliciting on behalf of, a picture of the solicitor or canvasser and shall contain a statement that the license does not constitute an endorsement by the city of the purpose of he solicitation or of the person or group conducting the solicitation. All licenses shall be endorsed by the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 80-465, § 1, 9-13-94)  
Sec. 24-151. - Display of license; transferability. 
Every solicitor or canvasser shall prominently display his/her license at all times while soliciting or canvassing in the city. It shall be unlawful for any solicitor or canvasser to refuse to exhibit his/her license upon request of a police officer or private citizen. Any license issued under this article shall be nontransferable. 
(Ord. No. 80-465, § 1, 9-13-94)  
Sec. 24-152. - Alteration prohibited. 
No solicitor or canvasser shall change, remove, obliterate or alter in any way the license issued under this article. 
(Ord. No. 80-465, § 1, 9-13-94)  
Sec. 24-153. - Location. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any solicitor or canvasser to operate in a congested area where his/her operations impede traffic and endanger safety. 
(b)  No solicitor or canvasser shall enter onto any private premises where there is a sign posted prohibiting solicitation. 
(Ord. No. 80-465, § 1, 9-13-94)  
Sec. 24-154. - Loud noises and speaking devices restricted. 
It shall be unlawful for any solicitor or canvasser to shout, cry, blow a horn, or use any sound device including loud speakers or sound amplifiers for the purpose of attracting attention to the solicitation or canvassing. 
(Ord. No. 80-465, § 1, 9-13-94) 
Cross reference— Unlawful noise from hawking, § 21-25; similar provisions for peddlers, § 24-19; similar provisions for transient merchants, § 24-74.  
Sec. 24-155. - Hours. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in solicitation or canvassing pursuant to this article except between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 9:00 p.m. 
(Ord. No. 80-465, § 1, 9-13-94)  
Sec. 24-156. - Denial, revocation and suspension. 
Any license issued pursuant to this article may be denied, revoked or suspended pursuant to the standards and procedures set forth in Chapter 18, section 18-12. 
(Ord. No. 80-465, § 1, 9-13-94)  
Secs. 24-157—24-160. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VII. - PEDDLING OR SOLICITATION BY MINORS[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Cross reference— Minors and parental responsibility, § 22-239 et seq. 
 
Sec. 24-161. - Hours. 
It shall be unlawful for any minor to engage in peddling, solicitation or canvassing pursuant to this chapter during school hours, unless legally excused from school; or to peddle, solicit or canvass after sunset or 8:00 p.m. whichever is earlier. 
(Ord. No. 80-484, § 1, 7-11-95)  
Sec. 24-162. - Severe weather. 
It shall be unlawful for any minor to peddle, solicit or canvass pursuant to this chapter when there is a wind chill or temperature of fifteen (15) degrees above zero (Fahrenheit) or less. 
(Ord. No. 80-484, § 1, 7-11-95)  
Sec. 24-163. - Responsibility for minors. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, association, partnership, corporation or organization to hire, employ, utilize or permit any minor to peddle, solicit or canvass on its behalf in violation of any of the provisions of this chapter. 
(b)  Any person, firm, association, partnership, corporation or organization that hires, employs or utilizes any minor to peddle, solicit or canvass on its behalf is responsible for the health, safety and welfare of the minors it utilizes, while peddling, soliciting or canvassing. 
(Ord. No. 80-484, § 1, 7-11-95)  
Sec. 24-164. - Display of license. 
Any minor peddling, soliciting or canvassing pursuant to a license issued under any of the provisions of Chapter 24 of the Code of Ordinances, unless exempt, shall carry and display upon request the original license issued. Duplicates or reproductions of the license which may include but are not limited to xerox copies and fax transmissions shall not constitute valid proof of licensing and any holder of such invalid license shall be in violation of this article. 
(Ord. No. 80-484, § 1, 7-11-95)  
Secs. 24-165—24-168. - Reserved.  
Chapter 25 - PERSONNEL[1] 
Footnotes:

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 25-1—25-20. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - CIVIL SERVICE[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Charter reference— Mandate for civil service plan, § 7.28. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 25-21. - Definitions. 
The following words and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them: 
Appointing officer or authority means a department head or other person possessing the authority to appoint persons to fill job vacancies. 
City service means employment by the city in a position covered by civil service. 
Co-op student employee means an individual who is employed in a temporary position on an hourly basis, and who works no more than twenty-five (25) hours per week during the school year and thirty-seven and one-half (37.5) hours per week when school is not in session. Co-op student employees must be receiving educational credit for such employment. Co-op students shall not be considered to have seniority, shall receive no fringe benefits, and shall not share in equalization of overtime. 
Demotion means any change of job classification where the classification to which the employee is appointed involves less responsibility, authority or technical ability and where the maximum pay rate authorized for the position in the city pay plan is less than that authorized for the position vacated by the employee upon appointment to the new job classification. 
Eligible list means a list of individuals who are eligible for appointment to a position in the classified service. 
General employees promotional eligible list means a list of individuals in city service who are eligible for promotion to a position in the classified service, the list not being limited to individuals within a specific division or department. 
Part-time employee means an individual who is employed in a temporary position on an hourly basis, and who is routinely scheduled to work less than thirty-seven and one-half (37.5) hours per week. Part-time temporary employees shall not be considered to have seniority, shall receive no fringe benefits, and shall not share in equalization of overtime. 
Part-time seasonal employee means an individual who is routinely scheduled to work at least thirty-seven and one-half (37.5) hours per week, but for no more than one hundred twenty (120) calendar days at a time. 
Promotion means any change of job classification where the classification to which the employee is appointed and where the maximum pay rate authorized for the position in the city pay plan is greater than that authorized for the position vacated by the employee upon appointment to the new job classification. 
Qualification examination means an examination designed to determine whether or not a person possesses the minimum skill and knowledge which will enable him or her to perform the duties of a given position. 
Reemployment list means a list of individuals eligible for appointment to a position in the classified service by reason of the fact that they have been laid off. 
Residence means the place where a person has a true, fixed, permanent home, where he or she habitually sleeps, keeps his or her personal effects and has a regular place of lodging, and in which he or she is a legal voter. 
Special assignment means any appointment or employment of technical, expert or highly skilled nature to assist in or carry out a special work and which is not a regular part of the administration of the city affairs, whether or not such work shall be for a longer period than six (6) months or periodic in its nature. Special assignments shall be deemed to include audits of the city records by auditors outside the regular city employ, the employment of special counsel or special engineering services, employment of a zoning expert, employment of a person skilled in personnel problems to assist in the administration of this article or other services of similar nature to those mentioned. The specific mention of any special service shall not be deemed to exclude others that may properly come within the terms. 
Temporary appointment means any interim appointment or employment required because of an emergency or temporary vacancy caused by sick leave or other leave of absence, or pending regular appointment of eligible persons certified by the civil service board. 
Transfer means any change of job classification where the classification to which the employee is appointed involves the same degree of responsibility, authority or technical ability and where the maximum pay rate authorized for the position in the city pay plan is the same as that authorized for the position vacated by the employee upon appointment to the new job classification. 
Veteran means any person who is credited by the federal government of the United States, or any of its branches, with having wartime service between the dates specified by the federal government for the federal civil service preference in any uniformed rank of the air force, army, navy, or the marine corps of the United States, or any person in the above mentioned forces who has been issued a campaign badge for expeditionary service as specified in the federal civil service code; provided, however, in all cases the person shall have received an honorable discharge from the service in order to be entitled to the benefits of this article. 
(Code 1967, § 2-115; Ord. No. 80-343, § 1, 8-25-87) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 25-22. - Employees subject to article. 
All positions in the city's service shall be subject to the provisions of this article, except as hereinafter specifically qualified and exempted; except, however, that the city council and the mayor shall determine the status of all department heads and special personnel to be created and employed in the future. 
(Code 1967, § 2-113)  
Sec. 25-23. - Positions exempt from article. 
(a)  The following positions shall be exempt from the operation of this article, so far as appointments to, promotion in and dismissal from the service are concerned and shall serve at the will of the appointing authority: 
Members of all boards and commissions 
Deputy city clerk 
Deputy city treasurer 
Deputy council secretary 
Executive administrator to the mayor 
Private secretary—Mayor 
Stenographer-secretary, mayor's office 
Community relations coordinator, mayor's office 
Industrial commercial coordinator, mayor's office 
Sanitary engineer, waste water treatment plant 
City engineer 
Public works superintendent 
Sanitation superintendent 
Water superintendent 
Manager, insurance and safety division 
Personnel assistant 
Director of operations, housing commission 
Assistant director of operations, housing commission 
Maintenance assistant, housing commission 
Helicopter mechanic 
Crime M.I.S. specialist 
Computer programmer I 
Building and grounds superintendent 
Beautification coordinator 
Assistant controller 
Associate manager of public works 
Waste water specialist 
Administrative supervisor, public service division 
Building and safety engineering director 
Assistant library director 
Communications director 
All department heads as follows: 
City attorney 
Controller 
Director of public service 
Planning director 
Police commissioner and fire commissioner 
City assessor 
Parks and recreation director 
Library director 
Personnel director 
Labor relations director 
All part-time employees, part-time seasonal employees, co-op student employees, temporary appointments and special assignments. 
All positions fully or partially funded by grants from the federal government and which are, by virtue of such funding, subject to federal statutes, rules or regulations regarding the qualifications for such positions, but only for so long as they are so funded and subject to such federal statutes, rules or regulations. 
(b)  Provided, however, that any person hereinabove exempted except elected officials, who shall have been, prior to the adoption of this article, employed by the City of Warren, the Charter Township of Warren or the Village of Warren, in any capacity affected by this article, shall, upon discontinuance of employment in such exempted position, be reinstated to the employment and duties classification held by such person at the time of acceptance of such exempted position; and provided, further, that in the event any city employee shall be appointed to any position exempted by this article, such employee shall, upon written application therefor, receive a leave of absence for the period of time that such employee shall serve in such exempted position and such city employees who have been appointed shall, upon discontinuance of employment in such exempted position, be reinstated to the employment and duties classification held by such person at the time of acceptance of such exempted position. The titles listed above are not necessarily civil service titles but may represent working titles. 
(c)  Any person who appoints any person to a position not qualified or exempted under this article is guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1967, § 2-114; Ord. No. 80-333, § 1, 2-24-87; Ord. No. 80-340, § 16, 6-9-87; Ord. No. 80-343, § 2, 8-25-87; Ord. No. 80-352, § 1, 5-10-88; Ord. No. 80-486, § 1, 9-26-95; Ord. No. 80-539, § 1, 12-8-98; Ord. No. 80-551, § 1, 1-25-00; Ord. No. 80-723, § 1, 8-19-14)  
Sec. 25-24. - Merit system established. 
There is hereby established a merit system for all positions in the civil service of the city, except as hereinafter qualified or exempted. All municipal personnel problems shall be approached so far as possible in a professional and impartial manner. Appointment to the city's service and promotions and transfers therein shall be based solely upon the fitness, training, seniority and experience of the individual, with no discrimination on account of race, color, religion, sex, age, national origin, height, weight, marital status, handicap, disabled veteran status or Vietnam veteran status. 
(Code 1967, § 2-101)  
Secs. 25-25—25-35. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - CIVIL SERVICE BOARD[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Charter reference— Quorum of boards, § 2.4; mayor member of certain boards, § 7.7. 
Cross reference— Boards and commissions generally, § 2-91 et seq. 
 
Sec. 25-36. - Created; purpose. 
There is hereby created a civil service board which shall administer the merit system for all positions in the city's service except as qualified or exempted in this article. 
(Code 1967, § 2-102)  
Sec. 25-37. - Appointment, term. 
The civil service board shall consist of five (5) electors of the city, to be appointed by the mayor and to serve, after their initial appointment, for respective terms of three (3) years. 
(Code 1967, § 2-102)  
Sec. 25-38. - Holding public city office or participating in politics prohibited. 
No member of the civil service board shall hold any other public city office or serve on any city political committee or take active part in the management of any city political campaign. 
(Code 1967, § 2-102)  
Sec. 25-39. - Oath required. 
(a)  Every member of the civil service board shall take and subscribe the oath of office prescribed by the constitution of this state before entering upon the discharge of the duties of office. 
(b)  The oath of office shall be certified by the officer administering it and filed with the city clerk. 
(Code 1967, § 2-103)  
Sec. 25-39.1. - Compensation. 
Members shall receive as compensation twenty-five dollars ($25.00) per month, excepting, however, that the member selected as chairperson as provided in section 25-43 shall receive thirty dollars ($30.00) per month. 
(Code 1967, § 2-102; Ord. No. 80-340, § 17, 6-9-87)  
Sec. 25-40. - Filling vacancies. 
If a vacancy occurs on the civil service board, the mayor shall appoint a member, as set forth in section 25-37, for the unexpired term of office. 
(Code 1967, § 2-102)  
Sec. 25-41. - Removal. 
Any member of the civil service board may be removed from office by his or her appointing authority upon notice in writing. 
(Code 1967, § 2-102)  
Sec. 25-42. - Meetings. 
The civil service board shall meet at least once during each month. 
(Code 1967, § 2-102)  
Sec. 25-43. - Officers. 
The civil service board shall elect one (1) of its members to serve as chairperson, and one (1) member to serve as secretary, each to serve for one (1) year. Thereafter these officers shall be elected annually. The secretary shall perform all secretarial and record-keeping functions of the board. 
(Code 1967, § 2-104)  
Sec. 25-44. - Facilities and supplies. 
The department of personnel management shall provide the civil service board with suitable and convenient quarters for carrying on its work and for conducting whatever examinations and tests are necessary and proper for the carrying out of the provisions of this article. The division of purchasing shall, upon proper requisition, supply the board with the necessary stationery, postage, stamps, and other supplies. The city council shall provide such secretarial and clerical help as may be determined by the board to be necessary. 
(Code 1967, § 2-105)  
Sec. 25-45. - Annual appropriation required. 
The city council shall annually make such appropriation as shall be necessary for meeting the expenses of effectually administering the merit system. All expenses incurred by the civil service board shall be paid out of the appropriation in the same manner and under the same conditions as near as may be as expenses for other departments are paid. 
(Code 1967, § 2-106)  
Sec. 25-46. - Powers and duties. 
The civil service board shall have the power to prescribe and enforce such rules and regulations as are necessary to carry into effect the provisions of this article and may from time to time add to, amend or rescind any such rules. Any such amendments or changes in the rules shall be posted in conspicuous places in the respective departments of the city at least ten (10) days before their effective date. The board shall have the power to conduct and supervise qualifications of applicants for the city's service. It shall keep minutes of its own proceedings and records of its official actions. Copies of all proceedings of the board shall be furnished by the secretary to the mayor and the city council upon request. 
(Code 1967, § 2-107)  
Sec. 25-47. - Minutes, records, eligibility, tests and applications. 
The minutes of the official proceedings of the civil service board, a roster of all officers and employees in the city's service and all eligibility lists for appointment to city service shall be public records open to public inspection, subject to reasonable regulation. Applications, examination papers, tests or results, recommendations from former employers, reports of department heads concerning employees and other such memoranda as in the operation of the board are confidential, shall be kept on file for the use of the board, but shall not be open for public inspection. Such records may be made available to the employee concerned or the employee's duly authorized agent. 
(Code 1967, § 2-108)  
Sec. 25-48. - Investigations. 
The civil service board, or any member thereof authorized by the board, may make investigations of all matters pertaining to the enforcement of this article and the rules and regulations prescribed thereunder, concerning the action of any examiner or other subordinate of the board, or any person in the city service, in respect to the administration of this article. 
(Code 1967, § 2-109)  
Sec. 25-49. - Examiner. 
The civil service board may, subject to the approval of the mayor, appoint an examiner to conduct specific examinations and other tests held for testing the ability of applicants for the city's service. The city may, upon approval of the mayor and council, enter into a contract for the services of a person or organization skilled in public personnel administration work, to prepare and conduct such examinations and tests and otherwise assist the board in carrying out the merit system. 
(Code 1967, § 2-110)  
Sec. 25-50. - Classification system. 
The civil service board shall make or cause to be made a study of the duties and responsibilities of all positions in the city's service, to the end that a proper duties classification system and plan of compensation may be in effect at all times. 
(Code 1967, § 2-111)  
Sec. 25-51. - Schedule of compensation. 
The civil service board shall be furnished whenever requested by the board, a schedule showing the compensation for each position in the city's service. The board shall make a study of the compensation for each position in relation to the duties performed and shall from time to time make such recommendations as it deems advisable to the mayor, in order that proper pay differentials may be established between positions that differ materially in duties performed and responsibilities exercised. 
(Code 1967, § 2-112)  
Secs. 25-52—25-70. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - NEW APPOINTMENTS 
 
Sec. 25-71. - Priorities. 
All new appointments to the civil service of the city except as hereinbefore exempted or qualified shall be made by the appointing authorities designated in the Charter and ordinances, and in accordance with the provisions of this article. All such appointments shall be based solely upon merit and the good of the service. All appointments shall be made from persons named on eligible lists furnished by the civil service board in the following order and priority: 
(1)  The name of the highest person on the reemployment list; if the list is exhausted, then will be furnished 
(2)  The name of the highest person on the general employees promotional eligible list; if the list is exhausted, then will be furnished 
(3)  The name of the highest qualified person on the police and fire civil service reemployment list. "Qualified" shall mean the person meets all the preliminary requirements of education and experience for the position; if the list is exhausted, then 
(4)  The appointing authority shall interview all individuals on the new hire eligible list who received the highest test score and appoint the person who, in the opinion of the appointing authority, is most qualified. If less than three (3) individuals received the highest score, then the appointing authority shall also interview all individuals who received the next highest score and appoint the most qualified, in his or her opinion. 
(Code 1967, § 2-118; Ord. No. 80-355, § 1, 6-14-88)  
Sec. 25-72. - Application; qualifications. 
All persons desiring employment in the city service, except to positions exempted under the provisions of this article, shall file applications with the civil service board. Any person eighteen (18) years of age or older and otherwise qualified shall be eligible for the examinations and tests hereinafter provided and consequent appointment to the city's service. 
(Code 1967, § 2-119; Ord. No. 80-319, § 1, 5-13-86)  
Sec. 25-73. - Contents of applications. 
(a)  The civil service board shall require persons applying for positions in the city service to file in its office an application prior to any examination or test is given. The applicant shall state in the application, under oath or affirmation: 
(1)  His or her name, residence and post office address; 
(2)  Condition of health and physical fitness for service in the position for which the application is filed; 
(3)  Occupation and previous employment for the five (5) years immediately prior to the application; 
(4)  Such other information as may be reasonably required, touching the applicant's qualifications and fitness for public service, or otherwise as required by law, and the rules and regulations of the board. 
(b)  Blank forms for application shall be furnished by the civil service board without charge to all persons requesting same at a time and place designated by the board. 
(c)  All applications accepted in order to compile an eligible list shall be kept on file for one (1) year, except all applications received from applicants whose name was included on an eligible list shall be kept for the term of the eligible list. 
(Code 1967, §§ 2-120, 2-121; Ord. No. 80-340, § 18, 6-9-87)  
Sec. 25-74. - Rejection; causes enumerated. 
The civil service board shall receive applications from any person desiring employment in the city service, but may reject the application of any person who is found to lack the established preliminary requirements or who is physically unfit for service in the position to which he or she seeks employment, or who is addicted to habitual use of alcoholic liquors or controlled substances, or who may have been guilty of any felony or disgraceful conduct, or who has been dismissed from the public service for cause, or who has made a false statement of any material fact or practiced or attempted to practice any deception or fraud in his or her application. The action of the board in rejecting an application shall be final, but the board may, prior to such final decision, in its discretion, hold a hearing and permit the applicant to appear and produce testimony in his or her behalf touching the matters concerning which his or her application is refused. 
(Code 1967, § 2-121)  
Sec. 25-75. - Physical fitness. 
All applicants for any regular position in the city service shall be required to furnish a statement relative to the applicant's physical fitness before assuming his or her duties. The director of personnel management shall determine the examining physicians to be used for this purpose. 
(Code 1967, § 2-122)  
Sec. 25-76. - Examinations—Rules and regulations. 
(a)  The civil service board shall prescribe such examinations or other tests to measure the applicant's qualifications as it shall deem reasonable and practicable for each class or kind of position in the city's service. Where practicable, such examinations or tests shall be competitive in nature. Such tests and examinations shall be held from time to time at the discretion of the civil service board to meet the prospective needs of the service. The civil service board shall adopt rules and regulations governing the giving of such tests and examinations, which rules and regulations shall give every applicant an equal opportunity for consideration and shall be open to the public. 
(b)  All examinations or tests for positions in the public service shall be practical in their character and shall relate to such matters and include such inquiries as will fairly and fully test the comparative merit and fitness of the person examined to discharge the duties of the employment sought by him or her. 
(Code 1967, § 2-123)  
Sec. 25-77. - Same—Time, place; notice. 
All examinations and tests under section 25-76 shall be open to all applicants who have fulfilled the preliminary requirements. Individuals deemed qualified by the Civil Service Board shall receive a letter through the United States Postal Service stating date, time and place upon which such examination will be held. 
(Code 1967, § 2-124; Ord. No. 80-340, § 19, 6-9-87)  
Sec. 25-78. - Same—Ratings. 
Each person taking any test or examination under the merit system shall be rated according to his or her attainments. The civil service board shall determine the method of making such ratings and prescribe a passing mark. The method of rating and passing mark shall be determined in advance of any examination or test. 
(Code 1967, § 2-126)  
Sec. 25-79. - Reserved.  
Sec. 25-80. - Employment lists enumerated. 
(a)  A reemployment list shall also be kept of all persons removed from the city service because of the abolishment of his or her position or for reasons of economy, or for any reason other than dismissal for cause or voluntary resignation. 
(b)  Persons already in the service who are applicants for a specific vacancy in some other position and are eligible for appointment thereto shall also be listed on a divisional promotional eligible list or general employees promotional eligible list, as the case may be. 
(c)  A reemployment list shall be kept of all persons removed from the police and fire civil service because of the abolishment of his or her position or for reasons of economy, or for any reason other than dismissal for cause or voluntary resignation. 
(d)  The names of all applicants for a position who have attained the required rating or better on the examination and who are otherwise eligible, shall be placed in the order to their relative attainment on the list of applicants eligible to appointment to the class of positions for which the examination was held. 
(e)  All eligible lists including promotional lists shall expire in two (2) years from date of certification. No eligible or promotional list shall be recertified once it has expired. This section shall not be construed to affect any reemployment list. 
(Code 1967, § 2-127; Ord. No. 80-355, § 2, 6-14-88)  
Sec. 25-81. - Filling vacancies; promotions; appointments, temporary appointments. 
(a)  An appointing officer shall immediately upon becoming aware that any position covered by civil service in his or her department is vacant or is to become vacant, give to the civil service board once it has been approved by the mayor, a written notice thereof and state whether or not he or she intends to fill the position. If the position is to be filled, the appointing officer shall specify the class, grade and title of the position, the salary, the duties thereof, and any other information regarding the same which the board may request. 
(b)  The rules provided for in this article shall provide, among other things, for the promotion in offices or positions on the basis of ascertained merit and seniority in service, or examination or test for the purpose of providing a list of eligible persons for certification and notify the appointing officer of the data and time for such examination or test. In the interval, the appointing officer may, if the needs of the service require, and with the consent of the board, make a temporary appointment for the period until a regular appointment can be made from the eligible persons certified by the civil service board. Successive temporary appointments shall not be made to the same positions; provided, however, when the number of persons on the eligible list shall be insufficient, or decline appointment, and it is impracticable to obtain a suitable eligible list due to an emergency or to special conditions over which the city has no control, the appointing authority may make successive temporary appointments, but only with the written consent of the civil service board. The term of such appointment or successive temporary appointments shall, unless otherwise stated by the board, terminate two (2) weeks following certification of an eligible list to the appointing officer. With the sole exception of temporary appointment as provided in this section and in section 25-82, all appointments to the service shall be permanent appointments, regardless of the duration of the appointment. 
(Code 1967, § 2-128; Ord. No. 80-340, § 20, 6-9-87)  
Sec. 25-82. - Temporary vacancies. 
In cases of emergency or to fill a temporary vacancy caused by sick leave or other leave of absence, an appointing officer may make a temporary appointment during the period of such temporary vacancy by filling the vacancy with the senior eligible employee in his or her department. 
(Code 1967, § 2-129)  
Sec. 25-83. - Positions requiring technical qualifications. 
In permanent and continuing positions employing only persons having professional or technical qualifications where there are likely to be few satisfactory applicants, and the persons qualified to serve are relatively few in number, then the civil service board may dispense with the requirements for formal tests and examinations and may prescribe other methods of determining the qualifications of the applicants; may dispense with its customary rules and regulations and proceed in an informal manner to assist the appointing authority in choosing a person qualified to fill any vacancy that may occur in such position. The board may in its discretion authorize either temporary or probationary status for such appointees; provided, however, that in case of permanent employment such employees shall become residents of the city within one (1) year from the date of such permanent employment. 
(Code 1967, § 2-130)  
Sec. 25-84. - Probationary period—Required; exceptions. 
All new appointments in the city service shall be for a probationary period of ninety (90) days. If at any time during the probationary period the appointing officer shall find the appointee unsatisfactory, he or she may dismiss such probationer and ask for the certification of new applicants. In case of such dismissal, the probationer, if he or she had civil service status in another position prior to his or her appointment to the position from which he or she is dismissed, shall automatically be restored to his or her former position; in other cases he or she may, in the discretion of the civil service board, be reinstated on the eligible list, if, after due inquiry, the board deems him or her worthy of such reinstatement. If, at the end of the probationary period, the appointing authority has found the services of the appointee satisfactory, he or she shall so notify the board and the probationer shall thereupon forthwith come under the merit system. 
(Code 1967, § 2-131)  
Sec. 25-85. - Reserved.  
Sec. 25-86. - Examinations, tests; record, inspection. 
A record shall be kept of all examinations and other tests and shall be kept on file for the private use of the members of the civil service board for no longer than one (1) year. Such records shall not be open to inspection by the general public without the consent of the civil service board except by order of a court of competent jurisdiction. Any applicant for a position or his or her duly authorized representative, however, shall at any time within sixty (60) days after taking the prescribed examination or test, be entitled to inspect any examination paper or other written test submitted by him or her and be fully informed as to his or her rating on the same. 
(Code 1967, § 2-133)  
Secs. 25-87—25-95. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - CITY RESIDENCE 
 
Sec. 25-96. - Residence during employment required. 
All employees within one (1) year of appointment to a civil service position shall be required to maintain a bona fide residence within the corporate limits of the city during the period of their employment. 
(Code 1967, § 2-135)  
Sec. 25-97. - Failure to comply; separation authorized. 
Any employee who now or in the future fails to maintain a bona fide residence within the corporate limits of the city within one (1) year of appointment shall be separated from city service immediately or as soon thereafter as a qualified person can be appointed to the position held by the nonresident employee. 
(Code 1967, § 2-136)  
Sec. 25-98. - Establishment of residence. 
All individuals appointed to city service shall be required to establish a bona fide residence within one (1) year from the date of his or her appointment to the position. 
(Code 1967, § 2-137; Ord. No. 80-340, § 21, 6-9-87)  
Sec. 25-99. - Separation from service deemed resignation. 
All employees who are separated from city service under the provisions of this division shall be deemed to have resigned and such an entry shall be made upon their personnel records. 
(Code 1967, § 2-138)  
Secs. 25-100—25-110. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 5. - PROMOTIONS AND TRANSFERS 
 
Sec. 25-111. - Vacancies filled by promotion; procedure. 
Vacancies in higher positions in the classified service shall be filled insofar as practicable by promoting persons holding positions in the next lower grades in the service. Such promotions shall be based upon merit as ascertained where practicable by test, and as shown by the previous service and experience of the person promoted. When a vacancy occurs the civil service board shall determine, following consultation with the appointing authority, whether promotion is possible and practicable, and if so, what classes of employees are eligible for such promotions and whether an examination or test shall be held to determine the relative fitness of eligible employees, or whether such relative fitness shall be determined by their seniority and efficiency records or by both such examination and records. Upon the recommendation of the appointing authority, and with the approval of the civil service board, an employee may be promoted solely on the basis of a passing grade obtained on a qualification examination. 
(Code 1967, § 2-139)  
Sec. 25-112. - Promotions with classifications; related classifications. 
Promotion shall not necessarily be confined to positions within a department, but may be within a specific classification or closely related classifications of service or positions in different departments. Position vacancies shall be filled, wherever possible, in the following order: qualified personnel within the same division; qualified personnel within the same department; qualified personnel city wide. 
(Code 1967, § 2-140)  
Sec. 25-113. - Length of service required for promotion. 
No employee is eligible for promotion while serving in a probationary status. 
(Code 1967, § 2-141; Ord. No. 80-340, § 22, 6-9-87)  
Sec. 25-114. - Certification for promotion. 
Certification to appointing officers of the names of persons eligible for promotion shall be made in the same manner as certification of persons eligible to original appointment. A person failing to qualify for promotion shall retain his or her position and eligibility for future promotion. 
(Code 1967, § 2-142)  
Sec. 25-115. - Transfer of employees. 
An employee who desires a transfer within his or her classification to another division or department shall submit the request for a transfer in writing to the personnel director. When a vacancy occurs within the requested division or department, the employee with the greatest seniority who requested a transfer writing shall be given the opportunity to transfer, provided that promotional lists take precedence over transfer requests. 
(Code 1967, § 2-143)  
Secs. 25-116—25-125. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 6. - REMOVAL 
 
Sec. 25-126. - Employees' status after abolishment of departments and positions. 
In the case of such abolishment of any position, office or employment, the person holding such position, office or employment shall be thereby transferred to an equal job, demoted or laid off; provided, however, such person shall continue eligible for any other position in the civil service for which he or she may be qualified and shall be retained on the reemployment list by the civil service board. 
(Code 1967, § 2-144)  
Sec. 25-127. - Lay-offs—Causes enumerated. 
The department head may, for reasons of economy or for more efficient administration, or when rendered necessary by lack of sufficient appropriation, lay off any employee in his or her department. Such persons shall continue eligible for reappointment to any position or vacancy in the city's service, and the civil service board shall retain the names of any such persons on its eligible list for appointment to any position which such person is qualified to fill. 
(Code 1967, § 2-145)  
Sec. 25-128. - Same—Procedure; employees' status. 
When lay-off is necessary in a given classification, the employee with the least seniority shall be laid off and his or her name placed on the reemployment list for that classification, ranked in the inverse order of lay-off. If the employee had civil service status in another classification, he or she may request to be reemployed in that classification or may request demotion to the next lower grade in the service. Final disposition of such requests shall be made by the civil service board. When a vacancy exists in a given classification and a reemployment list exists for the classification, the person highest on the list will be notified of his or her appointment to fill the vacancy. If that person declines the appointment, such person shall be deemed to have resigned and his or her name removed from the reemployment list and the next highest person notified. A person on a reemployment list who declines appointment or who fails to respond within ten (10) days of notification, shall not be employed in that classification unless he or she completes another examination, is subsequently appointed pursuant to certification by the civil service board of an eligible list, and serves a new, full probationary period. A person's name may be removed from a reemployment list for other reasons satisfactory to the board, such as failure to maintain residency, failure of postal authorities to locate the person, and the like. 
(Code 1967, § 2-146)  
Sec. 25-129. - Demotions, suspensions, dismissals. 
Demotions, suspensions or discharges shall be made only for inefficiency, incompetency, physical or mental incapacity, insubordination, neglect of duty, misfeasance or malfeasance in office. In all cases of reduction, demotion, lay-off, suspension or dismissal of any employee or subordinate, the appointing authority shall, within five (5) working days of the effective date thereof, furnish such employee and the civil service board with written notice of the reason or reasons for such reduction, lay-off, suspension or dismissal. Such notice may be delivered to such employee by certified U.S. mail, return receipt requested, or in the alternative, may be delivered personally by such appointing authority to such employee. In the latter case, such appointing authority shall make and deliver to the secretary of the civil service board a verified affidavit of such personal delivery. The employee or subordinate shall have the right to make and file a written answer to the charges placed against him or her, and to file same with the civil service board within ten (10) working days from and after receipt of the notice. Nothing herein contained shall limit the power of an appointing officer or department head to suspend without pay for purposes of discipline any person under his or her supervision for a reasonable period not to exceed five (5) days; provided, however, that the civil service board shall have jurisdiction to review such suspension and to make a final determination regarding same. 
(Code 1967, § 2-147)  
Sec. 25-130. - Tenure in office, requisites; dismissal, review. 
The tenure of a position in the city's service shall be only during good behavior and efficient service. The civil service board shall have the power to review all dismissals and all suspensions imposed for more than five (5) days. 
(Code 1967, § 2-148)  
Sec. 25-131. - Filing of charges against employees, filing. 
Any charge preferred by a citizen against any person under the merit system employed by the city during his or her working hours shall be made in writing and under oath and filed with the civil service secretary. All communications to the civil service board or any member thereof touching their duties as such shall be made in writing and filed with the civil service secretary. 
(Code 1967, § 2-149)  
Sec. 25-132. - Hearing for discharge, removal, suspension—Hearing. 
In case of discharge or removal or suspension for more than five (5) days, any officer or employee feeling himself or herself aggrieved thereby shall have a right to file a petition with the civil service board within ten (10) working days from the effective date of such removal or suspension asking for reinstatement in the service or other relief and giving reasons therefor. The civil service board shall grant the petitioner a hearing, which shall be either private or public at the option of the petitioner, provided that the petitioner may be represented by a representative of his or her own choice. 
(Code 1967, § 2-150)  
Sec. 25-133. - Same—Evidence, counsel. 
The civil service board shall grant such hearing within ten (10) working days after the petition is filed. The hearing shall be deemed an investigation and not a trial, and the board shall not be bound by technical rules of evidence and procedure. It shall, however, conduct the hearing in an orderly manner, confine the scope thereof to matters set forth in the reasons for dismissal, and secure both to the petitioner and the dismissing officer a full and impartial hearing in regard thereto. Both parties shall be permitted to be represented by counsel and to produce witnesses or any other testimony they may have pertinent to the matter. The petitioner shall be entitled to first hear the testimony against him or her and to face his or her accuser. The petitioner and his or her witnesses shall then be permitted to be heard in his or her own defense. Hearsay evidence, as the term is commonly understood, excepting declarations against interest, shall not be deemed sufficient proof to warrant removal, demotion or suspension. 
(Code 1967, § 2-151; Ord. No. 80-340, § 23, 6-9-87)  
Sec. 25-134. - Same—Determination; appeal to court. 
The civil service board shall make its decision on any appeal within ten (10) working days after the hearing. It shall have the power to pass upon the discharge or removal, suspension for more than five (5) working days, or other action from which the appeal has been taken, and may confirm, modify or reverse such action. The action of the civil service board on all such matters shall be final, except, however, that if such action results in removal or dismissal from employment, then such employee shall have rights of appeal to the circuit court of the county. If reinstated without discipline in the position from which he or she was removed, the employee shall be entitled to compensation from the time of his or her demotion or discharge until the time of his or her reinstatement. The dismissing authority and the petitioner shall be entitled to a copy of the findings of the civil service board upon request. 
(Code 1967, § 2-152)  
Sec. 25-135. - Determination of strike activity. 
If an employee of the city, who is disciplined for activity deemed to be a strike under the provisions of Section 6 of Act 379, Public Acts of 1965 (MCL 423.206), requests a determination as to whether he or she did violate the provisions of that act, such determination may be undertaken by the civil service board if the disciplined employee so requests in writing. In such event, the determination shall be made by a hearing conducted by the civil service board. 
(Code 1967, § 2-153)  
Secs. 25-136—25-145. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 7. - VETERANS' PREFERENCE 
 
Sec. 25-146. - Veteran defined. 
The term "veteran" as used in this article shall mean an honorably discharged veteran, as defined by Act No. 190 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1965 (MCL 35.61 et seq.), as amended. 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 25-147. - Evidence of status of veterans. 
In all instances the records of the duly constituted federal bureau covering the respective veteran's service and status shall be accepted as final evidence of his or her service and physical status in determining whether he or she is entitled to the benefits under this division. 
(Code 1967, § 2-155)  
Sec. 25-148. - Passing grade required. 
All veterans in order to be eligible for the preference granted under this division must attain a minimum passing mark of seventy (70) percent or more. 
(Code 1967, § 2-156)  
Sec. 25-149. - Additional points granted. 
All veterans who have a service-connected disability record with the veteran's bureau of administration or the federal bureau of pensions, may, upon obtaining the required minimum grade for original employment with the city, in the discretion of the civil service board, be granted an additional ten (10) points, which shall be added to their respective passing marks as attained in their examination. 
(Code 1967, § 2-157)  
Sec. 25-150. - Additional points for no service disability. 
All veterans not having a service-connected disability as described in section 25-149, may, on obtaining the required passing mark for initial employment in the city's service, in the discretion of the civil service board, have an additional five (5) points added to their respective passing marks obtained in their examinations, but shall not be entitled to such additional five (5) points in any promotional examination for promotion to a higher position in the service after they have already been in the city's employment. 
(Code 1967, § 2-158)  
Sec. 25-151. - Waiver of age limit, physical disability. 
Age limits and physical disability shall be waived for all veterans, provided they present to the civil service board a certificate of physical fitness. Such certificates shall state that the applicant veteran is in proper physical condition to fill the position for which he or she applies. The director of personnel management shall determine the examining physicians to be used for this purpose. 
(Code 1967, § 2-159)  
Sec. 25-152. - Benefits of state, federal legislation. 
No provision in this division shall deprive any veteran of benefits granted by legislation which may later be passed by the national government of the United States or the state government. 
(Code 1967, § 2-160)  
Secs. 25-153—25-165. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 8. - DEPARTMENT OF PERSONNEL MANAGEMENT[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference— Departments generally, § 2-76 et seq. 
 
Sec. 25-166. - Created. 
There is hereby created a department of personnel management. 
(Code 1967, § 2-161)  
Sec. 25-167. - Director. 
The director of the department of personnel management shall be appointed by and serve at the pleasure of the mayor. The department of personnel management shall be under the direct supervision and control of the director of personnel management. The director of personnel management shall have the following duties and responsibilities: 
(1)  Advise the mayor, city council and the civil service commission on matters pertaining to the enforcement of this article and policy including but not specifically limited to personnel administration, development of personnel rules, job classification plans and pay plans; 
(2)  Make recommendations relative to proposed revisions of the city job classifications plan to the mayor and the civil service board; 
(3)  Keep personnel records of all civil service employees, past and present; 
(4)  Provide applications and other necessary forms in order to carry out the civil service plan; 
(5)  Investigate employee applications; 
(6)  Prepare and monitor qualification examinations or hire the service of an organization skilled in such tasks; 
(7)  Prepare increment compensation plans for all civil service employees; 
(8)  Recommend to the civil service board the rules and regulations covering hiring, promotions, transfers, demotions and layoff procedures; 
(9)  Establish and maintain a centralized benefits section to serve all employees in regard to their benefits, which shall include but not be specifically limited to the following: 
a.  Sickness and accident insurance; 
b.  Hospitalization insurance; 
c.  Life insurance; 
d.  Workers' compensation insurance; 
e.  Seniority list; 
f.  Unemployment insurance; 
g.  Leaves of absence; 
h.  Dental program and insurance benefits. 
(10)  Establish training programs and safety programs for city employees or future city employees; 
(11)  Assist the director of labor relations in union contract negotiations by providing data as related to personnel practices; 
(12)  Process grievances for employees who elect to take such grievances to the civil service board and recommend to the civil service board solutions for such grievances; 
(13)  Prepare agenda for the meetings of the civil service board and make recommendations as needed; 
(14)  Participate in exchange of information with other communities, counties and state and national organizations relative to the city's position of personnel management. 
(Code 1967, §§ 2-161, 2-162; Ord. No. 80-340, § 24, 6-9-87)  
Sec. 25-168. - Job classification plan. 
The director of personnel management shall make an analysis of the duties and responsibilities of all positions in the classification service and shall recommend to the civil service board a job classification plan and revise as required. The job classification plan will consist of various jobs descriptions. 
(Code 1967, § 2-163)  
Sec. 25-169. - Rules and regulations. 
The civil service board shall establish rules and regulations to carry out the provisions of this article. Copies of such rules and regulations shall be filed with the city clerk which shall be made available to city employees upon request. 
(Code 1967, § 2-164)  
Secs. 25-170—25-180. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 9. - DEPARTMENT OF LABOR RELATIONS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference— Departments generally, 2-76 et seq. 
 
Sec. 25-181. - Created. 
There is hereby created a department of labor relations.  
Sec. 25-182. - Director. 
The director of labor relations shall be appointed by and shall serve at the pleasure of the mayor. The director of labor relations shall: 
(1)  Advise the mayor and the city council on matters of labor relations with respect to any and all labor unions formed or to be formed by the city employees; 
(2)  Investigate and make recommendations to the mayor and the city council relative to city employee union problems; 
(3)  Act as agent for the city in matters of negotiation, collective bargaining, agreements with the city employees; 
(4)  Negotiate union grievances and advise various departments in resolving union grievances and assist the processing of union grievances and recommend suitable solutions for the grievances; 
(5)  Represent the city's interest at hearings before the state or federal employment relations commissions; 
(6)  Advise management personnel regarding the interpretation of city collective bargaining agreements with the city's employees unions; 
(7)  Handle any and all matters in which unions are involved. 
(Code 1967, § 2-165)  
Sec. 25-183. - Rules and regulations. 
The director of labor relations shall, in consultation with the mayor, draft such rules as may be necessary to carry out the provisions of this article. Amendments to the rules shall be made in accordance with the above procedure. (Code 1967, § 2-167)  
Sec. 25-184. - Relationships with other city departments. 
(a)  The director of labor relations shall have information made available by all city departments when such information is needed in the proper function of the department of labor relations. 
(b)  The director of labor relations shall keep all city departments informed of matters which affect their operations. 
(c)  The city attorney or his or her designated assistant, the city controller of his or her designated assistant, and the director of personnel management or his or her designated assistant shall serve as an advisory committee to the director of labor relations. 
(Code 1967, § 2-168)  
Secs. 25-185—25-205. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - GENERAL EMPLOYEES RETIREMENT SYSTEM[6] 
Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Charter reference— Municipal pension plans, Ch. 16; mandate for pension plan for the general employees, § 16.3. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 25-206. - Establishment; election; officers and employees. 
(a)  Establishment. In accordance with section 16.3 of the City Charter, there is hereby established a general employees retirement system for the benefit of eligible employees and officers of the City of Warren. The general employees retirement system shall consist of a defined benefit plan and a defined contribution plan. Each plan shall be administered by a board of trustees as provided in this article. 
(b)  Member election. Before December 31, 1999, existing members of the defined benefit plan had an opportunity to elect to forfeit membership in the defined benefit plan, irrevocably waiving all benefits thereunder and electing participation in the defined contribution plan. Thereafter, said members shall receive all retirement benefits as provided by the applicable collective bargaining agreement pursuant to the defined contribution plan. 
(c)  Closed membership in the defined benefit plan. Membership in the general employees defined benefit plan was closed on the following dates for each applicable collective bargaining unit: 
UAW Local 412 Unit 59 November 10, 1998. 
UAW Local 412 Unit 35 April 13, 1999. 
AFSCME Local 1250 November 23, 1999. 
AFSCME Local 1917 January 11, 2000. 
(1)  Members qualifying for retirement benefits from the defined benefit plan, who did not elect to forfeit membership, shall remain members in the defined benefit plan and shall receive their retirement benefits from the defined benefit plan. Members who leave the service of the city, for whatever reason, shall be considered to have a break in service and the applicable provisions of section 25-218 or 25-219 shall control for all credited service provided prior to the break in service. If that person returns to city service in a position eligible for retirement benefits, for all service provided after the break in service, the officer or employee shall receive retirement benefits provided by the applicable collective bargaining agreement as a participant in the defined contribution plan. 
(2)  Officers and employees who elected to irrevocably forfeit membership in the defined benefit plan and participate in the defined contribution plan shall receive their retirement benefits provided by the applicable collective bargaining agreement as a participant in the defined contribution plan. 
(3)  Officers and employees eligible for retirement benefits who join the service of the city after membership in the defined benefit plan closed, shall receive their retirement benefits provided by the applicable collective bargaining agreement as participants in the defined contribution plan. 
(4)  City officers elected to office prior to the date membership in the defined benefit plan closed who leave the office elected to, for whatever reason, shall be considered to have a break in service and the applicable provisions of section 25-218 or 25-219 shall control for all credited service provided prior to the break in service. If that person is elected to another city office, is appointed to a city office or is hired to serve the city in a position eligible for retirement benefits, for all service provided after the break in service, the officer or employee shall receive retirement benefits provided by the applicable collective bargaining agreement as a participant in the defined contribution plan.
