(Ord. No. 80-546, § 2, 8-24-99; Ord. No. 80-660, § 1, 10-9-07)  
Sec. 25-207. - Definitions. 
When used in this article, the following words and phrases shall be defined as follows: 
Accumulated contributions means the sum of all amounts deducted from the compensation of a member and credited to his or her individual account in the reserve for members' contributions, together with regular interest thereon as determined by the defined benefit board of trustees. 
Beneficiary means any person, except a retirant, who is in receipt of, or who is designated to receive, a pension or other benefit, payable by the retirement system. 
City means the City of Warren and shall include its predecessors, the Township of Warren, the Warren Charter Township, and the Village of Warren. 
Compensation means a member's salary or wages including deferred compensation paid by the city for personal services rendered by him or her to the city. In case a member's pay includes lodging or meals, or both, the city council shall fix the value of the lodging and meals. 
Credited service means the number of years, and fraction of a year, of service credited a member by the board to the extent provided in this article. 
Defined benefit plan means the retirement benefit plan set forth in division 2. 
Defined contribution plan means the retirement benefit plan set forth in division 3. 
Defined contributions shall include all contributions and income accumulated in the defined contribution account including contributions made by the participant, the employer and any amounts transferred into the defined contribution plan. 
Employee means the employees providing service to the City of Warren or the 37th District Court. 
Final average compensation shall mean the average of the two (2) highest years of annual compensation received by a member. Each year utilized in the computation shall begin and end with the same month. If a member has less than two (2) years of credited service, the member's final average compensation shall be the annual average compensation received by the member during the total years of service. 
Fiscal year means the calendar period between January first and December thirty-first. 
Independent contractor means a person who contracts for a fee to do specific work using his/her own methods without being subject to the control of the employer. An independent contractor is not an employee, is not a member of any collective bargaining unit of the city and is not entitled to receive any fringe benefits. 
Member means any person who is included in the membership of the defined benefit plan. 
Participant means a present or former employee or officer for whom contributions have been made under the defined contribution plan and who has not yet received all of the payments of benefits to which he/she is entitled under the defined contribution plan. 
Pension means a monthly amount payable by the defined benefit plan throughout the future life of a person, or for a temporary period, as provided in this article. 
Pension reserve means the present value of all future payments to be made on account of any pension. Such pension reserve shall be computed upon the basis of such mortality and other tables of experience, and regular interest, as the defined benefit board shall from time to time adopt. 
Regular interest means such rate or rates of interest per annum, compounded annually, as the board shall from time to time adopt. 
Retirant means any member who retires with a pension payable by the defined benefit plan, including disability retirement. 
Retirement means a member's withdrawal from city employment with a pension payable by the defined contribution plan. 
Service means personal services rendered to the city by an officer or employee of the city. 
Trust means the trust created under the governmental money purchase plan which consists of all the assets of the plan derived from employer and participant contributions under the plan, plus any income and gains thereon, less any losses, expenses and distributions to participants and beneficiaries. 
Vesting means the member or participant's non-forfeitable interest in the applicable defined benefit plan or defined contribution plan account. 
Workers' compensation period means the period a member, retirant or beneficiary is in receipt of workers' compensation on account of a disability or death arising out of and in the course of a member's city employment. If he or she is paid a single sum in lieu of future workers' compensation payments, his or her workers' compensation period shall be designated as the period he or she was in receipt of weekly workers' compensation plus the period arrived at by dividing the said single sum by his or her weekly workers' compensation award. 
(Ord. No. 80-546, § 2, 8-24-99) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 25-208. - Assignments prohibited; exceptions; eligible domestic relations order. 
(a)  The right of an individual to a pension, to the return of accumulated contributions, to the payment of accumulated participant contributions and earnings, to any optional benefit, to any other right accrued or accruing to any member, retirant, participant or beneficiary under the provisions of this article, and any moneys belonging to the defined benefit plan or the defined contribution plan, shall not be subject to execution, garnishment, attachment, the operation of bankruptcy or insolvency law, or any other process of law whatsoever, and shall be unassignable, except as is specifically provided in this article. The city shall have the right of setoff for any claim arising from embezzlement by or fraud of a member, retirant or beneficiary. 
(b)  If a member of the defined benefit plan is covered by a group insurance or prepayment plan participated in by the city, and should he or she be permitted to, and elect to, continue such coverage as a retirant, he or she may authorize the defined benefit board to have deducted from his or her pension the payments required of him or her to continue coverage under such group insurance or prepayment plan. 
(c)  The prohibition of subsection (a) of this section shall not apply to the creation, assignment, or recognition of a right to any benefit payable to a member or participant pursuant to an eligible domestic relations order (EDRO) when such order is determined by the applicable board of trustees to be in accordance with the Eligible Domestic Relations Order Act, MCL 38.1701, as amended. If the EDRO is determined to apply to a member in the defined benefit plan, the distribution to the "alternate payee" identified in the order shall not commence until the member retires from the service of the city or until death of the member while in city service. If the EDRO is determined to apply to a participant in the defined contribution plan and the EDRO requires payment before the participant would have otherwise been entitled to payment, the plan administrator is authorized to make the distribution to the "alternate payee" identified in the EDRO only effective the first day of the month following the month that the EDRO is determined to be an EDRO or the first day of the month following the month that a distribution is payable under the plan. 
(Ord. No. 80-546, § 2, 8-24-99)  
Sec. 25-209. - Medical insurance benefits. 
In the event a person who has retired or left the employ of the city who is receiving medical benefits under either the defined benefit plan or the defined contribution plan is re-employed by the city, the person shall not be eligible for duplicate benefits. 
(Ord. No. 80-546, § 2, 8-24-99)  
DIVISION 2. - THE DEFINED BENEFIT PLAN 
 
Sec. 25-210. - Membership. 
(a)  The membership of the defined benefit plan shall include officers and employees of the city, the judges, appointed personnel and employees of the 37th Judicial District Court, persons who have ceased to be an officer or employee of the city or 37th Judicial District Court and have satisfied the requirements of section 25-218 of this chapter, and retirants, except as provided in section (b). 
(b)  The membership of the defined benefit plan shall not include: 
(1)  Any person whose services are rendered to the city as an independent contractor; nor 
(2)  Any person, except an elected officer of the city, employed in a position that is part-time, part-time seasonal, co-op, temporary appointment or special assignment; nor 
(3)  Any person who has elected to participate in the defined contribution plan and forfeit membership in the defined benefit plan irrevocably waiving all benefits thereunder. 
(4)  Any officer or employee joining the service of the city on or after April 13, 1999 who is eligible for retirement benefits in the defined contribution plan, shall be excluded from the defined benefit plan, except any employee who is represented by a bargaining unit that has not agreed that its members can participate in the defined contribution plan, such employee shall become a member of the defined benefit plan. 
(5)  Any person who is covered under the City Policemen and Firemen Retirement System established under Act No. 345 of the Public Acts of 1937 (MCL 38.551 et seq.), as amended; nor 
(6)  Any police cadet enrolled in a police cadet training program as provided under Act No. 201 of Public Acts of 1970 (MCL 38.521); nor 
(7)  Any person who becomes re-employed by the city and is receiving a service pension from the defined benefit plan, or is a participant in the defined contribution plan. 
(c)  Should any doubt arise as to the membership status of any individual in the defined benefit plan, the defined benefit board shall decide the issue. 
(d)  Except as otherwise provided in this article, should any member leave the employ of the city without having eight (8) or more years of credited service, for any reason except retirement or death, he or she shall thereupon cease to be a member. 
(e)  The defined benefit board shall fix and determine, by appropriate rules and regulations consistent with the provisions of this article, the amount of service to be credited any member; provided that in no case shall less than ten (10) days of service rendered by him or her in any calendar month be credited as a month of service; nor shall less than ten (10) months of service rendered by him or her in any calendar year be credited as a year of service; nor shall more than one (1) year of a service be credited any member for all service rendered by him or her in any calendar year. 
(f)  The defined benefit board may require a prospective member and members to submit to a medical examination to be conducted in a manner as required by the board. 
(Code 1967, § 2-210; Ord. No. 80-304, § 1(2-210), 2-26-85; Ord. No. 80-335, § 1, 4-14-87; Ord. No. 80-340, § 25, 6-9-87; Ord. No. 80-371, §§ 1, 2, 1-24-89; Ord. No. 80-546, § 2, 8-24-99)  
Sec. 25-211. - Termination of membership. 
Except as otherwise provided in this article, should any member of the defined benefit plan leave the office or employ of the city, for any reason except retirement or death, he or she shall thereupon cease to be a member and his or her credited service at that time shall be forfeited by him or her. Should a person again become a member of the retirement system and obtain credited service of thirty (30) months or more, and should the member return to the reserve for members' contributions any amount the member withdrew therefrom, together with interest compounded annually at the rate in effect from the date of withdrawal to the date of repayment, the member shall be restored the credited service forfeited, except members who have elected to participate in the defined contribution plan have irrevocably forfeited membership in the defined benefit plan and shall not have credited service restored. 
(Code 1967, § 2-211; Ord. No. 80-305, § 1(2-211), 3-12-85; Ord. No. 80-546, § 2, 8-24-99)  
Sec. 25-212. - Credited service for CETA participation and preceding governmental service. 
Any member who prior to membership in the defined benefit plan was employed by the city under the comprehensive employment and training act program or by a preceding governmental unit, as defined in the Reciprocal Retirement Act, Act 88, 1961 (MCL 38.1101 et seq.) as amended; or who served as a full-time military or civilian employee of the United States Government; may be credited with service actually provided during the employment provided that: 
(1)  Within fifteen (15) years from and after the date the participation in the program or employment in the preceding unit ended, the person becomes a member of the defined benefit plan and within two (2) years of becoming a member or until July 1, 1994, the person begins payment into the reserve for members' contributions: 
a.  For persons who become members prior to November 1, 1995 the sum of three (3) percent of the first four thousand two hundred dollars ($4,200.00) of base pay; and five (5) percent of the base pay in excess of four thousand two hundred dollars ($4,200.00). The base pay amount shall be that members' base pay at the time of the request for credit; 
b.  For persons who become members on or after November 1, 1995 the actual cost as determined by the defined benefit plan's actuary without cost to the city. 
The base pay amount shall be that member's base pay at the time of the request for credit. 
(2)  Payment of the member's contribution shall be made in full within three (3) years if buying two (2) years or less and within five (5) years if buying more than two (2) years; 
(3)  The amount credited to the member's defined benefit plan credit does not exceed six (6) years; 
(4)  For purposes of this section, service is qualifying if it is not and will not be recognized for the purpose of obtaining or increasing a benefit under another retirement system. A member may qualify service by making an irrevocable forfeiture of all rights in and to the actual or potential benefit from the other retirement system. 
(5)  Should a member that has received a credit of service hereunder subsequently obtain a credit for the service upon which the credit in this system is based, then the service credit obtained hereunder shall be revoked, and the contributions returned together with interest compounded annually at the rate in effect on the date of forfeiture. 
(6)  The payment under subsection 25-212(1) shall be credited to the member's individual account in the reserve for members' contributions. 
(7)  A person who becomes a member after the effective date of this ordinance [Ordinance No. 80-490], will not be credited with service credit until the member completes eight (8) years of actual full time service with the City of Warren. 
(Code 1967, § 2-212; Ord. No. 80-304, § 2(2-212), 2-26-85; Ord. No. 80-340, § 26, 6-9-87; Ord. No. 80-366, § 1, 11-22-88; Ord. No. 80-437, § 1, 9-28-93; Ord. No. 80-488, § 1, 10-10-95; Ord. No. 80-490, § 1, 10-10-95; Ord. No. 80-546, § 2, 8-24-99)  
Sec. 25-213. - Military service credit. 
(a)  A member who, while employed by the city, entered or enters any armed service of the United States during time of war or period of compulsory military service, shall be credited with such armed service actually required of him or her in the same manner as if he or she had served the city uninterruptedly; provided that: 
(1)  He or she is re-employed by the city within six (6) months from and after the date such armed service required of him or her terminates; 
(2)  He or she returns to the reserve for members' contribution the amount he or she might have withdrawn therefrom at the time he or she entered or while in such armed service, together with regular interest from the date of withdrawal to the date of repayment; and 
(3)  In no case shall more than six (6) years of service be credited any member for all such armed service rendered by him or her. In any case of doubt as to the period of such armed service to be credited any member, the defined benefit board shall have final power to determine such period. During the period of such armed service and until his or her return to city employment, his or her contributions to the defined benefit plan shall be suspended and any balance standing to his or her credit in the reserve for members' contribution and members supplemental voluntary contribution fund shall be accumulated at regular interest. 
(b)  A member, who before employment with the city, served in any armed service of the United States during a time of war or period of compulsory military service, shall have the option to buy credited service subject to the following requirements: 
(1)  Members are allowed two (2) years from the date they became a member of the defined benefit plan to elect this option. Current members of the defined benefit plan shall have until July 1, 1986, to elect this option. 
(2)  The member must have been discharged or released from the military service under honorable conditions and may only apply for the years that he or she was in the active service in the armed forces. In any case of doubt as to the period of such armed services or as to the nature of the discharge, the defined benefit board shall have final power to determine same. 
(3)  The maximum amount of time that may be purchased and credited to the member's service shall be six (6) years. 
(4)  For each year of military time purchased, the member shall pay as follows: 
a.  For persons who become members prior to November 1, 1995—the sum of three (3) percent of the first four thousand two hundred dollars ($4,200.00) of base pay; and five (5) percent of the base pay in excess of four thousand two hundred dollars ($4,200.00). The base pay amount shall be that member's base pay at the time of the request for credit; 
b.  For persons who become members on or after November 1, 1995—the actual cost as determined by the defined benefit plan's actuary without cost to the city. 
(5)  Members electing this option may pay same in one lump sum payment or in deductions from pay so that the total amount is paid within three (3) years, if buying two (2) years or under, and within five (5) years, if more than two (2) years. If a member dies before the entire amount is repaid, the surviving spouse may pay the amounts remaining to be paid. 
(6)  In no event will the military service credit be given until the entire amount is paid in full, except in case of death or retirement, the amount that has been paid by the member will be prorated and credited to the member. 
(c)  No military service credit shall be allowed for members that have received credit for military service in another retirement system, nor shall military service credit be allowed for members that are receiving or will be eligible to receive a pension from the United States government for services in the armed forces. 
(d)  A person who becomes a member after the effective date of this ordinance [Ordinance No. 80-490], will not be credited with service credit until the member completes eight (8) years of actual full time service with the City of Warren. 
Code 1967, § 2-213; Ord. No. 80-309, § 1, 8-27-85; Ord. No. 80-489, § 1, 10-10-95; Ord. No. 80-490, § 2, 10-10-95; Ord. No. 80-546, § 2, 8-24-99)  
Sec. 25-214. - Voluntary retirement. 
Any member, who has eight (8) or more years of credited service and has attained age fifty-five (55) years, may retire upon his or her written application filed with the defined benefit board setting forth at what time, not less than thirty (30) days nor more than ninety (90) days subsequent to the execution and filing thereof, he or she desires to be retired. Upon his or her retirement he or she shall be paid a pension provided in section 25-216. 
(Code 1967, § 2-214; Ord. No. 80-546, § 2, 8-24-99)  
Sec. 25-215. - Normal retirement. 
Upon his or her separation from city employment, a member who has attained the age of fifty-five (55) and who has eight (8) years or more of credited service, shall be paid a pension as provided in section 25-216. 
(Code 1967, § 2-215; Ord. No. 80-371, § 3, 1-24-89; Ord. No. 80-397, § 1, 11-26-91; Ord. No. 80-491, § 1, 10-24-95; Ord. No. 80-546, § 2, 8-24-99)  
Sec. 25-216. - Straight life pension. 
(a)  Upon a member's retirement, as provided in this article, he or she shall be paid the applicable straight life pension hereinafter provided in this section. Prior to the date the first payment of his or her pension becomes due, he or she may elect to receive his or her pension under an option provided in section 25-220 in lieu of a straight life pension. 
(b)  The straight life pension for a member who retires after June 30, 1970, shall be: 
(1)  For a member who retires prior to age sixty-two (62) years, the straight life pension payable to attainment of age sixty-two (62) years shall be equal to the number of years, and fraction of a year, of his or her credited service multiplied by 2.5 percent of his or her final average compensation, subject to subsection (c). 
(2)  Upon attainment of age sixty-two (62) years if retirement occurred prior to such age, or upon retirement if retirement occurs at or after such age, the straight life pension shall be equal to the number of years and fraction of a year of his or her credited service multiplied by the sum of 1.10 percent of the first three hundred fifty dollars ($350.00) of his or her final average compensation plus 2.5 percent of the portion, if any, of his or her final average compensation in excess of three hundred fifty dollars ($350.00). 
(c)  If a member retires before the age of sixty (60) years, except as provided in sections 25-221, 25-222 and 25-224, his or her pension shall be reduced one-half of one percent multiplied by the number of complete months in the period from the date he or she requests his or her pension to begin to the date he or she would attain age sixty (60) years. If a member retires before the age of sixty (60) years, he or she shall be allowed to select an option as provided under section 25-220. The option so selected shall be reduced as provided in the above sentence. Effective January 1, 1979, a member with thirty (30) or more years of credited service may retire at any age with no decrease in benefits because of age. Effective July 1, 1984, a member with twenty-five (25) years of credited service may retire at age fifty (50) with no decrease in benefits because of age. 
(d)  Optional Annuity Withdrawal: Any member may elect, not less than thirty (30) days or greater than ninety (90) days prior to the effective date of retirement, to be paid all or part of the accumulated contributions (excluding interest for military buy back and CETA buy back contributions) in the reserve for members' contributions. If a member makes such an election, the member's monthly pension shall be reduced by an amount which is the actuarial equivalent of the accumulated contributions paid. The actuarial equivalent shall be determined on the basis of the interest rate established by the Pension Benefit Guarantee Corporation for immediate annuities. 
(Code 1967, § 2-216; Ord. No. 80-302, § 1, 8-28-84; Ord. No. 80-310, § 1, 8-27-85; Ord. No. 80-546, § 2, 8-24-99)  
Sec. 25-217. - Straight life refund. 
If a retirant dies before he or she has received in straight life pension payments an aggregate amount equal to his or her accumulated contributions standing to his or her credit in the reserve for members' contributions at the time of his or her retirement, the difference between his or her accumulated contributions and the aggregate amount of straight life pension payments received by him or her shall be paid from the reserve for retirees' benefit payments to such person as he or she shall have nominated by written designation duly executed and filed with the defined benefit board. If there be no such designated person surviving the retirant, such difference, if any, shall be paid to his or her legal representatives. No benefits shall be paid under this section by the defined benefit plan on account of the death of a retirant if a pension becomes payable under option A or B, provided in section 25-220, on account of his or her death. 
(Code 1967, § 2-217; Ord. No. 80-546, § 2, 8-24-99)  
Sec. 25-218. - Deferred retirement. 
Should any member who has eight (8) or more years of credited service leave the employ of the city prior to his or her attainment of age fifty-five (55) years, for any reason except his or her retirement or death, he or she shall be entitled to a pension provided in section 25-216, as the section was in effect at the time he or she left city employment. In the case of a death of a member on deferred retirement status who has not attained the age of fifty-five (55) years, the pension if any, shall be paid to the person that he or she nominated by written designation filed with the defined benefit board prior to his or her death. Payment of a pension under this section by the defined benefit plan shall begin on the first day of the calendar month in which: 
(1)  The member attains the age of fifty-five (55) years and files an application for payment of a pension with the defined benefit board; or 
(2)  If a beneficiary files an application for payment of a pension hereunder, on or after the date that the deceased member would have reached age fifty-five (55) years, had he or she survived. 
Until the beginning date of his or her pension, his or her balances in the reserve for members' contributions and the members supplemental voluntary contribution fund shall be accumulated at regular interest. If he or she withdraws his or her accumulated contributions from the reserve for members' contributions, he or she shall thereupon forfeit his or her rights and the right of his or her beneficiary, to a deferred pension provided in this section. 
(Code 1967, § 2-218; Ord. No. 80-546, § 2, 8-24-99)  
Sec. 25-219. - City employment after retirement. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided in this article, if a retirant receiving a defined benefit pension is re-employed by the city or any entity that derives its revenue solely from the city, payment of his or her pension shall be suspended during the period of his or her re-employment, however, a retirant who is re-employed in a full time capacity may participate in the defined contribution system as a new participant. Upon termination of his or her re-employment, payment of the retirant's pension shall be resumed. However, during the period of re-employment the retirant: 
(1)  Shall not be a member of the defined benefit plan; and 
(2)  Shall not make contributions to the defined benefit plan; and 
(3)  Shall not be given credited service in the defined benefit plan while re-employed; and 
(b)  Notwithstanding subsection (a), any retirant receiving a defined benefit pension who is re-employed by the city in the capacity of a part-time employee working no more than six hundred and fifty (650) hours per year shall continue receiving pension payments during the period of re-employment; provided that during the period of re-employment, the retirant shall not earn any additional pension credits and shall not participate in the defined contribution pension plan. 
(Code 1967, § 2-219; Ord. No. 80-371, § 4, 1-24-89; Ord. No. 80-439, § 1, 6-22-93; Ord. No. 80-546, § 2, 8-24-99)  
Sec. 25-220. - Pension election; straight life; option A or B. 
Prior to the date the first payment of his or her pension becomes due, but not thereafter, a member may elect to be paid his or her pension as a straight life pension payable throughout his or her life, or nominate a beneficiary(ies), in accordance with the provisions of Option A or B, set forth below: 
(1)  Option A—one hundred (100) percent survivor pension. Upon the death of a retirant who elected Option A, his or her reduced pension shall be continued throughout the life of and paid to such person having an insurable interest in his or her life, such beneficiaries shall be nominated by written designation duly executed and filed with the defined benefit board prior to the date the first payment of his or her pension becomes due. If a minor is nominated beneficiary, the minor's pension shall terminate upon his or her adoption, marriage, attainment of age twenty-one (21), or death, whichever occurs first. 
(2)  Option B-50 percent survivor pension. Upon the death of a retirant who elected Option B, one-half of his or her reduced pension shall be continued throughout the life of and paid to such person having an insurable interest in his or her life, such beneficiaries shall be nominated by written designation duly executed and filed with the defined benefit board prior to the date the first payment of his or her pension becomes due. If a minor is nominated beneficiary, the minor's pension shall terminate upon his or her adoption, marriage, attainment of age twenty-one (21), or death, whichever occurs first. 
(Code 1967, § 2-220; Ord. No. 80-546, § 2, 8-24-99)  
Sec. 25-221. - Disability retirement after leaving service of city. 
(a)  Upon the application of a member, (i) who has left the employment of the city, (ii) and has eight (8) or more years of employment with the city, and (iii) who has become totally and permanently disabled for employment, by reason of a personal injury or disease, (iv) and who has no other income over two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00) per year, including all other pensions, workers' compensation, either in a single sum settlement or weekly payments, except social security payments shall not be included as income, may be retired by the defined benefit board; provided that after a medical examination of the member, made by or under the direction of a medical committee consisting of three (3) physicians, one of whom shall be named by the defined benefit board, one by the member, and the third physician to be designated by the first two (2) physicians so named, the medical committee certifies to the defined benefit board, (i) the member is mentally or physically totally incapacitated for any employment, (ii) his or her incapacity will probably be permanent, and (iii) the member should be retired. Final determination as to whether a member shall be retired shall be determined by the defined benefit board. 
(b)  The amount of disability pension shall be equal to the amount of his or her deferred pension reduced by one-half of one percent for each month his or her age at the time of disability retirement is less than sixty-two (62) years of age, but in no event shall such reduction exceed fifty (50) percent of his or her deferred pension. 
(c)  A member with a disability pension shall submit to such physical examination as required by section 25-224. Upon his or her retirement a member shall have the right to elect an option provided for in section 25-220. Pension benefits received shall not be increased when the retired member shall reach the age of ordinary retirement. 
(Code 1967, § 2-221; Ord. No. 80-375, § 1, 6-13-89; Ord. No. 80-546, § 2, 8-24-99)  
Sec. 25-222. - Disability retirement. 
Upon the application of a member, or his or her department head, a member who (i) is in the employ of the city, (ii) has eight (8) or more years of credited service, and (iii) becomes totally and permanently disabled for duty in the employ of the city by reason of personal injury or disease, may be retired by the defined benefit board; provided, that after a medical examination of the member, made by or under the direction of a medical committee consisting of three (3) physicians, one of whom shall be named by the defined benefit board, one by the member, and one by the first two (2) physicians so named, the medical committee certifies to the defined benefit board that (i) the member is mentally or physically totally disabled for duty in the employ of the city, (ii) his or her disability will probably be permanent, and (iii) the member should be retired. The eight (8) years of service requirement contained in this section shall not apply to a member whom the defined benefit board finds: 
(1)  To be totally and permanently disabled for duty in the employ of the city as the natural and proximate result of a personal injury or disease arising out of and in the course of his or her actual performance of duty in the employ of the city; and 
(2)  Is granted workers' compensation on account of his or her physical or mental disability. 
(Code 1967, § 2-222; Ord. No. 80-546, § 2, 8-24-99)  
Sec. 25-223. - Disability pension. 
(a)  Upon a member's retirement on account of disability, as provided in section 25-222, he or she shall be paid a disability pension by the defined benefit plan computed according to section 25-216. His or her disability pension payable to his or her attainment of age sixty (60) years shall not be less than fifteen (15) percent of his or her final average compensation. Prior to the date the first payment of his or her pension becomes due, he or she may elect to receive his or her pension under an option provided in section 25-220 in lieu of a straight life pension. 
(b)  Upon termination of a disability retirant's workers' compensation period, if any, he or she shall be given service credit for his or her workers' compensation period and his or her disability credit. Such additional service credit shall not include any period beyond age sixty-two (62) years. 
(Code 1967, § 2-223; Ord. No. 80-546, § 2, 8-24-99)  
Sec. 25-224. - Disability retirant; re-examination; earnings offset; return to work. 
(a)  At least once each year during the first five (5) years a retirant is in receipt of a disability pension, and at least once in each three-year period thereafter, the defined benefit board may require the retirant, if he or she has not attained age fifty-five (55) years, to undergo a medical examination to be made by or under the direction of a physician designated by the board. Should the retirant refuse to submit to such medical examination in any such period, the defined benefit board shall suspend payment of his or her disability pension until withdrawal of such refusal. If such refusal continues for one (1) year, his or her disability pension shall be forfeited by him or her. If upon such medical examination of the retirant, the physician reports to the defined benefit board that the retirant is physically able and capable of resuming employment with the city, he or she shall be returned to the employ of the city and his or her disability pension shall terminate, provided that the report of the physician is concurred in by the defined benefit board. In returning a retirant to city employment, reasonable latitude shall be allowed the city in placing him or her in a position commensurate to his or her type of work and compensation at the time of his or her retirement. 
(b)  If a disability retirant, who has not attained age sixty (60) years, becomes engaged in a gainful occupation, business or employment paying more than the difference between his or her annual rate of compensation at the time of his or her retirement and his or her disability pension, his or her disability pension shall be reduced to an amount which together with the amount so earned by him or her shall equal his or her annual rate of compensation. The disability retiree shall submit a copy of his or her U.S. income tax return and necessary supporting schedules and other information as required by the defined benefit board, so that his or her income may be determined for the purposes of this ordinance. Should the retirant refuse to submit the requested U. S. tax returns and supporting schedules, or any other information reasonably necessary to make the determination under this division, as determined necessary by the defined benefit board, the board shall suspend payment of his or her disability pension until withdrawal of such refusal. If such refusal continues for one (1) year, his or her disability pension shall be forfeited. 
(c)  A disability retirant who returns to the employ of the city, as provided in this section, shall have his or her credited service in force at the time of his or her retirement restored to his or her credit. He or she shall be given service credit for the period he or she was receiving both a disability pension and weekly benefits for workers' compensation on account of his or her total and permanent disability arising out of and in the course of his or her city employment; otherwise he or she shall not be given service credit for such period. 
(Code 1967, § 2-224; Ord. No. 80-371, § 5, 1-24-89; Ord. No. 80-396, § 1, 11-26-91; Ord. No. 80-464, § 1, 9-13-94; Ord. No. 80-546, § 2, 8-24-99)  
Sec. 25-225. - Non-duty death benefits. 
(a)  Any member who has eight (8) or more years of credited service may, at any time prior to the date of his or her retirement, elect option A provided in section 25-220 in the same manner as if he or she were then retiring from service, and nominate a beneficiary whom the defined benefit board finds to be dependent upon him or her for at least fifty (50) percent of his or her financial support. Prior to the date of his or her retirement, but not thereafter, the member may revoke his or her election of option A and nomination of beneficiary, and he or she may again, prior to the date of his or her retirement, elect option A and nominate a beneficiary as provided in this subsection. If a member who has an option A election in force dies while in city employment, his or her beneficiary if living shall immediately be paid a pension computed in the same manner as if the member had retired the day preceding the date of his or her death, notwithstanding that he or she might not have attained age fifty-five (55) years. If a member has an option A election in force at the date of his or her retirement, his or her election of option A and nomination of beneficiary shall thereafter continue in force, unless prior to the date of his or her retirement he or she elects to be paid his or her pension as a straight life pension or according to another option provided in section 25-220. Any pension payable under this subsection shall be subject to section 25-228. 
(b)  Any member who has eight (8) or more years of credited service and who does not have an option A election in force, dies while in the employ of the city, will be presumed to have retired the day preceding the age of his or her death, notwithstanding that he or she might not have attained age fifty-five (55) years, and the following applicable pensions shall be paid: 
(1)  If the deceased member leaves a spouse, the spouse shall be paid a pension equal to seventy-five (75) percent of the pension, computed according to section 25-216, earned by the member to the date of his or her death. If the spouse is more than five (5) years younger than the deceased, the seventy-five (75) percent is to be reduced by one (1) percent for each year over five (5). The percent, so reduced, shall not be less than fifty (50) percent, nor shall the spouse's pension be less than fifteen (15) percent of the member's final average compensation. The pension shall terminate upon the spouse's remarriage or death and shall be subject to section 25-228. 
(2)  If the deceased member does not leave a spouse, or if the spouse remarries or dies subsequent to the member's death, and the member leaves his or her unmarried child or children under age twenty-one (21) years, each such child shall be paid a pension of an equal share of fifty (50) percent of the pension, computed according to section 25-216, earned by the member to the date of his or her death; provided, that if the earned pension is less than fifteen (15) percent of his or her final average compensation. A child's pension shall terminate upon his or her adoption, marriage, attainment of age twenty-one (21) years, or death, whichever occurs first. The age twenty-one (21) years limit shall not apply in the case of the member's unmarried child whom the defined benefit board finds to be temporarily or permanently, mentally or physically disabled at the time of the member's death; such child's pension shall continue so long as the board finds the child to be so disabled. Upon termination of a child's pension it shall be divided into equal shares and added to the pensions being paid the deceased member's surviving eligible children, if any. A child's pension shall be subject to section 25-228. 
(Code 1967, § 2-225; Ord. No. 80-546, § 2, 8-24-99)  
Sec. 25-226. - Duty death pensions. 
(a)  If a member dies as the result of a personal injury or disease arising solely and exclusively out of and in the course of his or her employment with the city, and such death, injury or disease resulting in death be found by the defined benefit board to have been the result of his or her actual performance of duty in the employ of the city, the applicable benefits hereinafter provided in this subsection shall be paid, subject to the condition that the beneficiaries are granted workers' compensation on account of the death of the member. 
(1)  His or her accumulated contributions standing to his or her credit in the reserve for members' contributions at the time of his or her death shall be paid in accordance with the provisions of section 25-229 subject to subsection (b) of this section. 
(2)  The spouse shall be paid a pension equal to the weekly workers' compensation converted to a monthly basis. A spouse's pension shall begin upon termination of the workers' compensation period and shall continue until remarriage or death. A spouse's pension shall be subject to subsection (b) of this section. 
(3)  His or her unmarried child or children under age twenty-one (21) years shall each receive a pension equal to the child's weekly workers' compensation converted to a monthly basis. A child's pension shall begin upon termination of his or her workers' compensation period and shall continue until his or her adoption, marriage, attainment of age twenty-one (21) years, or death, which ever occurs first. If a spouse's pension is terminated, each child's pension shall be increased by an equal share of the spouse's pension. A child's pension shall be subject to subsection (b) of this section. 
(4)  His or her parents shall each be paid a pension equal to such parent's weekly workers' compensation converted to a monthly basis. A parent's pension shall begin upon termination of the parent's workers' compensation period and shall continue until his or her remarriage or death. A parent's pension shall be subject to subsection (b) of this section. 
(b)  As used in this section, the term "spouse" means the person to whom the member was married at the time of his or her employment with the city was last terminated. In no case shall any pensions or other payments be paid under subsection (a) of this section on account of the death of a member if any pensions are paid or will become payable under section 25-225 on account of his or her death. Pensions payable under this section shall be subject to section 25-228. 
(Code 1967, § 2-226; Ord. No. 80-546, § 2, 8-24-99)  
Sec. 25-227. - Subrogation. 
If a person becomes entitled to a pension payable by the defined benefit plan as the result of an accident or disease caused by the act of a third party, the city shall be subrogated to the rights of the person against the third party to the extent of benefits which the city pays or becomes liable to pay. 
(Code 1967, § 2-227; Ord. No. 80-546, § 2, 8-24-99)  
Sec. 25-228. - Pension maximum limit. 
The total of the pensions granted under any provision of this division on account of a member's retirement or death shall not exceed the difference between: 
• Seventy-five (75) percent of the member's final average compensation; and 
• The sum of the monthly equivalent of: 
(1)  Any workers' compensation payable on account of the member's city employment; and 
(2)  Any other benefit program, except social security and life insurance benefits, financed in whole or in part by the city. 
(Code 1967, § 2-228; Ord. No. 80-546, § 2, 8-24-99)  
Sec. 25-229. - Payment of member's accumulated contributions. 
(a)  Should any member of the defined benefit plan cease to be employed by the city, for any reason except his or her retirement or death, before he or she has eight (8) years of service or has satisfied the age and service requirements for retirement provided in section 25-214, he or she shall be paid his or her accumulated contributions standing to his or her credit in the reserve for members' contributions. 
(b)  Upon the death of a member of the defined benefit plan, if no pension is payable or will become payable by the defined benefit plan on account of his or her death, his or her accumulated contributions and interest standing to his or her credit in the reserve for members' contributions at the time of his or her death shall be paid to such person or persons as he or she shall have nominated by written designation duly executed and filed with the defined benefit board. If there be no such designated person surviving the member, or if he or she did not designate a beneficiary, his or her accumulated contributions shall be paid to his estate. 
(c)  Payments of accumulated contributions and interest as provided in this section may be made in a single sum or in installments as the defined benefit board shall from time to time determine by appropriate rules and regulations. 
(Code 1967, § 2-229; Ord. No. 80-546, § 2, 8-24-99)  
Sec. 25-230. - Reserve for members' contributions. 
(a)  The reserve for members' contributions is hereby created. It shall be the fund in which shall be maintained with accumulated interest, the contributions of members made in accordance with this article, and from which shall be made payments and transfer of accumulated contributions, as provided in this article. 
(b)  A member shall return to the reserve for members' contributions, by a single contribution or by a payment method approved by the defined benefit board, the amount, if any, he or she withdrew therefrom, together with regular interest from date of withdrawal to the date of repayment. In no case shall any member be given credit for service rendered prior to the date he or she withdrew his or her accumulated contributions until he or she returns to the reserve for members' contributions all amounts due the fund by him or her. 
(c)  Upon the retirement of a member, or upon his or her death if a pension becomes payable by the defined benefit plan on account of his or her death, his or her accumulated contributions shall be transferred from the reserve for members' contributions to the retirees' benefit payments, unless otherwise specifically provided in this article. At the expiration of a period of three (3) years from and after the date of a person ceasing to be a member, without entitlement to a deferred pension provided in section 25-218, any balance of accumulated contributions standing to his or her credit in the reserve for members' contributions, unclaimed by the member or his or her legal representative, shall be transferred to the reserve for undistributed income. 
(Code 1967, § 2-230; Ord. No. 80-546, § 2, 8-24-99)  
Sec. 25-231. - Member's supplemental voluntary contribution fund. 
(a)  The member's supplemental voluntary contribution fund is hereby created. It shall be the fund in which shall be accumulated, at regular interest, member's supplemental deposits, and from which shall be made payments and transfers of accumulated deposits, as hereinafter provided in this section. 
(b)  Each member shall be permitted to make supplemental deposits in the defined benefit plan in addition to his or her contributions provided in section 25-230. A member's supplemental deposits in any year beginning July first, shall not exceed five (5) percent of his or her annual compensation, nor be less than one hundred and eighty dollars ($180.00). The supplemental deposits shall be made in accordance with such rules and regulations as the defined benefit board shall from time to time adopt. A member's supplemental deposits, when made, shall be credited to his or her individual account in the member's supplemental voluntary contribution fund. 
(c)  At least once each fiscal year, the defined benefit board shall credit each member's account in the members supplemental voluntary contribution fund with regular interest at such rate as the board shall from time to time determine. The interest so credited shall be transferred from the reserve for undistributed income to the member's supplemental voluntary fund. 
(d)  A member may at any time withdraw all or part of his or her accumulated supplemental deposits standing to his or her credit in the member's supplemental voluntary contribution fund. If a member makes a withdrawal, he or she shall not again be permitted to make deposits in the members supplemental voluntary contribution fund until the expiration of one (1) year from and after the date of his or her last withdrawal. 
(e)  When a member becomes a "retirant" as defined in section 25-208, his or her deposits standing to his or her credit in the members' supplemental voluntary contribution fund, along with interest earned, shall be paid upon application for retirement. He or she may elect to receive his or her voluntary contributions along with earned interest in a lump sum payment or to be prorated on a monthly basis until the funds are exhausted. 
(f)  Upon a member's death, his or her balance, if any, with interest earned, if any, in the members supplemental voluntary contribution fund shall be paid in a single sum to such person or persons as he or she shall have nominated by written designation duly executed and filed with the defined benefit board. 
(Code 1967, § 2-231; Ord. No. 80-546, § 2, 8-24-99)  
Sec. 25-232. - Reserve for employer's contribution. 
(a)  The reserve for employer's contribution is hereby created. It shall be the fund in which shall be accumulated the contributions made by the city to the defined benefit plan, and from which shall be made transfers as provided in this section. Upon the basis of such mortality and other tables of experience, and regular interest, as the defined benefit board shall from time to time adopt, the actuary shall annually compute the pension reserves (i) for pensions being paid retirants and beneficiaries, and (ii) covering service rendered and to be rendered by members. The portion of the pension reserves which are not financed by members' contributions shall be financed by annual appropriations to be made by the council, the appropriations to be determined according to the following: 
(1)  The annual appropriations for members' current service shall be a percent of their annual compensations, which if paid annually by the city for the periods of their future service will be sufficient to provide the city-financed portions of the pension reserves at the time of their retirements for the pensions to be paid based upon their future service. 
(2)  The annual appropriation for members' accrued service shall be a percent of their annual compensations which will produce an amount which if paid annually by the city over a period of years, to be determined by the council, will amortize, at regular interest, the unfunded pension reserves for the accrued service portions of the pensions to be paid. 
(3)  The annual appropriation for pensions being paid retirants and beneficiaries shall be a percent of the annual compensations of members which will produce an amount which if paid annually by the city over a period of years, to be determined by the council, will amortize, at regular interest, the unfunded pension reserves, if any, for pensions being paid retirants and beneficiaries. 
(b)  Upon the retirement of a member, or upon his or her death if a pension becomes payable on his or her account, the difference between the pension reserve for the pension payable and the member's accumulated contributions shall be transferred from the reserve for employer's contribution to the reserve for retirees benefit payments. 
(Code 1967, § 2-232; Ord. No. 80-546, § 2, 8-24-99)  
Sec. 25-233. - Reserve for retirees' benefit payments. 
The reserve for retirees' benefit payments is hereby created. It shall be the fund from which shall be paid all defined benefit pensions payable as provided in this article. Should any retirant who retired on account of disability return to the employ of the city, his or her pension reserve, at the date of his or her return, shall be transferred from the reserve for retirees' benefit payments to the reserve for members' contributions and the reserve for employer's contribution in the same proportion as the reserves were originally transferred. 
(Code 1967, § 2-233; Ord. No. 80-546, § 2, 8-24-99)  
Sec. 25-234. - Reserve for administrative expense. 
The reserve for administrative expense is hereby created. The reserve for administrative expense shall be the fund to which shall be credited all money provided by the city to pay the administrative expenses of the defined benefit plan, and from which shall be paid all expenses necessary in connection with the administration of the defined benefit plan. 
(Code 1967, § 2-234; Ord. No. 80-546, § 2, 8-24-99)  
Sec. 25-235. - Reserve for undistributed income; allowance of regular interest. 
(a)  The reserve for undistributed income is hereby created. It shall be the fund to which shall be credited all interest, dividends and other income from investments of the defined benefit plan, all transfers from the reserve for members' contribution by reason of lack of claimant, and all moneys received by the defined benefit plan the disposition of which is not specifically provided in this article. The defined benefit board may accept gifts and bequests and the same shall be credited to the reserve for undistributed income. There shall be transferred from the reserve for undistributed income to the reserve for members' contributions, reserve for employer's contribution, reserve for retirees' benefit payments and members supplemental voluntary contribution fund the amounts required to credit regular interest to the respective funds. Whenever the defined benefit board determines the balance in the reserve for undistributed income is more than sufficient to cover the current charges to the fund, such excess may be used to provide contingency reserves or may be used to cover special needs of the other funds of the defined benefit plan, as the defined benefit board shall determine. If the balance in the reserve for undistributed income is not sufficient to meet the charges to the fund, the amount of such insufficiency shall be transferred to the reserve for undistributed income from the reserve for employer's contributions. A member's accumulated contributions which were transferred to the reserve of undistributed income may be returned upon a valid claim approved by the defined benefit board. 
(b)  The defined benefit board shall, at the end of each fiscal year, allow and credit regular interest to each member's individual account in the reserve for members' contributions; such interest shall be computed upon the difference between his or her balance in the fund at the beginning of the fiscal year and any withdrawal he or she might have made from the fund during the year. Members who have individual accounts in the supplemental voluntary contribution fund, upon approval of the defined benefit board, shall be allowed and credited regular interest at the end of each fiscal year to each member's individual account in such fund. Such interest shall be computed upon the difference between his or her balance in the fund at the beginning of the fiscal year and any withdrawal he or she might have made from the fund during the year. At the end of each fiscal year the defined benefit board shall allow and credit regular interest on the reserve for employer's contribution and reserve for retirees' benefit payments; such interest shall be computed upon the mean balances in the respective funds during the year. The amounts of interest so allowed and credited shall be transferred from the reserve for undistributed income. 
(Code 1967, § 2-235; Ord. No. 80-546, § 2, 8-24-99)  
Sec. 25-236. - Authorization; investment of assets; disbursements; transfer of funds. 
(a)  The defined benefit board shall be the trustees of the assets of the defined benefit plan and shall have full power to invest and reinvest such assets in accordance with the provisions of Act No. 314 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1965, as amended, MCL 38.1132 et seq.) The defined benefit board shall have the power to hold, purchase, sell, assign, transfer, and dispose of any securities and investments of the defined benefit plan, as well as the proceeds of such investments, and any moneys belonging to the defined benefit plan. 
(b)  There shall be kept on deposit available cash not to exceed five(5) percent of the total assets of the defined benefit plan. All assets of the defined benefit plan shall be held for the purposes of meeting disbursements for pensions and other purposes allowed under the provisions of Act No. 314 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1965, as amended, and this article. 
(c)  Funds may be transferred from the defined benefit plan to the defined contribution plan for any member who forfeits membership in the defined benefit plan and elects participation in the defined contribution plan. The transfer amount shall be determined by the actuary designated by the defined contribution board of trustees. The defined benefit board is authorized to determine from which account the lump sum transfer amount will be transferred from, except funds may not be transferred from the reserve for retirees' benefit payments account to cover any transfer to the defined contribution plan. Once calculated, all transfer amounts shall be submitted by the actuary to the defined contribution plan administrator. Upon notification from the defined contribution plan administrator, the defined benefit board of trustees shall transfer the requested transfer amount in a total lump sum to the plan administrator as designated by the defined contribution board of trustees. 
(d)  The various funds of the defined benefit plan, namely, the reserve for members' contributions, reserve for employer's contribution, reserve for retirees' benefit payments, members supplemental voluntary contribution, the reserve for administrative expense, and the reserve for undistributed income, shall be interpreted to refer to the accounting records of the defined benefit plan and not to the actual segregating of assets in the various funds. 
(e)  In interpreting and applying the provisions of this article, the defined benefit board shall comply with the standards and obligations of an investment fiduciary as provided in Act No. 314 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1965, as amended, and shall exercise the powers and authority granted to them as an investment fiduciary, under the provisions of such Act. 
(f)  The provisions of Act No. 314 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1965, as amended, supersede any of the provisions of this article or rules established by the defined benefit board. 
(Code 1967, § 2-236; Ord. No. 80-546, § 2, 8-24-99)  
Sec. 25-237. - Credit for service in a reciprocal retirement system. 
The Reciprocal Retirement Act, Act. No. 88 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1961 (MCL 38.1101 et seq.), and its subsequent amendments are hereby adopted and all of the provisions of the Act, as amended, are made applicable to members covered under this defined benefit plan. 
(Code 1967, § 2-237; Ord. No. 80-546, § 2, 8-24-99)  
Sec. 25-238. - Experience tables; regular interest. 
The defined benefit board of trustees shall from time to time adopt mortality and other tables of experience, and a rate or rates of regular interest, that is actuarially necessary for the operation of the defined benefit plan. 
(Code 1967, § 2-238; Ord. No. 80-546, § 2, 8-24-99)  
Sec. 25-239. - Correction of errors. 
Should any change or error in the records of the city or defined benefit plan result in any person receiving more or less from the defined benefit plan than he or she would have been entitled to receive had the records been correct, the defined benefit board shall correct such error and as far as practicable, shall adjust the payment of the benefit in such a manner that the actuarial equivalent of the benefit to which the person was correctly entitled shall be paid. 
(Code 1967, § 2-239; Ord. No. 80-546, § 2, 8-24-99)  
Secs. 25-240—25-245. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2A. - DEFINED BENEFIT BOARD OF TRUSTEES 
 
Sec. 25-246. - Created. 
There is hereby created for the city a defined benefit board of trustees. 
(Code 1967, § 2-203; Ord. No. 80-546, § 2, 8-24-99)  
Sec. 25-247. - Composition. 
The defined benefit board shall consist of five (5) trustees, as follows: 
(1)  The mayor, or a citizen of the city designated by the mayor as his or her alternate, to serve at the pleasure of the mayor; 
(2)  A councilperson to be selected by the council, to serve at the pleasure of the council; 
(3)  A citizen, who is an elector of the city and who is not eligible to participate in the retirement system as a member, retirant or beneficiary, to be appointed by the mayor; 
(4)  Two (2) members to be selected from and elected by the general membership of the defined benefit plan. 
(Code 1967, § 2-203; Ord. No. 80-546, § 2, 8-24-99)  
Sec. 25-248. - Terms. 
The term of office for the trustees selected under the provisions of section 25-247(3) and (4) shall be for three (3) years. 
(Code 1967, § 2-204; Ord. No. 80-299, § 1, 6-26-84; Ord. No. 80-546, § 2, 8-24-99)  
Sec. 25-249. - Compensation, expenses. 
Compensation for trustees selected under the provisions of section 25-247(1) and (3) may be established by resolution of council. Member trustees selected under the provisions of section 25-247(4) shall not suffer a loss because of absence from their employment with the city. A board member shall be reimbursed by the defined benefit plan for all actual and necessary travel and other expenses incurred in the performance of official duties as a board member. 
(Code 1967, § 2-204; Ord. No. 80-299, § 1, 6-26-84; Ord. No. 80-546, § 2, 8-24-99)  
Sec. 25-250. - Filling of vacancies. 
If a member trustee provided in section 25-247(4) ceases to be employed by the city, or if any trustee provided in section 25-247 shall fail to attend scheduled meetings of the defined benefit board for three (3) consecutive meetings, unless in each case excused for cause by the remaining trustees attending such meetings, the trustee shall be considered to have resigned from the defined benefit board and the board shall by resolution declare his or her office of trustee vacated as of the date of adoption of such, resolution. If a vacancy occurs in the office of trustee, the office shall be filled within thirty (30) days from and after the date of the vacancy. Vacancies occurring in the office of trustee shall be filled in the same manner as the original selection as provided in section 25-247. 
(Code 1967, § 2-205; Ord. No. 80-308, § 1, 9-16-85; Ord. No. 80-546, § 2, 8-24-99)  
Sec. 25-251. - Meetings. 
The defined benefit board shall hold meetings regularly and shall meet at 1 p.m. in the afternoon of any Wednesday of January, April, July, and October of each year and shall designate the place thereof. At any meeting of the defined benefit board, three (3) trustees shall constitute a quorum. Each trustee shall be entitled to one (1) vote on each question before the board, and at least three (3) concurring votes shall be required for a decision by the trustees. The defined benefit board shall adopt its own rules of procedure and shall keep a record of its proceedings. All meetings of the board shall be public. Special meetings may be held upon call by two (2) board members, with notice mailed or delivered forty-eight (48) hours before the special meeting. 
(Code 1967, § 2-206; Ord. No. 80-294, § 1, 11-22-83; Ord. No. 80-546, § 2, 8-24-99)  
Sec. 25-252. - Officers. 
(a)  The defined benefit board shall elect a chairperson and vice chairperson from its own members. 
(b)  The city controller or his or her assistant if so designated by the controller as his or her alternate, shall be the secretary to the defined benefit board of trustees and shall perform the duties as required in this article and as are required by the board. The secretary shall keep such data as shall be necessary for an actuarial valuation of the assets and liabilities of the defined benefit plan and provide an annual report to the defined benefit board before December 15 of each year or as otherwise required by the board. 
(c)  The city treasurer shall be treasurer of the defined benefit plan and shall make payments from the monies of the defined benefit plan as directed by the defined benefit board of trustees. Such payments shall be made only upon city vouchers signed by two (2) persons designated by the board. As the treasurer's authority to make payments upon such vouchers, a duly attested copy of the resolution shall be filed with the city treasurer bearing upon its face the signatures of the two (2) persons designated by the defined benefit board. 
(d)  The defined benefit board shall appoint an actuary; he or she shall be the technical advisor to the board on matters regarding the operation of the defined benefit plan and he or she shall perform such other duties as are required of him or her in this article. 
(e)  The legal advisor to the defined benefit board shall be the city attorney, his or her assistant or an attorney designated by the board. 
(f)  The defined benefit board shall have the authority to employ such professional and other services as are required for the proper operation of the defined benefit plan. Compensation for such services shall be fixed by the defined benefit board. 
(Code 1967, § 2-207; Ord. No. 80-300, § 1, 7-10-84; Ord. No. 80-546, § 2, 8-24-99)  
Sec. 25-253. - Power and authority. 
The defined benefit board of trustees is vested with the power and authority to administer, manage and operate the defined benefit plan, and to construe and make effective the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1967, § 2-203; Ord. No. 80-546, § 2, 8-24-99)  
Sec. 25-254. - Records, annual report. 
The defined benefit board shall annually render a report to the mayor and city council showing the fiscal transactions of the defined benefit plan for the preceding fiscal year. The board shall furnish such additional information regarding the operation of the defined benefit plan as the mayor or the city council shall from time to time request. 
(Code 1967, § 2-208; Ord. No. 80-300, § 2, 7-10-84; Ord. No. 80-546, § 2, 8-24-99;)  
Secs. 25-255—25-300. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - THE DEFINED CONTRIBUTION PLAN. 
 
Sec. 25-301. - Establishment; internal revenue code qualification. 
(a)  A defined contribution plan is established as part of the general employees retirement system. It is intended that the defined contribution plan be a qualified pension plan under the Internal Revenue Code section 401, and that the trust be an exempt organization under the Code, section 501. Once established, the city shall not be entitled to receive or recover any part of its contributions to the trust or the earnings thereof and the corpus or income of the trust may not be diverted to or used for any purpose other than the exclusive benefit of the participants or their beneficiaries. 
(b)  Retirement benefits, including contributions and distributions, provided under this division shall conform to the requirements of the Internal Revenue Code, all regulations adopted thereunder and the Governmental Money Purchase Plan adopted herein. 
(Ord. No. 80-546, § 2, 8-24-99)  
Sec. 25-302. - Adoption of governmental money purchase plan and trust. 
In order to provide retirement benefits to employees and officers eligible for participation in the defined contribution plan and their beneficiaries in the event of death, the City of Warren hereby adopts and incorporates by reference, as if all provisions were set forth herein. The ICMA Retirement Corporation Governmental Money Purchase Plan and Trust, which document shall be included in the Code of Ordinances as Appendix B. 
(Ord. No. 80-546, § 2, 8-24-99)  
Sec. 25-303. - Amendment of money purchase plan document; notice; recommendation. 
The Governmental Money Purchase Plan and Trust shall be amended by city council in order to retain the plan's status as a qualified plan and as an exempt trust under section 401(a) of the Internal Revenue Code or for any other purpose specified in the plan document. The plan administrator shall be required to provide notice to the board of any amendment to the plan necessary to retain the plan's status as a qualified plan and an exempt trust. Prior to any amendment of the plan by city council, notice of the proposed amendment shall be granted to the defined contribution board who may provide its recommendation on the amendment to the city council. 
(Ord. No. 80-546, § 2, 8-24-99)  
Sec. 25-304. - Appointment or removal of plan administrator. 
(a)  The defined contribution board of trustees shall appoint the plan administrator to perform the duties and obligations as set forth in the Governmental Money Purchase Plan and Trust. The plan administrator shall serve at the discretion of the defined contribution board of trustees. Within seven (7) days of making an appointment or removal of the plan administrator, the defined contribution board shall notify the city council and the mayor of such action. 
(b)  In order to qualify for appointment as the plan administrator for the defined contribution plan, the plan administrator appointee must be: 
(1)  Currently administering a municipal defined contribution plan for a minimum of five hundred (500) participants; and 
(2)  At least a medium size company that employs at least twenty (20) employees; and 
(3)  A registered investment advisor under the laws of the State of Michigan; or 
(4)  A registered as a bank under the laws of the State of Michigan; or 
(5)  An insurance company duly authorized to perform services under the laws of more than one state. 
(Ord. No. 80-546, § 2, 8-24-99)  
Sec. 25-305. - Defined contribution retirement benefits. 
Participants in the defined contribution plan shall receive all retirement benefits pursuant to the applicable collective bargaining agreement or resolution, the adopted Governmental Money Purchase Plan and Trust and in accordance with the provisions of the Internal Revenue Code section 401 and the rules of the Internal Revenue Commission. 
(Ord. No. 80-546, § 2, 8-24-99)  
Sec. 25-306. - Non-application of Reciprocal Retirement Act. 
The defined contribution plan is not a reciprocal retirement system under the provisions of the Reciprocal Retirement Act, Public Act No. 88 of 1961, MCL 38.1101 et seq., as amended. 
(Ord. No. 80-546, § 2, 8-24-99)  
Sec. 25-307. - Participation eligibility. 
Officers, appointed personnel and employees of the City of Warren, Judges, appointed personnel and employees of the 37 th District Court are eligible to participate in the defined contribution plan, unless the employee is represented by a bargaining unit that has not agreed to participate in the defined contribution plan; however, the following persons are excluded from participation in the defined contribution plan: 
(1)  Any person whose services are rendered as an independent contractor; 
(2)  Any person, except an elected officer of the city, employed in a position that is part-time, part-time seasonal, co-op, temporary appointment or special assignment; 
(3)  Any person who is member in the defined benefit plan and elected to not transfer into the defined contribution plan. 
(Ord. No. 80-546, § 2, 8-24-99)  
Sec. 25-308. - Participant vesting. 
(a)  Members of the defined benefit plan eligible for participation in the defined contribution plan, who elect to forfeit membership in the defined benefit plan, irrevocably waive all benefits thereunder and elect participation in the defined contribution plan shall, upon transfer of the funds into the defined contribution plan, receive immediate vesting in the defined contribution plan. 
(b)  Officers and employees joining the service of the city, who are eligible for participation in the defined contribution plan shall receive vesting in the defined contribution plan according to the following schedule: 
One year of service 	20% vested 
Two years of service 	40% vested 
Three years of service 	60% vested 
Four years of service 	80% vested 
Five years of service 	100% vested 
 
(c)  All city contributions shall be allocated to the savings oriented model portfolio until the new participant is fully vested in the defined contribution plan. 
(d)  Except for participants who transfer into the defined contribution plan pursuant to subsection (a) of this section, prior credited service in the defined benefit plan shall not be utilized in calculating vesting within the defined contribution plan. 
(Ord. No. 80-546, § 2, 8-24-99)  
Sec. 25-309. - Transition rules for participants transferring from the defined benefit plan to the defined contribution plan. 
(a)  For members of the defined benefit plan who are eligible and elect to irrevocably transfer their interest in the defined benefit plan to the defined contribution plan shall have a lump sum amount transferred from the defined benefit plan to the defined contribution plan. The transfer amount shall be determined as of the date established by the collective bargaining agreement. In determining the transfer amount, the following provisions shall control: 
(1)  The amount shall be calculated by using the earliest eligibility date for normal retirement reduced to the present value at the time of the transfer. 
(2)  The actuary shall use the 1984 group annuity mortality table with a 50/50 unisex mix. 
(3)  Calculation of the amount shall be discounted to current age using only interest at 7.5%. 
(4)  Final average compensation shall be calculated as follows: 
• 0 to 3.0 years credited service 	• Current base pay plus 5% 
• 3.1 to 9.0 years credited service 	• Current base pay plus 10% 
• 9.1 to 18 years credited service 	• Current base pay plus 15% 
• 18.1 or more years credited service 	• Current base pay plus 19% 
 
(5)  Current base pay shall mean the base wages in effect on the date of conversion including all percentage increases, step increases and wage inequities. 
(6)  The transfer amount shall include interest at the rate of 7.5 percent for the first thirty (30) days and eleven (11) percent thereafter added for the period between the transfer date to the date the funds are actually transferred into the defined contribution plan. 
(Ord. No. 80-546, § 2, 8-24-99)  
Sec. 25-310. - Loans to participants. 
Participants may apply for a loan from the defined contribution plan pursuant to the Governmental Money Purchase Plan. The defined contribution board of trustees shall adopt written guidelines governing the granting of loans. The guidelines shall not conflict with the applicable terms of the Governmental Money Purchase Plan document, shall maintain the qualification of the plan and trust under section 401(a) of the Internal Revenue Code and shall be approved by the plan administrator. 
(Ord. No. 80-546, § 2, 8-24-99)  
Sec. 25-311. - Appeal of denial of claim for benefits. 
If any claim for benefits is denied, the claimant may appeal such denial, in writing, to the plan administrator pursuant to the procedure set forth in the Governmental Money Purchase Plan. 
(Ord. No. 80-546, § 2, 8-24-99)  
Sec. 25-312. - Termination of plan. 
The city council may terminate the Governmental Money Purchase Plan and Trust as provided in the plan document. Prior to termination of the plan, notice of the proposed termination shall be granted to the defined contribution board who may provide its recommendation for termination to the city council. In the event of termination of the defined contribution plan, no part of the trust shall be used or diverted to any purpose other than the exclusive benefit of the participants or their beneficiaries. 
(Ord. No. 80-546, § 2, 8-24-99)  
Secs. 25-313—25-319. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3A. - DEFINED CONTRIBUTION BOARD OF TRUSTEES 
 
Sec. 25-320. - Board of trustees. 
There is hereby created for the city a defined contribution board of trustees that shall consist of five (5) trustees as follows: 
(1)  The mayor, or a designee of the mayor; 
(2)  A councilperson to be selected by the council, to serve at the pleasure of the council; 
(3)  The city controller, or a designee of the controller; 
(4)  Two (2) members to be selected from and elected by the participants of the defined contribution plan. 
(Ord. No. 80-546, § 2, 8-24-99; Ord. No. 80-754, § 1, 3-28-17)  
Sec. 25-321. - Terms. 
The term of office for the trustees selected under the provisions of section 25-320(4) shall be for three (3) years. 
(Ord. No. 80-546, § 2, 8-24-99; Ord. No. 80-754, § 1, 3-28-17)  
Sec. 25-322. - Power and authority. 
The defined contribution board of trustees is vested with the power and authority to facilitate administration of the defined contribution plan; the retirement health savings plan; and the deferred compensation plan governed by the Internal Revenue Code, Section 457(b). The defined contribution board shall be authorized to: 
(1)  Appoint and remove the plan administrator(s) in accordance with the Internal Revenue Code and pursuant to the provisions of the defined contribution plan; the retirement health savings plan; and the deferred compensation plan; and 
(2)  To decide all questions of eligibility and plan participation for the defined contribution plan; the retirement health savings plan; and the deferred compensation plan; and 
(3)  To hear appeals by any participant, employee, officer or beneficiary for a denial of participation or payment of benefits; and 
(4)  To engage an independent qualified public accountant when necessary; and 
(5)  To engage an independent actuary when necessary; and 
(6)  To administer and keep all necessary records for any loan permitted under the defined contribution plan; the retirement health savings plan; and the deferred compensation plan. 
(Ord. No. 80-546, § 2, 8-24-99; Ord. No. 80-754, § 1, 3-28-17)  
Sec. 25-323. - Budget; expenses. 
(a)  Annually, the board shall prepare an itemized budget of the expected expenditures of the board for the next fiscal year. The budget shall be submitted to the city controller not later than the first Monday in February of each year. The city controller shall then submit the budget of the defined contribution board to the mayor following the required budget procedure. The city council shall approve a budget providing for the operating expenses of the defined contribution board. 
(b)  Member trustees selected under the provisions of section 25-320(4) shall not suffer a loss because of absence from their employment with the city while performing official board duties. A board member shall be reimbursed by the city for all actual and necessary travel and other expenses incurred in the performance of official duties as a board member.
