(Ord. No. 80-546, § 2, 8-24-99; Ord. No. 80-754, § 1, 3-28-17)  
Sec. 25-324. - Filling of vacancies. 
If a member trustee provided in section 25-320(4) ceases to be employed by the city, or if any trustee provided in section 25-320 shall fail to attend scheduled meetings of the board for three (3) consecutive meetings, unless in each case excused for cause by the remaining trustees attending such meetings, the trustees shall be considered to have resigned from the board and the board shall by resolution declare his or her office of trustee vacated as of the date of adoption of such resolution. If a vacancy occurs in the office of trustee, the office shall be filled within thirty (30) days from and after the date of the vacancy. Vacancies occurring in the office of trustee shall be filled in the same manner as the original selection as provided in section 25-320. 
(Ord. No. 80-546, § 2, 8-24-99; Ord. No. 80-754, § 1, 3-28-17)  
Sec. 25-325. - Meetings. 
The defined contribution board shall hold meetings regularly and shall meet on the first Wednesday of January, April, July, and October of each year and shall designate a time and place thereof. At any meeting of the defined contribution board, three (3) trustees shall constitute a quorum. Each trustee shall be entitled to one (1) vote on each question before the board, and at least three (3) concurring votes shall be required for a decision by the trustees. The defined contribution board shall adopt its own rules of procedure and shall keep a record of its proceedings. All meetings of the board shall be public. Special meetings may be held upon call by two (2) board members, with notice mailed or delivered forty-eight (48) hours before the special meeting. 
(Ord. No. 80-546, § 2, 8-24-99; Ord. No. 80-754, § 1, 3-28-17)  
Sec. 25-326. - Officers. 
The defined contribution board shall elect a chairperson, vice chairperson and secretary from its own members to serve a term of one (1) year pursuant to the procedure set forth in its rules and regulations. 
(Ord. No. 80-546, § 2, 8-24-99; Ord. No. 80-754, § 1, 3-28-17)  
Sec. 25-327. - Records; confidentiality; legal adviser. 
(a)  The city controller shall maintain all documents and records of the defined contribution board and shall maintain a record of all official action taken by the board. All information regarding individual participants' accounts shall be kept confidential, not subject to disclosure except by court order. 
(b)  The legal advisor to the defined contribution board of trustees shall be the city attorney, his or her assistant or an attorney designated by the board. 
(Ord. No. 80-546, § 2, 8-24-99; Ord. No. 80-754, § 1, 3-28-17)  
Sec. 25-328. - Appeal. 
A participant may appeal a denial of participation to the defined contribution board of trustees. The appeal shall be in writing and filed with the defined contribution board within sixty (60) days of the date of the notification of denial. The request for appeal shall contain a statement of the reasons supporting the appeal. The defined contribution board shall schedule an appeal hearing within sixty (60) days of receipt of the request. The defined contribution board may affirm, reverse or modify the decision appealed from. The decision of the board shall be final. 
(Ord. No. 80-546, § 2, 8-24-99; Ord. No. 80-754, § 1, 3-28-17)  
Secs. 25-329—25-335. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - INTERNAL REVENUE SERVICE QUALIFICATION 
 
Sec. 25-336. - Qualified status. 
The retirement system is intended and has been administered as a qualified pension plan under Section 401 of the Internal Revenue Code, as amended, and further the trust is an exempt organization under Section 501 of the Internal Revenue Code. 
(Ord. No. 80-580, § 1, 2-26-02)  
Sec. 25-337. - Limitations on benefits and contributions. 
The amount of annual benefits and contributions credited to a member in any given year shall be subject to the following limitations: 
(1)  Defined benefit plans. The maximum permissible annual pension benefit with respect to any member shall be in accordance with IRC § 415(b) which provides that such annual pension benefit shall not exceed ninety thousand dollars ($90,000.00), as adjusted for inflation, which for 2002 is one hundred sixty thousand dollars ($160,000.00) (the "dollar limit"). 
a.  Special dollar limitations. If the benefit is payable prior to age sixty-two (62), the dollar limitation shall be reduced to the actuarial equivalent of a benefit commencing at age sixty-two (62). In the case of any full-time police or fire employee, who is a qualified participant as defined in IRC § 415(b)(2)(G), there is no reduction in the dollar limitation. If the benefit is not payable until after age sixty-five (65), the dollar limitation shall be increased to the actuarial equivalent of a benefit commencing at age sixty-five (65). 
b.  In the case of an employee who has less than ten (10) years of participation in the plan, the dollar limitation shall be reduced one-tenth ( 1/10 ) for each year of participation in accordance in IRC § 415(b)(5). 
(2)  Defined contribution plans. 
a.  For limitation years beginning after December 31, 1986 the term "annual addition" means, for purposes for this section, the sum, credited to a participant's account for any limitation year, of: 
1.  Employer contributions; 
2.  Employee contributions, and 
3.  Forfeitures. 
b.  Annual additions that may be contributed or allocated to a participant's account for a limitation year will not exceed the lesser of: 
1.  One hundred (100) percent of participant's compensation, within the meaning of IRC § 415(c)(3), or 
2.  Forty thousand dollars ($40,000.00), as adjusted for increases in the cost of living pursuant to IRC § 415(d). 
c.  Valuation of investments. Investments of the plan shall be valued as of the last day of each plan year in accordance with the methods consistently followed and uniformly applied to determine fair market value and in accordance with the requirements of revenue ruling 80-155. Contributions to the plan, along with earning thereon, shall be distributed in accordance with the terms of the plan. 
(3)  Excess benefit payment. The retirement system shall not pay any benefit that would exceed the benefit limitations for governmental plans as set forth in § 415 and regulations, as amended. 
(4)  Compensation. As defined by IRC § 415(c)(3)(D) and Treas. Reg. § 1.415-2(d)(2)(i), compensation means amounts actually paid to the employee during the limitation year, including: wages, salary, professional fees, percentage of profits, commissions, tips and bonuses paid or made available to the member during the limitation year for personal services actually rendered in the course of employment, any elective deferral, and any amount which is contributed or deferred by the employer at the election of the employee and which is not includable in the gross income of the employee by reason of IRC § 125 or 457. 
(Ord. No. 80-580, § 1, 2-26-02)  
Sec. 25-338. - Distributions. 
Distributions from the plan shall comply with the requirements of Code § 401(a)(9) and the regulations thereunder. A member's interest in the trust must begin to be distributed by the later of (i) April 1 of the calendar year following the calendar year that the employee attains the age of seventy and one-half (70½), or (ii) April 1 of the calendar year the member retires. With respect to distributions under the plan made for calendar years beginning on or after January 1, 2001, the plan will apply the minimum distribution requirements of IRC § 401(a)(9) in accordance with the regulations under IRC § 401(a)(9) that were proposed in January 2001, notwithstanding any provision in the plan to the contrary. This amendment shall continue in effect until the end of the last calendar year beginning before the effective date of final regulations under § 401(a)(9) or such other date as may be specified in guidance published by the Internal Revenue Service. 
(Ord. No. 80-580, § 1, 2-26-02)  
Sec. 25-339. - Eligible rollover distributions. 
This section applies to distributions made on or after January 1, 1993. Notwithstanding any provision of the plan to the contrary that would otherwise limit a distributee's election under this section, a distributee may elect, at the time and in the manner prescribed by the retirement system, to have any portion of an eligible rollover distribution paid directly to an eligible retirement plan specified by the distributee as a direct rollover. The following definitions shall apply with regard to this section. 
(1)  Eligible rollover distribution. An eligible rollover distribution is any distribution of all or any portion of the balance to the credit of the distributee, except that an eligible rollover distribution does not include: any distribution that is one (1) of series of substantially equal periodic payments (not less frequently than annually) made for the life (or life expectancy) of the distributee or the joint life (of joint life expectancies) of the distributee and the distributee's designated beneficiary, or for a specified period of ten (10) years or more, and any distribution to the extent such distribution is required under IRC § 401(a)(9). For purposes of the direct rollover provision, a portion of a distribution shall not fail to be an eligible rollover distribution merely because the portion consists of after-tax employee contributions which are not includable in gross income. However, such portion may be paid only to an individual retirement account or annuity described in IRC § 408(a) or (b), or to a qualified plan described in IRC § 401(a) or 403(b) that agrees to separately account for amounts so transferred, including separately accounting for the portion of such distribution which is includable in gross income and the portion of such distribution which is not so includable. 
(2)  Eligible retirement plan. An eligible retirement plan is an individual retirement account described in IRC § 408(a), an individual retirement annuity described in IRC § 408(a), an annuity plan described in IRC § 403(a), an annuity contract described in IRC 403(b), an eligible plan under IRC § 457 which is maintained by a state, political subdivision of a state and which agrees to separately account for amounts transferred into such plan or a qualified trust described in IRC § 401(a), that accepts the distributee's eligible rollover distribution. The definition of eligible retirement plan shall also apply in the case of a distribution to a surviving spouse or to a spouse or former spouse who is the alternate payee under a domestic relations order. 
(3)  Distributee. A distributee includes an employee or former employee. In addition, the employee's or former employee's surviving spouse is a distributee with regard to the interest of the surviving spouse. 
(4)  Direct rollover. A direct rollover is a payment by the retirement system to the eligible retirement plan specified by the distributee. 
(Ord. No. 80-580, § 1, 2-26-02)  
Sec. 25-340. - Maximum annual earnings. 
For plan years beginning on or after January 1, 1989 and before July 1, 1996, the annual compensation of each participant taken into account for determining all benefits provided under the plan for any determination period shall not include any amounts in excess of the annual compensation limit (originally two hundred thousand dollars ($200,000.00) provided for in IRC § 401(a)(17) prior to the Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1993 ("OBRA "93") and adjusted for inflation in the manner provided by IRC § 401(a)(17). For plan years beginning on or after July 1, 1996, the annual compensation of each employee taken into account shall not exceed the annual compensation limit provided for in IRC § 401(a)(17), as amended by the Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1993 ("OBRA "93") (two hundred thousand dollars ($200,000.00) in 2002). This limit may be adjusted as required by federal law for qualified government plans and shall be further adjusted for inflation in the manner provided by IRC § 401(a)(17). Annual compensation means compensation during the plan year or such other consecutive twelve-month period over which compensation is otherwise determined under the plan. The cost-of-living adjustment in effect for a calendar year applies to annual compensation for the determination period that begins with or within such calendar year. 
(Ord. No. 80-580, § 1, 2-26-02)  
Sec. 25-341. - Actuarial assumptions. 
Actuarial equivalence will be determined on the basis of the interest rate and mortality tables adopted by the retirement system. Actuarial assumptions that will be used to determine the amount or level of any optional benefit forms will be the actuarial equivalent of the normal retirement benefit. Optional benefits provided under the plan shall be actuarial adjusted in relation to the straight life annuity. For purposes determining the IRC § 415 limitations, the interest rate assumption will not be less than the greater of five (5) percent or the rate specified in the plan for determining actuarial equivalence for the particular form of retirement benefit. The actuarial early retirement reduction and reduction of the dollar limit if the employee has less than ten (10) years of participation under IRC § 415 do not apply to income received as a pension or annuity as a result of an employee's personal injury, sickness or death and shall be administered in accordance with IRC § 415(b)(2), as amended. 
(Ord. No. 80-580, § 1, 2-26-02)  
Sec. 25-342. - Forfeitures. 
Upon a member's termination date, the value of any forfeitable accrued benefit shall be forfeited by the member as of the termination date. The value of such forfeitures shall be used to reduce the employer's future contributions under the plan in accordance with IRC § 401(a)(8). No forfeitures under the plan shall be applied to increase the benefits that any member or beneficiary would otherwise receive at any time prior to the time when the plan may be terminated. If a member whose employment has terminated does not retain a vested benefit under the plan, he/she shall no longer be a member or retain or earn credited service under the plan unless and until he/she again becomes an employee. 
(Ord. No. 80-580, § 1, 2-26-02)  
Sec. 25-343. - Military service. 
Notwithstanding any provision of the plan to the contrary, contributions, benefits and service credit with respect to qualified military service will be provided in accordance with IRC § 414(u) and IRC Regulations. 
(Ord. No. 80-580, § 1, 2-26-02)  
Sec. 25-344. - Forfeitability of accrued benefits. 
An employee's right to his/her normal retirement benefit is nonforfeitable on the attainment of his/her normal retirement age as defined in IRC § 411(d)(3) and as defined and protected by Article 9 Section 24 of the State of Michigan Constitution. In the event of termination or partial termination of the plan, a member's interest is nonforfeitable to the extent funded in conformity with applicable sections of the Code and regulations thereunder. 
(Ord. No. 80-580, § 1, 2-26-02)  
Sec. 25-345. - Prohibition against reversion. 
The retirement system and trust have been created for the exclusive benefit of the members and beneficiaries as set forth herein. The funds thereof have been established for the benefit of the members and for the operation of the retirement system. No part of the principal and income of any of the funds of the system and trust shall revert to or be returned to the city prior to the satisfaction of all liabilities hereunder to all members, beneficiaries and anyone claiming by or through them. 
(Ord. No. 80-580, § 1, 2-26-02)  
Sec. 25-346. - Vesting. 
A member shall be one hundred (100) percent vested in his/her accrued benefit when he or she attains normal retirement age in accordance with IRC § 411(e) as in effect in 1974. 
(Ord. No. 80-580, § 1, 2-26-02)  
Sec. 25-347. - Actuarial reports. 
Annually, or more frequently, the retirement system shall obtain actuarial computations from an enrolled actuary as to the contributions necessary to fund the benefits provided by the plan on a reasonable basis in accordance with any applicable regulations, and such actuary shall certify such amounts to the employer. Contributions accumulated under the plan, along with the earnings thereon, will be distributed in accordance with the terms of the plan. 
(Ord. No. 80-580, § 1, 2-26-02)  
Sec. 25-348. - Qualified excess benefit arrangement. 
(a)  This section is enacted pursuant to Section 415(m) of the Internal Revenue Code and 2002 PA 100, the Michigan Public Employee Retirement Benefit Protection Act. 
(b)  A qualified excess benefit arrangement (QEBA) is established and shall be governed by a separate plan document and trust as established by city council. 
(c)  The amount of any retirement allowance that would exceed the limitations imposed by section 415 of the Internal Revenue Code, as set forth in the retirement system, shall be paid from the QEBA in accordance with necessary and appropriate procedures established by the defined benefit board of trustees for the administration of the QEBA. 
(d)  The QEBA shall be a separate portion of the plan. The QEBA is subject to the following requirements: 
(1)  The QEBA shall be maintained solely for the purpose of providing to retirants and beneficiaries that part of the retirant's or beneficiary's retirement allowance otherwise payable under the terms of the plan, but which exceed the limitations imposed by section 415 of the Internal Revenue Code; and 
(2)  Retirants and beneficiaries do not have an election, directly or indirectly, to defer compensation to the QEBA. 
(e)  If this ordinance amendment or any portion thereof is held to be invalid by any court competent jurisdiction, and said decision shall not effect the validity of the remaining provisions. 
(Ord. No. 80-615, § 1, 11-23-04)  
Secs. 25-349, 25-350. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - GENERAL RETIREMENT HEALTH, LIFE AND DISABILITY BENEFITS PLAN AND TRUST  
DIVISION 1. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 
 
Sec. 25-351. - Short title. 
This ordinance may be known and cited as the City of Warren Retirement Health, Life and Disability Benefits Plan and Trust ("plan and trust"). 
(Ord. No. 80-577, § 2, 12-11-01; Ord. No. 80-614, § 2, 7-27-04)  
Sec. 25-352. - Purpose. 
The plan and trusts herein established shall constitute "voluntary employees' beneficiary associations" (VEBA) under Section 501(c)(9) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as amended. The plan and trusts are created for the exclusive purpose of providing funding for health, and where applicable life and disability, benefits for those eligible to receive such retirement benefits under the City of Warren Employees Retirement Systems, their spouses and eligible dependents. The city intends the benefit expenses to be funded by the establishment and maintenance of a trust fund in conformance with all applicable federal statutes and IRS regulations, state and local law. 
Benefits shall be provided in accordance with the plan through policies issued by duly licensed commercial insurance companies; through a fund of self-insurance; or through any other lawful means of providing group health, life or disability insurance. 
The city reserves the right to enter into substitute contracts with commercial insurance carriers or with health maintenance organizations or preferred provider organizations in order to provide benefits under the plan. 
The city reserves the right to enter into insurance agreements, and to modify, alter or amend such agreements from time to time, with commercial insurance carriers, health maintenance organizations, preferred provider organizations or any other qualified entity currently existing or created for the purpose of providing such benefits. 
(Ord. No. 80-577, § 2, 12-11-01; Ord. No. 80-614, § 2, 7-27-04)  
Sec. 25-353. - Collective bargaining agreements. 
The benefit provisions of this plan incorporate the relevant provisions of the applicable collective bargaining agreements between the city and all employee associations. The provisions of a collective bargaining agreement relative to retirement health, life and disability benefits are controlling in the event of a conflict between the terms of the collective bargaining agreement and the plan. 
Nothing contained in this chapter shall be deemed to modify or limit in any way the rights of the parties to the collective bargaining agreement, any supplements or memoranda thereto, or any arbitrator's award to enforce the terms of the plan and trust, including the collection of any amount due to the trust and the right of the parties to sue for same. 
(Ord. No. 80-577, § 2, 12-11-01)  
Sec. 25-354. - Notice. 
Notice given to all interested parties shall, unless otherwise specified in this article, be in writing and personally delivered or sent by prepaid first class mail. The distribution or delivery of any statements or documents required under the plan and trust shall be sufficient if delivered in person or prepaid first class mail. 
(Ord. No. 80-577, § 2, 12-11-01)  
Sec. 25-355. - Reporting and disclosure. 
The city, the plan administrator and the board of trustees, or their respective designees, shall complete and file any reports as may be required by the Code, applicable federal, state or local law. A copy shall be provided to those eligible to receive benefits or participate in the plan. 
(Ord. No. 80-577, § 2, 12-11-01)  
Sec. 25-356. - Amendment. 
The provisions of the plan and trust may be amended by ordinance, adopted by the city council in accordance with applicable law provided the amendment does not alter the tax exempt status of the 501(c)(9) trust. 
(Ord. No. 80-577, § 2, 12-11-01)  
Sec. 25-357. - Interpretation; applicable law; construction. 
The plan is intended to qualify as a voluntary employees beneficiary association (VEBA) to provide group health, life and disability benefits under applicable provisions of the Internal Revenue Code, section 501 and sections 105, 106 and 162; the regulations promulgated under each section; and applicable federal and Michigan law. If any provisions of the plan are determined invalid or unenforceable, the remaining provisions shall remain in effect. 
Neither the establishment of the plan nor the trust nor any modification thereof, nor the creation of any fund or account, nor the payment of any benefits, shall be construed as giving to any person covered under the plan and trust or other person any legal or equitable right against the city, its elected or appointed officials or employees, the trustees or any individual trustee, except as may otherwise be provided in this article. 
Neither the city nor the trustees shall be responsible for the validity of any insurance agreement issued in connection with the plan or trust or for the failure on the part of the insurer to make payments provided by such insurance agreement, or for the action of any person which may delay payment or render an insurance agreement null and void or unenforceable in whole or in part. 
(Ord. No. 80-577, § 2, 12-11-01)  
Secs. 25-358, 25-359. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - DEFINITIONS 
 
Sec. 25-360. - Definitions. 
For the purposes of Article IV, the following words shall have the following meanings respectively ascribed to them: 
Base plan means the retirement health, life and disability benefits in effect at the time of eligibility as provided by the policy or the comprehensive program in place at that time. The city may elect to provide a substantially equivalent policy or program. HMO, PPO and other alternative plans are not included in the base plan. 
Benefit eligibility means the determination that an individual is entitled to receive benefits implemented by this plan pursuant to the eligibility criteria set forth in this article. 
Board refers to both the board of trustees of the general retirement health, life and disability benefits and the board of trustees of the police and fire retirement health benefits. 
Code means the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as amended. Reference to any section or subsection of the Code includes reference to any and all amendments. 
Collective bargaining agreement(s) means any written agreement, supplemental agreement or memorandum of understanding by and between the applicable collective bargaining associations and the city; or any final arbitration or judicial decision interpreting the written agreement. 
Collective bargaining associations means those associations which have negotiated to participate in this plan and trust. 
Contributions means the payment required to be made to the trust by the city to provide funding for retirement group health insurance, life insurance and disability benefits for those eligible to receive benefits from the plan. 
Dependent means dependent as defined in the applicable City of Warren Medical Benefit Plan; alternate insurance policy offered by the city; or future insurance policy or plan which may be provided. 
Disability plan means the City of Warren Disability Benefit Plan which provides disability benefits to individuals eligible under the defined contribution plan as provided in Division 4 of this article. 
Employees retirement system means the City of Warren General Employees Retirement System, as provided in Chapter 25, Article III of the City of Warren Code of Ordinances which includes the defined benefit plan, the defined Contribution plan, and the retirement health, life and disability benefits plan and trust. 
Insurance agreement means the health, life and disability insurance plan(s) and amendments, including any substitute insurance agreement with a commercial insurance carrier. 
Insurance carrier means a commercial health, life and disability insurance provider, health maintenance organization, preferred provider organization or other qualified entity designated by the city to provide benefits under the plan. 
Major life event changes means birth of a child, legal adoption, legal separation, divorce, legal guardianship, death, or marriage of a dependent child. 
Plan means the retirement health, and where applicable life and disability, benefits plan as provided by this ordinance, any subsequent amendments, the collective bargaining agreements, the medical benefit plan, insurance agreement(s), and other applicable insurance policy documents incorporated by reference into the plan. 
Plan administrator means the person, firm, corporation or insurance company appointed by the city to administer the plan. The plan administrator shall be responsible for the day to day operations of the plan and shall carry out the directives of the city. The city may appoint more than one (1) plan administrator. 
Plan year is a calendar year commencing on January 1 and ending on December 31 of each year. 
Qualified beneficiary means any person satisfying the eligibility requirements of the plan for beneficiaries including spouses and dependents. 
Retirement health care benefit plan means the City of Warren's self-insured health care benefit plan which provides retirement health care benefits to those eligible to participate in the plan pursuant to the applicable collective bargaining agreement which may include medical, dental, vision and/or life insurance benefits. 
Special entrant dependent means special entrant as defined in the applicable City of Warren Medical Benefit Plan, alternate insurance, or future insurance policy or plan which may provide coverage. 
Sponsored dependent means sponsored dependent as defined in the applicable City of Warren Medical Benefit Plan, alternate insurance policy offered by the city, or future insurance policy or plan which may provide coverage. 
Spouse means those individuals legally married on the date of benefit eligibility. 
Trust means the declaration of trust for both the general retirement health, life and disability benefits plan and the police and fire retirement health benefits plan established in Division 6 of this article. 
(Ord. No. 80-577, § 2, 12-11-01; Ord. No. 80-614, § 3, 7-27-04)  
DIVISION 3. - RETIREMENT HEALTH CARE BENEFIT PLAN 
 
Sec. 25-361. - Retirement health care benefits. 
The city shall provide retirement health care benefits to those eligible pursuant to the applicable collective bargaining agreements, implemented through ordinance, insurance agreements and/or the City of Warren Medical Benefit Plan. 
Those individuals eligible for benefits shall be entitled to the retirement health care benefits in effect on the date of benefit eligibility. The benefits may be provided under the same policy or program in place on that date or under a substantially equivalent policy or program as provided in the collective bargaining agreements. All individuals in receipt of health care benefits at the time of enactment of this plan and trust shall continue to be eligible for the same benefits. 
(Ord. No. 80-577, § 2, 12-11-01)  
Sec. 25-362. - Life insurance benefits included. 
The retirement health care benefit plan shall include life insurance benefits for those eligible and the nominated qualified beneficiaries provided in the applicable collective bargaining agreement in effect on the date of benefit eligibility. 
Subject to all applicable provisions of the plan and/or insurance agreements, each eligible to participate in the plan must nominate a beneficiary(ies) with the city. The death of an individual eligible to participate in the plan, must be reported to the city. Upon notification, the nominated beneficiary(ies) will be required to complete form(s) supplied by the city and submit certain required information to effectuate processing and payment of the death benefits to the nominated beneficiary(ies). 
Individuals eligible for life insurance benefits at the time of enactment of this plan and trust shall continue to be eligible for the same benefits. 
(Ord. No. 80-577, § 2, 12-11-01)  
Sec. 25-363. - Incorporation of applicable provisions; description of benefits. 
The collective bargaining agreements, insurance agreement(s) and/or City of Warren Medical Benefit Plan are incorporated herein by reference. A complete description of benefits provided under the plan, the insurance agreements, the City of Warren Medical Benefit Plan and the collective bargaining agreements, shall be maintained by the plan administrator. 
(Ord. No. 80-577, § 2, 12-11-01)  
Sec. 25-364. - Eligibility; health care benefits. 
Subject to applicable collective bargaining agreement provisions, eligibility for retirement health care benefits during any plan year shall be based on the following criteria: 
(1)  Member of the general employee or police and fire defined benefit plan- has met the age and credited service eligibility requirements for retirement under the applicable defined benefit plan of the city, terminated employment and commenced retirement benefits. 
(2)  Participant in the defined contribution plan - has met the age and credited service requirements for collection of retirement health care benefits as provided in the applicable collective bargaining agreement and has terminated employment with the City of Warren. 
(3)  Member of the defined benefit plan on a deferred retirement - has met the age and credited service eligibility requirements for retirement under the defined benefit plan of the city and has commenced receipt of retirement benefits. 
(4)  Retiree, retiree's spouse or dependent - on the effective date of this ordinance, a retiree, retiree's spouse or dependent who was eligible and receiving retirement health benefits from the city. 
(5)  Disability retirant - has been granted a disability retirement benefit under the defined benefit plan or this plan and has commenced receipt of disability retirement benefits. 
(6)  Spouse - is legally married on the date of benefit eligibility to the participant, member or retiree eligible to receive benefits from the plan who meets the age and credited service requirements for collection of retirement health care benefits as provided in the applicable collective bargaining agreement. 
(7)  Survivor benefits - a spouse, dependent, sponsored dependent or special entrant dependent of an eligible participant may be eligible for survivor health care benefits after the death of the participant provided: 
(a)  Defined contribution plan. the participant in the defined contribution plan, on the date of death, was eligible and receiving retirement health care benefits and had the right to name a beneficiary; and there is a surviving spouse or surviving dependent, sponsored dependent or special entrant dependent the participant named as beneficiary; or 
(b)  Defined benefit plan. the member of the defined benefit plan, on the date of death, was eligible for retirement health care benefits and had elected an optional joint and survivor beneficiary form of retirement and had named the spouse or dependent as beneficiary of the option benefit in compliance with section 25-220 of this ordinance; or the spouse or dependent qualifies for benefits from the defined benefit plan pursuant to section 25-225 or 25-226. 
(c)  The surviving spouse health care benefit shall not terminate upon re-marriage; however coverage shall not extend to the surviving spouse's successive spouse and/or dependents. 
(8)  Settlement agreement - retirement health care benefits were granted under a settlement agreement between the city and the participant. 
(9)  Court order - retirement health care benefits were granted by court order provided that satisfactory documentation of the order is presented at the time enrollment for benefits is made, provided however, the city reserves the right to challenge the validity of any court order produced and if such challenge proves successful then the cost of any benefits provided shall be reimbursed to the trust. 
(10)  No person shall be eligible to receive benefits under the plan who is a part-time, part-time seasonal, co-op, temporary appointment, special assignment employee or who is compensated for services to the city on a fee or independent contractual basis. 
(11)  In the event there is an issue as to eligibility for participation in the plan, the board of trustees shall decide who is eligible within the meaning of the provisions of this plan and trust, the applicable ordinance provisions, the collective bargaining agreements and established written city policy. 
(Ord. No. 80-577, § 2, 12-11-01; Ord. No. 80-614, § 4, 7-27-04)  
Sec. 25-365. - Commencement of benefit. 
Subject to all applicable provisions of the plan, the insurance agreements, and/or the City of Warren Medical Benefit Plan, retirement health care benefits shall commence on the first day the eligibility requirements are satisfied and enrollment for coverage has been completed. 
(Ord. No. 80-577, § 2, 12-11-01)  
Sec. 25-366. - Enrollment. 
Retirement health care benefits shall not commence until enrollment for coverage has been completed in compliance with the following provisions: 
(1)  The city shall give those eligible to participate in the plan written notice of eligibility and the right to enroll for coverage under the plan at least thirty (30) days prior to the date of eligibility. Enrollment for coverage shall be initiated on a form provided by and filed with the city. All information requested by the city, the plan administrator and/or the insurance carrier shall be furnished prior to commencement of benefits. The city, the plan administrator and the insurance carrier may rely upon the information as provided on the enrollment form and the information furnished. 
(2)  Qualified beneficiaries such as a spouse and eligible dependents shall be enrolled for coverage under the plan at the time the individual who is eligible to participate in the plan enrolls for coverage under the plan or as provided for in subsection (3). 
(3)  Anyone participating in the plan must report "major life event changes" to the city promptly in order to add or delete beneficiaries from their benefit plan. "Major life event changes" may impact eligibility for benefits. 
(Ord. No. 80-577, § 2, 12-11-01)  
Sec. 25-367. - Alternative policies or programs. 
The city, in its discretion, may offer alternative policies or benefit structures. In the event that the city chooses to offer alternative policies or benefit structures, those eligible may transfer from one (1) policy or benefit structure to another policy or benefit structure during open enrollment periods. However, any additional cost of the alternative policy or benefit structure cost shall be born by those who elect to participate in the alternative policy or benefit structure. The city will have no obligation to give notice of the open enrollment period for alternative policies or benefit structures. 
(Ord. No. 80-577, § 2, 12-11-01)  
Sec. 25-368. - Coordination of benefits. 
Payment under this plan shall not exceed the amount of the expenses incurred. For this reason, benefits shall be coordinated with other insurance policies according to industry standards and applicable laws. The following provisions shall apply in coordinating benefits: 
(1)  Reimbursement. If an expense is paid under the plan by the plan administrator and such expense is subsequently paid from any other source, in whole or in part, the individual who received the benefit, shall remit to the plan an amount equal to the duplicated benefits. In addition, the plan administrator may reimburse any other plan, person or entity which has paid an expense on behalf of anyone participating in the plan, for any amount which was payable under the plan. In such event, the plan, plan administrator and/or the insurance carrier shall be relieved of all further responsibility with respect to that expense. 
(2)  Subrogation. In the event any payment is made by the trust under the plan, the plan and the trust shall be subrogated and shall succeed to the rights of anyone participating in the plan or any qualified beneficiary, against any other plan, person or entity for recovery of health care expenses for which such other plan, person or entity is legally liable. All amounts recovered by settlement, judgment or otherwise, shall be paid to the trust. Those participating in the plan shall furnish information requested, shall execute and deliver any assignments, documents or other instruments requested, and shall secure the rights of the plan. Those participating in the plan shall take no action to prejudice the rights and interests of the plan hereunder. 
(3)  Effect of exclusions. The provisions of this section shall not be construed to create any independent right to payment of any benefit under this plan. Any exclusion or limitation contained in the plan, insurance agreement and/or City of Warren Medical Benefit Plan shall supersede any provision of this section regarding coordination of benefits. 
(Ord. No. 80-577, § 2, 12-11-01)  
Sec. 25-369. - Medicare eligibility. 
Upon attaining Medicare eligibility, those participating in the plan and/or qualified spouses may enroll for Medicare coverage, unless specifically required pursuant to the applicable collective bargaining agreement. Upon receipt of Medicare coverage and upon making application for reimbursement, the plan shall reimburse the basic monthly premium cost of Medicare coverage and shall provide complimentary coverage in accordance with the applicable collective bargaining agreement and/or the benefit coverage in effect at the time of retirement. 
(Ord. No. 80-577, § 2, 12-11-01; Ord. No. 80-614, § 4, 7-27-04)  
Sec. 25-370. - Termination of benefits. 
Except as provided in section 25-371, participation in the plan shall terminate as provided by the applicable collective bargaining agreement and/or the plan on the earliest date: 
(1)  Termination of the plan; or 
(2)  Non-payment of any required contributions; or 
(3)  Death of the individual receiving benefits under the plan; or 
(4)  The written election to cease coverage under the plan; or 
(5)  Upon becoming a full-time member of the armed services of any country; or 
(6)  In the case of a spouse or dependent, the date the spouse or dependent ceases to be a spouse or dependent as defined in the plan; or 
(7)  In the case of a spouse, dependent, sponsored dependent, or special entrant dependent, death of the eligible member who elected a straight life equivalent form of retirement benefit at the time of retirement; or if the eligible participant failed to nominate the required beneficiary necessary to ensure coverage of the spouse, dependent, sponsored dependent or special entrant dependent; or 
(8)  In the case of an eligible participant, upon that individual assuming employment elsewhere and the subsequent employer providing health care benefit coverage to the eligible participant which does not substantially differ from that offered by the plan; however, in the event the subsequent health benefit coverage is discontinued for any reason, including voluntary or involuntary separation of employment, the city's obligation to provide health coverage under the plan shall recommence immediately upon the presentation of proof of discontinuation; or 
(9)  As otherwise provided for by collective bargaining. 
(Ord. No. 80-577, § 2, 12-11-01)  
Sec. 25-371. - COBRA continuation coverage. 
Notwithstanding the above provisions of section 25-370, continuing health care benefit insurance coverage shall be provided under the plan to those eligible, in accordance with Internal Revenue Code provisions, Section 4980B, and Title XXII of the Public Health Services Act,"COBRA continuation coverage," as amended. 
(Ord. No. 80-577, § 2, 12-11-01)  
Sec. 25-372. - Conversion privilege. 
An individual who is no longer eligible to receive health care benefits under the plan, including a spouse, dependent or COBRA qualified beneficiary, may, if permitted by and in accordance with the terms of the plan, the insurance agreement, or the City of Warren Medical Benefit Plan, convert his or her coverage under the plan to an individual medical expense policy with the plan administrator and/or the insurance carrier, without the necessity of a medical examination and with no interruption in coverage. Application for individual conversion coverage must be made to the city and/or the plan administrator in accordance with the plan. A COBRA qualified beneficiary must be given notification of this conversion privilege during the one hundred eighty-day period ending on the expiration of the qualified beneficiary's COBRA continuation period. The cost of individual conversion coverage shall be paid solely by the applicant. 
(Ord. No. 80-577, § 2, 12-11-01)  
Secs. 25-373—25-379. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - DISABILITY BENEFIT PLAN 
 
Sec. 25-380. - Disability benefits. 
(1)  Participants in the defined contribution plan and trust shall receive disability benefits from the plan which are equivalent to the disability benefits provided in Article III, Division 2, sections 25-221 through 25-224 of this ordinance, as amended. The benefits provided shall conform to the applicable collective bargaining agreement 
(2)  Members of the defined benefit plan shall receive disability benefits from the defined benefit plan as set forth in Article III, Division 2, sections 25-221 through 25-224 of these ordinances, as amended. 
(3)  Division 4, disability benefit plan, does not apply to members of the police and fire retirement system. 
(Ord. No. 80-577, § 2, 12-11-01; Ord. No. 80-614, § 5, 7-27-04)  
Sec. 25-381. - Disability benefits eligibility. 
In order to be eligible for disability benefits during any plan year, a current employee must qualify as totally and permanently disabled by reason of a personal injury or disease pursuant to sections 25-221 through 25-224 of this ordinance; and 
(1)  Is a participant of the defined contribution plan and trust; or 
(2)  Is a member of the defined benefit plan. 
(Ord. No. 80-577, § 2, 12-11-01)  
Sec. 25-382. - Computation of benefits for participant in defined contribution plan and trust. 
The disability benefits provided pursuant to the applicable collective bargaining agreement to an eligible participant in the defined contribution plan and trust, shall be computed as provided in section 25-216 of Division 2 of Article III of this chapter of the Code of Ordinances, as amended. The city's liability for the disability benefit shall be offset by: 
(1)  Any amount which may be payable pursuant to the Workers' Compensation Act, if applicable; and 
(2)  By the lifetime annuity value of the employee's 401(a) defined contribution account, determined as of the effective date of the participant's disability-related separation from service. 
(Ord. No. 80-577, § 2, 12-11-01)  
Secs. 25-383—25-389. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 5. - ADMINISTRATION OF PLAN BENEFITS 
 
Sec. 25-390. - City administrative duties. 
(a)  The city shall be responsible for the performance of its duties as employer and plan sponsor under applicable Internal Revenue Code sections. The city may employ a plan administrator and/or insurance carrier who may be responsible for the administration and the payment of claims under the plan. The city may delegate all or any part of its plan administration responsibilities to the plan administrator and/or insurance carrier. Any delegation shall be done in writing. 
(b)  The city shall be responsible for complying with the code's reporting and disclosure requirements and for fulfilling such other plan administrative functions as are not specifically assigned to the plan administrator and/or insurance carrier. 
(c)  The city may contract one (1) or more persons to render advice with regard to any responsibility under the plan. Any fiduciary, agent, representative or other person contracted to perform services to the plan, shall be entitled to reasonable compensation and reimbursement for expenses actually incurred. Any city employee providing services to the plan shall not be entitled to any additional compensation from the plan and trust. 
(d)  The city shall furnish the plan administrator and/or insurance carrier any information required for enrollment under the plan; for the processing of terminations or other changes in coverage; and shall furnish to the plan administrator and/or insurance carrier such other information required for the administration of the plan. 
(Ord. No. 80-577, § 2, 12-11-01)  
Sec. 25-391. - Insurance carrier administrative duties. 
Each insurance carrier shall have the responsibility for interpreting and administering their respective insurance agreement; for processing and paying benefit claims thereunder; and shall provide the city with such information as the city may deem necessary to permit the timely filing of all reports required by law. The insurance carrier shall also provide a description of the benefits provided under their respective insurance agreement directly to all those participating in the plan. 
(Ord. No. 80-577, § 2, 12-11-01)  
Sec. 25-392. - Plan administrator duties. 
The plan administrator shall have the responsibility for administering the plan and for processing and paying benefit claims thereunder, and shall provide the board of trustees with such information necessary to permit the timely filing of all reports required by applicable laws or regulations governing the trust. 
(Ord. No. 80-577, § 2, 12-11-01)  
Sec. 25-393. - Benefit eligibility dispute determination by board of trustees. 
Any dispute as to benefit eligibility shall be referred to the board of trustees to determine applying the benefit eligibility requirements set forth herein. 
(Ord. No. 80-577, § 2, 12-11-01)  
Sec. 25-394. - Claims procedures for health benefits. 
A claim for benefits under the plan must be submitted in writing to the plan administrator and/or insurance carrier in accordance with procedures established and distributed in writing. The plan administrator and/or insurance carrier shall provide adequate notice to anyone whose claim for benefits under this plan has been denied. The denial shall be provided in writing and shall specify the reasons for such denial. Any dispute involving the payment of benefits shall be resolved by the plan administrator and/or respective insurance carrier administering the benefits under the plan. The plan administrator and/or insurance carrier shall afford a reasonable opportunity for a full and fair review of any decision denying a claim. 
(Ord. No. 80-577, § 2, 12-11-01)  
Secs. 25-395—25-399. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 6. - DECLARATION OF TRUST 
 
Sec. 25-400. - Irrevocable VEBA; establishment of trusts. 
The Internal Revenue Code, section 501(c)(9) exempts from taxation voluntary employees' beneficiary associations (VEBA) which provide health, life and accident benefits to its members. Based on this IRS authorization, the city hereby authorizes the VEBA and establishes two (2) VEBA Trusts to provide health, and where applicable life and disability, benefits to eligible members, participants and retirees of both the general employees retirement system and the police and fire Retirement system. The VEBA trusts shall be titled the City of Warren General Retirement Health, Life and Disability Benefits Trust, and the City of Warren Police and Fire Retirement Health Benefits Trust. The trusts shall be irrevocable and shall conform to all applicable provisions of the Internal Revenue Code. 
(Ord. No. 80-577, § 2, 12-11-01; Ord. No. 80-614, § 6, 7-27-04)  
Sec. 25-401. - Funding of the trust. 
(1)  For the purpose of creating and maintaining a pre-funded plan for the payment of health, life and disability benefits under the plan, the city shall pay to the trusts an amount consistent with actuarial valuations and calculations. In addition, funding provisions contained in the collective bargaining agreements shall be effectuated. 
(2)  Qualified beneficiaries shall pay to the trust contributions as required for additional benefit coverage elected by the qualified beneficiary. 
(3)  The board of trustees shall adopt rules and procedures for all payments made to the trust, and shall provide the forms required to accompany such payments, unless specified otherwise in the trust. All rules and procedures shall conform to all tax provisions of the City Charter and state law, 
(4)  The board of trustees shall adopt a schedule for all payments to be made to the trust. All payments made shall be immediately processed. The regular and timely payment of contributions is essential to the operation of the trust and the providing of benefits under various insurance programs. 
(Ord. No. 80-577, § 2, 12-11-01; Ord. No. 80-614, § 6, 7-27-04)  
Sec. 25-402. - Trust assets. 
Each trust shall consist of all contributions paid by the city; contributions paid by those participating and any qualified beneficiaries due to the election of additional benefit coverage beyond that provided by the city; all investments made or held under trust; all investment income, both received and accrued; and any other property received or held by the trust. Funds paid as a result of premium sharing required pursuant to applicable collective bargaining agreements and/or city policy, shall be paid as directed by the plan administrator. 
(Ord. No. 80-577, § 2, 12-11-01; Ord. No. 80-614, § 6, 7-27-04)  
Sec. 25-403. - Use of trust assets. 
(a)  All income, profits, contributions, forfeitures, recoveries and any and all monies, securities and properties of any kind at any time received or held by the board of trustees, shall become part of the trust when received, and shall be held for the use and purposes of the trust. 
(b)  The trust assets shall be used for the exclusive purpose of providing retirement health, life and disability benefits for those eligible to participate in the plan and may include administrative expenses for professional services and expenses related to operation of the trust. The trust assets shall not be used for or diverted to purposes other than to provide the health, life and disability benefits contemplated under the plan. 
(c)  No one participating in the plan shall be entitled to receive any part of the contributions made by the city or payments required to be made by the trust in lieu of benefits provided under the plan. 
(Ord. No. 80-577, § 2, 12-11-01)  
Sec. 25-404. - Trust liabilities. 
(a)  The city shall not be liable for payment to the trust of any amount other than those required of it by the trust and/or any applicable collective bargaining agreement. Neither the city, nor any trustee, nor anyone participating in the trust shall be liable for any debt, liability or obligation of the trust, except as provided for in this chapter. Any contribution improperly paid into the trust shall be returned by the board of trustees upon the request of the city or other payee upon discovery by the board of trustees that such monies have been improperly paid into the trust. 
(b)  No part of the trust or any benefit payable by the board of trustees shall be subject to alienation, sale, transfer, assignment, pledge or encumbrance by any person. 
(Ord. No. 80-577, § 2, 12-11-01)  
Sec. 25-405. - Termination of the trust. 
(a)  Subject to the limitations of this chapter, new employment benefit decisions may be made by the city or through collective bargaining which modify the provisions of the trust. The trust shall continue during such period of time as may be necessary to carry out the provisions of any ordinance or collective bargaining agreement requiring the trust and the fact that such collective bargaining agreements or employment benefit decisions are not extended shall not by itself terminate the trust, which shall continue for a period of time sufficient to wind up the affairs of the trust. 
(b)  In the event there is no longer anyone eligible to participate in the trust or receive benefits from the trust, the trust may be terminated at that time by the board of trustees, provided that the termination is not inconsistent with any ordinance or collective bargaining agreement. It shall not be necessary for the city or the collective bargaining associations to execute such an agreement for termination of the trust. 
(c)  Upon termination of the trust, the board of trustees shall forthwith notify the plan administrator and any insurance carrier providing insurance under the plan. 
(d)  In the event of the termination of the trust, the funds remaining after providing for all the outstanding obligations shall be used in a manner pursuant to and consistent with all provisions of the Internal Revenue Code. 
(Ord. No. 80-577, § 2, 12-11-01)  
Secs. 25-406—25-409. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 7. - BOARDS OF TRUSTEES FOR THE CITY OF WARREN GENERAL RETIREMENT HEALTH, LIFE AND DISABILITY BENEFITS PLAN AND TRUSTS 
 
Sec. 25-410. - Administration of plan and trusts by board of trustees. 
The general administration, management and responsibility for the proper operation of both the City of Warren General Retirement Health, Life and Disability Benefits Trust and the Police and Fire Retirement Health Benefits Trust, shall be vested in the respective board of trustees, consistent with applicable state and federal laws and regulations. A trustee or other fiduciary under the trust shall discharge his or her duties with respect to the trust solely for the purpose of providing retirement health, life and disability benefits to those eligible to receive such benefits. The trustees shall discharge their duties with the care, skill and caution which a prudent person, acting in a like capacity and familiar with those matters, would use in the conduct of an activity of like character and purpose. 
(Ord. No. 80-577, § 2, 12-11-01; Ord. No. 80-614, § 7, 7-27-04)  
Sec. 25-411. - Composition and operation of board of trustees. 
(a)  The general employees defined benefit board of trustees as composed pursuant to section 25-247 to 25-254 of Division 2A of Article III of Chapter 25, is hereby authorized to serve as the board of trustees for the VEBA trust entitled the general retirement health, life and disability benefits plan and trust. 
(b)  The police and fire retirement board of trustees authorized by sec. 16.1 of the City Charter and as composed pursuant to Public Act 345 of 1937, as amended, is hereby authorized to serve as the board of trustees for the VEBA trust entitled the City of Warren Police and Fire Retirement Health Benefits Plan and Trust. 
(Ord. No. 80-577, § 2, 12-11-01; Ord. No. 80-614, § 7, 7-27-04)  
Sec. 25-412. - Authority of the board of trustees. 
(a)  Consistent with applicable state and federal laws and regulations, the board of trustees shall have the power to promulgate rules and regulations for the day-to-day management of the trust; the investment of monies held by the trust; and to determine all questions regarding the interpretation of the trust. 
(b)  Whenever the signature of a trustee is required on any document, signature of the chairperson/acting chairperson and secretary shall be required. 
(c)  In the event of any suit brought against the board of trustees arising out of an act within the scope and powers of the board of trustees, or in the event of any lawsuit brought by the board of trustees as authorized by this chapter, the cost of defense or prosecution of such lawsuit shall be charged to the trust, and shall be paid directly from the trust, provided such costs are not incurred by reason of bad faith, gross negligence, or breach of a fiduciary obligation to the trust or to the beneficiaries thereof. 
(d)  The board of trustees may employ such clerical personnel or administrative personnel to perform administrative functions that are required in the proper performance of the trust. In addition, the board of trustees may, if they desire, contract with an administrator to perform such clerical and administrative duties as they may, in their sole discretion, determine is reasonably and prudently necessary to carry out the trust's activities and purposes. Under no circumstances shall said administrator have control or authority with respect to the management of the trust or its assets. The said administrator shall not be clothed with any type of authority or power which will constitute the administrator as a fiduciary. The administrator will not have the power or authority to act as an investment counselor or manager and will not be authorized to furnish investment advice. 
(e)  The board of trustees may utilize city staff for such functions as legal counsel, personnel, administration, accounting, banking and purchasing and will comply with all established city control procedures and policies related to these services. The board will annually reimburse the city for actual costs of these services as determined by a method jointly agreed upon by the board and the city. 
(f)  The city may, upon the request of the board, assign employees to assist in administration of the trust. When providing services to the board of trustees, said employees shall be subject to the supervision of the board. The board will annually reimburse the city for the actual costs of these employees as determined by a method jointly agreed upon by the board and the city. 
(g)  The board of trustees may employ investment managers to manage the assets of the trust. Each investment manager shall be registered under the Investment Advisor's Act of 1940, as amended, and must meet all applicable state and federal requirements to act as an investment manager. In addition, the board of trustees may appoint and enter into agreements with managers, banks or insurance companies to serve as fiduciary and may convey to such fiduciary the assets of the trust to manage and/or hold the assets pursuant to the directive of the agreement and in accordance with the provisions of Public Act 314 of 1965, as amended. 
(h)  The board of trustees may employ legal counsel with whom they may seek advice, consult with, require attendance at meetings and to otherwise represent the trustees in matters relating to the trust. 
(i)  The board of trustees may authorize the purchase of insurance for the trust and for the trustees to cover liability or losses occurring for any reason, including but not limited to, errors or omissions of a fiduciary, including trustees; however, in case of a breach of fiduciary obligation, the insurance policy shall provide recourse by the insured against the fiduciary, including the trustee or trustees involved. 
(j)  The board of trustees shall appoint an actuary who shall advise the board on the actuarial operation of the plan and trust. The trustees shall, from time to time, adopt such mortality and other tables of experience and a rate or rates of regular interest as are necessary in the operation of the trust on an actuarial basis. 
(Ord. No. 80-577, § 2, 12-11-01)  
Sec. 25-413. - Board meetings. 
Regular meetings of the board of trustees shall be held monthly at a time and place to be designated by the board. An annual schedule of regular meetings shall be adopted at the first meeting in January and shall be thereafter posted. All special meetings may be called by two (2) board members and all meetings shall be noticed and conducted in accordance with the Open Meetings Act, MCL 15.261 et seq. Three (3) trustees shall constitute a quorum at any meeting of the board. Each trustee shall be entitled to one (1) vote on each question before the board and at least three (3) concurring votes shall be necessary for a decision of the board. 
(Ord. No. 80-577, § 2, 12-11-01)  
Sec. 25-414. - Qualification of trust as tax exempt under Section 501(c)(9). 
The plan and trust shall be tax exempt and shall qualify under the Internal Revenue Code, Section 501(c)(9), and any amendments of the Code applicable to plans of this type. The trustees shall take no action nor make any determination inconsistent with any qualification or ruling of the Internal Revenue Service, an arbitrator or the courts with respect to the trust. The trustees shall have the continuing duty to propose to the city amendments to this article to the extent it becomes necessary to qualify said plan and trust under the Internal Revenue Code and to continue the tax exempt status of the trust. In the case of amendments to the Internal Revenue Code or changes of regulations by the Internal Revenue Service or the Labor Department, the trustees are empowered to take all action authorized by this article, federal and state law and regulations, to continue the qualification of the trust. In carrying out the purposes of the trust, the trustees shall have the following powers and duties: 
(1)  The board of trustees, in order to effectuate the purposes of the trust, shall be bound by the terms of the plan, the trust, all applicable collective bargaining agreements and shall comply with all applicable laws. 
(2)  The board of trustees shall establish a uniform system for the timely transmission of required reports and contributions from the city. 
(3)  The trustees, in accordance with the requirements of law, may direct an impartial firm of independent certified public accountants to act as agent of the trustees to examine the payroll records and reports as may be necessary. Such agent shall prepare a written report for submission to the board with a copy to the city. 
(4)  The trustees shall maintain, or cause to be maintained, proper books of accounts and records of and for the administration of the trust, including the minutes of all meetings, make them available for inspection at the permanent office of the board of trustees. 
(5)  The financial records of the trust shall be subject to the annual audit of the city. The trustees shall fully comply with all applicable statutory and municipal budgetary and accounting procedures and provide access to and/or documentation of all assets and liabilities of the trust and a resume of the operations of the trust for the preceding year together with such other data as may be required by law and/or as part of the city's annual financial report to the state treasurer. 
(6)  The trustees shall be authorized, pursuant to Public Act 149 of 1999, as amended, to invest the assets of the trust in accordance with the provisions of Public Act 314 of 1965, as amended. 
(7)  The trustees shall hold all the powers that are necessary to carry out the purposes of the trust and are generally available to trustees under the laws of the State of Michigan, except as limited by the trust and by federal law and regulations. 
(Ord. No. 80-577, § 2, 12-11-01)  
ARTICLE V. - RETIREMENT HEALTH SAVINGS PLAN (RHS) 
 
Sec. 25-415. - Retirement health savings plan (RHS). 
(a)  Establishment . The city shall provide retirement health care benefits savings plan to those eligible pursuant to the applicable collective bargaining agreements, implemented through ordinance, insurance agreements and/or the City of Warren Retirement Health Savings Plan. 
(b)  Administration; appointment or removal of plan administrator. The defined contribution board of trustees is vested with the power and authority to facilitate administration of the retirement health savings plan. The defined contribution board of trustees shall appoint the plan administrator to perform the duties and obligations as set forth in the retirement health savings plan. The defined contribution board of trustees is authorized to execute an administrative/recordkeeping service agreement. However, any agreement that imposes a cost to the city in an amount as set forth in chapter 2, section 2-337c(6) shall require council approval. The plan administrator shall serve at the discretion of the defined contribution board of trustees. Within seven (7) days of making an appointment or removal of the plan administrator, the defined contribution board of trustees shall notify the city council and the mayor of such action. 
(c)  Amendment. The retirement health savings plan document(s) shall be amended by city council in order to retain the plan's status as a qualified plan in accordance with the provisions of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as amended or for any other purpose specified in the plan document. The plan administrator shall be required to provide notice to the defined contribution board of trustees of any amendment to the plan necessary to retain the plan's status as a qualified plan and trust. Prior to any amendment of the plan by city council, notice of the proposed amendment shall be provided to the defined contribution board of trustees who may provide its recommendation on the amendment to the city council. 
(d)  Termination of plan. The city council may terminate the retirement health savings plan as provided by the applicable collective bargaining agreement and/or the plan document. Prior to termination of the plan, notice of the proposed termination shall be provided to the defined contribution board of trustees who may provide its recommendation for termination to the city council. 
(Ord. No. 80-754, § 2, 3-28-17)  
Secs. 25-416—25-420. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - THE DEFERRED COMPENSATION PLAN 
 
Sec. 25-421. - Deferred compensation plan. 
(a)  Establishment . The city provides the option for participation in a deferred compensation plan for eligible employees. The primary purpose of the plan is to provide retirement income and other deferred benefits to eligible officers and employees in accordance with the provisions of Section 457 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as amended. 
(b)  Adoption. The city council adopts and incorporates by reference, the deferred compensation plan(s) and trust for each approved provider as if all provisions were set forth herein. 
(c)  Administration; appointment or removal of plan administrator. The defined contribution board of trustees is vested with the power and authority to facilitate administration of the deferred compensation plan(s). The defined contribution board of trustees shall appoint the plan administrator(s) to perform the duties and obligations as set forth in the deferred compensation plan and trust. The defined contribution board of trustees is authorized to execute an administrative/recordkeeping service agreement. However, any agreement that imposes a cost to the city in an amount as set forth in chapter 2, section 2-337c(6) shall require council approval. The plan administrator shall serve at the discretion of the defined contribution board of trustees. Within seven (7) days of making an appointment or removal of the plan administrator, the defined contribution board of trustees shall notify the city council and the mayor of such action. 
(d)  Amendment. The deferred compensation plan and trust shall be amended by city council in order to retain the plan's status as a qualified plan in accordance with the provisions of Section 457 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as amended or for any other purpose specified in the plan document. The plan administrator shall be required to provide notice to the defined contribution board of trustees of any amendment to the plan necessary to retain the plan's status as a qualified plan and trust. Prior to any amendment of the plan by city council, notice of the proposed amendment shall be provided to the defined contribution board of trustees who may provide its recommendation on the amendment to the city council. 
(e)  Participation eligibility. The defined contribution board of trustees may provide a recommendation to the mayor and city council regarding amendments to the eligibility requirements. Any amendments to the eligibility requirements shall be done by city council resolution and as provided under the terms of the plan document. 
(f)  Loans to participants. Participants may apply for a loan subject to the terms in the deferred compensation plan documents. 
(g)  Termination of plan. The city council may terminate the deferred compensation plan as provided by the applicable collective bargaining agreement and/or the plan document. Prior to termination of the plan, notice of the proposed termination shall be provided to the defined contribution board of trustees who may provide its recommendation for termination to the city council. In the event of termination of the deferred compensation plan, no part of the trust shall be used or diverted to any purpose other than the exclusive benefits of the participants or their beneficiaries. 
(Ord. No. 80-754, § 3, 3-28-17)  
Secs. 25-422—25-430. - Reserved. 

Chapter 26 - POLICE[1] 
Footnotes:
