No business shall be conducted between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. 
(Ord. No. 80-673, § 1, 11-25-08)  
Sec. 30-44. - Display of sign; license. 
Every secondhand motor vehicle dealer business shall post in or upon in a conspicuous place on the business premises, a sign which legibly states the business name, occupation and business license. 
(Ord. No. 80-673, § 1, 11-25-08)  
Sec. 30-45. - Record of transaction. 
Each dealer in secondhand motor vehicles shall keep and preserve a book in which shall be legibly written in ink at the time of each transaction relating to the purchase, sale, exchange or barter of any secondhand or used motor vehicle in compliance with the Michigan Vehicle Code, MCL 257.251. 
(Ord. No. 80-673, § 1, 11-25-08)  
Sec. 30-46. - Wrecking, storage, open display; prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any licensee to cause any vehicles or parts thereof to be wrecked, dismantled or junked on the licensed premises unless the property is properly zoned and a valid certificate of occupancy has been issued for such purposes. 
(Ord. No. 80-673, § 1, 11-25-08)  
Sec. 30-47. - Inspection. 
The record of transactions, the business premises, and all articles of property received or maintained on the premises shall be open to inspection at all times during open business hours by a city attorney, a member of the police department, a prosecutor, or member of the state police. As a condition of doing business, a licensee is deemed to have given consent to the inspection prescribed by this subsection. 
(Ord. No. 80-673, § 1, 11-25-08)  
Sec. 30-48. - Licensee prohibitions. 
A licensee, agent or an employee shall not purchase or receive by sale, barter or exchange or otherwise, any secondhand motor vehicle: 
(a)  The licensee has reason to believe is stolen; 
(b)  From any person between the hours of 9 p.m. and 7 a.m.; 
(c)  From any person who is at the time intoxicated or from a habitual drunkard; 
(d)  From any person known by the dealer to have been convicted of theft or receipt of stolen property; 
(e)  From a person unless that person presents a valid driver's license, a birth certificate, a valid state identification card, or passport; 
(f)  From any person under eighteen (18) years of age. 
(Ord. No. 80-673, § 1, 11-25-08)  
Secs. 30-49, 30-50. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - PAWNBROKERS  
DIVISION 1. - LICENSE 
 
Sec. 30-51. - Purpose. 
It is the purpose of this article to regulate pawnshops in order to promote the health, safety, and general welfare of the citizens of the city and to preserve the character of the community. It has been demonstrated that pawnshops increase the rates of robbery, burglary and larceny. It has also been demonstrated that the number of pawnshops in a county is a strong and significant predicator of larcenies and burglaries. It is the city's intent to establish reasonable and uniform regulations to prevent the deleterious effects on both business and residential locations within the city causing crime and blight. The City of Warren implemented regulations and procedures relating to pawnshops in order to deter the trading of stolen property and related crimes in order to protect the citizenry and the residential and business locations in the city. 
(Ord. No. 80-753, § 1, 2-28-17)  
Sec. 30-52. - License required. 
No person shall carry on the business of pawnbroker, as defined in article I, without first procuring a license issued by the city clerk as required in this article and pursuant to the general licensing provisions of chapter 18. The license shall expire pursuant to the provisions of section 18-13 of the Code of Ordinances and shall not be prorated. 
(Ord. No. 80-673, § 1, 11-25-08)  
Sec. 30-53. - Internet drop-off store excluded from licensing requirements. 
The requirements of this article shall not apply to an internet drop-off store, as defined in section 30-1, provided the internet drop-off store complies with all provisions contained in section 30-3. 
(Ord. No. 80-673, § 1, 11-25-08)  
Sec. 30-54. - Application. 
Application for a pawnbroker license shall be made to the City Clerk on the form provided. No application will be accepted unless the following information is provided: 
(a)  Full name, address and phone number of the applicant and owner and any other names used by the applicant and owner in the preceding five (5) years. 
(b)  Name and address of the business to be licensed, including flea market location, if applicable. 
(c)  Name and address of all other pawnbroker businesses presently operated by the applicant and owner. 
(d)  If the applicant or owner is an individual, the date of birth; if the applicant or owner is a business entity, the date of birth of the representative/agent. 
(e)  The applicant's federal taxpayer identification number; the state employer identification number, if applicable; and a copy of the applicant's Michigan sales tax license. 
(f)  Written proof of identity, in the form of a driver's license or a copy of a birth certificate, state identification or passport. 
(g)  A statement as to whether the applicant has ever been convicted of, has pled guilty or no contest to violating any law in the conduct of a pawnbroker business or to receiving and concealing stolen property and, if so, the date and facts surrounding the conviction(s). 
(h)  The application shall be signed by the applicant, or if a business entity by the representative/agent, and dated. 
(i)  The applicant has paid the nonrefundable fee pursuant to section 18-18. 
(j)  The applicant shall provide a minimum of two bonds, each in the sum of one thousand five hundred dollars ($1,500.00), with at least two (2) sureties for a total of three thousand dollars ($3,000.00) in bonds, for the faithful performance of the duties and obligations of the business and for the payment of all costs and damages incurred by any person as a result of any violation of this article. 
(Ord. No. 80-673, § 1, 11-25-08)  
Sec. 30-55. - Issuance of license. 
(a)  Review. Prior to issuance of a license, the city clerk shall distribute the application for review and approval to the following departments. Each department shall review the application for compliance with this chapter and shall recommend approval or disapproval based on the review. The review shall be conducted and the application returned to the clerk's office within twenty (20) calendar days together with the department's recommendation. 
(1)  Police department. Shall conduct a background investigation, including criminal history check to determine if the applicant has been convicted of, pled guilty or no contest to any violation of law in the conduct of a pawnbroker business or to the crime of receiving and concealing stolen property and to determine the applicant is at least eighteen (18) years of age. 
(2)  Division of buildings and safety engineering. Shall review the application to determine whether the business location complies with the zoning district and any applicable locational criteria required by subsection 15.01(e) of the zoning ordinance; and if required, a certificate of occupancy has been issued. 
(3)  Mayor's office. The mayor's office shall review the application and recommendations of the police department and division of buildings and safety engineering. The mayor's signature confirms that the administrative departments have reviewed the application and recommended approval. 
(b)  Issuance. Once the city clerk has received approval from the above departments and further determined the application complies with all applicable ordinance requirements, the city clerk shall issue the license. 
(Ord. No. 80-673, § 1, 11-25-08)  
Secs. 30-56, 30-57. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - GENERAL REGULATIONS 
 
Sec. 30-58. - Compliance with provisions. 
Every person operating under a pawnbroker business license, whether as owner, clerk, agent, servant or employee shall comply with all provisions and requirements contained in the Code of Ordinances and all applicable state laws. 
(Ord. No. 80-673, § 1, 11-25-08)  
Sec. 30-59. - Compliance with other regulations. 
In the event the transaction is also regulated by the precious metal and gems provisions, the business is required to comply with all applicable regulations including additional licensing, fingerprinting and separate transaction reports that may be required. 
(Ord. No. 80-673, § 1, 11-25-08)  
Sec. 30-60. - Business location; not transferable. 
(a)  Location. The pawnbroker business license shall designate the particular place in the city where the person shall carry on the business, including a flea market location. New owners/businesses must obtain a certificate of occupancy from the division of building and safety engineering. 
(b)  Not transferable. The business shall be conducted only in the place designated in the license and the license is not transferable to another person or location. 
(Ord. No. 80-673, § 1, 11-25-08)  
Sec. 30-61. - Compliance with zoning regulations. 
The licensee shall comply with the applicable zoning regulations. The requirements of the zoning ordinance are enumerated as follows: 
(a)  Residential districts (R-1-A, R-1-B, R-1-C, R-1-P, R-2, R-3, R-3-A, R-4 or R-5 and any mixed residential zone such as a planned unit development or the downtown district). As regulated by the zoning ordinance, a pawnbroker business is not permitted in any residential zoning district. Further, all open storage of goods is prohibited in all residential districts. 
(b)  General business districts (C-2). Section 14.01(r) of the zoning ordinance permits the operation of a pawnbroker in C-2 zoning districts if the following locational criteria are complied with: 
(1)  The site shall be located more than one thousand (1,000) feet from the nearest lot line of any of the following zoning districts within the City of Warren: R-1-A, R-1-B, R-1-C, R-1-P, R-2, R-3, R-3-A, R-4 or R-5 and any mixed residential zone such as a planned unit development or the downtown district; and 
(2)  The site must be located more than one thousand (1,000) feet from the nearest lot line of any of the following land uses within the City of Warren: 
i.  Any public or private preschool, elementary school, middle school, junior high school, or high school; 
ii.  Any public or private child day care facility licensed by the State of Michigan; 
iii.  Any public library; 
iv.  Any church, synagogue, mosque, temple or building which is used primarily for religious worship, provided that buildings containing food banks, homeless shelters, emergency shelters, and similar uses shall not be considered a "church, synagogue, mosque, temple or building which is used primarily for religious worship" notwithstanding the fact that worship services may also occur on the property; 
v.  Any public park or public recreational area under the control, operation, or management of the department of parks and recreation of the city or any other federal, state, or local municipality, which has been designated for park or recreational activities, including recreation centers, parks, playgrounds, nature trails, swimming pools, athletic fields, basketball or tennis courts, pedestrian/bicycle paths, or wilderness areas. 
vi.  The pawnbroker business must be located more than one thousand (1,000) feet from the nearest structure used for a pawnshop or other secondhand goods business. 
(c)  Special land use . Approval of a special land use permit is required from the city council, after application to and recommendation of the planning commission, and under such conditions as the council finds the use meets the standards for approval set forth in section 22.14 of the zoning ordinance. A special land use permit is also required for the expansion of an existing pawnbroker business. 
All open storage of goods is prohibited in all general business zoning districts (C-2). 
(Ord. No. 80-673, § 1, 11-25-08; Ord. No. 80-753, § 2, 2-28-17)  
Sec. 30-62. - Hours of operation. 
No business shall be conducted between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. or at any time on Sunday. All licenses issued shall include the following statement: "No business shall be conducted between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. or at any time on Sunday". 
(Ord. No. 80-673, § 1, 11-25-08)  
Sec. 30-63. - Display of sign; license. 
Every pawnbroker business shall post in a conspicuous place in or upon the business premises, a sign which legibly states the business name, occupation and business license. 
(Ord. No. 80-673, § 1, 11-25-08)  
Sec. 30-64. - Written record of property received. 
At the time of receipt of any article of personal property or other valuable thing, the pawnbroker shall keep a written record of property received by way of pawn or pledge as required by MCL 46.205. Each entry in the record of property received shall be numbered consecutively commencing with number 1. The record shall be written in the English language and shall include the following information: 
(1)  A sequential pre-printed transaction number; 
(2)  A description of the article received; 
(3)  Any amount of money loaned on the article; 
(4)  The name, residential address and thumb or finger print of the person from whom the article was received; 
(5)  The driver's license number or official state personal identification card number, or government identification number of the person from whom the article was received; 
(6)  A description of the person from whom the article was received; 
(7)  The date and time the article was purchased or received. 
(Ord. No. 80-673, § 1, 11-25-08)  
Sec. 30-65. - Transaction form. 
(a)  Record required. Upon the receipt of any article of personal property or other valuable thing by way of pawn, the pawnbroker shall make a permanent record of the transaction on a form provided by the pawnbroker that substantially complies with the form described in subsection (c). Each record of transaction shall be completed in duplicate by the pawnbroker, legibly written in the English language, and shall contain all applicable information required to complete the record of transaction form under subsection (c). 
(b)  Copy to police. The pawnbroker shall retain a record of each transaction and, within forty-eight (48) hours after the property is received, shall electronically transmit one (1) copy of the record of transaction to the police department as required by section 30-67. 
(c)  Form. The pawnbroker shall use the following record of transaction form in an eight and one-half by 11-inch size: 
 
 
(Ord. No. 80-673, § 1, 11-25-08)  
Sec. 30-66. - Inspection. 
The record of transactions, the business premises, and all articles of property received or maintained on the premises shall be open to inspection at all times during open business hours by a city attorney, a member of the police department, a prosecutor, or member of the state police. As a condition of doing business, a licensee is deemed to have given consent to the inspection prescribed by this subsection. The record of transactions shall not be open to inspection by the general public. 
(Ord. No. 80-673, § 1, 11-25-08)  
Sec. 30-67. - Copy of record of transactions for police. 
(a)  [Submittal requirements.] Each day, the licensee shall transmit by electronic means a legible and correct copy of the record of transactions maintained from the previous week to the police department. The record of transactions transmitted to the police department shall contain a statement verifying that the copy is a true and accurate copy of the record of transactions and shall be dated and signed by the licensee or agent. 
(b)  Format required. The transmission of the information required shall be provided in an electronic format as required by the police department. Any costs incurred to utilize the electronic format required shall be borne by the licensee. 
(Ord. No. 80-673, § 1, 11-25-08)  
Sec. 30-68. - Purchaser's memorandum of pawn; contents. 
At the time of a loan, a pawnbroker shall deliver to the person pawning or pledging any article a memorandum or note signed by him or her, containing all the information required to be included in the written record of property received. A charge shall not be made or received by the pawnbroker for the entry, memorandum, or note. The memorandum or note shall be consecutively numbered and upon its back shall be printed in English in 12-point type the following: 
"If interest or charges in excess of three (3) percent per month, plus storage charges provided in this document, are asked or received, this loan is void and of no effect; and the borrower cannot be made to pay back the money loaned, any interest on the loan, or any charges or any part of the charges, and the pawnbroker loses all right to the possession of the goods, article, or thing pawned, and shall surrender the item to the borrower or pawner upon due demand for the item." 
(Ord. No. 80-673, § 1, 11-25-08)  
Sec. 30-69. - Interest on loans; rate; storage and usage fees. 
(a)  Interest. A pawnbroker may charge a rate of interest not to exceed three (3) percent per month upon any loan and is not required to accept any interest less than fifty cents ($.50) on a single loan. A pawnbroker or the pawnbroker's agent or employee shall not charge or receive interest on the loan in excess of this amount. Interest on any loan is not payable in advance and shall be computed on unpaid monthly balances without compounding. 
(b)  Storage fee. A pawnbroker may also charge one dollar ($1.00) per month or fraction of a month for the storage of unencumbered personal property under any single pledge or pawn. 
(c)  Usage fee. A pawnbroker may charge one dollar ($1.00) per month or fraction of a month for a usage fee for unencumbered personal property pawned or pledged and used by the pawner during the term of the pawn or pledge. A usage fee charged under this subsection is not considered interest. 
(d)  Fees limited. A pawnbroker is not entitled to any examination fee and shall not make any charge in excess of the amounts provided for in this section. 
(Ord. No. 80-673, § 1, 11-25-08)  
Sec. 30-70. - Title to item; sale of pawned property. 
(a)  Title. Title to the item pledged or pawned vests in the pawnbroker upon the expiration of three (3) months or of any period beyond three (3) months agreed upon by the parties if the borrower has not paid the debt, interest, and charges on the item pledged or pawned. 
(b)  Sale. A pawnbroker shall not sell any article pawned or pledged until the item has remained in his or her possession for at least three (3) months. 
(Ord. No. 80-673, § 1, 11-25-08)  
Sec. 30-71. - Payment before sale. 
If at any time before the sale of the item pledged or pawned, the borrower pays or tenders to the pawnbroker the debt, the interest and all charges due on the item, that payment or tender reinvests the pawner with the title and right of possession to the property pledged. 
(Ord. No. 80-673, § 1, 11-25-08)  
Sec. 30-72. - Usage agreement. 
A pawnbroker may agree in writing, after pledged or pawned unencumbered personal property has been deposited with the pawnbroker, to allow the pawner to maintain possession and use of the pledged or pawned unencumbered personal property during the term of the pawn or pledge transaction. The agreement may also include the payment of a usage fee under section 30-69. A pawnbroker may take possession of the pledged or pawned property pursuant to section 9609 of the Uniform Commercial Code, MCL 440.9609. 
(Ord. No. 80-673, § 1, 11-25-08)  
Sec. 30-73. - Licensee prohibitions. 
A pawnbroker, agent or an employee shall not: 
(a)  Deface, scratch, obliterate, melt, separate, or break into parts any article or thing received by pawn or pledge, or in any manner cause, or cause others to do anything that renders it difficult to determine, destroys or tends to destroy the identity of the article or thing; 
(b)  Accept by way of pledge, pawn, purchase, or exchange any article or thing that customarily bears a manufacturer's serial number or other identifying insignia unless the number or insignia is plainly visible on the article or thing; 
(c)  Accept by way of pledge, pawn, purchase, or exchange any article or thing that the licensee has reason to believe is stolen; 
(d)  Accept by way of pledge, pawn, purchase, or exchange any article or thing from any person between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m.; or at any time on Sunday; 
(e)  Accept by way of pledge, pawn, purchase, or exchange any article or thing from any person who is at the time intoxicated or from a habitual drunkard; 
(f)  Accept by way of pledge, pawn, purchase, or exchange any article or thing from a person unless that person presents a valid driver's license, a valid state personal identification card, or official government identification which includes photographic identification; 
(g)  Accept by way of pledge, pawn, purchase, or exchange any article or thing that from any person under eighteen (18) years of age. 
(Ord. No. 80-673, § 1, 11-25-08)  
Secs. 30-74—30-76. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - PENALTY 
 
Sec. 30-77. - Pawnbroker penalty. 
Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of the pawnbroker article, whether as owner, or as clerk, agent, servant or employee, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction shall be fined not less than twenty-five dollars ($25.00) nor more than one hundred dollars ($100.00), or by imprisonment in the county jail not less than ten (10) days nor more than three (3) months, or by both plus costs and other sanctions as determined by the court. 
(Ord. No. 80-673, § 1, 11-25-08)  
Sec. 30-78. - General penalty. 
The violation of any provision of this chapter, other than article IV regulating pawnbrokers, by any person, whether as owner, or as clerk, agent, servant or employee, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor which, upon conviction, shall be punished by a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisonment for a term not to exceed ninety (90) days in jail, or both plus costs and other sanctions for each violation. 
(Ord. No. 80-673, § 1, 11-25-08)  
Sec. 30-79. - Revocation of license. 
Upon the conviction of any licensee, or of any clerk, agent, servant, or employee of the licensee for violation of any provision of this chapter, the license issued pursuant to this chapter, shall be revoked as provided in section 18-12 of the Code of Ordinances and upon entry of a conviction such person shall not be permitted to carry on a secondhand goods or pawnbroker business within this city for a period of one (1) year after that conviction. 
(Ord. No. 80-673, § 1, 11-25-08)  
Chapter 31 - SIGN ERECTORS AND SIGN PERMIT FEES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 80-494, § 1, adopted March 12, 1996, repealed former Ch. 31, §§ 31-1—31-23, relative to signs, and § 3 of said ordinance enacted a new Ch. 31 to read as herein set out. The provisions of former Ch. 31 derived from Code 1967, §§ 6-701—6-722, 7-131; Ord. No. 80-358, adopted June 14, 1988; Ord. No. 80-391, adopted June 11, 1991; Ord. No. 80-392, adopted June 25, 1991; Ord. No. 80-393, adopted June 25, 1991; Ord. No. 80-443, adopted Oct. 26, 1993; Ord. No. 80-485, adopted Aug. 22, 1995. 
Charter reference— Authority to regulate signs and billboards, § 3.1(b)(2)(f). 
Cross reference— Advertising, Ch. 3; buildings and building regulations, Ch. 9; subdivision regulations, Ch. 35; zoning, App. A. 
State Law reference— Highway advertising act, MCL 252.301 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - LICENSING OF SIGN ERECTORS 
 
Sec. 31-1. - License required. 
All contractors, firms or corporations erecting, constructing, repairing or maintaining any sign or display structure within the city shall obtain a license to perform such work from the division of buildings and safety engineering prior to the commencement of any work within the geographic limits of the city. 
(Ord. No. 80-494, § 3, 2-13-96)  
Sec. 31-2. - License fee. 
The fee for a license required by section 31-1, shall be collected by the division of buildings and safety engineering in accordance with the fee schedule established by resolution adopted by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 80-494, § 3, 2-13-96; Ord. No. 80-608, § 1, 4-27-04)  
Sec. 31-3. - Application. 
The application for a sign erectors license shall contain the following information: 
(a)  Name, address, telephone number of the applicant; 
(b)  Whether the applicant is a corporation, partnership or sole ownership; 
(c)  Provide the names, home addresses and titles of all owners or corporate officers; 
(d)  Be signed by the applicant and notarized by a duly authorized Notary Public. 
Providing false information in the application shall be grounds for denial or revocation of a license. 
(Ord. No. 80-494, § 3, 2-13-96)  
Sec. 31-4. - Insurance. 
(a)  The applicant must procure and maintain for the duration of the license period, comprehensive general liability insurance in the following minimum limits of liability: 
Bodily injury: 	$250,000.00 for each person 
	$500,000.00 for each occurrence 
Property damage: 	$1,000,000.00 for each accident 
 
(b)  The policy of insurance shall also name the city as an insured. The policy of insurance shall be issued by an insurance company and in form satisfactory to the city attorney. The policy shall also provide for at least ten (10) days' written notice to the city in the event of cancellation or any material change. A copy of the policy shall be delivered to the city prior to the issuance of the license. If the policy of insurance is cancelled or materially changed, the contractor's license shall be immediately suspended until a policy of insurance acceptable to the city has been obtained. 
(Ord. No. 80-494, § 3, 2-13-96)  
Sec. 31-5. - Denial, revocation and suspension. 
Any license issued pursuant to this article, in addition to the other reasons enumerated herein, may be denied, revoked or suspended pursuant to the standards and procedures set forth in Chapter 18, section 18-12. 
(Ord. No. 80-494, § 3, 2-13-96)  
Sec. 31-6. - Penalty. 
Except if there is an administrative hearings officer vacancy as described in chapter 2.5, section 2.5-4(d), the violation of a provision of this chapter is a blight violation. The administrative hearings bureau shall punish a violator found responsible for a blight violation as provided in Warren Code of Ordinances, chapter 2.5, section 2.5-7. 
(Ord. No. 80-527, § 22, 1-13-98; Ord. No. 80-731, § 10, 8-11-15; Ord. No. 80-750, § 2, 2-14-17)  
Secs. 31-7—31-10. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - SIGN PERMIT FEES 
 
Sec. 31-11. - Plans and specifications. 
(a)  Before any permit is granted for the erection of a sign or outdoor display structure, plans and specifications shall be filed with the division of buildings and safety engineering indicating the dimensions, materials and required details of construction including location on the property, design loads and stresses, method of anchorage and electrical connection. 
(b)  All signs shall be subject to a zoning plan review and fee which shall be collected by the division of buildings and safety engineering in accordance with the fee schedule established by resolution adopted by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 80-494, § 3, 2-13-96; Ord. No. 80-608, § 2, 4-27-04)  
Sec. 31-12. - Sign permit fees. 
Any sign permit required by the Warren Code of Ordinances shall not be issued until the fee prescribed shall be collected by the division of buildings and safety engineering in accordance with the fee schedule established by resolution adopted by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 80-494, § 3, 2-13-96; Ord. No. 80-608, § 3, 4-27-04)  
Sec. 31-13. - Sign inspections. 
A fee for biennial sign inspections shall be collected by the division of buildings and safety engineering in accordance with the fee schedule established by resolution adopted by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 80-494, § 3, 2-13-96; Ord. No. 80-608, § 4, 4-27-04)  
Sec. 31-14. - Sign removal fees. 
A fee for removal of a sign, whether temporary or permanent, shall be collected by the division of buildings and safety engineering in accordance with the fee schedule established by resolution adopted by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 80-494, § 3, 2-13-96; Ord. No. 80-608, § 5, 4-27-04)  
Sec. 31-15. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 80-608, § 6, adopted April 27, 2004, repealed § 31-15, which pertained to erectors license. See also the Code Comparative Table.  
Chapter 32 - SOIL REMOVAL, DUMPING AND REGRADING[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 9; filling excavations for moved buildings. § 9-344; subdivision regulations, Ch. 35; regulation of soil, refuse or fuel carrying vehicles, § 37-631 et seq.; zoning, App. A. 
State Law reference— Soil conservation districts law, MCL 282.1 et seq.; soil erosion and sedimentation control act, MCI 282.101 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 32-1. - Soil defined. 
The word "soil," as used in this chapter, shall be top soil, sand, gravel, earth, or any other material proposed to be removed from land or used in filling land. 
(Code 1967, § 6-601) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 32-2. - Purpose. 
The purpose of this chapter is to promote the public health, safety and general welfare of the residents of the city and preserve the natural resources and to prevent the creation of nuisances and hazards to the public welfare, health, safety, well-being and general welfare. 
(Code 1967, § 6-602)  
Sec. 32-3. - Conduct of operations. 
If permission to remove, dump or regrade soil shall be granted, the owner or person in charge shall so conduct the operations that there shall be no sharp declivities, pits or depressions, and in such a manner that the area shall be properly leveled off, cleared of debris, and graded to conform with the contour lines and grades as approved by the division of engineering. 
(Code 1967, § 6-610)  
Sec. 32-4. - Top soil retention. 
The owner of the premises or the person in charge of the removal of soil, when permission has been duly granted, shall not take away the top layer of arable soil for a depth of six (6) inches, but such top layer of arable soil to a depth of six (6) inches shall be set aside for retention on the premises, and shall be respread over the premises not constructed upon when the rest of the soil has been removed, pursuant to levels and contour lines approved by the division of engineering. 
(Code 1967, § 6-611)  
Sec. 32-5. - Soil removal below building grade. 
The owner of the premises or the person in charge of the removal of soil, when permission has been duly granted, shall not remove any soil below the normal grade as established from the nearest existing or proposed street, when the building grade has been established and approved by the division of engineering. This regulation shall not prohibit the normal removal of soil for the construction of an approved building or structure when such plans have been approved by the division of building and safety engineering, a building permit issued, and a contract let for the building development. 
(Code 1967, § 6-612)  
Secs. 32-6—32-25. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - PERMIT 
 
Sec. 32-26. - Required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to remove any soil from any parcel of land lying within the city without having first obtained a permit for the removal thereof as provided in this article. It shall also be unlawful for any person to dump any soil in excess of fifty (50) cubic yards upon any parcel of land lying within the city without having first obtained a permit for the dumping thereof as provided in this article. It shall also be unlawful for any person to regrade the existing soil in excess of fifty (50) cubic yards on any parcel of land lying within the city without having first obtained a permit for the regrading thereof as provided in this article. 
(Code 1967, §§ 6-603, 6-614)  
Sec. 32-27. - Application. 
(a)  Application for a permit under this article shall be made to the director of public service and shall be in writing and contain the following information: 
(1)  Names and addresses of the persons making the application; 
(2)  Names and addresses of the owners of the land for which a permit is applied for; 
(3)  Full legal description of the land from which soil is desired to be removed, dumped or regraded; 
(4)  Estimated length of time removal, dumping or regrading activity will consume, and purpose for which the permit is desired. 
(b)  There shall be filed with the application a map of the premises under consideration, showing the contour lines and proposed contour grades resulting from such intended removal, dumping or regrading of soil in relation to the topography of the premises. 
(c)  Upon filing the application and map there shall be paid to the city treasurer a filing fee of fifty dollars ($50.00), which fee shall not be returnable to the applicant. 
(Code 1967, §§ 3-125(45), 6-604—6-606; Ord. No. 80-320, § 1(43), 5-13-86)  
Sec. 32-28. - Examination and approvals. 
(a)  The director of public service shall transmit the application and map under this article to the division of engineering. It shall be the duty of the division of engineering to examine the application and map, and make such investigation as may be necessary to enable it to properly approved or disapprove the application or map. In the event of disapproval, the application and map shall be returned by the division of engineering to the applicant along with its reasons, in writing, for such disapproval. If the application and map is approved, the division of engineering shall transmit the same to the director of public service together with its recommendations. 
(b)  The director of public service shall consider particularly whether the proposed removal, dumping or regrading activities would create or be likely to create a public or private nuisance, whether it would result in an unreasonable depletion of the natural resources of the city, whether such activity would create a hazard to the public health, welfare and safety, and whether the activity would create a place of danger, whether or not the proposed site is in conflict with any uses as prescribed by the zoning ordinance of the city, whether or not the issuance of the permit would tend to depreciate property values of the surrounding property, and such other factors as may bear upon or relate to the coordinated, adjusted and harmonious physical development of the city. 
(Code 1967, §§ 6-607, 6-608)  
Sec. 32-29. - Issuance; term. 
If, after due consideration, the director of public service shall be of the opinion that the proposed soil removal, dumping or regrading will not create conditions inimical to the public health, welfare and safety, and will not result in the creation of any sharp declivities, pits or depressions, soil erosion or fertility problems, depressed land values, nor create any drainage, sewerage problem, or other conditions of danger, permission to remove, dump or regrade the soil shall be granted. Any permission granted to remove, dump or regrade soil under this article shall be valid only for a period of one (1) year following the date such permission is granted by the director of public service, unless the date shall be extended by the director of public service upon application therefor. 
(Code 1967, § 6-609)  
Sec. 32-30. - Bond required. 
(a)  Before any permit for soil removal, soil dumping or soil regrading shall be issued, the owner or applicant shall file with the director of public service a corporate, surety or cash bond or letter of credit in accordance with the following schedule: 
(1)  Less than one (1) acre: Five hundred dollars ($500.00) cash bond or letter of credit. 
(2)  One (1) acre to five (5) acres: One thousand dollars ($1,000.00) cash bond or letter of credit for each acre. 
(3)  More than five (5) acres: Five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) cash bond or letter of credit and a corporate surety bond in the amount of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for each acre in excess of five (5) acres. 
(b)  The bonds or letters of credit shall be in a form which shall be acceptable to the director of public service. 
(c)  The bond required in this section is meant to operate as a guarantee on the part of the permittee to the city that work at the site will be conducted in such a manner as: 
(1)  To prevent any depositing by truck wheels of dirt on the surface of any adjacent streets to a degree that may create slippery road surface conditions or dust clouds; 
(2)  To assure level grading of dirt as it is hauled to the site; 
(3)  To assure maintenance of grade levels as approved by the division of engineering; and 
(4)  To assure certification prepared by a civil engineer or land surveyor showing that conditions of grade levels at the conclusion of the proposed grading plan which was previously approved by the city engineer. 
Failure to comply with any of these conditions will result in a notice being filed with the contractor by certified letter from the division of engineering, outlining the exact nature of the complaint and allowing seven (7) calendar days for correction. Failure to correct the conditions resulting in the complaint within seven (7) calendar days allowed will constitute forfeiture of the bond and consenting by the contractor to allow the city to enter upon the site or adjacent roadways with its forces or contractor to correct the condition and recover all costs from the bond fund as deposited. 
(Code 1967, §§ 6-613, 6-615)  
Sec. 32-31. - Display. 
The permit under this article shall be prominently displayed at all times at the site of the soil removal, dumping or regrading operation. 
(Code 1967, § 6-614)  
Sec. 32-32. - Penalty. 
Unless provided otherwise, the violation of any provision of this chapter is a municipal civil infraction which shall result in the assessment of a fine of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) or not more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per violation, plus costs and other sanctions for each infraction. 
(Ord. No. 80-656, § 1, 5-8-07)  
Chapter 33 - SPECIAL ASSESSMENTS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference— Authority for public improvements, § 3.1(b)(4); special assessments, Ch. 10; mandate for special assessment procedure, § 10.2. 
Cross reference— Streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 34; determination and procedure for repair and construction of sidewalks, § 34-54; paving of driveway approaches, § 34-56. 
State Law reference— Powers re special assessments, MCL 117.4a, 117.4b, 117.4d, 117.5. 
 
ARTICLE I. - PUBLIC IMPROVEMENTS (IN GENERAL) 
 
Sec. 33-1. - Definitions. 
The following words and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them: 
Cost when referring to the cost of any improvement, shall include the cost of surveys, plans, rights-of-way, spreading of rolls, notices, advertising, financing and construction, legal and all other costs incident to the making of such improvement, the special assessments therefor and the financing thereof. 
Improvement means any public improvement, any part of the cost of which is to be assessed against one (1) or more lots or parcels of land to be especially benefited thereby, in proportion to the benefit to be derived therefrom. Improvements initiated for sidewalks, trees and service leads shall be governed by Article III, except that any sidewalk and driveway approach improvement completed in conjunction with road paving shall be governed by Article I. 
Service lead means any instrumentality that connects an affected property, including a structure, fixture, or improvement on the property, to the sewage disposal system and that is neither owned nor maintained by the city. 
Sewage disposal system means all interceptor sewers, storm sewers, sanitary sewers, combined sanitary and storm sewers, sewage treatment plants, and all other plants, works, instrumentalities, and properties used or useful in connection with the collection, treatment, and disposal of sewage and industrial wastes, and includes a stormwater drain system under the jurisdiction of the city. 
(Code 1967, § 2-301; Ord. No. 80-557, § 1, 7-11-00; Ord. No. 80-582, § 1, 2-26-02) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 33-2. - Council authority. 
The city council shall have the power to make public improvements within the city and, as to public improvements which are of such a nature as to especially benefit any property within a district, the city council shall have the power to determine, by resolution, that the whole or any part of the expense of any such public improvement shall be defrayed by special assessment, in proportion to the benefits derived or to be derived. 
(Code 1967, § 2-302) 
Charter reference— Similar provisions, § 10.1(a).  
Sec. 33-3. - Authorized improvements. 
In addition to the other improvements which the city may make and finance, in whole or in part, by special assessments, the city may (1) install a boulevard lighting system on any street; (2) install and connect sewers and waterworks on and to property within the city; (3) install asphalt or concrete pavement in unimproved rights-of-way; and (4) replace existing gravel roads, or deteriorated asphalt or concrete roads, in public rights-of-way, with asphalt or concrete roadway. The city may finance these improvements, in whole or in part, by special assessments upon the land abutting thereon. 
(Code 1967, § 2-303; Ord. No. 80-619, § 1, 4-12-05) 
Charter reference— Similar provisions, § 10.1(b).  
Sec. 33-4. - Filed objections; vote required. 
If, prior to the adoption of a resolution finally authorizing the making of a public improvement to be financed by special assessments, written objections to the proposed improvements have been filed by the owners of property in the district, which according to estimates will be required to bear more than fifty (50) percent of the amount of such special assessments, or by more than fifty (50) percent of the owners of land to be assessed for such improvement, no resolution finally determining to proceed with the improvement shall be adopted except by the affirmative vote of six (6) members of the city council. 
(Code 1967, § 2-304) 
Charter reference— Similar provisions, § 10.1(c).  
Sec. 33-5. - Petitions; advisory not jurisdictional. 
The city council, in order to ascertain whether or not a reasonable number of property owners to be assessed desire any particular improvement to be made, may request and receive a petition therefor, or may receive such a petition voluntarily presented; but in either event such petition shall be advisory only and shall not be jurisdictional. 
(Code 1967, § 2-305)  
Sec. 33-6. - City engineer's report. 
Before determining to make any improvement, any part of the cost of which is to be defrayed by special assessment, the city council shall require the city engineer to ascertain the assessed valuation of all property affected by the proposed improvement, the number of parcels which show tax delinquencies, the number of parcels owned by public authorities, the number of parcels which are vacant, and to prepare, or cause to be prepared, plans and specifications therefor and an estimate of the cost thereof, and to file the same with the city clerk, together with his or her recommendation as to what proportion of the cost should be paid by special assessment and what part, if any, should be a general obligation of the city, the number of installments in which assessments may be paid, and the lands which should be included in the special assessment district. 
(Code 1967, § 2-306)  
Sec. 33-7. - Public hearing. 
(a)  After the report is filed under section 33-6, a public hearing shall be held before the city council, which hearing shall be held not less than ten (10) days after notice of the time and place thereof has been published in a newspaper with general circulation in the city and published in the county, and mailed by the city clerk. Notice of this hearing shall be sent by first-class mail to each property owner or party having an interest in property in the proposed district whose name appears upon the current assessment roll of the city, addressed to that owner or party at the address shown on the tax records. 
(b)  Cost estimates as prepared by the city engineer as provided in section 33-6 shall be open to inspection at the public hearing, along with proof of mailing as provided in subsection (a) of this section. 
(c)  At the time and place specified in the notice for the public hearing, the city council shall meet and hear any person to be affected by the proposed public improvement. The hearing may be adjourned from time to time by the council. Any person deeming him or herself aggrieved by the proposed improvement, may object to the proposed improvement by appearing at the hearing in person or by filing a written objection with the city clerk or the city council prior to the hearing. 
(Code 1967, §§ 2-307—2-309; Ord. No. 80-434, § 1, 7-13-93) 
State Law reference— Special assessment notices and hearings, MCL 211.741 et seq.  
Sec. 33-8. - Council determination. 
After the public hearing under section 33-7, the city council may, by resolution, determine to make improvement and to defray the whole or any part of the cost of the improvement by special assessment upon the property especially benefited in proportion to the benefits derived or to be derived. By such resolution the city council shall approve the plans and specifications for the improvement; determine the estimated cost thereof, determine what proportion of such cost shall be paid by special assessment upon the property especially benefited and what part, if any, shall be a general obligation of the city; determine the number of installments in which assessments may be paid; determine the rate of interest to be charged on installments, not to exceed the maximum lawful interest; designate the district or land and premises upon which special assessments shall be levied; and direct the assessor to prepare a special assessment roll in accordance with the council's determination. 
(Code 1967, § 2-310)  
Sec. 33-9. - Preparation of roll. 
The city assessor shall thereupon prepare a special assessment roll including all lots and parcels of land within the special assessment district designated by the city council, and shall assess to each such lot or parcel of land such relative portion of the whole sum to be levied against all the lands in the special assessment district as the benefit to such lot or parcel of land bears to the total benefits to all lands in such district. There shall also be entered upon such roll the amount which has been assessed to the city at large, if any. 
(Code 1967, § 2-311)  
Sec. 33-10. - Endorsement of roll. 
When the city assessor shall have completed the assessment roll, he or she shall attach thereto, or endorse thereon, his or her certificate to the effect that the roll has been made by him or her pursuant to a resolution of the city council (giving date of adoption of same) and that in making the assessments therein he or she has, as near as may be, according to his or her best judgment, conformed in all respects to the directions contained in the resolution, and to the Charter and the provisions of this chapter. Thereupon he or she shall present the same to the city council. 
(Code 1967, § 2-312)  
Sec. 33-11. - Meeting to review and confirm roll. 
Upon receipt of the special assessment roll the city council shall order it filed in the office of the city clerk for public examination; and shall fix the time and place when it will meet to review and confirm such roll, which meeting shall be held not less than ten (10) days after notice thereof has been sent by the city clerk. Notice of this hearing shall be sent by first-class mail to any property owner or party having an interest in property in the proposed district whose name appears upon the current assessment roll, addressed to that owner or party at the address shown on the tax records. The notice shall specify the time and place of the meeting. The city council may, in its discretion, publish notice of the meeting not less than ten (10) days prior to date of the meeting. 
(Code 1967, § 2-313; Ord. No. 80-434, § 2, 7-13-93) 
State Law reference— Special assessment notices and hearings, MCL 211.741 et seq.  
Sec. 33-12. - Protesting the proposed assessment. 
Any owner or party having an interest in the property to be assessed, or his or her agent, may protest the proposed special assessment by appearing at the hearing described in section 33-11 in person or by filing his or her objections in writing with the city clerk or city council prior to the close of that hearing. The city council shall maintain a record of all parties who protest the special assessment. 
(Code 1967, § 2-314; Ord. No. 80-434, § 3, 7-13-93)  
Sec. 33-13. - Confirmation of roll. 
The city council shall meet and review the special assessment roll at the time and place appointed, or at an adjourned date therefor, and shall consider any objections thereto. The city council may correct the roll as to any assessment or description of any lot or parcel of land, or other errors appearing therein. Any changes made in the roll shall be noted in the council's minutes. After the hearing and review the council may confirm such special assessment roll with such corrections as it may have made, if any, or may refer it back to the assessor for revision or may annul it and any proceedings in connection therewith. Any such corrections and changes made by the assessor shall be reviewed by the city council in the same manner as the original assessment. The city council shall endorse the date of confirmation upon each special assessment roll. The roll shall, upon confirmation, be final and conclusive. 
(Code 1967, §§ 2-315, 2-316; Ord. No. 80-434, § 4, 7-13-93)  
Sec. 33-14. - Attachment of roll. 
All special assessments contained in any special assessment roll, including any part thereof deferred as to payment, shall, from the date of confirmation of the roll, constitute a lien upon the respective lots or parcels of land assessed and until paid shall be a charge against the respective owners of the several lots and parcels of land and a debt to the city from the persons to whom they are assessed. The lien shall be of the same character and effect as the lien created by the Charter for city taxes and shall include accrued interest and penalties. No judgment or decree, nor any act of the city council vacating a special assessment, shall destroy or impair the lien of the city upon the premises assessed for the amount of the assessment as may be equitably charged against the same, or as by a regular mode of proceeding might be lawfully assessed thereon. All special assessments shall become due upon confirmation of the special assessment roll or in annual installments not to exceed thirty (30) in number as the city council may determine at the time of confirmation, and if in annual installments, the city council shall determine the first installment to be due on the following July first and subsequent installments on July first of succeeding years. 
(Code 1967, § 2-317) 
Charter reference— Lien for special assessments, § 10.5(a).  
Sec. 33-15. - Transmission of roll for collection. 
The assessment roll shall be transmitted to the city treasurer for collection immediately after its confirmation. The city treasurer shall give notice by one (1) publication in a newspaper that the special assessment roll (identifying it) has been filed in his or her office and specifying when and where payments may be made thereon. He or she shall mail statements of the several assessments to the respective owners, as indicated by the records of the city assessor, of the several lots and parcels of land assessed, stating the amount of the assessment and the manner in which it may be paid; provided, however, that failure to mail or receive if mailed any such statement shall not invalidate the assessment or entitle the owner to an extension of time within which to pay the assessment. 
(Code 1967, § 2-318) 
Charter reference— Collection of special assessments, § 10.5(b).  
Sec. 33-16. - Transmission of roll to assessor; installments. 
The city treasurer shall transmit such roll to the city assessor with all payments upon assessments noted thereon. The city assessor shall then divide any remaining balance of each assessment into such number of equal installments as shall have been fixed by the city council; provided, that if such division operates to make any installment less than ten dollars ($10.00), then the city assessor shall reduce the number of installments so that each installment shall be above and as near to ten dollars ($10.00) as possible. 
(Code 1967, § 2-319)  
Sec. 33-17. - Spreading installments on city tax roll. 
The first installment shall be spread upon the next city tax roll in a column headed "Special Assessments," together with interest upon all unpaid installments from such date as may be determined by the city council to the first day of July of the year in which the tax roll is made. Thereafter one (1) installment shall be spread upon each annual tax roll, together with one (1) year's interest upon all unpaid installments; provided, that when any annual installment shall have been prepaid as hereinafter provided, then there shall be spread upon the tax roll for such year only the interest upon all unpaid installments. 
(Code 1967, § 2-320)  
Sec. 33-18. - Collection of installments by city treasurer; return to county treasurer. 
After each installment has been placed on the tax rolls, the same shall be collected by the city treasurer with the same rights and remedies, and the same penalties, interest and collection fees, as provided in the Charter for the collection of taxes, and shall be due and payable on the first day of July of the fiscal year in which levied. All such assessment installments which are paid on or before the thirty-first day of August of such year shall be collected by the city treasurer without the addition of any fee or charge for the collection thereof. Provided, that at the election of the taxpayer he or she may pay one-half of the assessment installment on or before the thirty-first day of August of such year to the city treasurer without the addition of any fee or charge for collection thereof, and provided that the balance of the assessment installment, if one-half was paid on or before the thirty-first day of August, shall be due and payable on the first day of December of such year, provided further that the taxpayer may pay the balance of the assessment installment by the thirty-first day of January of the following year to the city treasurer without the addition of any fee or charge for collection thereof, and provided further that if the taxpayer fails to pay the first one-half by the specified date, the half payment option is void, payment thereafter must be made on the full amount subject to a collection fee on the assessment installment of one (1) percent during the month of September and an additional one-half of one percent per month during each and every month or fraction of a month which shall elapse thereafter before the payment of such assessment installment is made, until the last day of February next following the date that such assessment installments become due and payable; and provided further, that if the taxpayer fails to pay the second half payment by the thirty-first day of January, payment thereafter will be subject to the above fees on the amount due. Upon all city assessments returned to the county treasurer upon any delinquent tax roll, a charge of three and one-half (3½) percent shall be added and the same shall be collected by the county treasurer in like manner as and together with the taxes, charges and assessments so returned. 
(Code 1967, § 2-321)  
Sec. 33-19. - Advance payments. 
Any person desiring to pay any installment in advance shall first secure the proper statement from the city assessor to permit the city treasurer to compute the amount to be paid. The city treasurer shall report to the city assessor all advance payments on installments so that the city assessor shall have such information before spreading installments on the next city tax roll. 
(Code 1967, § 2-322)  
Sec. 33-20. - Completed improvements; certification of costs. 
Upon completion of the improvement and the payment of the cost thereof, the city engineer shall certify to the city council the total cost of the improvement, together with the amount of the original roll for the improvement. 
(Code 1967, § 2-323)  
Sec. 33-21. - Insufficient assessments; additional assessment authorized. 
Should the assessments in any special assessment roll, including the amount assessed to the city at large, prove insufficient for any reason to pay the cost of the improvement for which they were made, then the city council shall make additional assessments against the city and the several lots and parcels of land, in the same ratio as the original assessments, to supply the deficiency; but the total amount assessed against any lot or parcel of land shall not exceed the value of the benefits received from the improvement, provided that the additional pro rata assessment shall not exceed twenty-five (25) percent of the assessment as originally confirmed unless a meeting of the city council be held to review such additional assessment, for which meeting notices shall be mailed as provided in the case of review of the original special assessment roll. 
(Code 1967, § 2-324) 
Charter reference— Similar provisions, § 10.3(a).  
Sec. 33-22. - Disposition of excessive assessments. 
The excess by which any special assessment proves larger than the actual cost of the improvement and expenses incidental thereto may be placed in the general fund of the city if such excess is five (5) percent or less of the assessment, but should the assessment prove larger than necessary by more than five (5) percent, the entire excess shall be refunded on a pro rata basis to the parties who paid the excess assessment. The refund shall be made by credit against future unpaid installments in the inverse order in which they are payable to the extent such installments then exist and the balance of such refund shall be in cash. No refunds may be made which contravene the provisions of any outstanding evidence of indebtedness secured in whole or part by such assessment. 
(Code 1967, § 2-325)  
Sec. 33-23. - Invalidity of roll due to irregularity, informality; remedy. 
Whenever any special assessment shall, in the opinion of the city council, be invalid by reason of irregularity or informality in the proceedings, or if any court of competent jurisdiction shall adjudge such assessment to be illegal, the city council shall, whether the improvement has been made or not, or whether any part of the assessment has been paid or not, have power to cause a new assessment to be made for the same purpose for which the former assessment was made. All proceedings on such reassessment and for the collection thereof shall be conducted in the same manner as provided for the original assessment; and whenever the assessment, or any part thereof, levied upon any premises has been so set aside, if the same has been paid and not refunded, the payment so made shall be applied upon the reassessment and the reassessment shall to that extent be deemed satisfied. 
(Code 1967, § 2-326) 
Charter reference— Similar provisions, § 10.3(b).  
Secs. 33-24—33-45. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - NUISANCES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Nuisances generally, Ch. 21. 
 
Sec. 33-46. - Abatement of nuisances. 
When any lot, lots, building or structure within the city, because of an accumulation of refuse, or debris, the uncontrolled growing of noxious weeds, or age or dilapidation, or because of any other condition or happening, becomes, in the opinion of the city council, a public hazard or nuisance, which is dangerous to the health, safety or welfare of the inhabitants of the city or those residing or habitually going near such lot, lots, building or structure, the city council may, by resolution, after investigation, determine that a hazard or nuisance exists. The city clerk shall send the notice by certified mail return receipt requested, addressed to the last known address of the owners of the land. If a signed return receipt is not received by the city clerk's office, the city clerk shall publish the notice in a local newspaper at least seven (7) days prior to the public hearing. 
(Code 1967, § 2-327; Ord. No. 80-318, § 1, 4-22-86)  
Sec. 33-47. - Notice required. 
The notice to abate or remove a hazard or nuisance under this article shall specify the nature of the hazard or nuisance and describe the property on which the same is located and require the owner to abate or remove the hazard or nuisance promptly, and shall designate a time within which the same shall be abated or removed which shall be commensurate with the nature of the hazard or nuisance. The notice shall further establish the date for a public hearing before the city council at which time the owner may raise any objections to the proposed abatement. The city clerk shall also give due notice of the hearing to persons to whom real property within three hundred (300) feet of the premises in question is assessed, and to the occupants of single and two-family dwellings within three hundred (300) feet, notice to be delivered personally or by mail addressed to the respective owners and tenants at the address given in the last assessment roll. If the tenant's name is not known, the term "occupant" may be used. The hearing shall be held within thirty (30) days of approval by the city council of the initial resolution specified in section 33-46, and the notice shall provide a minimum notice of fourteen (14) calendar days to the owner. 
(Code 1967, § 2-328)  
Sec. 33-48. - Failure to comply; removal by city. 
If at the expiration of the time limit specified in the notice to remove or to abate a hazard or nuisance, the owner has not complied with the requirements thereof, or in any case where the owner of the land or of the building or structure itself is not known, the city council may, by resolution, order such hazard removed or nuisance abated under the direction of the director of public service by the proper department or agency of the city, or may do the work by contract or by hire. 
(Code 1967, § 2-329)  
Sec. 33-49. - Duty of director of public; report. 
The director of public service shall take all steps necessary to carry out the directions of the city council in removing a hazard or abating a nuisance, shall keep or cause to be kept an accurate record of all expense in connection therewith, and upon completion of the work to be performed, shall submit a report of the work done and all expense in connection therewith, to the city council. 
(Code 1967, § 2-330)  
Sec. 33-50. - Recovery of costs. 
The city council shall, by resolution, after examination of the director of public service's report, determine what amount or part of each such expense shall be charged and the person, if known, against whom and the premises upon which the same shall be levied as a special assessment. By such resolution the city council shall determine the number of installments in which the assessment may be paid, determine the rate of interest to be charged on installments, not to exceed the maximum lawful interest, designate the district or land and premises upon which special assessments shall be levied, direct the city assessor to prepare a special assessment roll in accordance with the council's determination and designate the name by which said assessment roll shall be known and referred. The city clerk shall notify the owner of the costs to be assessed as determined by the city council. The city clerk shall send the notice by ordinary mail and by certified mail return receipt requested, addressed to the last known address of the owners of the land. 
(Code 1967, § 2-331; Ord. No. 80-318, § 1, 4-22-86)  
Sec. 33-51. - Preparation of roll. 
The city assessor shall thereupon prepare a special assessment roll including all lots and parcels of land within the special assessment district designated by the city council and shall assess to each such lot or parcel of land such sums as may have been directed by the city council. 
(Code 1967, § 2-332)  
Sec. 33-52. - Endorsement of roll. 
When the city assessor shall have completed the assessment roll, he or she shall attach thereto and endorse thereon his or her certificate to the effect that the roll has been made by him or her pursuant to a resolution of the city council (giving date of adoption of same) and that in making the assessments therein he or she has, as near as may be, according to his or her best judgment, conformed in all respects to the directions contained in the resolution and the Charter and the provisions of this chapter. Thereupon, he or she shall file the special assessment roll with the city clerk who shall forthwith give notice as has been required by the city council. 
(Code 1967, § 2-333)  
Sec. 33-53. - Notice of hearing. 
Upon receipt of the special assessment roll under section 33-52, the city clerk shall give notice as has been directed by the city council, which notice shall state the basis of the assessment, the amount thereof, describe the property affected thereby and give a reasonable time, which shall not be less than thirty (30) days, in which a hearing may be had thereon or payment made. 
(Code 1967, § 2-334)  
Sec. 33-54. - Hearing objections. 
If payment is not made within the time specified in the resolution and notice, the city council shall meet at the time and place provided and hear any objections to the roll as prepared. 
(Code 1967, § 2-335)  
Sec. 33-55. - Changes in roll. 
The city council may correct the roll as to any assessment or description of any lot or parcel of land or other errors appearing therein. Any changes made in the roll shall be noted in the council minutes. 
(Code 1967, § 2-336)  
Sec. 33-56. - Confirmation of roll. 
After the hearing the city council shall confirm the special assessment roll with such corrections as may have been made and the city clerk shall endorse the date of confirmation thereon, and upon confirmation such roll shall be final and conclusive. 
(Code 1967, § 2-337)  
Secs. 33-57, 33-58. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - PUBLIC IMPROVEMENTS—SIDEWALKS, TREES AND SERVICE LEADS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 80-557, §§ 2, 3, adopted July 11, 2000, completely repealed the provisions of former Art. III of this chapter which encompassed §§ 33-76—33-82 and pertained to general provisions regarding special assessments. Ord. No. 80-557 replaced former Art. III with Art. III, §§ 33-60—33-84 as currently set out herein. Former §§ 33-76—33-82 derived from the Code of 1967, §§ 2-338—2-344. Subsequently, Ord. No. 80-582, § 2, adopted Feb. 26, 2002, amended the title of Art. III to read as herein set out. 
 
Sec. 33-59. - Service leads. 
Whenever the water division superintendent or designate determines, pursuant to water division specifications, that a service lead is required to be constructed for the public health, safety, welfare, or is in a state of disrepair, unsafe or blocked for use, the water division superintendent or designate may advise the owner of the property affected to repair the service lead. The water division superintendent or designate may construct, reconstruct or repair such service lead if the owner consents to the voluntary service lead program. If the city constructs, reconstructs, or repairs such service lead, it may charge the expense to the premises and the owner as a special assessment. 
(Ord. No. 80-582, § 2, 2-26-02)  
Sec. 33-60. - Sidewalks. 
Whenever the city engineer or designate determines, pursuant to the engineering division specifications, that a sidewalk, crosswalk or driveway approach is required to be constructed for the public health, safety, welfare, or is in a state of disrepair, unsafe or blocked for use, the city engineer or designate may order the owner of the property abutting the sidewalk to repair the sidewalk. The city engineer may construct, reconstruct, or repair such sidewalk, crosswalk or driveway approach. If the city constructs, reconstructs, or repairs such sidewalk, crosswalk or driveway approach it may charge the expense to the premises and the owner as a special assessment. 
(Ord. No. 80-557, §§ 2, 3, 7-11-00)  
Sec. 33-61. - Trees. 
Whenever the director of parks and recreation or designate determines, pursuant to the parks and recreation department specifications, that a tree in the public right-of-way is an obstruction, in a state of disrepair or hazardous to the public health and safety, the director of parks and recreation or designate may order the owner of the property abutting the tree to repair, remove and/or plant a tree. The director of parks and recreation or designate may repair, remove and/or plant the tree. If the city repairs, removes and/or plants a tree, it may charge the expense to the premises and the owner as a special assessment. 
(Ord. No. 80-557, §§ 2, 3, 7-11-00)  
Sec. 33-62. - Sidewalk, tree and sewer board of review. (STS) 
(a)  Creation. The sidewalk, tree and sewer board of review is hereby created, composed of three members, appointed by the mayor and confirmed by city council, each of whom shall be a resident of the city and who are owners of property assessed for taxation in the city. 
(b)  Term of office. The terms of office shall be three (3) years, except that of the members first appointed, one (1) each shall be appointed for terms of one (1), two (2), and three (3) years. Members other than the first members shall be appointed before July 1 of the year of appointment. Vacancies shall be filled by the mayor for the remainder of the unexpired term. 
(c)  Function. The board shall hear complaints of all persons considering themselves aggrieved by special assessments relating to the sidewalk, tree, and sewer service lead program. If it shall appear that any person or property has been wrongfully specially assessed or omitted from the roll, the board shall correct the roll in such manner as it deems appropriate. The board shall forward its confirmation to city council. 
(d)  Meetings of the board; quorum; concurrence of majority; chairperson. The board shall convene as needed to efficiently process the recommended public improvement by special assessments. A majority of the members of the board constitutes a quorum for conducting the business of the board. The board shall not take action or make a determination without the concurrence of a majority of the board. The board shall elect a chairperson from among its members and shall elect other officers from its membership as it may deem necessary. 
(e)  Procedures, records. The board shall adopt its own rules and procedures and shall keep a record of its proceedings. 
(f)  Open meetings. The business which the board may perform shall be conducted at a public meeting of the board held in compliance with Act No. 267 of the Public Acts of 1976, being sections 15.261 et seq. of the Michigan Compiled Laws. 
(g)  Expenditures. No members of the board shall incur any expenses or create any obligation or liability on the city. If any expenditure of city funds is necessary in connection with the functioning of the commission, prior approval of such expenditures shall first be obtained from the city council. 
(Ord. No. 80-557, §§ 2, 3, 7-11-00; Ord. No. 80-582, § 2, 2-26-02)  
Sec. 33-63. - Report from the engineering department and/or the parks and recreation department, and/or water department. 
Prior to a public hearing before the sidewalk, tree, and sewer board of review, the engineering department and/or the parks and recreation department and/or the water department shall ascertain the assessed valuation of the property affected by the proposed improvement, the number of parcels which show tax delinquencies, the number of parcels owned by public authorities, the number of parcels which are vacant, and to prepare or cause to be prepared, plans and specifications for the public improvement, and an estimate of the cost of the special assessment. This information is to be filed with the city clerk and the city assessor, together with its determination as to what proportion of the cost should be paid by the special assessment and what part if any should be a general obligation of the city, the number of installments in which assessments may be paid, the rate of interest to be charged on installments, not to exceed the maximum lawful interest, and the lands which should be included in the special assessment district. The engineering department and/or the parks and recreation department and/or the water department shall then forward the report to the city assessor in order to prepare a special assessment roll in accordance with the report. 
(Ord. No. 80-557, §§ 2, 3, 7-11-00; Ord. No. 80-582, § 2, 2-26-02)  
Sec. 33-64. - Preparation of roll. 
Prior to the public hearing, the city assessor or designate shall prepare a special assessment roll including the lots and parcels of land within the special assessment district designated by engineering and/or parks and recreation department and/or the water department and shall assess to each such lot or parcel of land such relative portions of the whole sum to be levied against all the lands in the special assessment district as the benefit to such lot or parcel of land bears to the total benefits to all lands in such district. There shall also be entered upon such roll the amount which has been assessed to the city at large, if any. 
(Ord. No. 80-557, §§ 2, 3, 7-11-00; Ord. No. 80-582, § 2, 2-26-02)  
Sec. 33-65. - Endorsement of roll. 
When the city assessor or designate completes the assessment roll, he or she shall attach and endorse his or her certificate to the effect that the roll has been made by him or her pursuant the engineering and/or parks and recreation department and/or water department report, and that in making the assessments, he or she has, as near as may be, according to his or her best judgment, conformed in all respects to the directions contained in the charter and the provisions of this chapter. Upon completion, he or she shall forward the same to the sidewalk, tree and sewer board of review. 
(Ord. No. 80-557, §§ 2, 3, 7-11-00; Ord. No. 80-582, § 2, 2-26-02)  
Sec. 33-66. - Notice; special assessment public hearing. 
(a)  Upon receipt of the engineering and/or parks and recreation and/or water department report and the special assessment roll, the sidewalk, tree and sewer board of review shall order the information filed in the office of the city clerk for public examination; and shall fix the time and place when it will meet to hear complaints of those persons considering themselves aggrieved by the special assessment and review and confirm such roll, which meeting shall not be less than ten (10) days after notice of special assessment has been sent by the city clerk. 
(b)  Notice of hearing shall be given to each owner of or party in interest in property to be assessed whose name appears upon the tax assessment records maintained in the city assessor's office. The notice of hearing shall be mailed by first class mail, addressed to that owner or party at the address shown on the tax records at least ten (10) days before the date of the hearing. The tax assessment records maintained by the city assessor's office means the last assessment roll for ad valorem tax purposes that has been reviewed by the board of review (assessing), as supplemented by any subsequent changes in the names or the addresses of the owners or parties listed on that roll. 
(c)  The notice of hearing shall include a statement that appearance and protest at the hearing in the special assessment proceedings is required in order to appeal the amount of the special assessment to the state tax tribunal and shall describe the manner in which an appearance and protest shall be made. 
(d)  An owner or party in interest, or his or her agent may appear in person at the hearing to protest the special assessment, or shall be permitted to file his or her appearance or protest by letter and his or her personal appearance shall not be required. 
(e)  The city shall maintain in the city clerk's office a record of the parties who appear to protest at the hearing. If a hearing is terminated or adjourned for the day before a party is provided the opportunity to be heard, a party whose appearance was recorded is considered to have protested the special assessment in person. 
(f)  Where any person claims an interest in real property whose name and correct address do not appear upon the last tax assessment records, he or she shall be obligated to file immediately his or her name and address with the assessor. This requirement shall be deemed effective only for the purpose of establishing a record of the names and addresses of those persons entitled to notice of hearing in special assessment proceedings. It shall be the duty of the city assessor to immediately enter on the tax assessment records any changes in the names and addresses to owners or parties in interest filed with him and at all times to keep such tax assessment records current and complete and available for public inspection. 
(Ord. No. 80-557, §§ 2, 3, 7-11-00; Ord. No. 80-582, § 2, 2-26-02)  
Sec. 33-67. - Changes in roll. 
The sidewalk, tree and sewer board of review may correct the roll as to any assessment or description of any lot or parcel of land or other errors appearing therein. Any changes made in the roll shall be noted in the board of review minutes. 
(Ord. No. 80-557, §§ 2, 3, 7-11-00; Ord. No. 80-582, § 2, 2-26-02)  
Sec. 33-68. - Sidewalk, tree and sewer board of review determination. 
After the public hearing pursuant to section 33-66, the sidewalk, tree and sewer board of review, may by resolution, determine to make the public improvement and to defray the whole or any part of the cost of the improvement by special assessment upon the property specially benefited in proportion to the benefits derived or to be derived. By such resolution, the sidewalk, tree and sewer board of review shall approve plans and specifications for the improvement; determine the estimated cost, determine what proportion of such cost shall be paid by special assessment upon the property especially benefited and what part, if any, shall be a general obligation of the city; determine the number of installments in which may be paid; determine the rate of interest to be charged on the installments, not to exceed the maximum lawful interest; designate the district or land and premises upon which special assessments shall be levied. The sidewalk, tree and sewer board of review shall forward its confirmation to city council for its approval. 
(Ord. No. 80-557, §§ 2, 3, 7-11-00; Ord. No. 80-582, § 2, 2-26-02)  
Sec. 33-69. - Confirmation of roll.
