After the public hearing, the sidewalk, tree and sewer board of review may confirm the special assessment roll with such corrections as may have been made and the city clerk shall endorse the date of confirmation thereon, and upon confirmation such roll, it shall be the sidewalk, tree and sewer board of review's final and conclusive determination. 
(Ord. No. 80-557, §§ 2, 3, 7-11-00; Ord. No. 80-582, § 2, 2-26-02)  
Sec. 33-70. - Failure to give notice; invalidation of assessment; reassessment. 
Any failure to give notice as required in section 33-66 shall not invalidate an entire assessment roll but only the assessments on property affected by the lack of notice. A special assessment shall not be declared invalid as to any property if the owner or party in interest thereof has actually received notice, has waived notice, or has paid any part of the assessment. If any assessment is declared void by court order or judgment, a reassessment against the property may be made. 
(Ord. No. 80-557, §§ 2, 3, 7-11-00)  
Sec. 33-71. - Validation of previously held hearings. 
Each special assessment hearing held is validated insofar as any notice of hearing is concerned, if notice was given by mail to the owners or parties in interest whose names appeared at the time of mailing on the last local tax assessment records. Any such special hearing is also validated as to any owner or party in interest who has actually received notice of hearing, has waived such notice, or has paid any part of the special assessment. 
(Ord. No. 80-557, §§ 2, 3, 7-11-00)  
Sec. 33-72. - Approval by city council. 
Upon receipt of the sidewalk, tree and sewer board of review's confirmation, city council shall meet and review the engineering and/or park and recreation and/or the water department's report, the special assessment roll, and the confirmation of the sidewalk, tree and sewer board of review. The city council may by resolution, determine to make the public improvement and to defray the whole or any part of the cost of the improvement by special assessment upon the property specially benefited in proportion to the benefits derived or to be derived. By such resolution, the city council shall approve plans and specifications for the improvement; approve the estimated cost, approve what proportion of such cost shall be paid by special assessment upon the property especially benefited and what part, if any, shall be a general obligation of the city; approve the number of installments in which may be paid; approve the rate of interest to be charged on the installments; not to exceed the maximum lawful interest; approve the designation of the district or land and premises upon which special assessments shall be levied. 
The city council may correct the roll as to any assessment or description of any lot or parcel of land, or other errors appearing therein. Any changes made in the roll shall be noted in the city council's minutes. After review of the records, city council may approve the confirmation of the special assessment roll with such corrections as it may have made, if any, or may refer it back to the city assessor or appropriate department for revision or may annul it and any proceedings in connection therewith. Any such corrections made by the city assessor shall be reviewed by the city council in the same manner as the original assessment. The city council shall endorse the date of its approval of the confirmation upon each assessment roll. The roll shall, upon approval of the confirmation, be final and conclusive. If prior to the adoption of a city council resolution finally authorizing the making of a public improvement to be financed by special assessments, written objections to the proposed improvement have been filed by the owners of property in the district, which according to estimates will be required to bear more than fifty (50) percent of the amount of such special assessments, or by more than fifty (50) percent of the owners of land to be assessed for such improvement, no resolution finally determined to proceed with such improvement shall be adopted, except by the affirmative vote of six (6) members of city council. 
(Ord. No. 80-557, §§ 2, 3, 7-11-00; Ord. No. 80-582, § 2, 2-26-02)  
Sec. 33-73. - Attachment of roll. 
All special assessments contained in any special assessment roll, including any part thereof deferred as to payment, shall, from the date of approval of the confirmation of the roll by city council, constitute a lien upon the respective lots or parcels of land assessed and until paid shall be a charge against the respective owners of the several lots and parcels of land and a debt to the city from the persons to whom they are assessed. The lien shall be of the same character and effect as the lien created by the Charter for city taxes and shall include accrued interest and penalties. No judgment or decree, nor any act of the city council vacating a special assessment, shall destroy or impair the lien of the city upon the premises assessed for the amount of the assessment as may be equitably charged against the same, or as by a regular mode of proceeding might be lawfully assessed thereon. All special assessments shall become due upon approval of the confirmation of the special assessment roll or in annual installments not to exceed thirty (30) in number as the city council may determine at the time of the approval of the confirmation, and if in annual installments, the city council shall determine the first installment to be due. 
(Ord. No. 80-557, §§ 2, 3, 7-11-00; Ord. No. 80-582, § 2, 2-26-02)  
Sec. 33-74. - Transmission of roll for collection. 
The assessment roll shall be transmitted to the city treasurer for collection immediately after its approval by city council. The city treasurer shall give notice by one (1) publication in a newspaper that the special assessment roll (identifying it) has been filed in his or her office and specifying when and where payments may be made thereon. He or she shall mail statements of the several assessments to the respective owners, as indicated by the records of the city assessor, of the several lots and parcels of land assessed, stating the amount of the assessment and the manner in which it may be paid; provided, however, that failure to mail or receive if mailed any such statement shall not invalidate the assessment or entitle the owner to an extension of time within which to pay the assessment. 
(Ord. No. 80-557, §§ 2, 3, 7-11-00; Ord. No. 80-582, § 2, 2-26-02)  
Sec. 33-75. - Transmission of roll to city assessor; installments. 
The city treasurer shall transmit such roll to the city assessor with all payments upon assessments noted thereon. The city assessor shall then divide any remaining balance of each assessment into such number of equal installments as shall have been fixed by the city council; provided, that if such division operates to make any installment less than ten dollars ($10.00), then the city assessor shall reduce the number of installments so that each installment shall be above and as near to ten dollars ($10.00) as possible. 
(Ord. No. 80-557, §§ 2, 3, 7-11-00)  
Sec. 33-76. - Spreading installments on city tax roll. 
The first installment shall be spread upon the city tax roll in a column headed "special assessments," together with interest upon all unpaid installments from such date as may be determined by the city council. Thereafter, one (1) installment shall be spread upon each annual tax roll, together with one (1) year's interest upon all unpaid installments; provided, that when any annual installment shall have been prepaid as hereinafter provided, then there shall be spread upon the tax roll for such year only the interest upon all unpaid installments. 
(Ord. No. 80-557, §§ 2, 3, 7-11-00; Ord. No. 80-582, § 2, 2-26-02)  
Sec. 33-77. - Collection of installments by city treasurer; return to county treasurer. 
After each installment has been placed on the tax rolls, the same shall be collected by the city treasurer with the same rights and remedies, and the same penalties, interest and collection fees, as provided in the Charter for the collection of taxes, and shall be due and payable. All such assessment installments which are paid on or before the thirty-first day of August of such year shall be collected by the city treasurer without the addition of any fee or charge for the collection thereof. Provided, that at the election of the taxpayer he or she may pay one-half (½) of the assessment installment on or before the thirty-first day of August of such year to the city treasurer without the addition of any fee or charge for collection thereof, and provided that the balance of the assessment installment, if one-half (½) was paid on or before the thirty-first day of August, shall be due and payable on the first day of December of such year, provided further that the taxpayer may pay the balance of the assessment installment by the thirty-first day of January of the following year to the city treasurer without the addition of any fee or charge for collection thereof, and provided further that if the taxpayer fails to pay the first one-half (½) by the specified date, the half payment option is void, payment thereafter must be made on the full amount subject to a collection fee on the assessment installment of one (1) percent during the month of September and an additional one-half of one (0.5) percent per month during each and every month or fraction of a month which shall elapse thereafter before the payment of such assessment installment is made, until the last day of February next following the date that such assessment installments become due and payable; and provided further, that if the taxpayer fails to pay the second half payment by the thirty-first day of January, payment thereafter will be subject to the above fees on the amount due. Upon all city assessments returned to the county treasurer upon any delinquent tax roll, a charge of three and one-half (3½) percent shall be added and the same shall be collected by the county treasurer in like manner as and together with the taxes, charges, and assessments so returned. 
(Ord. No. 80-557, §§ 2, 3, 7-11-00; Ord. No. 80-582, § 2, 2-26-02)  
Sec. 33-78. - Advance payments. 
Any person desiring to pay any installment in advance shall first secure the proper statement from the city assessor to permit the city treasurer to compute the amount to be paid. The city treasurer shall report to the city assessor all advance payments on installments so that the city assessor shall have such information before spreading installments on the next city tax roll. 
(Ord. No. 80-557, §§ 2, 3, 7-11-00)  
Sec. 33-79. - Completed improvements; certification of costs. 
Upon completion of the improvement and the payment of the cost thereof, the city engineer and/or director of parks and recreation and/or water division superintendent shall certify to the city council the total cost of the improvement, together with the amount of the original roll for the improvement. 
(Ord. No. 80-557, §§ 2, 3, 7-11-00; Ord. No. 80-582, § 2, 2-26-02)  
Sec. 33-80. - Insufficient assessments; additional assessment authorized. 
Should the assessments in any special assessment roll, including the amount assessed to the city at large, prove insufficient for any reason to pay the cost of the improvement for which they were made, then the city council shall make additional assessments against the city and the several lots and parcels of land, in the same ratio as the original assessments, to supply the deficiency; but the total amount assessed against any lot or parcel of land shall not exceed the value of the benefits received from the improvement, provided that the additional pro rata assessment shall not exceed twenty-five (25) percent of the assessment as originally confirmed unless a meeting of the city council be held to review such additional assessment, for which meeting notices shall be mailed as provided in the case of review of the original special assessment roll. 
(Ord. No. 80-557, §§ 2, 3, 7-11-00)  
Sec. 33-81. - Disposition of excessive assessments. 
The excess by which any special assessment proves larger than the actual cost of the improvement and expenses incidental thereto shall be refunded on a pro rata basis to the parties who paid the excess assessment. The refund shall be made by credit against future unpaid installments in the inverse order in which they are payable to the extent such installments then exist and the balance of such refund shall be in cash. No refunds may be made which contravene the provisions of any outstanding evidence of indebtedness secured in whole or part by such assessment. 
(Ord. No. 80-557, §§ 2, 3, 7-11-00)  
Sec. 33-82. - Invalidity of roll due to irregularity, informality; remedy. 
Whenever any special assessment shall, in the opinion of the city council, be invalid by reason of irregularity or informality in the proceedings, or if any court of competent jurisdiction shall adjudge such assessment to be illegal, the city council shall, whether the improvement has been made or not, or whether any part of the assessment has been paid or not, have power to cause a new assessment to be made for the same purpose for which the former assessment was made. All proceedings on such reassessment and for the collection thereof shall be conducted in the same manner as provided for the original assessment; and whenever the assessment, or any part thereof, levied upon any premises has been so set aside, if the same has been paid and not refunded, the payment so made shall be applied upon the reassessment and the reassessment shall to that extent be deemed satisfied. 
(Ord. No. 80-557, §§ 2, 3, 7-11-00)  
Sec. 33-83. - Appeal. 
If a special assessment is made against a property, the notice of special assessment sent to the property owner or person responsible for the ad valorem property taxes under the general property tax act, MCL 211.1 to MCL 211.157, shall include, in addition to any other requirements by statute or charter, a statement that the owner or any person having an interest in the real property may file a written appeal of the special assessment with the state tax tribunal within thirty (30) days of the confirmation hearing held by the sidewalk, tree and sewer board of review if that special assessment was protested at the sidewalk, tree and sewer board of review hearing (held for the purpose of confirming the roll). 
(Ord. No. 80-557, §§ 2, 3, 7-11-00; Ord. No. 80-582, § 2, 2-26-02)  
Sec. 33-84. - Conflict and severability. 
As to sidewalk, tree, and service lead assessments, if any part of this article or the application thereof to any persons or circumstance shall be found to be invalid by any court, such invalidity shall not affect the remaining parts or application of this article which can be given effect without the invalid part or application, provided such remaining parts are not determined by the court to be inoperable, and to this end all provisions of this article are declared severable. The article is to read in conjunction with the Charter and city ordinances; if however, there is conflict with other ordinance language, this article shall prevail. 
(Ord. No. 80-557, §§ 2, 3, 7-11-00; Ord. No. 80-582, § 2, 2-26-02)  
Secs. 33-85—33-89. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 33-90. - Use of funds by special assessment. 
Monies raised by special assessment for any public improvement shall be credited to a special assessment account and shall be used to pay for the costs of the improvements for which the assessment was levied and of expenses incidental thereto, to repay any principal or interest on money borrowed therefor, and to refund excessive assessments, as herein provided. 
(Ord. No. 80-557, § 4, 7-11-00)  
Sec. 33-91. - Inability to pay assessment. 
Any person who, in the opinion of the city assessor, and upon confirmation by the city council, are, by reason of poverty, unable to contribute toward the cost of the making of a public improvement may execute to the city an instrument prepared by the city attorney, creating a lien for the benefit of the city on all or any part of the real property owned by them and benefitted by any public improvement, which lien will mature and be effective from and after the execution of such instrument; and shall be enforceable in the event that title to or any interest in such property is thereafter transferred in any manner whatsoever, or in the event that, in the opinion of the city assessor, upon confirmation by the city council, such condition of poverty ceases to exist. 
(Ord. No. 80-557, § 4, 7-11-00)  
Sec. 33-92. - Deferment of special assessment. 
(a)  Eligibility. An owner of a homestead who is sixty-five (65) years of age or older or who is totally and permanently disabled, a citizen of the United States, a resident of this state for five (5) or more years, and the sole owner of the homestead for five (5) or more years is eligible for the deferment of special assessments on that homestead pursuant to Act No. 225 of the Public act of 1976, as amended that being MCL 211.761 et seq. 
(b)  Application. An owner may apply to the assessor's office for deferment of the payment of special assessments on the owner's homestead. The application shall be made upon an affidavit form to be furnished and made available by the Michigan Department of Treasury at convenient locations throughout the state. The affidavit form shall contain the following statement in 10-point boldface type located immediately above the affiant's signature: 
"If this deferment is authorized the state will place a lien on your property." 
A person making a false affidavit for the purpose of obtaining deferment of special assessments under this act is guilty of perjury. If the homestead is owned jointly by husband and wife, each spouse shall sign and file the affidavit. If the homestead is encumbered by a mortgage or an unpaid balance on a land contract, a deferment of special assessments shall not be made without the written consent of the mortgagee or the land contract vendor, which shall be filed with the affidavit. The affidavit shall be filed with the assessor's office at least thirty (30) days after the due date of a special assessment or installment of a special assessment for which deferment is requested. 
(c)  Determination of eligibility by assessor. Upon receipt of the affidavit, the assessor shall promptly examine it to determine if the applicant meets the requirements of this article and state law. The assessor's office shall make an inspection of the property and property records and conduct an investigation and survey as it deems necessary. An applicant shall not be compelled to supply information not reasonably essential to a proper determination of the eligibility of the owner and the homestead for the relief provided under this article and state law. The assessor shall promptly make its decision with respect to an application under this section and shall notify the applicant of its decision not later than the due date for a special assessment involved in the application. A decision of the assessor shall be final except as otherwise provided pursuant to the constitution. 
(d)  Procedure. The procedure relating to deferment of special assessments on homesteads are governed by MCL 211.761 et seq as amended. 
(Ord. No. 80-557, § 4, 7-11-00)  
Sec. 33-93. - Liability for public improvements. 
The owners of all real property, including such as is exempt from taxation by law, or exempted by the board of review (assessing), and with or without valuation placed thereon, shall be liable for the cost of public improvements benefiting such property, unless exempted from special assessments by law, the same as other property, as provided herein and such special assessments shall be levied, collected and returned, and the premises may be sold or forfeited in the same manner as for nonpayment of city taxes. 
(Ord. No. 80-557, § 4, 7-11-00)  
Sec. 33-94. - Action in assumpsit for delinquent assessments. 
In addition to any other remedies and without impairing the lien therefor, any delinquent special assessment, together with interest and penalties, may be collected in an action in assumpsit in the name of the city against the person assessed, in any court having jurisdiction of the amount. If in any such action it shall appear that by reason of any irregularities or informalities the assessment has not been properly made against the defendant or upon the premises sought to be charged, the court may, nevertheless, on satisfactory proof that expense has been incurred by the city which is a proper charge against the defendant or the premises in question, render judgment for the amount properly chargeable against such defendant or upon such premises. 
(Ord. No. 80-557, § 4, 7-11-00)  
Sec. 33-95. - Consent by owners for alternative procedure. 
If any person or property owner to be affected by any proposed improvement agrees that such proposed improvement be made and that a special assessment be levied in connection therewith, the City may, in lieu of the foregoing procedure in this chapter enter into a written contract with the person or property owner affected thereby, which contract when properly approved and executed, shall operate as a complete special assessment procedure and the assessment shall be made in accordance with the contract. 
(Ord. No. 80-557, § 4, 7-11-00)  
Sec. 33-96. - Resolution of council prerequisite to financing improvements. 
No public improvement to be financed in whole or in part by special assessment shall be made before the city council determines by resolution to make the improvement and to defray the whole or any part of the cost of the improvement by special assessment. 
(Ord. No. 80-557, § 4, 7-11-00)  
Chapter 33.5 - LOW INCOME HOUSING TAX CREDIT PROGRAM[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— State Housing Development Authority Act of 1966 (1966 PA 346, as amended; MCL 125.1401, et seq.), Section 42 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as amended, U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development, Section 8 of the U.S. Housing Act of 1937, as amended and General Property Tax Act (1893 PA 206, as amended; MCL 211.1, et seq.). 
 
ARTICLE I. - ANNUAL SERVICE CHARGE PAYMENT EQUAL TO SIX (6) PERCENT OF THE ANNUAL SHELTER RENT COLLECTED IN LIEU OF AD VALOREM PROPERTY TAXES FOR PATRIOT PLACE HOMES HOUSING DEVELOPMENT 
 
Sec. 33.5-1. - Purpose. 
This chapter provides for an annual service charge payment in lieu of ad valorem property taxes for a city housing development identified within this chapter as "Patriot Place Homes" to service low income or moderate income persons or families to be financed with a federally-aided mortgage or Authority-aided mortgage, or an advance or grant from the Michigan State Housing Development Authority (Authority) as defined in the State Housing Development Authority Act of 1966 (1966 PA 346, as amended; MCL 125.1401, et seq.) (Act 346). 
(Ord. No. 80-751, § 1, 2-28-17)  
Sec. 33.5-2. - Preamble. 
(a)  It is acknowledged that it is a proper public purpose of the State of Michigan and its political subdivisions to provide housing for low income or moderate income persons and families and to encourage the development of such housing by providing for an annual service charge payment in lieu of ad valorem property taxes in accordance with Act 346. The city is authorized by Act 346 and this chapter to establish or change the annual service charge payment to be paid in lieu of taxes by any and all classes of housing exempt from taxation under Act 346 at any amount it chooses, not to exceed the taxes that would be paid, but for Act 346. It is further acknowledged that housing for low income or moderate income persons or families is a public necessity, and as the city will be benefitted and improved by such housing, the encouragement of the same by providing real estate tax exemptions for such housing is a valid public purpose. It is further acknowledged that the continuance of the provisions of this chapter for tax exemption and an annual service charge payment in lieu of all ad valorem taxes during the period contemplated within this chapter are essential to the determination of economic feasibility for the housing development identified as Patriot Place Homes that is to be constructed and financed in reliance upon such tax exemption. 
(b)  The city acknowledges that Patriot Place Homes Limited Dividend Housing Association Limited Partnership, Michigan Limited Partners (the sponsor) has offered, subject to receipt of the low income housing tax credit allocated by the Michigan State Housing Development Authority, to construct, own and operate a housing development identified herein as "Patriot Place Homes" on certain properties located within Warren, Michigan, which are identified in section 33.5-12 of this chapter, to serve low income or moderate income persons or families, and the Sponsor has offered to pay to the city on account of this housing development an annual service charge payment for public services in lieu of all ad valorem property taxes. 
(Ord. No. 80-751, § 1, 2-28-17)  
Sec. 33.5-3. - Definitions. 
The following terms and phrases, when used within this chapter shall have the following meanings ascribed to them: 
Act 346: means the State Housing Development Authority Act of 1966 (1966 Public Acts of Michigan 346, as amended; MCL 125.1401, et seq.). 
Ad valorem property taxes : means a tax with the amount based upon the assessed value of the property. 
Annual shelter rent(s) or shelter rent(s) or contract rent(s) : means the total actual collections received in connection with the operation of Patriot Place Homes housing development during an agreed upon annual period from all occupants representing rent or occupancy charges, exclusive of furnished utilities. 
Authority: means the Michigan State Housing Development Authority created within the State Housing Development Authority Act of 1966 (1966 Public Acts of Michigan 346, as amended; MCL 125.1401, et seq.)(Act 346). 
Authority-aided mortgage or an advance or grant from the Authority: means that the Authority may make a mortgage loan or loans to the Sponsor for the construction or for the long-term financing of Patriot Place Homes Housing Development. 
Federally-aided mortgage: means any of the following: 
(1)  A below market interest rate mortgage insured, purchased, or held by the Secretary of the Department of Housing and Urban Development; 
(2)  A market interest rate mortgage insured by the Secretary of the Department of Housing and Urban Development and augmented by a program of rent supplements; 
(3)  A mortgage receiving interest reduction payments provided by the Secretary of the Department of Housing and Urban Development; 
(4)  A mortgage on a housing development (Patriot Place Homes) to which the Authority allocates the Low Income Housing Tax Credit Program pursuant to Act 346, as amended; 
(5)  A mortgage receiving special benefits under another federal law designated specifically to develop low and moderate income housing, consistent with Act 346, as amended. 
Housing development: means any of the following: 
(1)  Residential real property developed or to be developed (Patriot Place Homes) or receiving benefits under Act 346 to service low income or moderate income persons or families; 
(2)  A specific work or improvement either for rental or for subsequent sale to an individual purchaser undertaken by a nonprofit housing corporation (sponsor) pursuant to or receiving benefits under Act 346 to provide dwelling accommodations, including the acquisition and construction of lands; or 
(3)  Social, recreational, educational or communal facilities that the Authority finds to serve and improve a residential area in which housing described above herein subparagraphs (1) or (2) is located or is planned to be located, thereby enhancing the viability of the housing development. 
Limited dividend housing association: means a limited divided housing association that is an association organized and qualified exclusively to provide housing facilities for persons or families of low income or moderate income and shall include a general or limited partnership or other joint venture relationship as approved by the Authority. 
Low Income Housing Tax Credit or Low Income Housing Tax Credit Program and/or Tax Exemption: means the Low Income Housing Tax Credit Program allocated by the Authority under Section 42 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as amended. 
Low income or moderate income persons or families: means persons or families who cannot afford to pay for housing at the cost that a private establishment requires, as defined in Act 346. 
Sponsor: for purposes of this chapter, the sponsor is identified as Patriot Place Homes Limited Dividend Housing Association Limited Partnership, Michigan Limited Partners. To receive the Low Income Housing Tax Credit, the sponsor is required to receive or assume a federally-aided mortgage, Authority-aided mortgage or an advance or grant from the Authority. 
Utilities: means the charges for gas, electric, water, sanitary sewer and other similar services that are furnished to the occupants and paid for by Patriot Place Homes. 
(Ord. No. 80-751, § 1, 2-28-17)  
Sec. 33.5-4. - Class of housing development. 
It is determined that the class of housing developments to which the tax exemption shall apply and for which an annual service charge payment shall be paid in lieu of ad valorem property taxes shall be housing developments for low income or moderate income persons or families that are financed with a federally-aided mortgage, Authority-aided mortgage or an advance or grant from the Michigan State Housing Authority. It is further determined that Patriot Place Homes Housing Development is of this class. 
(Ord. No. 80-751, § 1, 2-28-17)  
Sec. 33.5-5. - Establishment of annual service charge. 
(a)  In reliance upon the enactment and continuing effect of this chapter, and in reliance upon the qualification of Patriot Place Homes Housing Development as it relates to the annual service charge payment in lieu of ad valorem property taxes, both the Sponsor and the Authority have established the economic feasibility pertaining to the development, construction and operation of Patriot Place Homes Housing Development as established within this chapter, which the city acknowledges. 
(b)  In consideration of the sponsor's offer to develop, construct, and operate the Patriot Place Homes housing development, the city agrees to accept payment of an annual service charge for public services in lieu of all ad valorem property taxes that would otherwise be assessed to Patriot Place Homes Housing Development under Michigan law. The sponsor hereby agrees that Patriot Place Homes is to be developed, constructed and maintained in compliance with this chapter, the city's Code of Ordinances, and the real estate development agreement pertaining to Patriot Place Homes. 
(c)  The housing development identified as Patriot Place Homes and the properties on which it will be located, identified in section 33.5-12 of this chapter, shall be exempt from all ad valorem property taxes from and after the commencement of construction for the duration stated within this chapter, and subject to the following terms and conditions: 
(1)  The adoption of this chapter; 
(2)  Executing a real estate purchase agreement; 
(3)  Executing a real estate development agreement pertaining to Patriot Place Homes; 
(4)  Subject to the sponsor's timely filing, with the city assessor, a certified notification of exemption relating to receiving the low income housing tax credit allocated by the Authority before November 1 st of the year preceding the tax year in which the exemption it to begin; 
(5)  So long as the purpose for the development and construction of Patriot Place Homes Housing Development is to service low income or moderate income persons and families, and is financed with a federally-aided mortgage, authority-aided mortgage or an advance or loan from the Authority; and 
(6)  This tax exemption for Patriot Place Homes shall only apply to ad valorem property taxes and will not apply to any other form of property taxation such as special assessments. 
(d)  Subject to the sponsor's substantial compliance with all of the requirements, terms and conditions set forth within this chapter, the annual service charge payment in lieu of ad valorem property taxes relating to Patriot Place Homes Housing Development shall be equal to six (6) percent of the annual shelter rents and contract rents actually collected during each operating year. 
(Ord. No. 80-751, § 1, 2-28-17)  
Sec. 33.5-6. - Limitation on the annual service charge payment. 
With respect to the payment of the annual service charge, notwithstanding section 33.5-5 of this chapter, the service charge to be paid each year in lieu of ad valorem property taxes for the part of Patriot Place Homes Housing Development that is tax exempt but which is occupied by other than low income or moderate income persons or families or if the sponsor is not in compliance with the Code of Ordinances or the real estate development agreement pertaining to Patriot Place Homes, then the amount due shall be equal to the full amount of taxes which would be paid on that portion of Patriot Place Homes if it were not tax exempt and such amount shall be added to the service charge. 
(Ord. No. 80-751, § 1, 2-28-17)  
Sec. 33.5-7. - Contractual effect of chapter. 
Notwithstanding the provisions of section 15(a)(5) of Act 346 to the contrary, a contract is effectuated by the enactment of this chapter between the city and the sponsor (Patriot Place Homes Limited Dividend Housing Association Limited Partnership, Michigan Limited Partners) with the authority acting as a third party beneficiary under the contract. Said contract is to provide Patriot Place Homes Housing Development with a tax exemption and for the city to accept an annual service charge payment in lieu of ad valorem property taxes for Patriot Place Homes Housing Development. The terms and conditions of this contract are set forth within this chapter, and the real estate development agreement pertaining to Patriot Place Homes. 
(Ord. No. 80-751, § 1, 2-28-17)  
Sec. 33.5-8. - Payment of service charge. 
(a)  The annual service charge payment in lieu of ad valorem property taxes as determined under this chapter shall be payable in the same manner as general property taxes are payable to the city and distributed to the several units levying the general property tax in the same proportion as prevailed with the general property tax in the previous calendar year. The annual service charge payment for each operating year shall be paid on or before July 1 st of the following year. Collection procedures shall be in accordance with the provisions of the General Property Tax Act (1893 PA 206, as amended; MCL 211.1, et seq.). 
(b)  Any late annual service charge payments will be subject to a late fee, as determined by the city assessor. After a ten (10) day late fee written notice, any default regarding the service charge payment or late fee shall result in revocation of this chapter; thereby causing the tax exemption to automatically terminate, requiring the full amount of the ad valorem property taxes that would be applied to Patriot Place Homes Housing Development due and payable to the city. The nonpayment of an annual service charge or late fee shall result in the city placing a lien upon the appropriate property(s). 
(Ord. No. 80-751, § 1, 2-28-17)  
Sec. 33.5-9. - Duration. 
(a)  This chapter shall remain in effect and shall not terminate for a maximum term of sixteen (16) consecutive years commencing the first year in which the Sponsor activates this tax exemption, subject to section 33.5-9(b) and the following terms and conditions: 
(1)  So long as the properties associated with Patriot Place Homes Housing Development, identified in section 33.5-12 of this chapter, are subject to an outstanding and unpaid federally-aided mortgage, Authority-aided mortgage or an advance or grant from the Authority (but not more than sixteen (16) years as stated above); 
(2)  As long as Patriot Place Homes Housing Development serves low income or moderate income persons or families and complies with the rent restrictions pursuant to the Low Income Housing Tax Credit Program requirements (but not more than sixteen (16) years as stated above); and 
(3)  If the sponsor (Patriot Place Homes Limited Dividend Housing Association Limited Partnership, Michigan Limited Partners) files, with the city assessor, the required certified notification of exemption relating to receiving the Low Income Housing Tax Credit allocated by the Authority before November 1 st of the year preceding the tax year in which the exemption is to begin, pursuant to section 15a of Act 346 (but not more than sixteen (16) years as stated above). 
(b)  This exemption allowing for an annual service charge payment in lieu of ad valorem property taxes for Patriot Place Homes Housing Development shall automatically expire, terminate and be of no effect if: 
(1)  The construction of Patriot Place Homes Housing Development does not commence within two (2) years from the date the Sponsor acquires the city owned lots identified in section 33.5-12 of this chapter; 
(2)  The sponsor failing to substantially comply with the terms and conditions set forth in this chapter; or 
(3)  The sponsor failing to substantially comply with the terms and conditions set forth within the real estate development agreement pertaining to Patriot Place Homes. 
(Ord. No. 80-751, § 1, 2-28-17)  
Sec. 33.5-10. - Filing of annual audit. 
All annual audits relating to Patriot Place Homes Housing Development required by any entity (federal government, State of Michigan, the Authority or any other) shall be simultaneously filed with the city assessor. In the event that an annual audit is not required by any entity, then the city requires an annual detailed audit to be filed with the city assessor pertaining to the occupancy of Patriot Place Homes Housing Development disclosing such information as the annual shelter rents received, annual contract rents received and the cost associated with the furnished utilities and maintenance. 
(Ord. No. 80-751, § 1, 2-28-17)  
Sec. 33.5-11. - Compliance requirements. 
(a)  This exemption allowing for an annual service charge payment in lieu of ad valorem property taxes for Patriot Place Homes Housing Development is subject to strict compliance with all applicable laws, regulations, codes, development agreements, and ordinances, including this chapter, the Authority and Act 346 relating to the construction, completions, maintenance and occupancy of Patriot Homes. Upon such violation, this chapter shall automatically expire, terminate and be of no effect thereby requiring all ad valorem property taxes pertaining to Patriot Place Homes Housing Development due and payable to the city as of the date of such default. 
(b)  In the event, the Sponsor (Patriot Place Homes Limited Dividend Housing Association Limited Partnership, Michigan Limited Partners) or any successor or assign changes the scope or purpose of Patriot Place Homes Housing Development without obtaining written consent from the city, after thirty (30) days from the city's written notice to cure has concluded, then this chapter creating a tax exemption for Patriot Place Homes shall automatically expire, terminate and be of no effect thereby requiring all ad valorem property taxes pertaining to Patriot Place Homes Housing Development due and payable to the city as of the date of such default. 
(c)  This chapter allowing for an annual service charge payment in lieu of ad valorem property taxes for Patriot Place Homes Housing Development is subject to strict compliance with all applicable housing discrimination laws, statues, acts, and regulations relating to all areas of housing (real estate purchase, sale, rental, lease, financing, auditing, rental application(s), rental processing, housing fees and but not limited to advertising of housing). Upon such violation, this chapter shall automatically expire, terminate and be of no effect thereby requiring all ad valorem property taxes pertaining to Patriot Place Homes Housing Development due and payable to the city as of the date of such default. 
(Ord. No. 80-751, § 1, 2-28-17)  
Sec. 33.5-12. - Description of Patriot Place Homes Housing Development. 
The Patriot Place Homes Housing Development shall consist of the following sixty-nine (69) vacant lots described below by their tax identification numbers: 
13-27-327-022, 13-27-328-029, 13-376-006, 13-28-452-023, 13-28-452-024, 13-27-378-001, 13-27-359-012, 13-33-205-027, 13-33-205-029, 13-33-206-014, 13-33-227-003, 13-34-107-024, 13-34-131-026, 13-34-203-010, 13-34-108-027, 13-33-228-016, 13-33-207-039, 13-33-208-001, 13-33-208-005, 13-33-208-013, 13-34-228-052, 13-34-229-020, 13-34-229-013, 13-34-229-035, 13-34-205-018, 13-34-134-006, 13-34-110-008, 13-33-230-014, 13-34-181-011, 13-34-181-034, 13-34-256-008, 13-34-252-034, 13-34-157-024, 13-34-152-024, 13-34-157-007, 13-33-277-002, 13-33-257-003, 13-34-158-007, 13-34-158-009, 13-33-257-026, 13-33-258-010, 13-34-154-012, 13-34-179-004, 13-34-184-004, 13-34-184-002, 13-34-185-009, 13-34-185-001, 13-34-160-026, 13-34-160-019, 13-33-258-023, 13-33-254-002, 13-33-254-003, 13-33-254-004, 13-33-426-022, 13-34-301-039, 13-34-302-047, 13-33-406-038, 13-33-427-021, 13-34-302-050, 13-33-409-002, 13-33-409-006, 13-33-409-011, 13-33-428-029, 13-34-328-019, 13-34-329-008, 13-34-329-007, 13-34-304-008, 13-34-304-007, and 13-33-411-033. 
(Ord. No. 80-751, § 1, 2-28-17)  
Sec. 33.5-13. - Real estate purchase agreement and development agreement effect of chapter. 
(a)  Within sixty (60) days from the sponsor filing a certified notation of receiving the low income housing tax credit allocated by the Authority with the city assessor, and subject to the terms and conditions set forth in this chapter, a separate written real estate purchase agreement shall be drafted by the city attorney's office and executed by the city and the sponsor (Patriot Place Homes Limited Dividend Housing Association Limited Partnership, Michigan Limited Partners) pertaining to the sixty-nine (69) vacant lots identified in section 33.5-12 of this chapter. The real estate purchase agreement shall set the purchase price of each vacant lot at one dollar ($1.00) per lot, for a total sale price in the amount of sixty-nine dollars ($69.00). The Sponsor is to develop and construct only single-family homes on the sixty-nine (69) vacant lots identified in section 33.5-12 of this chapter, subject to the terms and conditions set forth in this chapter and the real estate development agreement pertaining to Patriot Place Homes. This real estate purchase agreement is effectuated by enactment of this chapter. Said purchase agreement shall be approved by the city attorney's office and a copy of which shall be maintained in the office of the city clerk. 
(b)  Within ninety (90) days from the sponsor filing a certified notation of receiving the Low Income Housing Tax Credit allocated by the Authority with the city assessor and subject to the terms and conditions set forth in this chapter, a separate written real estate development agreement pertaining to Patriot Place Housing Development shall be drafted by the city attorney's office and be executed by the city and the sponsor (Patriot Place Homes Limited Dividend Housing Association Limited Partnership, Michigan Limited Partners) regarding the sixty-nine (69) vacant lots identified in section 33.5-12 of this chapter. The real estate development agreement shall include but not be limited to the following terms and conditions: the development of single-family homes, construction, completion, operation, maintenance and annual service charge payment associated with Patriot Place Homes Housing Development. This real estate development agreement is effectuated by enactment of this chapter. Said development agreement shall be approved by the city attorney's office and a copy of which shall be maintained in the office of the city clerk and recorded in the Macomb County Register of Deeds Office. 
(Ord. No. 80-751, § 1, 2-28-17)  
Sec. 33.5-14. - Real estate conveyance effect of chapter. 
Upon the sponsor receiving the Low Income Housing Tax Credit allocated by the Authority and subject to the terms and conditions set forth in this chapter and in the real estate development agreement pertaining to Patriot Place Homes, the city shall convey, by quit claim deed(s), the sixty-nine (69) vacant lots identified in section 33.5-12 of this chapter which are located within Warren, Michigan to the Sponsor (Patriot Place Homes Limited Dividend Housing Association Limited Partnership, Michigan Limited Partners) to construct Patriot Place Homes Housing Development. This real estate conveyance is effectuated by enactment of this chapter, all real estate documents associated with this conveyance shall be drafted and approved by the city attorney's office and a copy of which shall be maintained in the office of the city clerk. In addition, the quit claim deed(s) shall be recorded in the Macomb County Register of Deeds Office. 
(Ord. No. 80-751, § 1, 2-28-17)  
Sec. 33.5-15. - Severability. 
The various sections and provisions of this chapter shall be deemed to be severable, and should any section or provision of this chapter be declared by any court of competent jurisdiction to be unconstitutional or invalid, such declaration shall not affect the validity of the remainder sections and provisions of this chapter, and the remaining sections and provisions shall remain in full force and effect. 
(Ord. No. 80-751, § 1, 2-28-17)  
Sec. 33.5-16. - Repeal. 
All ordinances or parts of ordinances inconsistent or in conflict with this chapter are hereby repealed to the extent of such inconsistency or conflict. 
(Ord. No. 80-751, § 1, 2-28-17)  
Chapter 34 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference— Authority to regulate streets and public ways, § 3.1(b)(3). 
Cross reference— Any ordinance dedicating, naming, establishing, locating, relocating, opening, paving, widening, vacating, etc., any street or public way in the city saved from repeal, § 1-6(3); distributing handbills in public places, § 3-18; animals running at large prohibited, § 7-3; dogs running at large prohibited, § 7-26; cats running at large prohibited, § 7-101; buildings and building regulations, Ch. 9; moving buildings, § 9-341 et seq.; mobile homes and trailers, Ch. 20; spitting in public places, § 22-3; disobeyance of signs and persons supervising public places, § 22-21; offenses against public peace, § 22-106 et seq.; parks and recreation, Ch. 23; peddlers, solicitors and transient merchants, Ch. 24; railroads, Ch. 28; special assessments, Ch. 33; subdivision regulations, Ch. 35; traffic and motor vehicles, Ch. 37; vehicles for hire, Ch. 39; water and sewers, Ch. 41; zoning, App. A. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 34-1. - Destruction, etc., of street installations on public property. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to destroy, damage, deface or remove any barrier erected to protect any excavation or obstruction in any street, alley or public place, or any light placed as a warning of such excavation or obstruction; or any street sign placed to designate the name of the street, avenue, court or place; or any street lamp, light post, pole or any of the parts or attachments thereto, or any telephone or telegraph pole or any wire or appliances thereof, or any device erected by the authority of the city, or any public property whatsoever. 
(Code 1967, § 7-134) 
State Law reference— Malicious mischief, MCL 750.377 et seq.  
Sec. 34-2. - Placing snow, dirt and litter on public ways. 
(a)  No person shall place, sweep, push, plow, shovel or cause to be placed, swept, pushed, plowed or shoveled, any snow, ice, dirt, oil, grease, flammable liquid, wastewater, or litter of any kind from any private property or building upon any street or public way of the city. 
(b)  No person shall place, sweep, push, plow, shovel or cause to be placed, swept, pushed, plowed or shoveled, any snow, ice, dirt, oil, grease, flammable liquid, wastewater, or litter of any kind from any private property or building upon any parking space designated for the use of handicapped individuals as defined in MCL 257.942a. 
(c)  No person shall place, sweep, push, plow, shovel or cause to be placed, swept, pushed, plowed or shoveled, any snow, ice, dirt, oil, grease, flammable liquid, wastewater, or litter of any kind in or on any parcel of land not belonging to the depositor. This subsection shall not be construed to permit depositing on one's own property if said depositing is prohibited by any other ordinance or statute. 
(Code 1967, § 7-136; Ord. No. 80-579, § 1, 2-26-02; Ord. No. 80-728, § 1, 2-24-15) 
Cross reference— Littering generally, §§ 16-10, 21-5; deposit of unwholesome substances, § 21-3.  
Sec. 34-3. - Placing leaves, grass, etc., on public ways or private property. 
(a)  No person shall cause to be placed or burned any grass clippings, leaves, lawn rakings, tree or bush trimmings, tree trunks, stumps, ashes, soil, dirt or household debris in or on any street, alley or public way in the city. 
(b)  No person shall cause to be placed any grass clippings, leaves, lawn rakings, tree or bush trimmings, tree trucks, stumps, ashes, soil, dirt or household debris in or on any parcel of land not belonging to the depositor. This section shall not be construed to permit depositing on one's own property if said depositing is prohibited by any other ordinance or statute. 
(Code 1967, § 7-137; Ord. No. 80-444, § 1, 11-9-93)  
Sec. 34-4. - Exhibition of goods and merchandise. 
(a)  No person shall place, store, display or exhibit, or cause to be placed, stored, displayed or exhibited, any goods, articles, materials, merchandise or objects in or upon any street, alley, sidewalk or other public way or property. 
(b)  The city council shall have the authority to grant a special permit for any of the above prohibited uses after having received the recommendation of the police commissioner, and may impose reasonable conditions thereon in order to protect the public health, safety, peace and general welfare of the community. 
(Code 1967, § 7-138(b))  
Sec. 34-5. - Shopping carts. 
(a)  Definitions. The following terms, whenever used or referred to in this section, shall have the following respective meanings, which definitions shall apply in the interpretation and enforcement of this section unless a different meaning clearly appears from the context: 
Cart means any rolling or nonrolling basket or container commonly used in so-called supermarkets or self-service stores. 
Property means and includes any cart. 
Store means and includes any individual store, chain store and/or supermarket. 
(b)  Removal from premises. It shall be unlawful for any person to take or use without authority any cart from the premises of any store, without intent to steal the same. 
(c)  Abandoning carts on public ways. It shall be unlawful for any person to abandon or suffer to be abandoned any cart, from any store or supermarket, on any street, highway, alley, boulevard or public place within the city. 
(d)  Metallic tag required. It shall be unlawful for any person to provide carts for patrons' use on the store premises, unless such carts bear thereon a welded metallic tag denoting the name of the owner. 
(e)  Impounding of abandoned carts. Whenever any cart is found abandoned on any street, highway, boulevard, alley or other public place in the city, the property shall be impounded by the police, who shall notify the owner thereof, who may reclaim the same by the payment of five dollars ($5.00). If the property is not reclaimed in a reasonable time, not to exceed thirty (30) days, it shall be disposed of as unclaimed property in the manner provided by section 26-41 et seq. 
(Code 1967, § 7-140)  
Sec. 34-6. - Planking and paving required at crossings. 
Every railroad company shall cause its tracks, where the tracks cross any public way in the city, to be properly planked or paved upon both sides of the tracks and between the rails at an even level with the top of the rails at such crossings. 
(Ord. No. 80-626, § 4, 3-14-06)  
Sec. 34-7. - Snow alerts. 
(a)  Purpose. Severe winter weather frustrates vehicular and pedestrian mobility, and creates a risk of harm to public health, safety, and welfare. As a preventative measure, this section gives the mayor the authority to declare a snow alert prompting the removal of parked cars, trailers, and other motor vehicles from city streets. The City of Warren engages in various efforts to subdue the risks created by inclement weather by reducing or eliminating the accumulation of snow and ice from public roadways. The primary and most efficient method by which the city engages such efforts is through use of snow plows and salt trucks. Motor vehicles which have not been removed will cause portions of the streets to remain unplowed and slick. Therefore, the city streets need to be clear of parked motor vehicles and trailers for the city to effectively reduce or eliminate the hazardous conditions. 
(b)  Definitions. For purposes of this section, the following words and phrases shall be interpreted as defined below, unless the context of the reading clearly manifests a contrary intent. 
City. City of Warren, Macomb County, Michigan. 
Mayor. The mayor of the City of Warren, or in the mayor's absence, his or her authorized representative. 
Street. The entire width between the boundary lines of every way which is publicly maintained for purposes of vehicular travel. 
Motor vehicle. Any self-propelled conveyance used for, or capable of being used for, purposes of land transportation. 
Trailer. Any apparatus, motorized or not, designed to be used in conjunction with or separate from a motor vehicle, which may be used for transportation or dwelling purposes. 
Stalled vehicle. A motor vehicle or trailer which has become immobilized due to the failure or absence of one (1) or more components essential to its operation. 
Snow alert. A parking prohibition caused by hazardous winter weather conditions, which becomes effective upon the declaration by the mayor in a manner prescribed by this section. 
(c)  Snow alert implementation; automatic effect; exemptions. 
(1)  Whenever the mayor finds, on the basis of falling snow, sleet, freezing rain, or a forecast by the United States Weather Bureau or other weather service, that weather conditions will make it necessary for motor vehicle traffic to be expedited and that parking on city streets be prohibited or restricted for snowplowing and other relevant purposes, the mayor may put into effect a parking prohibition on some streets, all streets, or parts thereof, within the boundaries of the City of Warren. 
(2)  This parking prohibition shall take immediate effect upon the mayor's declaration of a snow alert in a manner prescribed by this section. 
(3)  Any street on which parking is prohibited by the snow alert, but which has become clear of snow and ice from curb to curb for the entire length of the street, shall then be excluded from the parking restrictions imposed by the implementation of this section. 
(d)  Notice and termination. 
(1)  Upon the mayor's declaration of a snow alert, appropriate notice specifying the affected area(s) in which the parking prohibition has taken effect shall be publicly announced by means of television and radio broadcasts and/or telecasts by stations whose operating range services the entire city. Notice of the snow alert shall be placed on the city's online website and on the city's government television channel. 
(2)  When the conditions which gave rise to the declaration of the snow alert no longer exist and the purpose of this section has been served, the mayor shall terminate the parking prohibition by means of notice in a manner substantially consistent with the method in which the snow alert was announced. 
(e)  Prohibited parking; exemptions. 
(1)  While the snow alert is in effect, no person shall park or allow to remain parked, any motor vehicle, on any street within the city, on which parking has been prohibited by the mayor's declaration of the snow alert. 
(2)  In all areas where the snow alert has taken effect, owners of motor vehicles which have a license plate or properly placed placard which designates the vehicle for disabled parking shall be exempt from the parking restrictions imposed by this section; residents exempt under this subsection are required to park their motor vehicles as close to the curb as possible to provide maximum street access for plow trucks and emergency vehicles. 
(f)  Stalled vehicles. Whether in violation of this section or not, whenever any vehicle becomes stalled for any reason, on any city street within the City of Warren, the owner and/or operator of the vehicle shall take immediate action to have the stalled vehicle towed or otherwise removed from the city street. When a snow alert has been declared, no owner and/or operator shall abandon or leave the stalled vehicle on the city street regardless of whether the owner and/or operator has made an indication of the vehicle's stalled status, except for the actual time required to secure assistance and return without delay. 
(g)  Presumption of responsibility. For purposes of this section, the registered owner or lessee shall be presumed to be the party responsible for parking and/or leaving the motor vehicle in violation of this section. In any prosecution regarding a motor vehicle parked in violation of this section, proof that the motor vehicle was parked in violation of this section together with proof that the defendant named in the complaint was the registered owner or lessee of the motor vehicle at the time the violation occurred, shall constitute prima facie evidence that the named defendant is the party responsible for violating this section. 
(h)  Time for removal of vehicle; impoundment. 
(1)  Within six (6) hours after the snow alert has taken effect, all motor vehicles and trailers must be removed from any city street over which the snow alert has been declared. 
(2)  Upon the expiration of the six-hour period for removal, and pursuant to authority granted by MCL 257.252d(f), any motor vehicle or trailer parked on any city street subject to the snow alert, may be removed and impounded by order of the police department or a governmental agency designated by the police department. 
(3)  In addition to any fines which may be assessed for a violation of this section, the owner of the removed motor vehicle or trailer will be responsible for paying any costs related to its towing and impoundment. 
(i)  Penalty. 
(1)  The owner of any parked or stalled motor vehicle in violation of this section shall be responsible for the penalties outlined below in Section 34-8. 
(2)  The owner of any parked or stalled motor vehicle in violation of this section may be issued a municipal civil infraction for each 24-hour period the motor vehicle remains parked in violation. 
(j)  Existing traffic or zoning regulations. While temporarily in effect, this section shall not be interpreted as permitting parking in any area of the city where parking a motor vehicle or trailer is already prohibited by another provision of law. 
(Ord. No. 80-672, § 1, 10-28-08) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 80-672, adopted Oct. 28, 2008, amended § 34-7 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former § 34-7 pertained to penalties and derived from Ord. No. 80-626, adopted Mar. 14, 2006.  
Sec. 34-8. - Penalties. 
The violation of any provision of article I is a municipal civil infraction which shall result in the assessment of a fine of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) or more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per violation, plus costs and other sanctions for each infraction. 
(Ord. No. 80-672, § 2, 10-28-08)  
Secs. 34-9—34-25. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - VACATING PUBLIC WAYS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Charter reference— Authority to vacate public ways, § 3.1(b)(3)(a). 
 
Sec. 34-26. - Council authority. 
The city council shall have power to vacate any street, alley or public place, or any part thereof, subject to state law. Such power may be exercised by resolution of the city council. 
(Code 1967, § 7-101)  
Sec. 34-27. - Resolution required; delivery to planning commission; exception. 
Whenever the city council shall deem it advisable to vacate any street, alley or public place, or any part thereof, the city council shall by resolution so declare, and a copy of such resolution shall be delivered to the planning commission, except that when a petition for the vacating of any street, alley or public place, or any part thereof, shall have been duly executed by sixty (60) percent of all owners of record of land contiguous and adjoining such street, alley or public place, or any part thereof, being vacated, such petition shall be filed with the city clerk and by him or her delivered to the planning commission within seven (7) days after receipt thereof. 
(Code 1967, § 7-102)  
Sec. 34-28. - Consent by owners; hearing, notice not required. 
If the petition under section 34-127 shall have been duly executed by all owners of record of property contiguous and adjacent to such street, alley or public place, or any part thereof, as shown by the official records of the city, the planning commission may consider the petition and proceed as hereinafter provided, except that no publication of notice of public hearing shall be required. 
(Code 1967, § 7-103)  
Sec. 34-29. - Planning commission hearing; notice required. 
Within sixty (60) days from the delivery to the planning commission of the petition or copy of the city council's resolution pertaining to the vacating of any street, alley or public place, or any part thereof, the commission shall hold a public hearing on the proposed vacating of such street, alley or public place, or any part thereof, and make its report and recommendations thereon to the council; provided, however, that at least fifteen (15) days notice of the time and place of the public hearing shall be published in a newspaper of general circulation in the city and shall be given by United States mail to all owners of record of property contiguous and adjacent to such street, alley or public place, or any part thereof, at their respective addresses as indicated in the last assessment roll, and to each public utility company and each railroad company owning or operating across, upon or within three hundred (300) feet of such street, alley or public place, or any part thereof. 
(Code 1967, § 7-104)  
Sec. 34-30. - Council determination; resolution required. 
Any resolution vacating a street, alley or public place, or any part thereof, shall be adopted in the same manner as other resolutions, except as otherwise provided in this article; provided, however, that any resolution which overrules the recommendations of the planning commission shall require an affirmative vote of at least six (6) members of the city council. Action of the city council refusing to vacate any street, alley or public place, or any part thereof, shall be by resolution. 
(Code 1967, § 7-105)  
Sec. 34-31. - Vesting title under state law. 
Title to the land included within any street, alley or public place, or any part thereof, vacated under the provisions of this article, shall vest in the person entitled to the same under state law; provided, however, that in any case or cases not controlled by state law, the city council may provide for the vesting of title by the same resolution in which any street, alley or public place or any part thereof is vacated and may in such instances authorize the making and delivery of quit claim deeds on behalf of the city, to facilitate such vesting of title. 
(Code 1967, § 7-106) 
State Law reference— Disposition of vacated lands under state subdivision control act, MCL 560.227a.  
Sec. 34-32. - Resolutions vacating public ways; filing required. 
Within thirty (30) days after the adoption of a resolution vacating any street, alley or public place, or any part thereof, the city clerk shall file with the county register of deeds and the auditor general for the state, a certified copy of the resolution together with his or her certificate giving the name of any plat, subdivision or addition affected by the resolution. The city clerk shall further cause copies of the resolution to be recorded or filed in such other place and shall perform such other acts in relation thereto as may be required by law. 
(Code 1967, § 7-107)  
Sec. 34-33. - Vacating fees. 
The application shall be accompanied by a check for two hundred dollars ($200.00), payable to the city treasurer, to cover the costs of processing the application. This is in accordance with the requirements of this chapter and as approved by city council resolution. 
(Ord. No. 80-410, § 1, 6-23-92)  
Secs. 34-34—34-50. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - SIDEWALKS  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 34-51. - Definitions. 
The following words and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them: 
Contractor means the party performing the work. 
Driveway approach/apron means the improved portion of the street right-of-way designed to provide for vehicular travel from private property to a public roadway. 
Inspector means any representative of the city engineer designated to act as an inspector. 
Owner means the party holding title to the property abutting upon the public property or, for a condominium abutting upon public property, the condominium association. 
Sidewalk means squares of concrete generally parallel with the street and usually located one (1) foot from the property line in the public right of way and which is designed for pedestrian travel and does not include a lead walk or a driveway approach. 
Specifications means the standard specifications for sidewalks, driveways and curb cuts established by and on file with the division of engineering. 
(Code 1967, § 7-108; Ord. No. 80-559, § 2, 7-11-00) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally § 1-2.  
Sec. 34-52. - Permit required for construction and repair. 
No person shall construct, alter, change or repair any sidewalk, crosswalk, driveway approach, or any opening in or through any curb in any street or public way except in accordance with the lines, grade, slope and specifications as established by the city engineer and without first procuring a permit from the division of buildings and safety engineering or obtaining a street excavation permit from the department of public service. Permits shall be prominently displayed on the construction site. Permits may be revoked for failure to comply with the lines, grade, slope or specifications of the city engineer. 
(Code 1967, § 7-109; Ord. No. 80-559, § 2, 7-11-00)  
Sec. 34-53. - Unsafe, dangerous conditions prohibited. 
No person shall permit any sidewalk, crosswalk, or driveway approach which adjoins property owned by him or her to fall into a state of disrepair or to be unsafe or to be blocked by obstructing the same with bushes, trees, fixtures, or any other thing so that pedestrians or travelers on that sidewalk or vehicles traveling on the driveway approach do not have full use of the sidewalk or driveway approach. A violation of this section is a municipal civil infraction which shall result in the assessment of a fine of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) or not more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per violation, plus costs and other sanctions for each infraction. 
(Code 1967, § 7-110; Ord. No. 80-527, § 23, 1-13-98; Ord. No. 80-559, § 2, 7-11-00) 
Cross reference— Nuisances generally, Ch. 21.  
Sec. 34-54. - Determination and procedure for repair and construction. 
(a)  Whenever the city engineer or his designate shall determine that, pursuant to the engineering division specifications, a sidewalk, crosswalk or driveway approach is required to be constructed for the public health, safety or welfare, or is in a state of disrepair, unsafe or blocked for use, he/she or his/her designate, shall give a written notice to repair thereof to the owner. The notice to repair shall specify the construction of the sidewalk, crosswalk or driveway approach required, or the nature of the repairs to be made. The notice to repair shall also state that if the owner fails to comply within the specified time, then the city shall construct, reconstruct, or repair such sidewalk, crosswalk or driveway approach and charge the expense to the premises and the owner together with an administrative charge to cover administrative, bidding, engineering, and collection expenses. The appeal process whereby the owner may contest the notice to repair requirements shall also be included in the notice to repair. 
(b)  The engineering division shall develop a sidewalk policy and procedure manual and a copy shall be filed with the city clerk. 
(c)  The notice to repair shall be served by first class mail and a postcard notifying the owner of the need to repair shall be posted upon a conspicuous part of the owner's property abutting/adjacent to the sidewalk, crosswalk, or driveway approach/apron. Information as to the identity of the property owner is limited to the records maintained in the assessor's office at the time of the first notice to repair. 
(d)  The owner shall have forty-five (45) days from the date of the notice to repair to construct, reconstruct, or repair the sidewalk, crosswalk or driveway approach. If the owner fails to comply within forty-five (45) days, the engineering division or appropriate division may proceed with the required work. 
(e)  Appeal. The owner has twenty-one (21) days from the date of the notice to repair to appeal the order of repair to the director of public service or his/her designate. The director of public service or his/her designate shall hear the appeal and determine if the construction, reconstruction, or repair is necessary for the interest of public safety of the city. The director of public service or his/her designate may uphold orders, modify orders, invalidate orders or make such other determinations. The determination of the director of public service shall be final. If the owner fails to comply with the order of the public service director, the engineering division may proceed with the construction or repair. 
(f)  The engineering division may dispense with the notice requirement and proceed with the construction or repair of the sidewalk, crosswalk or driveway approach, if, in its opinion, the condition of the sidewalk, crosswalk, or driveway approach is unsafe and dangerous and requires immediate repair to assure public safety and to prevent the possibility of city liability for personal injury or property damage. 
(g)  The costs for construction or repair including administrative costs, penalties, and interests therein shall be a lien against the property abutting the sidewalk. If the owner fails to pay the costs of construction or repair, including administrative costs, the city may recover the money in an appropriate court of law and/or add all costs to the taxes assessed against the property as described in chapter 33. The costs when collected, shall be paid into the general fund of the city. 
(Code 1967, § 7-111; Ord. No. 80-407, § 1, 5-12-92; Ord. No. 80-559, § 2, 7-11-00) 
Charter reference— Special assessments, Ch. 10. 
Cross reference— Special assessments generally, Ch. 33.  
Sec. 34-55. - Driveway approaches required for curb cuts. 
No permit to cut any curb along a paved street shall be issued by the division of buildings and safety engineering unless the applicant shall agree in the application, as a condition of the issuance of the permit, to install a driveway approach of concrete within ninety (90) days after completion of the cut; provided, however, that if the work is stopped by the city because of cold weather, the ninety-day time limit will be tolled and will commence again from the date upon which further work is authorized to be resumed by the city engineer. Materials other than concrete may be allowed by the city engineer if in his or her judgment the construction is to be considered as temporary. 
(Code 1967, § 7-112)  
Sec. 34-56. - Paving of driveway approaches. 
(a)  Any existing driveway approach abutting a concrete street, or a concrete street overlayed with asphalt, shall be paved with concrete. If the driveway or approach is not paved with concrete, the director of public service shall give the property owner thirty (30) days' notice to pave the same, and if the person shall neglect or refuse to do so, the director of public service shall cause the driveway approach to be paved and he or she shall make a detailed report to city council of the cost and expense of performing such work, which cost and expense shall be charged to the property owner in the manner provided by the Charter relative to special assessments and pursuant to the provisions of this Code. 
(b)  Any existing driveway approach abutting an asphalt street, be paved with asphalt. If the driveway or approach is not paved with asphalt, the director of public service shall give the property owner thirty (30) days' notice to pave the same, and if the person shall neglect or refuse to do so, the director of public service shall cause the driveway approach to be paved and he or she shall make a detailed report to city council of the cost and expense of performing such work, which cost and expense shall be charged to the property owner in the manner provided by the Charter relative to special assessments and pursuant to the provisions of this Code. 
(c)  The design cross-sections governing the construction of an asphalt or concrete drive approach will be according to the standards set forth and maintained by the engineering division. 
(Code 1967, § 7-113; Ord. No. 80-620, § 1, 4-12-05) 
Charter reference— Special assessments, Ch. 10. 
Cross reference— Special assessments generally, Ch. 33.  
Sec. 34-57. - Completion of work. 
Work contemplated under any permit under this article shall be completed within ninety (90) days of the issuance of the permit, unless the work shall have been stopped by the city because of cold weather. In such case, the ninety (90) days will be tolled and will commence again from the day upon which further work shall be authorized by the city engineer. The division of engineering shall be notified at least twenty-four (24) hours in advance of the commencement of any concrete pouring under the permit. No concrete shall be placed until an inspection of all proposed work has been approved by the division of engineering. 
(Code 1967, § 7-117)  
Sec. 34-58. - Building materials, etc.; safety requirements. 
No person owning, building or repairing any house or other building shall permit any lumber, brick, plaster, mortar, earth, clay, sand, stone or other material to remain on the sidewalk after sunset of the day upon which it was placed there, without written permission from the police commissioner, subject to safeguards he or she may prescribe. 
(Code 1967, § 7-119)  
Sec. 34-59. - Temporary sidewalks. 
If a sidewalk is removed during construction, the owner or contractor shall furnish a temporary sidewalk to the satisfaction of the director of public service. The temporary sidewalk shall be replaced within thirty (30) days after construction is completed, or as soon thereafter as may be practicable. 
(Code 1967, § 7-120)  
Sec. 34-60. - Removal of snow and ice. 
The occupant of any premises, or the owner of any unoccupied premises, is required to keep the sidewalks in front of or adjacent to such premises cleared, so far as is practicable and reasonable, from snow and ice to facilitate pedestrian use. Where there are no sidewalks, the occupant or owner shall clear a path free from snow and ice where a sidewalk would otherwise be, to facilitate pedestrian use. Whenever any snow or ice has fallen or accumulated, it shall be cleared within twelve (12) hours after it has fallen or accumulated. The violation of this section is a municipal civil infraction which shall result in the assessment of a fine of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) or more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per violation, plus costs and other sanctions for each infraction. 
(Code 1967, § 7-121; Ord. No. 80-527, § 23, 1-13-98) 
Charter reference— Authority to require removal of snow, ice, dirt, etc., § 3.1(b)(3)(e).  
Sec. 34-61. - Limited guarantee—Sidewalk replacement. 
(a)  The city will replace a sidewalk not more than once every ten (10) years if it meets all the following criteria: 
(1)  If roots from a tree located in the public right-of-way caused the sidewalk to fall within the city's repair criteria; and 
(2)  The sidewalk was built on or after the effective date of this section pursuant to a permit and in full compliance with city standards and guidelines; and 
(3)  The property owner paid for the cost of replacing the existing sidewalk. 
(Ord. No. 80-559, § 3, 7-11-00)  
Sec. 34-62. - Permit for temporary holiday sidewalk displays. 
Anyone wanting to erect a temporary holiday sidewalk display shall contact the city's engineering division for a free permit. The proposed temporary holiday display shall not exhibit any public safety concerns such as trip hazards or exposed wiring hazards, which will be determined by the city's engineering division. The holiday display permit shall be valid for thirty (30) days. The permit holder may apply once for a three-week extension by contacting the city's engineering division. All fees and costs associated with a temporary holiday sidewalk display permit shall be waived. 
(Ord. No. 80-775 , § 1, 3-12-19)  
Secs. 34-63—34-70. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - CONTRACTOR'S LICENSE[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference— Licensing generally, Ch. 18. 
 
Sec. 34-71. - Required. 
All contractors laying, constructing or replacing sidewalks, crosswalks and/or driveway approaches or altering or cutting curbs within the city shall be required to obtain a license to perform such work from the office of the city clerk prior to the commencement of any of the aforementioned work as provided in this division. 
(Code 1967, § 7-118(a))  
Sec. 34-72. - Application. 
All applicants for a license under this division shall be required as a condition precedent to obtain a license to identify themselves; describe the type of entity, i.e., corporation, partnership or sole ownership; give the names, home addresses and titles of all corporation officers, number of partners, or sole owners. All applications must be signed by the applicant or his or her authorized representative, and the signature shall be notarized by a duly authorized notary public. 
(Code 1967, § 7-118(d))  
Sec. 34-73. - Fee. 
The license fee under this division shall be as prescribed in section 18-18. 
(Code 1967, § 7-118(a))
