Sec. 34-74. - Bond required. 
No license shall be issued to any contractor, firm or corporation until a blanket cash or surety bond in the amount of one thousand five hundred dollars ($1,500.00) is filed with the office of the city clerk, conditioned upon the faithful performance of all of the provisions of this article and all of the ordinances, rules and regulations of the city pertaining to the work to be done under any permit issued under this article, and shall be further conditioned upon the keeping and maintaining of all sidewalks, crosswalks and/or driveway approaches laid, constructed or replaced by him or her under any permit covered by the bond in good condition and fit for public travel for a period of two (2) years from and after the date of the final work inspection by the city engineer. 
(Code 1967, § 7-118(b))  
Sec. 34-75. - Insurance required. 
As a condition precedent to obtaining the license under this division, the contractor, at his or her expense, shall provide and keep in force during the entire year, comprehensive general liability insurance in the minimum limits of liability with respect to bodily injury of two hundred fifty thousand dollars ($250,000.00) for each person and five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) for each occurrence, and in respect to property damage one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for each accident. The policy of insurance shall be conditioned to pay all damages to the public ways of the city and for which the city may be held liable by reason of, or which is occasioned by, the doing of a thing or the exercise of the privilege for which the above license was granted. The policy of insurance shall be issued by an insurance company and in form satisfactory to the city, shall provide for at least ten (10) days prior written notice to the city in the event of cancellation or any material change, and a copy of such policy shall be delivered to the city prior to the issuance of the license. If the policy of insurance is cancelled or materially changed, the contractor's license shall be immediately suspended until a policy of insurance acceptable to the city has been reobtained; provided, however, that no such bond or insurance aforementioned shall be required of any owner for the laying, construction or replacement of any sidewalk, crosswalk and/or driveway approach adjoining property owned by such owner where such work is to be done and is in fact done personally by such owner. The applicant must submit in writing an agreement to hold the city harmless of every other damage of every other nature whether to persons or property, for which the city may be held liable, by reason of, or which is occasioned by, the doing of a thing or the exercise of a privilege for which the above license was granted. 
(Code 1967, § 7-118(c); Ord. No. 80-457, § 1, 6-14-94)  
Sec. 34-76. - Revocation. 
Giving false information in the application for a license or continued violation of the provisions of this article shall be grounds for revocation of this license by the director of public service. 
(Code 1967, § 7-118(d))  
Secs. 34-77—34-85. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - PERMIT 
 
Sec. 34-86. - Required. 
No work shall be performed under this article without a permit as provided in this division.  
Sec. 34-87. - Plans and specifications; supervision. 
No work for which a permit is required under this division shall be done by any person except in accordance with plans and specifications approved by the city engineer, and all work shall be done under the supervision of the division of engineering. 
(Code 1967, § 7-114)  
Sec. 34-88. - Permit fee required. 
A fee for a permit to construct or replace a curb cut, sidewalk, crosswalk or driveway approach shall be collected by the division of buildings and safety engineering as established by resolution adopted by city council. 
(Code 1967, § 7-116; Ord. No. 80-359, § 1, 6-28-88; Ord. No. 80-559, § 4, 7-11-00; Ord. No. 80-609, § 1, 4-27-04)  
Sec. 34-89. - Refusal to issue; appeal, hearing. 
If the division of buildings and safety engineering shall refuse to issue any permit under this division, the applicant may appeal to the city council which shall grant a hearing thereon, and the decision of the city council shall be final. In granting a permit after the hearing, the city council may impose such conditions therefor as it may deem desirable to protect the safety of persons and property. 
(Code 1967, § 7-122)  
Sec. 34-90. - Suspension and revocation. 
All work done pursuant to any permit under this division shall be inspected by the city engineer, and he or she may suspend or revoke any permit so granted where either the workmanship or materials used does not conform to the plans and specifications approved or required upon issuance of the permit, or when the terms of any permit or of this article are violated. No person shall perform any work authorized by any permit or cause any such work to be performed while that permit is suspended or revoked. 
(Code 1967, § 7-115)  
Secs. 34-91—34-110. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - STREET EXCAVATION OR OPENINGS 
 
Sec. 34-111. - Permit required. 
No person shall make any excavation or opening in or under any street or public place without first procuring a permit from the department of public service. 
(Code 1967, § 7-123)  
Sec. 34-112. - Construction regulations of department of public service. 
The department of public service may make such regulations pertaining to the making of openings or excavations in streets or public places as are necessary to secure the health and safety of the public and for the protection of property, and such regulations shall constitute the standards upon which the permit required under this article shall be issued. 
(Code 1967, § 7-126)  
Sec. 34-113. - Bond and/or insurance required. 
(a)  No permit shall be granted under this article until a bond or policy of insurance has been filed with the department of public service. The bond or policy of insurance shall be in the sum of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00), unless a larger bond shall be required by the director of public service. All bonds or policies of insurance shall be conditioned to pay all damages to the streets of the city and to hold the city harmless of every other damage of every other nature, whether to persons or property, for which the city may be held liable by reason of, or which is occasioned by, the doing of a thing or the exercise of the privilege for which the permit upon which the bond or policy of insurance was based, was granted. 
(b)  Excavations on local residential streets shall require a minimum surety bond in the amount of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00), insurance coverage in limits of three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) public liability and five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) property damage, a maximum surety bond in the amount of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00), and insurance coverage in the limits of five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) public liability and one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) property damage. 
(c)  Excavations on major thoroughfares shall require a minimum surety bond in the amount of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) and insurance coverage in the limits of five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) public liability and one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) property damage, a maximum surety bond in the amount of three million dollars ($3,000,000.00), and insurance coverage in the limits of one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) public liability and two million dollars ($2,000,000.00) property damage. 
(Code 1967, §§ 7-125, 7-125.1)  
Sec. 34-114. - Barricade required. 
No person making an opening in a street or public way shall fail to guard the same fully during the period of construction, and no person causing any such opening to be used, nor the owner thereof, shall fail to guard or barricade the same while in use, so as to protect the safety of the public. No person using any street opening, or causing the same to be used, shall fail to close the opening in accordance with the directions of the director of public service immediately after use. 
(Code 1967, § 7-124(a))  
Sec. 34-115. - Liability to city for loss or damage. 
Whenever any person performs any work, as provided in this article, either under contract with the city or by virtue of any permit issued by the city, such person shall be liable to the city for any and every loss or damage which the city may sustain and for all sums which it may have to pay to any person by reason of any loss or injury sustained through any carelessness or negligence in doing the work, or by reason of any neglect or failure to comply with the provisions of this article or Code. 
(Code 1967, § 7-133)  
Chapter 35 - SUBDIVISION REGULATIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference— Planning department, planning commission, § 7.22. 
Cross reference— Any ordinance dedicating or accepting any plat or subdivision in the city saved from repeal, § 1-6(8); buildings and building regulations, Ch. 9; mobile homes and trailers, Ch. 20; signs, Ch. 31; soil removal, dumping and regrading, Ch. 32; streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 34; water and sewers, Ch. 41; zoning, App. A. 
State Law reference— Subdivision control act, MCL 560.101 et seq.; minimum standards, MCL 560.259. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 35-1. - Short title. 
This chapter shall be known and may be cited as the City of Warren Subdivision Regulations 
(Code 1967, § 6-501)  
Sec. 35-2. - Purposes. 
(a)  The purpose of this chapter is to regulate and control the subdivision of land within the corporate limits of the city, in order to promote the safety, public health and general welfare of the community. 
(b)  This chapter is designed to: 
(1)  Provide for the orderly growth and harmonious development of the community, consistent with the master plan; 
(2)  Secure adequate traffic circulation through coordinated street systems with relation to major thoroughfares, adjoining subdivisions and public facilities; 
(3)  Achieve individual property lots of maximum utility and livability; 
(4)  Ensure adequate provisions for water, drainage and sanitary sewer facilities, and other health requirements; 
(5)  Secure adequate provisions for recreational areas, school sites, and other public facilities; and 
(6)  Facilitate the further resubdivision of large tracts into smaller parcels of land. 
(c)  This chapter is also formulated to aid in the enforcement of development standards as authorized in the building code, zoning ordinance and the master plan for the city. 
(Code 1967, § 6-502)  
Sec. 35-3. - Definitions. 
The following words and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them: 
Accessible means that the parcel: 
(1)  Has an area where a driveway does provide or can provide vehicular access to an existing road or street and the area meets all applicable standards of the state department of transportation, county road commission, or city ordinance; or 
(2)  Is served by an existing easement or proposed easement that provides or can provide vehicular access to an existing road or street and that area meets all applicable standards of the state transportation department, county road commission, or city ordinance. 
Alley means public or private right-of-way which provides a secondary means of access to a lot, block or parcel of land. 
Block means property abutting one (1) side of a street and lying between the two (2) nearest intersecting streets, or between the nearest such street and railroad right-of-way, unsubdivided acreages, river or live stream; or between any of the foregoing and any other barrier to the continuity of development. 
Building line or setback line means a line parallel to a street right-of-way line, shore of a lake, edge of a stream, river bank or drain, established on a parcel of land or on a lot for the purpose of prohibiting construction of a building, parking area or other structure between such line and right-of-way, public area or shore of a lake, edge of a stream, river bank or drain. 
Building site means any parcel or lot described as a single parcel or lot in an instrument of conveyance or plat and intended for building development. Designation of a parcel identification number does not signify that the site is buildable. A lot or parcel of land shall not be a building site unless the lot or parcel conforms to the minimum area dimensions required for the zoning district in which it is located; except those lots described and fixed in a plat recorded prior to the time of the adoption of the zoning ordinance shall still be considered building sites even if they do not meet the minimum lot dimensions. 
Caption means the name by which the plat is legally and commonly known. 
Commercial development means a business center establishing building area, parking areas, service areas, screen planting and widening, turning movement and safety lane roadway improvements. 
Comprehensive development plan or master plan means the comprehensive land use plan for the city, including graphic written proposals indicating the general locations recommended for streets, parks, schools, public buildings, zoning districts, and all physical developments of the city and includes any unit or part of such plan separately adopted, and any amendments to such plan or parts thereof duly adopted by the planning commission and certified to the city council and to the county register of deeds. 
County plat coordinating committee (P.C.C.) means a committee represented by the officers of the county road commission, the county public works commission, the county department of health and the county planning commission and established for the purpose of reviewing preliminary plats to afford, advise and give assistance to the developer and his or her engineer. 
Dedication means the intentional appropriation of land by the owner to public use. 
Developer. See "subdivider." 
Division means the partitioning or splitting of a parcel or tract of land by the proprietor thereof or by his or her heirs, executors, administrators, legal representatives, successors, or assigns that results in one (1) or more parcels of less than 40 acres or the equivalent, and that satisfies the requirements of sections 108 and 109 of the Land Division Act, MCL 560.101 et seq. 
The Land Division Act, MCL 560.101 et seq., does not designate a property transfer between two (2) or more adjacent parcels where the property taken from one (1) parcel is added to an adjacent parcel a division, however, such property transfer shall be reviewed pursuant to section 35-27 to determine whether the resulting parcels are in conformity with the Code of Ordinances. Any resulting parcel shall not be considered a building site unless the parcel conforms to all requirements of the Code of Ordinances. 
Easement means a right or privilege over a specific portion of land area granted by the owner to the public, a corporation, or some particular person or persons for specific uses and purposes, and which is designated a "public" or "private" easement depending on the nature of the user. 
Exempt split means the partitioning or splitting of a parcel or tract of land by the proprietor that does not result in one (1) or more parcels of less than forty (40) acres or the equivalent provided that the resulting parcels are accessible. 
The Land Division Act, MCL 560.101 et seq., does not require approval under the Act for an exempt split when the property transfer is between two (2) or more adjacent parcels and the property taken from one (1) parcel is added to the adjacent parcel, however, such property transfer shall be reviewed pursuant to section 35-27 to determine whether the resulting lots or parcels are in conformity with the Code of Ordinances. Any resulting lot or parcel shall not be considered a building site unless the lot or parcel conforms to all requirements of the Code of Ordinances. 
Floodplain means that area of land adjoining the channel of a river, stream, watercourse, lake or other watercourse which will be inundated by a flood as defined by the zoning ordinance for the city. 
Greenbelts or bufferparks means a strip or parcel of land, privately restricted or publicly dedicated as open space located between similar or dissimilar uses for the purpose of protecting and enhancing each use. 
Health department means the state, city, county or district health department having jurisdiction. 
Improvements means grading, street surfacing, curb and gutter, sidewalks, crosswalks, water mains and lines, sanitary and storm sewers, culverts, bridges, utilities, trees, and other additions to the natural state of land which increases its value, utility or habitability. 
Industrial development means a planned area designed specifically for nonresidential use with special accommodations for industrial uses providing screened buffers, streets with seventy (70) feet of right-of-way and turning movement and safety lane roadway improvements where necessary. 
Lot means a measured portion of a parcel or tract of land, which is described and fixed in a recorded plat. 
(1)  Lot depth means the horizontal distance between the front and rear lot lines, measured along the median between the side lot lines. 
(2)  Lot width means the horizontal distance between the side lot lines measured at the setback line and at right angles to the lot depth. 
Lot split means the partitioning or splitting of a lot described and fixed in a recorded plat into one (1) but no more than four (4) lots. 
Master plan. See "comprehensive development plan." 
Outlot, when included within the boundary of a recorded plat, means a lot set aside for purposes other than a building site, park, or other land dedicated to public use or reserved to private use. 
Parcel means a continuous area or acreage of land which is described in an instrument of conveyance or survey prepared by a professional surveyor. 
Performance guarantee means any security including performance bonds, escrow agreements, and other similar collateral or surety agreements, which may be accepted by the city council as a guarantee that required subdivision improvements will be made by the developer. 
Plat means a map or chart of a subdivision of land drawn in accordance with this chapter. 
(1)  Pre-preliminary plat means a map drawn to scale, showing the existing features of a site and its surroundings and the general layout of a proposed subdivision prepared in conformance with section 35-22. 
(2)  Preliminary plat means a map showing the salient features of a proposed subdivision of land submitted to an approving authority for purposes of preliminary consideration prepared in conformance with the Subdivision Control Act and sections 35-23 and 35-24. 
(3)  Final plat means a map of all or part of a subdivision prepared and the accuracy certified by a registered civil engineer or professional surveyor in accordance with the requirements of the Subdivision Control Act and section 35-25 and suitable for recording. 
Professional surveyor means a land surveyor who is licensed and registered in the state. 
Property transfer means the transfer of ownership of property by an instrument of conveyance such as, a deed or land contract. 
Proprietor means a natural person, firm, association, partnership, corporation or any combination that holds an ownership interest in land whether recorded or not. 
Public open space means land dedicated or reserved for use by the general public. It includes, but is not limited to parks, parkways, recreation areas, school sites, community or public building sites, streets and highways, and public parking spaces. 
Public reservation means a portion of a subdivision which is set aside for public use and made available for public use and acquisition. 
Public utility means any person, firm or corporation, municipal department, board or commission, duly authorized to furnish, and furnishing under state or city regulations to the public: gas, steam electricity, sewage disposal, communication, telegraph, transportation or water or other services of a similar nature. 
Replat means the process of changing, or a map or plat which changes, the boundaries of a recorded subdivision plat or part thereof as provided in the Subdivision Control Act. 
Right-of-way means land reserved, used or to be used for a street, alley, walkway or other public purposes. 
Sight distance means the unobstructed vision on a horizontal plane along a street centerline, from a driver-eye height of three and three-fourths (3.75) feet and an object height of six (6) inches. 
Sketch plan. See "preliminary plat." 
Street means a public way or right-of-way dedicated to public use, which provides vehicular and pedestrian access to adjacent properties, whether designated as a street, highway, thoroughfare, parkway, road, avenue, lane or however otherwise designated, and includes the land between right-of-way lines whether improved or unimproved and may compromise pavement, shoulders, curbs and gutters, sidewalks, parking areas, lawn areas and other areas within the right-of-way lines. The following are included. 
(1)  Collector street means a street intended primarily to gather traffic from minor streets and carry it to major streets. 
(2)  Cul-de-sac means a short minor street, having one (1) end open to traffic and being permanently terminated at the other end by a vehicular turn around. 
(3)  Expressway means those streets designed for high speed, high volume traffic, with full or limited access, some grade crossings and limited driveway connections. 
(4)  Freeway means those streets designed for high speed, high volume through traffic with completely controlled access, no grade crossings and no private driveway connections. 
(5)  Industrial street means a street serving or intended to serve lots of parcels of land platted or to be developed for industrial use or as an industrial subdivision. 
(6)  Major thoroughfare means an arterial street of great continuity which is intended to serve as a large volume traffic way for both the immediate area and region beyond, and may be designated in the master road plan as a major thoroughfare. 
(7)  Marginal access street means a minor street parallel and adjacent to a major thoroughfare and which provides access to abutting properties and protection from through traffic. 
(8)  Minor street means a street supplementary to a secondary thoroughfare and intended to serve primarily the local needs of the neighborhood and of limited continuity used primarily as access to abutting residential properties. 
(9)  Public walkway means a public right-of-way dedicated for the purpose of a pedestrian access to residential areas, and located so as to connect to two (2) or more streets, or a street and parcel of land, or other open space. 
Subdivide or subdivision means the partitioning or splitting of a parcel or tract of land by the proprietor that results in one (1) or more parcels of less than forty (40) acres or the equivalent, and that is not exempted from the platting requirements under section 108 and 109 of the Land Division Act. 
The Land Division Act, MCL 560.101 et seq., does not require subdivision for a property transfer between two (2) or more adjacent parcels where the property taken from one (1) parcel is added to the adjacent parcel, however, such property transfer shall be reviewed pursuant to section 35-27 to determine whether the resulting parcels are in conformity with the Code of Ordinances. Any resulting parcel shall not be considered a building site unless the parcel conforms to all requirements of the Code of Ordinances. 
Subdivider means a person or persons, firm, corporation, association, partnership, trust or any legal combination of them or any other legal entity proceeding under this chapter to affect a division or subdivision of land under this chapter. The word "subdivider" shall include the word "proprietor." 
Subdivision Control Act means Act 288 of Public Acts of 1967 (MCL 560.101 et seq.), as amended, and retitled the Land Division Act, Public Act 591 of 1996. 
Topographical survey map means a map indicating all the dimensions, physical characteristics, and if requested, contour lines at sufficient intervals to permit determination of existing and proposed grades and drainage. 
Tract means two (2) or more parcels that share a common property line and are under the same ownership. 
(Code 1967, § 6-503; Ord. No. 80-563, § 1, 11-28-00) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
State Law reference— Similar definitions, MCL 560.102.  
Sec. 35-4. - Variances. 
(a)  Where in the case of a particular proposed subdivision, it can be shown that strict compliance with the requirements of this chapter would result in extraordinary hardship to the subdivider because of unusual topography, or other such not self-inflicted condition, or that these conditions would result in inhibiting the achievement of the objectives of this chapter, the planning commission may vary, modify or waive the requirements so that substantial justice may be done and the public interest secured; provided, that any such variance, modification or waiver will not have the effect of nullifying the intent and purpose of this chapter and the master plan for the city. 
(b)  In no case shall any variation, modification or waiver be more than a minimum easing of the requirements and in no instance shall it have the effect of reducing the traffic capacity of any street (below that shown of the master plan for the city) or be in conflict with any existing zoning regulations. 
(c)  Such variances, modifications and waivers may be granted only by the affirmative vote of two-thirds of all members of the planning commission. 
(d)  In granting variances, modifications and waivers, the planning commission may require such conditions as will, in its judgment, secure substantially the objectives of the standards or requirements so affected. 
(Code 1967, § 6-549)  
Secs. 35-5—35-20. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - PLATTING PROCEDURE AND DATA REQUIRED 
 
Sec. 35-21. - Preapplication investigation. 
(a)  Prior to the preparation of a preliminary plat, the subdivider may meet informally with the planning department and other city agencies concerned to investigate the procedures and standards of the city. 
(b)  The subdivider shall familiarize himself or herself with the zoning ordinance, subdivision regulations, engineering specifications and other similar ordinances or controls relative to the subdivision and improvements of land, so as to make himself or herself aware of the requirements of the city. 
(c)  The subdivider shall review the area zoning for the proposed subdivision to determine if it is properly zoned for the intended use. 
(d)  The subdivider shall complete an investigation of existing schools and of public open spaces including parks and playgrounds to serve the proposed subdivision. 
(e)  The subdivider shall investigate the relationship of the proposed subdivision with respect to the master thoroughfare plan. 
(f)  The subdivider shall investigate the standards for sewage disposal, water supply and drainage of the city and county, and the health standards of the county and the state. 
(g)  The subdivider shall review the Subdivision Control Act, and the requirements of those state and county agencies which are required by such public act to review and approve the plat. 
(Code 1967, § 6-504)  
Sec. 35-22. - Preapplication review. 
(a)  The preapplication layout, if submitted, shall consist of the following: 
(1)  General layout of streets, blocks and lots in sketch form; 
(2)  Existing conditions and characteristics of the land and adjacent to the site; 
(3)  Any general area set aside for schools, parks and other community facilities. 
(b)  Procedure: 
(1)  The subdivider shall submit ten (10) copies of the preapplication layout to the county plat coordinating committee for their preliminary review and present evidence of having done so with the city planning department. 
(2)  The subdivider shall submit twelve (12) copies of the preapplication layout to the planning department. 
(3)  The planning department will review the plan with the subdivider or his or her agent. The review shall consist of examining the following: 
a.  Major thoroughfares in the area; 
b.  Utility systems available to service the platted areas; 
c.  Adjacent land use; 
d.  Unusual development problems; 
e.  Topography; 
f.  Existing zoning; 
g.  Adequacy of existing schools and public open space; 
h.  Availability and feasibility of providing city services; 
i.  Conformance to the master plan; 
j.  Application ordinance provisions; 
k.  Environmental effects. 
(4)  The planning department shall review the proposed subdivision and: 
a.  Stipulate the necessary changes that would make the plat acceptable for processing; 
b.  Notify the proprietor of the results of the preapplication review. 
(5)  The subdivider shall submit to the county plat coordinating committee seven (7) copies for their preliminary review and present evidence of having done so with the planning department. 
(Code 1967, § 6-504)  
Sec. 35-23. - Application, review and tentative approval of preliminary plat. 
(a)  Procedure. The subdivider shall submit to the city clerk not less than thirty (30) copies of the preliminary plat and location map, together with a written application in triplicate and other data required by this chapter. 
(b)  Submittal. The following shall be shown on the preliminary plat or submitted with it: 
(1)  Statement of intended use of the proposed plat, such as residential single-family, two-family and multiple housing, commercial, industrial or recreational; 
(2)  Proposed sites, if any, for multifamily dwellings, shopping centers, churches, industry and other nonpublic uses exclusive of single-family dwellings; 
(3)  Any sites proposed for parks, playgrounds, schools or other public uses. 
(c)  Fees. The application shall be accompanied by a check for five hundred dollars ($500.00) for the first five (5) acres or portion thereof plus twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for each additional one (1) acre or portion thereof as required in accordance with this chapter and as approved by city council resolution. 
(d)  Preliminary plat. The preliminary plat, with a topographical map superimposed at the same scale, shall contain the following information and shall be drawn up and submitted in the following manner: 
(1)  Scale of map (minimum scale one (1) inch equals one hundred (100) feet); 
(2)  Name of and acreage contained within the proposed subdivision; 
(3)  Name, address and phone number of subdivider, proprietor, owner, engineer, land surveyor, designer or planner who prepared the preliminary plat: 
(4)  Location of the subdivision, giving the numbers of section, town and range, and the name of the city and county; 
(5)  Date of preparation, scale and north point; 
(6)  Lots and outlots shall be known as follows: 
a.  All lots to be numbered consecutively; 
b.  Total number of lots to be shown; 
c.  All outlots to be lettered alphabetically; 
d.  Total number of outlots to be shown; 
e.  The length of each lot line; 
f.  Width of each lot; 
g.  Building setback lines; 
h.  Width and location of any known existing easement. 
(7)  Existing elevations around the perimeter of the property to be subdivided to a point two hundred fifty (250) feet outside the perimeter. The elevations shall be given at all points or locations where property lines change course or at intervals of not more than one hundred (100) feet. Contour lines shall be shown at one (1) foot intervals except where the topography is such that the intervals except where the topography is such that the interval should be increased for clarity, in which case contours shall be shown at two (2) foot or five (5) foot intervals as determined by the city engineer; 
(8)  The proposed street layout shall be shown indicating: 
a.  Width of the right-of-way; 
b.  Proposed connections with existing or future streets; 
c.  Width and location of public walkways; 
d.  Rights-of-way and easements, showing location, width and purpose. 
(9)  Designation of any land proposed to be acquired, reserved or dedicated for public use and/or the use of property owners in the subdivision; 
(10)  All land within the boundaries of the plat shall be shown thereon in such a manner that title to the area may be clearly established as to whether dedicated to public use or reserved to private use; 
(11)  The exterior boundaries of the subdivision shall include and correctly show the area within the existing right-of-way of any abutting street, county road or state trunk line highway, if such area has not previously been dedicated to public use and if it is the proprietor's land; 
(12)  When any part of this land lies within or abuts a flood plain area, the plat shall include the following: 
a.  The flood plain, as established by ordinance of the city, shall be shown within a contour line; 
b.  The flood plain area shall be clearly labeled on the plat. 
(e)  Review of preliminary plat (step 1): 
(1)  Upon being furnished with all the required information and data, the preliminary plat and location map shall be referred to the appropriate city departments, the appropriate local school districts, Michigan Bell, Detroit Edison, Consumers Power, Comcast Cablevision of Warren, and any other governmental board, agency or authority the city deems has an interest or concern in the plat for their review and recommendations. 
(2)  Following review of the preliminary plat by the above, it shall be forwarded to the planning department with written comments and recommendations by the reviewing party. 
(f)  Review of preliminary plat (step 2): 
(1)  The planning department shall also incorporate into its review the reports filed by the various city departments other governmental authorities and utility companies as provided for in subsection (e)(1). In addition, the planning department shall incorporate the findings and reports from the county plat coordinating committee. 
(2)  The planning department shall prepare a report of its findings and recommendations based on the above review and shall submit same to the planning commission at the time of the hearing before the planning commission. 
(g)  Notice of hearing. The planning commission shall hold a hearing on the proposed plat and notice of the hearing shall be sent to the name and address shown on the plat by registered or certified mail; the notice shall inform of the time and place of the meeting of the planning commission which will consider the plat; the notice shall be sent not less than five (5) days before the date fixed therefor. Similar notice shall be mailed to owners of land immediately adjoining the platted land, as their names appear on the tax records of the city or county. A notice of hearing shall be sent to Michigan Bell, Detroit Edison, Consumers Power Company and any other affected public utility company. 
(h)  Tentative approval of preliminary plat by planning commission. Following the receipt and review of all comments and recommendations and following the hearing on the plat, the planning commission shall, if it finds that all conditions have been met, recommend tentative approval of the preliminary plat and record same on the plat in its minutes; or recommend disapproval of the proposed plat with reasons for such disapproval to be recorded in the minutes of the planning commission meeting, and forward the same with a letter advising of the approval or disapproval and the reasons therefor to the city council and the subdivider. The planning commission shall forward its recommendations to the city council within fifty-six (56) days after submittal of the application to the city clerk. 
(i)  Tentative approval of preliminary plat by city council. The city council, within ninety (90) days from the date of filing of application, shall tentatively approve the proposed plat and date its approval on the plat which is to be returned to the developer; or set forth in writing its reasons for rejection and requirements for tentative approval. The ninety-day period may be extended if the applicant consents. 
(j)  Conditions and duration of tentative approval. Tentative approval of the preliminary plat shall confer upon the proprietor for a period of one (1) year from date approval of lot sizes, lot orientation and street layout. Such tentative approval may be extended if applied for by the proprietor and granted by the city council. 
(Code 1967, § 6-505; Ord. No. 80-411, § 1, 6-23-92) 
State Law reference— Preliminary plat, MCL 560.111 et seq.  
Sec. 35-24. - Final approval of preliminary plat. 
(a)  Distribution to authorities. The subdivider shall submit an approved tentative preliminary plat to the various authorities as required by Sections 112 through 119 of the Subdivision Control Act. 
(b)  List of authorities. The subdivider shall file with the director of public service a list of all authorities to whom validated copies of the preliminary plat have been distributed. 
(c)  Submittal to the city clerk: 
(1)  When the subdivider has secured the approval of the various approving authorities as required by Sections 112 and 119 of the Subdivision Control Act he or she shall deliver all copies plus not less than twenty (20) copies of the proposed final preliminary plat to the city clerk. 
(2)  A certificate signed by a registered engineer or surveyor certifying that all proposed lots conform to the minimum requirements for the particular zoning district as set forth in the zoning ordinance shall accompany the submittal. 
(3)  The application shall be accompanied by a check for five hundred dollars ($500.00) for the first five (5) acres or portion thereof plus twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for each additional one (1) acre or portion thereof as required in accordance with this chapter and as approved by city council resolution. 
(d)  Review and final approval of preliminary plat: 
(1)  The preliminary plat shall be reviewed by the director of public service in order that the director shall make written comments to the city council regarding the preliminary plat. 
(2)  The planning department shall also review the preliminary plat and prepare a written report for the director of public service relative to how the plat conforms with the approved tentative plat with respect to street layout and lot orientation. 
(3)  If the preliminary plat does not meet all requirements the director of public service shall notify the subdivider by letter of what specific requirements have not been met and the information necessary to meet requirements for approval and the date for resubmission of required information. 
(4)  When the preliminary plat meets all requirements laid down for tentative approval and the certifications required by Sections 112 through 119 of the Subdivision Control Act have been verified the director of public service shall forward the preliminary plat to the city council. 
(e)  Final approval of the preliminary plat by city council: 
(1)  The city council shall consider and review the preliminary plat at its next meeting, or within twenty (20) days from the date of verified compliance with all conditions of tentative approval of preliminary plat. 
(2)  The city council shall give final approval of the preliminary plat, if the proprietor has met all conditions laid down for approval of the plat, or reject the plat and advise the proprietor of the reasons for the rejection. 
(3)  The city council shall instruct the city clerk to promptly notify the proprietor of approval of rejection in writing. 
(4)  The city council shall instruct the city clerk to note all proceedings in the minutes of the meeting, which minutes shall be open for inspection. 
(5)  The twenty-day period for consideration by the city council may be extended if the applicant consents. 
(f)  Conditions and duration of approval of preliminary plat: 
(1)  Approval of a preliminary plat shall not constitute approval of the final plat, but rather, that final plat approval shall be conditional on all requirements being met. 
(2)  Final approval of the preliminary plat shall be effective for a period of two (2) years from the date of approval by the city council, but may be extended for periods not to exceed one (1) year, if applied for by the subdivider in writing and granted in writing by the city council. 
(3)  No installation or construction of any improvements shall be made before the final approval of the preliminary plat by the city council, final approval of engineering plans by the city engineer and payment of all fees to the city treasurer as required under the provisions of this chapter. 
(g)  Final engineering plans review fee schedule. All final plat fees shall be determined by the director of public service and collection of same verified by the director of public service and collection of same verified by the director of public service. All fees shall be established by council resolution and collected in advance of the installation or construction of any improvements. 
(Code 1967, § 6-505; Ord. No. 80-412, § 1, 6-23-92) 
State Law reference— Preliminary plat, MCL 560.111 et seq.  
Sec. 35-25. - Final plat. 
The procedure for preparation and review of the final plat shall be as follows: 
(1)  Requirements: 
a.  The final plat shall comply with the provisions of the Subdivision Control Act. 
b.  The final plat shall conform to the preliminary plat (stage 2) as approved, shall constitute only that portion of the approved preliminary plat which the subdivider proposed to record and develop at the time; provided, however, that such portion conforms to this chapter. 
c.  A written application for approval and the filing and recording fee required by Section 241 of the Subdivision Control Act shall accompany all final plats. 
(2)  Filing and review: 
a.  One (1) mylar and not less than twenty-five (25) copies of the final plat shall be filed with the city clerk and the subdivider shall deposit such sums of money as required by this chapter or any other ordinance of the city with the city treasurer. 
b.  The final plat shall be reviewed by the director of public service as to compliance with the approved preliminary plat and plans for utilities and other improvements. 
c.  The director of public service shall notify the city council of their recommendations for approval or rejection of the final plat. 
(3)  Final approval: 
a.  The city council shall consider and review the final plat at its next meeting within twenty (20) days from the date of submission to the city clerk. 
b.  If the final plat meets all requirements, the city council shall prepare a resolution of approval of the final plat and authorize the city clerk to sign the plat on behalf of the city. 
c.  If the final plat does not meet all requirements, the city council shall reject the plat and specify the reasons for rejection. 
d.  Upon the approval of the final plat by the city council the subsequent approvals shall follow the procedure set forth in the Subdivision Control Act. The mylar copy shall be forwarded to the clerk of the county plat board. 
(Code 1967, § 6-506) 
State Law reference— Submission of final plat, MCL 560.161 et seq.  
Sec. 35-26. - Lot splits. 
(a)  Application. The applicant filing a request to split a lot located within a recorded plat shall submit an application to the planning commission for lot split. The application shall include the following information and documents: 
(1)  An application for approval of lot split shall be submitted to the planning department. Upon receipt of a complete application, the planning commission shall schedule and hold a hearing. An application is complete upon receipt of: 
a.  The required maps of the proposed lot split; 
b.  The application fee; and 
c.  Any other information specified by the planning department to ascertain that the proposed lot split conforms to the provisions of the ordinance. 
(2)  Owner's name, address and signature assenting to the application; 
(3)  Full legal description including subdivision name and lot numbers; 
(4)  Names of abutting subdivisions or names of the owners of the abutting un-platted property; 
(5)  Twenty-four (24) maps of the proposed lot split, drawn to a scale required by the planning department, and prepared by a professional surveyor. 
(6)  Fee. The application shall be accompanied by a check in the amount of two-hundred dollars ($200.00). Such fee is required to cover the costs of processing the application, holding the hearing and conducting a site inspection. 
(b)  Map specifications. The map of the proposed lot split shall be prepared pursuant to the specifications required by the planning department. 
(c)  Review of proposed lot split. The map of the proposed lot split shall be distributed and reviewed by the following city departments: 
(1)  Assessing department to determine whether the number of splits exceed the allowable number of divisions under the Land Division Act, MCL 560.101 et seq. 
(2)  Building division, to determine whether the split complies with all applicable building regulations. 
(3)  Zoning official to determine whether each resulting lot is accessible; the proposed split complies with all applicable zoning ordinance provisions; and the resulting lots meet the minimum lot size dimensions. 
(4)  Engineering division to assess whether the lots and abutting streets are satisfactorily graded and drained. 
(5)  Fire department to determine whether each resulting lot is accessible. 
(6)  Treasurer to determine whether the currently due taxes have been paid. 
Each department shall review the map of the proposed lot split and provide a recommendation of approval or disapproval to the planning commission within fifteen (15) days before the scheduled hearing date. 
(d)  Review of proposed lot split by planning department. The planning department shall review the proposed lot split for conformance with all ordinances, the Land Division Act requirements, applicable administrative regulations and the master plan for the City. Such review shall include a site inspection. A recommendation shall be prepared and submitted to the planning commission for consideration at the hearing. No approval shall be recommended unless: 
(1)  Each resulting lot is accessible. 
(2)  The proposed split complies with all applicable ordinance provisions. 
(3)  The proposed split does not render an existing structure to not comply with the zoning ordinance, unless such structure is removed. 
(4)  The number of splits do not exceed the allowable number of divisions under the Land Division Act, MCL 560.101 et seq. 
(5)  The lots and abutting streets are graded and drained to the satisfaction of the engineering division; and 
(6)  The utility companies are provided with notice of the proposed lot split so that they have an opportunity to acquire any easement they may require. 
(7)  All taxes currently due and owing on the parent parcel are paid in full. 
(e)  Hearing. The planning commission shall schedule and hold a hearing on the proposed lot split within thirty (30) days of receiving a complete application. The planning commission shall provide notice of the hearing to all abutting property owners as found in the records of the city assessor. A notice of hearing and location map shall be sent to the school district affected, county drain commission, county road commission, and all applicable utility companies. 
(f)  Planning commission recommendation. After holding a public hearing on the proposed lot split, if it is determined that the proposed lot split complies with all applicable requirements, the planning commission may recommend approval. If it is determined that the proposed lot split does not meet all requirements of the ordinances, the planning commission shall recommend disapproval. If the proposed lot split does not meet a requirement of the zoning ordinance, the applicant may seek a variance from the zoning board of appeals before the recommendation of the planning commission is forwarded to the city council. 
(g)  City council consideration. A resolution containing the planning commission's recommendation shall be forwarded to the city council. They shall consider the proposed lot split. The city council shall not approve any lot split that does not comply with all applicable ordinance requirements. If it is determined that the proposed lot split complies with all applicable requirements, the council may adopt a resolution approving the lot split. The resolution shall be forwarded to the city clerk for recording with the Macomb County Register of Deeds, to the city assessor for assignment of new parcel identification numbers, and a copy provided to the applicant. 
(Code 1967, § 6-507; Ord. No. 80-413, § 1, 6-23-92; Ord. No. 80-563, § 2, 11-28-00) 
State Law reference— Further partition or division of property, MCL 560.263.  
Sec. 35-27. - Division of non-subdivided property. 
(a)  Application. The applicant filing a request to divide a non-subdivided parcel or tract of land shall submit an application for land division to the planning department. The application shall include the following information and documents: 
(1)  Owner's name, address and signature assenting to the application; applicant's name, address and authorization for representation. 
(2)  Full legal description of the parcel or tract of land and the proposed legal descriptions of the land as divided. 
(3)  Names of abutting subdivisions or names of the owners of the abutting un-platted property. 
(4)  Fourteen (14) parcel maps of the proposed land division, drawn to a scale required by the planning department, and prepared by a professional surveyor. 
(5)  Fee. The application shall be accompanied by a check in the amount of one-hundred dollars ($100.00). Such fee is required to cover the costs of processing the application and conducting a site inspection. 
(6)  A final decision approving or disapproving the land division shall be rendered within forty-five (45) days of receipt of the complete application. An application will be deemed complete upon receipt of all information required to ascertain if the provisions of the ordinance have been met, the required maps of the proposed land division, and the application fee. 
(b)  Parcel map specifications. The proposed land division map shall be prepared pursuant to the land division parcel map specifications required by the planning department. 
(c)  Review of proposed land division. The proposed land division map shall be distributed and reviewed by the following city departments: 
(1)  Assessing department to determine whether the number of divisions exceed the allowable number of divisions under the Land Division Act. 
(2)  Building division, to determine whether the division complies with all applicable building regulations. 
(3)  Zoning official to determine whether each resulting parcel is accessible; the division complies with all applicable zoning ordinance provisions; and the resulting parcels meet the minimum lot size dimensions. 
(4)  Engineering division to assess whether the parcels and abutting streets are satisfactorily graded and drained. 
(5)  Fire department to determine whether each resulting parcel is accessible. 
(6)  Treasurer to determine whether the taxes currently due have been paid. 
Each department shall review the proposed land division map and provide a recommendation of approval or disapproval to the planning department within fifteen (15) days. 
(d)  Review of proposed land division by planning department. The planning department shall review the proposed land division for conformance with all ordinances, Land Division Act requirements, applicable administrative regulations and the master plan for the city. Such review shall include a site inspection. No approval shall be granted unless: 
(1)  Each resulting parcel is accessible. 
(2)  The proposed division complies with all applicable ordinance provisions. 
(3)  The proposed division does not render an existing structure to not comply with the zoning ordinance, unless such structure is removed. 
(4)  The number of divisions do not exceed the allowable number of divisions under the Land Division Act, MCL 560.101 et seq. 
(5)  The parcels and abutting streets are graded and drained to the satisfaction of the engineering division; and 
(6)  The utility companies are provided with notice of the proposed division so that they have an opportunity to acquire any easement they may require. 
(7)  All taxes currently due and owing on the parent parcel are paid in full. 
(e)  Planning department approval. If it is determined that the proposed division complies with all ordinance requirements, the planning department shall approve the proposed land division. If it is determined that the proposed division does not meet all requirements of the ordinances, the planning department shall disapprove the land division. If the proposed land division does not meet a requirement of the zoning ordinance, the applicant may seek a variance from the zoning board of appeals before a final decision is made. The approval or disapproval shall be provided in writing to the applicant, and shall further comply with the following: 
(1)  If the land division is approved conditionally, the conditions and reasons supporting the conditions shall be specified in the written approval. In the event an application is approved conditionally, the planning department may require the applicant to submit a revised land division map prior to final processing. 
(2)  If the recommendation is to disapprove the application, the reasons supporting disapproval shall be stated in the written disapproval. 
(f)  Recording of approval. The land division approval shall be prepared in a recordable form and shall be forwarded to the city clerk for recording with the Macomb County Register of Deeds, to the city assessor for assignment of new parcel identification numbers, and a copy provided to the applicant. 
(Ord. No. 80-563, § 3, 11-28-00)  
Secs. 35-28—35-50. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - DESIGN STANDARDS 
 
Sec. 35-51. - Street plan and relation to adjoining street system. 
(a)  The arrangement, character, extent, width, grade and location of all streets in a proposed subdivision shall conform to the city master thoroughfare plan and this chapter. 
(b)  All such streets shall be related to existing and proposed streets in the area, topographical conditions, public convenience and safety, and existing and proposed land uses along such streets. 
(c)  All streets shall be platted in such a manner that all resulting lots shall conform to the applicable zoning regulations. 
(d)  Where such streets are not shown in the master plan, the arrangements of these streets in the subdivision shall either: 
(1)  Provide for the continuation or appropriate projection of existing streets in the surrounding areas; or 
(2)  Conform to a neighborhood plan approved or adopted by the planning commission. 
(e)  Minor streets shall be laid out so as to discourage through traffic. 
(f)  Where a residential subdivision abuts or contains an existing or proposed major thoroughfare, the planning commission may require: 
(1)  Marginal access streets; 
(2)  Reverse frontage with screen planting contained in a nonaccess reservation along the rear property line; 
(3)  Deep lots with rear service alleys; or 
(4)  Such other treatment as may be necessary for the adequate protection and stabilization of residential properties and to afford separation of through and local traffic. 
(Code 1967, § 6-508)  
Sec. 35-52. - Relation to railroad rights-of-way. 
Where a subdivision borders on or contains a railroad right-of-way or limited access highway, the planning commission may require a street approximately parallel to and on each side of the right-of-way. 
(Code 1967, § 6-509) 
Cross reference— Railroads generally, Ch. 28.  
Sec. 35-53. - Reserve strips prohibited. 
Reserve strips controlling access to streets shall be prohibited. 
(Code 1967, § 6-510)  
Sec. 35-54. - Street alignment. 
(a)  Street jogs with centerline offsets of less than one hundred twenty-five (125) feet shall be avoided. 
(b)  A tangent at least one hundred (100) feet long shall be introduced between reverse curves on arterial and collector streets. 
(c)  When connecting street lines deflect from each other at any one (1) point by more than ten (10) degrees, they shall be connected by a curve with a radius adequate to insure a site distance of not less than one hundred twenty (120) feet for minor collector streets and of such greater radii as the planning commission shall determine for special cases. The planning commission shall determine the radius of the curve required, generally in consultation with the city engineer and local traffic authorities. 
(Code 1967, § 6-511)  
Sec. 35-55. - Street rights-of-way and roadway widths. 
(a)  Street rights-of-way and roadway widths shall conform to the master thoroughfare plan. 
(b)  All streets shall be paved. 
(c)  The following minimum standards shall apply: 
Street Type 	Right-of-way 
Width 
(feet) 	Roadway 
Width 
(feet) 
Super highways 	204 	as determined by proper authorities 
Major thoroughfares 	120 	as determined by proper authorities 
Collector roads 	86 	38 
Industrial road 	70 	38—40 
Minor res. streets 	60 	28—32 
Multiple apt. streets 	60 	36 
 
(Code 1967, § 6-512; Ord. No. 80-340, § 29, 6-9-87)  
Sec. 35-56. - Half streets. 
(a)  Half streets shall be prohibited, except where essential to the reasonable development of the subdivision in conformity with the other requirements of this chapter. 
(b)  In no event, however, shall lots facing a one-half minor residential street be permitted. 
(c)  Wherever an existing half street is adjacent to a tract to be subdivided, the other half of the street shall be planned within such tract. 
(Code 1967, § 6-513)  
Sec. 35-57. - Street and subdivision names. 
(a)  No street name shall be used which will duplicate or be confused with the names of existing streets. 
(b)  Street and subdivision names shall be subject to the approval of the director of public service. 
(Code 1967, § 6-514)  
Sec. 35-58. - Street grades. 
(a)  The minimum grade of all streets shall be 0.3 percent or otherwise as approved by the director of public service. 
(b)  The maximum grade of all streets shall not be greater than six (6) percent or otherwise as approved by the director of public service. 
(Code 1967, § 6-515; Ord. No. 80-340, § 30, 6-9-87)  
Sec. 35-59. - Street intersections. 
(a)  Streets shall be laid out to intersect at right angles where possible, and may be curved, if necessary, in order to make this possible. In no event shall a street intersect any other street at an angle of less than seventy-five (75) degrees. 
(b)  Street corners on local residential streets shall have a minimum radius of twenty (20) feet at curb line or its equivalent. Street corners on commercial and industrial streets shall have a minimum radius of twenty-five (25) feet at the curb line or its equivalent. Street intersections involving major thoroughfares shall have a minimum street corner radius of thirty (30) feet at the curb line or its equivalent. 
(c)  All street corner radii shall be shown on the street improvement plan. 
(Code 1967, § 6-516)  
Sec. 35-60. - Corner visibility. 
A twenty-five-foot area of clear vision at street intersections in subdivisions shall be provided. This area shall be kept clear of all structures and vegetation exceeding a height of three (3) feet above the curb line. 
(Code 1967, § 6-517)  
Sec. 35-61. - Cul-de-sacs and dead-end streets. 
(a)  The maximum length of a cul-de-sac shall be six hundred (600) feet. 
(b)  Each cul-de-sac shall be provided with a turnaround having a minimum right-of-way radius of fifty (50) feet. 
(c)  The road surface within the cul-de-sac right-of-way shall have a minimum radius of thirty-six (36) feet. 
(d)  In the case of temporarily dead-ended streets, which are stub streets designed to provide future connection with unsubdivided areas adjoining, the planning commission may require: 
(1)  Temporary easement for a turn-around having a radius of fifty (50) feet; or 
(2)  An appropriate area for a back-around. 
(e)  In all instances, proper provision shall be made for adequate storm drainage so that storm water does not collect at the ends of these streets. 
(Code 1967, § 6-518; Ord. No. 80-340, § 31, 6-9-87)  
Sec. 35-62. - Alleys. 
(a)  In general, service alleys shall not be platted in residential districts and the planning commission reserves the right to determine the need for such alleys in commercial and industrial districts. 
(b)  Where alleys are permitted, the following shall be applied: 
(1)  Minimum width of twenty (20) feet; 
(2)  All alleys shall be paved; 
(3)  Abrupt changes in alignment or dead-ends shall be avoided. 
(c)  Dead-end alleys shall be avoided where possible. If unavoidable, such alleys shall be provided with adequate turn-around facilities at the deadend, as determined by the planning commission. 
(Code 1967, § 6-519)  
Sec. 35-63. - Easements. 
(a)  Where alleys are not provided or may not be used for that purpose, easements shall be provided as may be advisable for poles, wires, conduits, storm sewers, sanitary sewers, gas lines, water mains and lines, and other similar purposes. 
(b)  Rear yard easements shall be at least twelve (12) feet wide. If one-half of an easement is platted, it shall be not less than six (6) feet in width. 
(c)  Where a subdivision is transversed by a water course, drainage way, channel or stream, there shall be provided a storm water easement or drainage right-of-way conforming substantially with the lines of such watercourse and such further width or construction or both as will be adequate for the purpose. Parallel streets or parkways may be required in connection therewith. 
(d)  Sixty-foot utility easements shall be provided at the end of cul-de-sacs along major thoroughfares. 
(Code 1967, § 6-520)  
Sec. 35-64. - Aerial easements. 
(a)  A three-foot aerial easement shall be provided along all side lot lines in proposed subdivisions to provide street light drop-outs for the Detroit Edison Company. 
(b)  Prior to the approval of the final plat for a proposed subdivision: 
(1)  A statement shall be obtained from the Detroit Edison Company indicating that it has been granted these easements. 
(2)  A notation shall be made on the final canvasback indicating the following: "All side lot lines are subject to street light drop-out rights granted to Detroit Edison Company." 
(Code 1967, § 6-521)  
Sec. 35-65. - Blocks. 
(a)  In general, blocks should have the following dimensions: 
	Minimum 	Maximum 
Length (feet) 	750 	1500 
Width (feet) 	200 	400 
 
(b)  The foregoing dimensions shall be subject to adjustment by the planning commission where topography, the character of the proposed development, or other similar conditions, justify blocks of greater or lesser length and/or width. 
(c)  Block lengths and widths shall be measured from the street right-of-way line. 
(d)  Wherever blocks are longer than one thousand two hundred (1,200) feet, crosswalks may be required at the approximate center of the block. 
(Code 1967, § 6-522)  
Sec. 35-66. - Lots. 
(a)  The lot size, width, depth, shape, orientation, and the minimum building setback lines, shall be appropriate for the location of the subdivision and for the type of development and use contemplated. 
(b)  Lot dimensions shall conform to existing zoning regulations. 
(c)  The subdividing of land shall be such as to provide each lot with satisfactory access at least twenty (20) feet in width to an existing public street by means of a public street or by an easement for ingress and egress of motor vehicles. The said easement shall be irrevocable and shall run with the land. 
(d)  Double frontage and reverse frontage lots should be avoided except where their use will produce definite advantages in meeting special situations in relation to topography, sound site planning, and proper land use. 
(e)  A planting screen easement of at least ten (10) feet, and across which there shall be no right of access, shall be provided along the line of lots abutting such a traffic artery or other disadvantageous use. 
(f)  Corner lots should have such extra width and area beyond the minimum requirements for other lots as may be necessary to permit appropriate set-backs on both streets and assume adequate visibility in furtherance of traffic safety. 
(g)  Side lot lines shall be substantially at right angles or radial to street lines. 
(h)  Lot remnants or lots below minimum area, left over after subdividing tracts of land, should be added to adjacent lots rather than remain as unusable parcels. 
(Code 1967, § 6-523; Ord. No. 80-453, § 1, 4-12-94)  
Sec. 35-67. - Sidewalks. 
Sidewalks shall be required in conjunction with any street or highway except in R-1-A districts where the planning commission finds that sidewalks would detract from the country-like appearance of the area and where the low density character of the area does not make such sidewalks necessary. 
(Code 1967, § 6-524)  
Sec. 35-68. - Crosswalks. 
Where necessary to obtain satisfactory pedestrian circulation in a subdivision and where blocks exceed one thousand two hundred (1,200) feet in length, the planning commission may require a paved and fenced crosswalk or pedestrian way six (6) feet wide. 
(Code 1967, § 6-525)  
Sec. 35-69. - Parking. 
Proper consideration shall be given to providing suitable off-street parking, consistent with the requirements of the city zoning ordinance. 
(Code 1967, § 6-526)  
Sec. 35-70. - Trees. 
(a)  A minimum of one (1) street tree shall be planted in front of each lot, between the curb and sidewalk. The builder shall deposit with the division of buildings and safety engineering, the sum of sixty dollars ($60.00) for each lot in his or her subdivision, which money shall be used by the city forester to purchase a tree to be placed in front of each lot. 
(b)  Before planting, the builder shall consult with the director of parks and recreation regarding approved tree species, placement regulations, and requirements of chapter 38 relative to trees and shrubs. 
(Code 1967, § 6-527; Ord. No. 80-340, § 32, 6-9-87) 
Cross reference— Vegetation generally, Ch. 38.  
Sec. 35-71. - Public sites and open spaces. 
(a)  Where a site for a proposed park, playground, playfield, school, library, fire station, or other public use is proposed by the master plan for the city, or is deemed by the planning commission to be necessary, is located in whole or in part in a subdivision, the planning commission may require the reservation of such area within the subdivision. 
(b)  The developer shall give the public agency involved thirty (30) days written notice of the proposed subdivision, with a copy of such notice to be mailed to the planning commission. During that thirty-day period, the agency may or may not express its interest in the proposed subdivision in connection with the provision of appropriate public site. Should such interest be expressed, that agency shall have a period of thirty (30) days within which to arrange for the acquisition of the public site under consideration. 
(c)  Where the proposed subdivision is too small to provide space of suitable size for the public site intended, the site provided may be combined with that provided or to be provided in adjoining areas. Thus, in the aggregate, there will be provided site of suitable size for the purpose intended. 
(Code 1967, § 6-528) 
Cross reference— Parks and recreation generally, Ch. 23.  
Sec. 35-72. - Community unit development. 
(a)  The standards and requirements of this chapter may be modified by the planning commission in the case of a plan and program for a complete community or a neighborhood unit, which in the judgment of the planning commission will provide adequate public spaces and improvements for the circulation, recreation, light, air, and the service needs of the area when fully developed and populated. 
(b)  Such plan and program shall include such legal provisions as will assure achievement of the plan as finally approved by the planning commission. 
(Code 1967, § 6-529)  
Secs. 35-73—35-90. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - REQUIRED IMPROVEMENTS 
 
Sec. 35-91. - Survey monuments. 
(a)  A complete survey of the subdivision shall be made by a registered civil engineer or surveyor. 
(b)  The traverse of the exterior boundaries of the tract and of each block, when computed from field measurements of the ground, shall close within a limit of error of one (1) foot to ten thousand (10,000) feet of the perimeter. 
(c)  Permanent metal monuments shall be installed in compliance with and as specified by the Subdivision Control Act. 
(Code 1967, § 6-530) 
State Law reference— Survey monuments, MCL 560.125.  
Sec. 35-92. - Streets. 
(a)  The developer shall provide streets constructed according to plans, profiles, cross-sections and specifications prepared by or for him or her and approved by the director of public service, prior to the start of any development. 
(b)  The classification of streets shall be in accord with the master thoroughfare plan and shall conform to roadway widths specified in section 35-55. 
(c)  All streets shall be graded to the full width of the right-of-way as shown on plans and profiles approved by the director of public service. 
(d)  All streets shall be constructed of Portland cement concrete in accordance with cross-sections and detailed specifications on file in the office of the director of public service and as otherwise specified in this chapter. In addition, all developers shall execute a bond in the amount of twenty-five (25) percent of actual pavement costs in a form acceptable to the city attorney, guaranteeing that the developer will repair and maintain all defects in street paving projects arising from faulty material or workmanship, for a period of three (3) years of acceptance by the city; provided, however, that any person damaging the pavement after installation shall be responsible to the city. 
(Code 1967, § 6-531; Ord. No. 80-340, § 33, 6-9-87)  
Sec. 35-93. - Portland cement concrete pavements. 
(a)  All required pavements are to be constructed of Portland cement concrete in accordance with the standard specifications for roads as designated by the Michigan Department of Transportation standard specifications for construction. 
(b)  All pavement designs, including drainage, thickness and grades, shall be in accordance with specifications on file in the office of the director of public service and as otherwise specified in this chapter. 
(c)  All drawings shall be presented in accordance with the specifications on file in the office of the director of public service. 
(d)  All pavements shall attain a strength of three thousand five hundred (3,500) pounds per square inch by standard tests and shall be acquired in twenty-eight (28) days. 
(e)  Pavement thickness: 
(1)  Residential pavements shall not be less in thickness than the conventional six (6) inch uniform pavement design, except, however, that uniform eight (8) inch thick pavement shall be provided in residential streets as follows: 
a.  Intersections, as measured from the point of tangency of the street lines with each radii approaching the intersection; 
b.  Cul-de-sacs and turn-arounds, as measured from the points of tangency of the street lines and the radii approaching the turn-around; 
c.  "Bubbles or eye-brows," as measured from the points of tangency of the street line and the radii approaching the eyebrows. 
(2)  Pavements for major thoroughfares and streets intended to handle heavy traffic loads, as determined by the director of public service, shall be not less than nine (9) inches in thickness. 
(3)  Commercial and industrial pavements shall be not less than eight (8) inches in thickness. 
(f)  The construction period for all street pavements shall comply with dates established by the Michigan Department of Transportation. A deviation from these dates may be authorized by the director of public service in the event of unusual weather conditions permitting the construction of concrete pavements. In no case, however, shall the construction deadline extend beyond November fifteenth. 
(Code 1967, § 6-532; Ord. No. 80-340, § 34, 6-9-87)  
Sec. 35-94. - Portland cement concrete curbs and gutters. 
(a)  Curbs and gutters are to be constructed of Portland cement concrete in accordance with the standard specifications for roads as designated by the Michigan Department of Transportation standard specifications as amended. 
(b)  "7" "Roll" type curbs shall be provided and shall be in accordance with standard specification drawings on file in the offices of the director of public service. 
(c)  The thickness of all curbs shall conform with the type and thickness of the pavement to which it is connected. 
(d)  Curbs and gutters shall attain a strength of three thousand five hundred (3,500) pounds per square inch by standard tests and shall be acquired in twenty-eight (28) days. 
(Code 1967, § 6-533; Ord. No. 80-340, § 35, 6-9-87)  
Sec. 35-95. - Sidewalks. 
(a)  Portland cement concrete sidewalks shall be installed in all subdivisions and along all abutting major thoroughfares and collector roads. 
(b)  The planning commission may waive the sidewalk requirement on one or both sides of a street in subdivisions where lots have a width of ninety (90) feet or more at the building line. 
(c)  Sidewalks shall have a minimum width of five (5) feet. 
(d)  The construction of sidewalks shall conform to the specifications on file in the office of the director of public service. Sidewalks shall attain a strength of three thousand (3,000) pounds per square inch by standard tests and shall be acquired in twenty-eight (28) days. 
(e)  Sidewalks shall be extended to the curb at all street intersections. 
(Code 1967, § 6-534; Ord. No. 80-340, § 35.1, 6-9-87)  
Sec. 35-96. - Crosswalks. 
(a)  Where required by the planning commission, crosswalks through blocks shall be constructed to a line and grade as determined by the director of public service. 
(b)  Walkways shall be surfaced with Portland cement concrete to a width of five and one-half (5.5) feet and fenced on both sides with a four (4) foot high cyclone fence. 
(c)  All crosswalks shall be constructed in accordance with section 35-95(d). 
(Code 1967, § 6-535)  
Sec. 35-97. - Excavations. 
(a)  Excavations within the dedicated right-of-way for sanitary and storm sewers, water mains, gas or electrical conduits over five (5) feet in depth and other utilities, shall be backfilled to the subgrade elevation with the excavated material. 
(b)  In the case of existing paved or traveled roads or in streets where a new pavement base has been constructed, all trenches and excavations under or within three (3) feet of the pavement shall be backfilled with sand to subgrade elevation and properly compacted either by tamping or flooding with water, as directed by the director of public service. 
(Code 1967, § 6-536)  
Sec. 35-98. - Fill compaction. 
(a)  For roadways, sidewalks and curbs to be built on fill, such fill shall be compacted by mechanical equipment ahead of the rolling operation and shall be subject to the approval of the director of public service. 
(b)  A slope of at least two (2) to one (1) shall be maintained at the sides to properly support the fill. 
(Code 1967, § 6-537; Ord. No. 80-340, § 36, 6-9-87)  
Sec. 35-99. - Storm sewers. 
(a)  The developer shall provide and be responsible for proper and adequate disposal of all surface and underground storm water. Existing water courses that are retained, shall be dedicated as drainage courses. 
(b)  Storm sewers shall be designed to flow full and shall be designed for the storm of that intensity which can be interpreted as the conventional ten-year storm for the area. The run-off from platted areas shall in no case be considered less than thirty (30) percent and in case of large paved areas not less than seventy-five (75) percent. 
(c)  Storm sewers shall be connected on crowns and when the velocity exceeds twenty (20) feet per second, the invert shall be paved with vitrified tile or other abrasion-resisting material. Storm sewers may be vitrified tile, reinforced concrete pipe or cement asbestos pipe of adequate load carrying capacity as determined by the city engineer. 
(d)  Catch basins shall be so placed that the line of travel from the sidewalk can be made without crossing the gutter flow. In areas outside traveled roadways, plain concrete pipe will be permitted when depth consideration is adequately protected. 
(e)  The type, extent, location and capacity of all drainage facilities shall be determined by the director of public service. 
(f)  All properties shall be served by underground storm sewer systems discharging into approved outlets and constructed in accordance with standard specifications on file in the office of the director of public service. 
(Code 1967, § 6-538; Ord. No. 80-340, § 37, 6-9-87)  
Sec. 35-100. - Open channels. 
(a)  The director of public service may waive the requirement of complete rip-rap or any portion thereof depending upon the degree of proposed alteration to the existing ditch alignment, velocity of flow or other physical features. 
(b)  Where it has been decided the surfaces shall have rip-rap, it shall be of a good quality native limestone or other stone of acceptable quality. The stones shall not be less than six (6) inches in width, twelve (12) inches in length or nine (9) inches in thickness nor the volume less than one-half cubic foot. Gravel used for filling joints shall be compiled of pebbles which will pass a three-fourths inch ring. Mortar where required shall conform to the requirements specified. Gravel used for foundations shall be bank run gravel, reasonably free from loam, clay and organic matter. 
(c)  The foundation for stone rip-rap shall be thoroughly compacted and covered with six (6) inches of gravel. The stones shall be rough dressed, set to line and grade and firmly embedded in the grade so as to break joints. Joints shall not exceed three-quarters inch in width and shall be well filled with fine gravel. 
(Code 1967, § 6-539)  
Sec. 35-101. - Rear yard storm drainage. 
(a)  The developer shall provide for adequate and safe disposal of all rear yard storm water. 
(b)  Rear yard storm drainage pipe shall be provided in the rear yard of each lot with suitable catch basins provided at intervals of four hundred eighty (480) feet in areas of sixty-foot lots, or the equivalent of four (4) lots each direction of flow for a total of eight (8) lots between catch basins in areas of lots exceeding sixty (60) feet in width, at the discretion of the city engineer. All such construction shall be under the supervision of the director of public service.
