(4)  Any other justifiable cause related to the best interests of the public health, safety and welfare. 
(Ord. No. 80-730, § 2, 6-9-15)  
Sec. 37-580. - Suspension from the active police tow list. 
(1)  Duration. The police commissioner may recommend to the Towing Committee and to city council, suspension of any wrecker or wrecker owner assigned to the active police tow list for any of the grounds set forth in this article and Chapter 18 of the Code of Ordinances. 
(a)  First time violation, suspension up to twenty-one (21) days; 
(b)  Second violation within a two (2) year period from the first suspension, suspension up to ninety (90) days; 
(c)  Third violation within a two (2) year period from the first suspension, suspension up to one (1) year. 
(Ord. No. 80-730, § 3, 6-9-15)  
Sec. 37-581. - Notification and hearing for removal or suspension from the active police tow list. 
The procedure for notification and hearing for removal or suspension from the active police tow list shall be described in section 37-582. 
(Ord. No. 80-730, § 3, 6-9-15)  
DIVISION 4. - DENIAL, REVOCATION, OR SUSPENSION—IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 37-582. - Denial, suspension or revocation. 
(1)  Standards for denial, suspension, revocation. The city clerk may deny, suspend, or revoke any license under this article, when the clerk finds: 
(a)  That the license was secured by fraud or by the concealment of a material fact by the wrecker vehicle owner and such fact, if known, would have caused the refusal to issue a license; 
(b)  That the wrecker vehicle owner has violated any of the requirements or regulations established under this article; 
(c)  That the licensee paid, in the form of a gratuity, to any third person not involved in an accident for information as to the location of an accident; 
(d)  Any causes set forth in chapter 18 of the Code of Ordinances. 
(2)  Notification and appeal. Notification of denial, revocation or suspension shall be in writing and delivered by first class mail to the address listed on the license application. The licensee shall be notified of: 
(a)  The nature of the violation; 
(b)  The proposed action and the reasons for the proposed action; 
(c)  That the licensee has a right to a hearing before city council with the recommendation of the towing committee regarding the proposed action, provided a written request is filed with the city clerk within ten (10) calendar days following the delivery or mailing of the notice of the notice of denial, revocation or suspension. 
(3)  Hearing and decision for revocation, suspension or termination. The hearing before city council with the recommendation of the towing committee shall be limited to determining by a preponderance of the evidence whether or not the city clerk's determination as set forth in the notice of revocation, suspension or termination was in accordance with grounds set forth in this article and Chapter 18. 
(a)  Procedure. Any hearing before city council shall comply with the following procedures: 
i.  The administrative hearing shall be subject to the Open Meetings Act, MCL 15.261 et seq. 
ii.  The licensee may present evidence and testimony, may cross-examine witnesses, and may be represented by an attorney. 
iii.  City council may reverse or affirm the determination to: issue or to deny the issuance of a license; revoke a license; or to suspend a license. 
iv.  City council may grant or reinstate the license. 
v.  City council shall submit to the licensee a written statement of its findings, determination, and specific grounds for affirming or reversing the termination. 
(b)  No person, wrecker or wrecker owner shall operate any business during any time when the wrecker/tow service license has been denied, suspended, or revoked or cancelled. 
(Ord. No. 80-730, § 4, 6-9-15)  
Sec. 37-583. - Conflict and severability. 
(1)  Conflict. In case of a conflict between the provisions of this article and Chapter 18, which cannot be resolved by construing them to be complementary or supplementary to each other, the provisions of this article shall control. 
(2)  Severability . The provisions of this chapter are hereby declared to be independent and, not withstanding any other evidence of legislative intent, it is hereby declared to be the controlling legislative intent that if any provisions of this chapter, or the application thereof to any person or circumstance is held to be invalid, the remaining provisions and the application of all provisions to any person or circumstances other than those to which it is held invalid, shall not be affected thereby. It is hereby declared that such provisions would have been passed independently of such provision so known to be invalid. Should any procedural aspect of this chapter be invalidated, such invalidation shall not affect the enforceability of the substantive aspects of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 80-730, § 4, 6-9-15)  
Secs. 37-584—37-590. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - PARKING LOTS AND STATIONS  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 37-591. - Defined. 
"Open parking station," for the purposes of this article, means any plot, piece or parcel of land used for the purpose of parking and storing motor vehicles where the owner or person storing such vehicles is charged a fee, whether such lots or parcels of land are enclosed or unenclosed, and which are open to the general public. 
(Code 1967, § 3-1401) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 37-592. - Signs required; rates; refusal to accept vehicles. 
(a)  Each licensee under this article shall maintain at each entrance to such open parking station a permanently affixed sign stating the name of the licensee; the hours of the day and/or night during which such place is open for business; the rates charged; and the closing hour of such station. The letters and figures on such sign indicating the rates charged and the closing hour of such business shall be not less than six (6) inches in height. Where the licensee operates a receiving station, in which cars are accepted with the understanding that such cars may be removed to another station, the licensee shall post on such sign, in letters not less than twelve (12) inches in height, the following statement: "Receiving station. Cars parked here may be moved to No. ___________ Street." (Stating the address to which such cars are moved.) All such signs shall be subject to the approval of the city clerk. 
(b)  Where separate rates or charges are made for day parking and for night parking, the change in rate shall become effective at 5:30 p.m. and notice thereof shall be posted on the sign as is prescribed in subsection (a). 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any licensee or his or her agent to refuse to accept for parking any motor vehicle driven into such station, unless the capacity of such station for the storage of cars has been reached. 
(Code 1967, § 3-1406)  
Sec. 37-593. - Parking checks. 
At the time of accepting a motor vehicle for storing or parking in an open parking station, the person conducting the same, his or her agent, servant or employee, shall furnish to such person parking his or her motor vehicle, a distinctive check which shall be numbered to correspond to a coupon placed upon such motor vehicle, which check shall contain the name and address of the licensee operating such open parking station and upon which shall be written, or stamped, the date and the license number of the motor vehicle. This provision shall not apply where cars are stored on a monthly fee basis. It shall be unlawful to affix any parking tags on any motor vehicle so as to obliterate in whole or in part any portion of the motor vehicle license plates on such vehicles. 
(Code 1967, § 3-1407)  
Sec. 37-594. - Charges. 
No licensee under this article shall make any charge for parking or storing any motor vehicle in an open parking station in excess of that set forth in his or her application for a license unless and until he or she has notified the city clerk in writing of the change and posted signs showing such increase in the same manner as set forth herein. 
(Code 1967, § 3-1408)  
Sec. 37-595. - Claims; liability. 
(a)  Each licensee under this article shall immediately notify the city clerk of any claim made by reason of any loss, theft or conversion occurring upon his or her premises or of any claim for damages arising from the operation of his or her open parking station. 
(b)  The obligations herein created of any person operating or conducting an open parking station under the terms of this article to the owner of a motor vehicle parked therein, shall not extend beyond the regular business hours as posted upon such open parking station and printed upon the regular receipt furnished to such motor vehicle owner. 
(Code 1967, § 3-1409)  
Sec. 37-596. - Agreement limiting liability prohibited. 
No contract, agreement, lease, receipt, rule or regulation shall exempt any licensee from liability for damage or loss caused by the negligence of the licensee or his or her agents or employees. 
(Code 1967, § 3-1410)  
Sec. 37-597. - Fire extinguishers required. 
Open parking stations shall be equipped with fire extinguishers as specified by the fire commissioner and all motor vehicles shall be so stored as to be readily accessible in the event of fire or other emergency. 
(Code 1967, § 3-1411) 
Cross reference— Fire prevention and protection generally, Ch. 13.  
Sec. 37-598. - Fences, sidewalks; entrance, etc., attendant required. 
(a)  Licensees under this article shall maintain on the perimeter of the premises a suitable fence, wall or other barrier, so that motor vehicles may not be removed from such stations except at the regular established entrances and exits. Each licensee shall keep the sidewalks abutting the premises free from dirt, ice, sleet and snow and shall keep the sidewalks in safe condition for the travel of pedestrians. Unless otherwise approved by the city clerk, each station shall have one (1) common entrance and one (1) common exit, which may or may not be combined, and an attendant shall at all times during regular business hours be stationed thereat. 
(b)  Licensee shall maintain the premises free from dust by frequent sprinkling or the use of calcium chloride or other means to avoid nuisance to adjacent property owners or others. 
(c)  No licensee shall sublet, sublease or otherwise permit any parking lot or any portion thereof to be used by any vendor of goods, wares or merchandise or services unless such business is conducted in a permanent building or structure. 
(Code 1967, § 3-1412)  
Sec. 37-599. - Removal of vehicles; unauthorized use prohibited. 
No licensee or his or her agents or employees under this article shall sit in, drive, or otherwise make any unauthorized use of any motor vehicle parked or stored on the premises, except that the licensee may move any motor vehicle from a so-called receiving station to another parking lot if adequate signs as required by this article are properly erected and maintained; and that in such cases the licensee shall maintain, adequate service to assure prompt delivery of the car; and that such removal shall not exceed a distance of five (5) blocks from the receiving, station, and that the car is re-delivered within a reasonable time upon call of the customer. Vehicles remaining unlocked on lots after closing hours may be removed by the licensee to another lot, the location of which shall be designated by an appropriate sign on the lot; provided that the licensee shall be liable to the owner of any motor vehicle so moved for any damage to such motor vehicle caused by such moving. 
(Code 1967, § 3-1413)  
Secs. 37-600—37-610. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference— Licensing generally, Ch. 18. 
 
Sec. 37-611. - Required. 
No person shall maintain or conduct an open parking station within the city, without first obtaining a license therefor as provided in this division. 
(Code 1967, § 3-1402)  
Sec. 37-612. - Application. 
Applications for licenses for open parking stations shall be made in the form and manner required by this Code, and shall set forth, among other things: 
(1)  The number of motor vehicles which may at any one (1) time be parked or stored upon the premises; 
(2)  The hours during which the motor vehicles may be parked or stored; 
(3)  A complete schedule of the rates to be charged for parking or storing motor vehicles; and 
(4)  The hours during which such lots shall be open for business. 
(Code 1967, § 3-1403)  
Sec. 37-613. - Fee. 
The license fee for the operation of an open parking station shall be as prescribed in section 18-18. 
(Code 1967, § 3-1404)  
Sec. 37-614. - Issuance. 
If, after investigation, the city clerk is reasonably satisfied that the applicant is a person of good moral character as provided in section 18-8, a license shall be issued upon payment of the required fee. The city clerk shall keep a record of all applications and licenses issued, indexed alphabetically and by location. 
(Code 1967, § 3-1405)  
Secs. 37-615—37-630. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - SOIL, REFUSE OR FUEL CARRYING VEHICLES[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference— Garbage and rubbish generally, Ch. 16; soil removal, dumping and regrading generally, Ch. 32. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 37-631. - Intent. 
It is the intent of the city council that this article be liberally construed for the purpose of providing a sanitary and satisfactory method of transporting soil, refuse and fuel in the city. 
(Code 1967, § 4-1108)  
Sec. 37-632. - Definitions. 
The following words and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them: 
Fuel means coal, coke, charcoal, parts of trees not exceeding three (3) feet in length or six (6) inches in diameter, oil, gasoline, benzine, kerosene, or other similar oil or oily substance or liquid. 
Refuse means: 
(1)  Municipal waste or wastes consisting of discarded products incident to housekeeping and commercial enterprises. 
(2)  Garbage, including waste animal, fish, fowl, fruit or vegetable matter incident to the use and storage of food for human consumption, and including spoiled food and dead animals. 
(3)  Rubbish, including waste materials resulting from the usual routine of housekeeping, miscellaneous waste materials resulting from the operation of mercantile enterprises, boxes, paper, rags, excelsior, grass, leaves, straw, barrels, waste from building construction, alteration or repair, and similar rejected matter. 
(4)  Ashes, including residue of combustion of any fuel such as wood, coal, coke, charcoal, or like substances. 
Soil means topsoil, subsoil, sand, gravel, earth and similar materials removed from land. 
Soil, refuse and/or fuel carrying motor vehicles means all motor vehicles propelled otherwise than by muscular power, and which are capable of transporting a load of soil, refuse or fuel. The term "soil, refuse and/or fuel carrying motor vehicles" shall include trailers and semi-trailers pulled or towed by self-propelled vehicles, but shall exclude tractors; and for the purpose of this article trucks, trailers and semi-trailers shall be construed to be separate units. The term "soil, refuse and/or fuel carrying motor vehicles" shall in no case be deemed to include any vehicle subject to the jurisdiction of the state public service commission pursuant to the State Motor Carriers Act, being Act No. 254 of the Public Acts of 1933 (MCL 475.1 et seq.), as amended. 
(Code 1967, § 4-1101) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 37-633. - Compliance required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to operate, or cause or permit any of his or her agents or employees to operate, any soil, refuse and/or fuel carrying motor vehicle on any public street or alley in the city, contrary to the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1967, § 4-1103)  
Sec. 37-634. - Complete enclosure required. 
Motor vehicles transporting refuse, soil or fuel through the public ways of the city shall be so constructed or equipped as to completely enclose and cover by an enclosure, the contents of such vehicle. Such construction or equipment shall be tightly fitted to exclude flies. 
(Code 1967, § 4-1105)  
Sec. 37-635. - Annoyance, etc. 
The transportation of soil, refuse and/or fuel through the streets and alleys of the city shall be conducted in such a manner as to create the least possible annoyance or irritation. 
(Code 1967, § 4-1106)  
Secs. 37-636—37-645. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference— Licensing generally, Ch. 18. 
 
Sec. 37-646. - Required. 
No person shall operate any soil, refuse and/or fuel carrying motor vehicle without first procuring a city license and a license plate from the city clerk. 
(Code 1967, § 4-1102)  
Sec. 37-647. - Application. 
The application for a license under this division shall state the: 
(1)  Applicant's name and address; 
(2)  Owner's name and address if the vehicle is not owned by the applicant; 
(3)  Make, model, type and year of truck; 
(4)  Annual state license number; 
(5)  Character of business; 
(6)  Rated capacity in tons; 
(7)  Vehicle weight or tare; 
(8)  Number of wheels; 
(9)  Width of all tires. 
(Code 1967, § 4-1102)  
Sec. 37-648. - Fee. 
The fee for a license under this division shall be as prescribed in section 18-18. 
(Code 1967, § 4-1102)  
Sec. 37-649. - Plate. 
Every motor vehicle under this division shall have the license plate attached to the right hand side thereof, in some conspicuous place; provided, however, that this section shall not apply to vehicles subject to the jurisdiction of the state public service commission pursuant to the provisions of the State Motor Carriers Act, being Act No. 254 of the Public Acts of 1933 (MCL 475.1 et seq.), as amended. 
(Code 1967, § 4-1102)  
Secs. 37-650—37-700. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - OTHER TRAFFIC REGULATIONS 
 
Sec. 37-701. - Operation of motor vehicles on public property and public easements. 
(a)  Operation of motor vehicles on public property. It shall be unlawful for any motor vehicle, including but not limited to motorcycles and mini-bikes, to operate on any public property, unless the public property can be identified as a street, alley, parking lot or driveway. 
(b)  Operation of motor vehicles on public easements. It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a motor vehicle, including but not limited to motorcycles and mini-bikes, on any public easement or utility corridor, without the expressed written consent of the owner; this provision, however, is not applicable to easements and corridors which can be identified as a street, alley, parking lot or driveway. 
(Ord. No. 80-568, § 10, 5-8-01)  
Sec. 37-702. - Commercial vehicles, vehicles; parking, night-time, residential areas. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to park any commercial vehicle on any street in the city for a period longer than thirty (30) minutes between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 4:00 a.m. on the same day, including Sundays and holidays. The police commissioner, for good cause shown, may grant special parking permits permitting parking of commercial vehicles during the above hours, provided each permit is granted for a definite period of time. 
(b)  Upon the erection of signs sufficient to apprise the ordinarily observant person, it shall be unlawful to park a vehicle any day between the hours of 2:30 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. of the same day on those sections or segments of the public highways or streets within a specified area. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to park any truck, truck tractor, truck trailer, or any combination of the foregoing, whether self-propelled or not, upon any street in a residential area within the city; provided, however, that any panel truck or truck with a load limit of three-quarters (¾) of a ton (one thousand five hundred (1,500) pounds), or less, according to the manufacturer's rating, shall be exempt from the provisions of this section; and provided, further, that temporary parking upon any street in a residential area by any truck, truck tractor, truck trailer or any combination thereof shall be lawful for the purpose of delivering merchandise to residences upon such street, or for the purpose of rendering other services to residences upon such street, or for the purpose of rendering other services to residences upon such street requiring the presence of such vehicle, or for the purpose of making emergency road repairs to such vehicle. The term "temporary parking" shall not include overnight parking. 
(d)  No person shall operate or cause to be operated upon or within any park or street, any commercial motor vehicle as defined in the chapter, or any other vehicles used for the hauling or distribution of merchandise, freight or material when the street is properly posted with the following sign: "Commercial vehicles keep off." Provided however, that such a truck or vehicle may be operated upon or within the parks or streets, for the shortest possible distance, when necessary to serve any property located within or upon the park or street or contiguous thereto or when it is necessary to cross any street. The provisions of this section shall not apply to vehicles operated by the department of parks and recreation. 
(Ord. No. 80-568, § 10, 5-8-01)  
Sec. 37-703. - Use of mopeds, gopeds, and low speed vehicles by minors. 
(a)  The motor vehicle code applies to the operation of mopeds, gopeds, and other low speed vehicles on public streets and sidewalks. Section 257.312a requires any person before operating a moped, goped, or low speed vehicle on a public street to procure a license from the Secretary of State to operate the vehicle on the public streets. The parent of a minor or the guardian of a ward, shall not authorize or knowingly permit or allow the minor to operate a moped, goped, or low speed vehicle on a public street in the city unless the minor compiles with all of the following: 
(1)  The minor is at least fifteen (15) years of age; and 
(2)  If the minor does not have an operator's license, the minor has obtained a special restricted license, to operate a moped, from the Secretary of State; and 
(3)  The minor's parent or legal guardian has signed the special restricted license application in accord with established Secretary of State requirements; and 
(4)  The operation of the vehicle is in compliance with all rules set forth in the Motor Vehicle Code, MCL 257.656 et seq.; 
A violation of this section is a civil infraction which shall result in the assessment of a fine to the minor's parent or legal guardian of one hundred dollars ($100.00), plus costs and other applicable sanctions for each infraction. 
(b)  A moped, goped, or low speed vehicle shall not be operated on a sidewalk constructed for the use of pedestrians. Pursuant to the Motor Vehicle Code section 257.656, a person who violates this subsection is responsible for a civil infraction. 
(c)  Exemptions. The regulations contained in this section shall not apply to the operation of a toy electric vehicle operated by a minor on a sidewalk and which is powered by a twelve-volt battery and does not exceed a speed of five (5) mph. 
(Ord. No. 80-657, § 1, 5-22-07)  
Sec. 37-704. - Distracted driving. 
(a)  Except as provided in subsection (c), a person shall not operate a motor vehicle on a highway, street, or other place open to the general public in a distracted manner. 
(b)  "Distracted manner" means performing an activity that diverts attention from operating the vehicle in such a way that it endangers drivers, pedestrians, or property. Activities that divert attention include using a cell phone or other electronic device, reading, writing, performing personal grooming tasks, or other similar actions. Endangering drivers, pedestrians, or property includes swerving, drifting, pulling out in front of other vehicles, or other similar dangerous driving maneuvers. 
(c)  The following are exemptions from the general prohibition listed in subsection (a): 
(1)  Peace officers, while performing their official duties as peace officers; 
(2)  A person reporting a traffic accident, medical emergency, road hazard, criminal activity, or other emergency situation that a reasonable person would consider an emergency justifying the violation. 
(d)  A violation of this section is a municipal civil infraction punishable by a fine of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) but not more one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). 
(Ord. No. 80-770 , § 1, 12-18-18)  
Chapter 38 - VEGETATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference— Authority to regulate trees and shrubs, § 3.1(b)(3)(l). 
Cross reference— Noxious weeds, § 21-46 et seq.; design standards for trees in subdivisions, § 35-70. 
State Law reference— Care of trees and shrubs, MCL 247.241 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 38-1. - Definitions. 
For the purposes of this chapter, the following words have the meanings described below: 
Low growth area is an area that is made up of either (1) grass or other groundcover that is six (6) inches or less, or (2) a flat landscaping material that is flush with the sidewalk or surrounding property. 
Medium growth area is an area that is made up of plants that do not exceed four (4) feet in height. 
Native plant is a plant that: (1) is listed as a native plant in the Michigan State University Native Plants and Ecosystem Services' Southern Lower Peninsula Regional Plant List (RPL), as amended; or (2) has existed and evolved in Southeast Michigan over hundreds or thousands of years. A copy of the RPL is available in the clerk's office. 
Non-native plant is a plant introduced with human help (intentionally or accidentally) to a new place or new type of habitat where it was not previously found. 
Opportunistic plant is a plant that is: (1) listed as opportunistic by the RPL; or (2) is an invasive species. Invasive species include non-native plants that have no natural controls and are able to out-compete and gradually displace native plants or cause other economic or environmental harm. 
Planned natural landscaping area is a deliberate and maintained area consisting of native plants. Non-native plants are discouraged. Opportunistic plants are prohibited. 
Plant is any tree, shrub, herb, grass, fern, vine, or similar organism. 
Shrub is a low woody plant that is less than twenty (20) feet in height. Shrubs are typically bushy owing to multiple small trucks and branches that emerged from near the ground. 
Tree is a woody perennial plant that can grow taller than twenty (20) feet and has a single, usually elongated, main stem with few or no branches on its lower part. 
(Code 1967, § 7-201; Ord. No. 80-745, 11-22-16) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 38-2. - Control by director of parks and recreation in public places; rules and regulations. 
The director of parks and recreation shall have complete charge and control of the planting, cutting, trimming and removal of trees and other growth upon all public highways and places, and the director may promulgate and adopt rules and regulations to effectuate the provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1967, § 7-202)  
ARTICLE II. - VEGETATION REGULATIONS, AND PUBLIC WAY AND PLACES REQUIREMENTS 
 
Sec. 38-3. - Prohibited varieties. 
The planting of any poplar, soft maple, box elder, tree of heaven, ash, wild chestnut, or cottonwood tree, or any variety thereof, in the public ways, parks or places in the city is prohibited. 
(Code 1967, § 7-203)  
Sec. 38-3.5. - Undesirable species. 
(a)  Undesirable species includes Box Elder, Chinese Elm, Cottonwood, Mulberry, Poplar, Silver Maple, Tree of Heaven, Willow and those other species that the director of parks and recreation determines are undesirable. 
(b)  Removal. Any owner of property may remove an undesirable species of tree by a city licensed and approved contractor on the condition that the new tree planted to replace the removed tree is a desirable species (as defined by the director of parks and recreation). 
(Ord. No. 80-558, § 1, 7-11-00)  
Sec. 38-4. - Permit required for planting, removing, etc., in public ways. 
No person, except the city, shall plant, remove or destroy any ornamental shade tree or shrub in any public way without first procuring a permit from the director of parks and recreation. 
(Code 1967, § 7-204)  
Sec. 38-5. - Permit required for trimming in public ways. 
(a)  No person shall cut, mutilate, remove, saw or trim any tree within any public way in the city to make room for any telegraph, telephone or electric lines, moving buildings or machinery or other things, or for repairing sidewalks, without first procuring a permit from the director of parks and recreation. 
(b)  No person owning or operating any bus line or other motor transportation over the city streets, or any public utility lines upon, above or below the surface, shall trim, cut or cause to be trimmed or cut any tree, shrub or plant along any public way or park, without first having submitted to the director of parks and recreation a plan of the work to be done and having procured a permit for such work. 
(c)  Nothing in this section shall be construed to apply to the removal, under the direction of the director of parks and recreation, of any stump, roots, tree, shrub, vine, plant or part thereof, wherever such removal shall be found necessary in the construction or repair of any street, sidewalk, sewer, pavement or other public improvement. 
(Code 1967, §§ 7-206, 7-207)  
Sec. 38-6. - Application for permits; approval requisite. 
Applications for any permit required by the provisions of this chapter shall be available in the office of the department of parks and recreation. No permit shall be granted until it has been approved by the director of parks and recreation. 
(Code 1967, § 7-208)  
Sec. 38-7. - Repair of gas pipes and mains. 
Gas pipes or mains within or beneath any public way shall be maintained so as to avoid any leakage therefrom. If any leak exists or occurs, it shall be reported to the owner of the pipe and main, and the leak shall be repaired within twenty-four (24) hours. The city may repair any leak not stopped within twenty-four (24) hours and the owner of the pipe or main causing the leak shall be charged with the cost of repair and the damage caused thereby. 
(Code 1967, § 7-205)  
Sec. 38-8. - Attaching articles or animals to trees in public ways prohibited. 
No person shall attach, tack or in any manner fasten to any tree in a public way any wire, rope, chain, cable, sign, card, board, poster or other article, nor hitch any animal thereto. 
(Code 1967, § 7-206)  
Sec. 38-9. - Obstructions to public-way prohibited. 
The owner or person in charge or control of any lot or parcel of land within the city upon which any tree, shrub, vine or plant may be standing adjacent to any public way, shall trim or cause to be trimmed, either at the property line or to a clear height of at least eight (8) feet above the surface of such public way, all branches thereof which overhang any portion of such public way, or which obstruct or interfere with the passage of light from any street lighting system, and shall not plant or maintain any thereof so close to any property line as to obstruct thereby the vision of travelers along the streets. The city may enter upon any such private premises to do such trimming as it determines necessary, or to remove such obstructions herein prohibited upon the failure of the owner to do so after notice to him or her in writing. The owner shall, or the city may, remove from such tree, shrub, plant or vine, all dead, decayed, unsightly, broken or dangerous limbs and branches that overhang or are close to the public way; and when any such tree, shrub, plant or vine is dead, the owner shall remove the same, or after notice of such intention to the owner, the city may do so and charge the cost thereof to such owner. 
(Code 1967, § 7-209)  
Sec. 38-9.1. - Obstructions to visibility. 
In order to provide for the safety of pedestrians, no person shall plant or maintain any shrub or hedge in the front yard of any dwelling that obscures the vision of a driver of an automobile exiting any driveway adjacent to such dwelling. 
(Ord. No. 80-428, § 1, 2-23-93)  
Sec. 38-10. - Excavations, etc., in public way; guards required. 
In any excavation, or the erection, alteration or repair of any building or structure, or other work, the owner thereof or someone for him or her shall place or cause to be placed such guards around all nearby trees, shrubs and plants in the public way as will effectually prevent injury to them. 
(Code 1967, § 7-210)  
Sec. 38-11. - Stones, bricks, sand, etc., injuring trees in public way. 
No person shall place or maintain upon the ground in any public way or public place of the city any stone, brick, sand, concrete or other material or article which may injure or which may in any way impede the full and free passage of water, air or fertilizer to the roots of any tree, shrub, vine or plant, without leaving an open space of ground not less than four (4) feet in diameter surrounding same. 
(Code 1967, § 7-211)  
Sec. 38-12. - Destruction of diseased trees, etc. 
The owner or occupant of any premises on which is located any tree or other growth, if infected by disease or by injurious insects or in a dangerous condition, shall destroy same when such destruction is necessary for the protection of other trees and growth and for the public safety, health and welfare. 
(Code 1967, § 7-212)  
Sec. 38-13. - Trees in front of dwellings. 
Wherever feasible, as determined by the director of parks and recreation, every dwelling in the city shall have a tree planted in front of the dwelling in the area between the sidewalk and the curb. All dwelling owners shall have one (1) year from the date of receipt of the notice from the director of parks and recreation to comply with this provision. 
(Code 1967, § 7-213)  
Sec. 38-14. - Failure of owners or occupants to comply with chapter. 
If the owner or occupant of any premises fails to perform any duty required of him or her by this chapter, the director of parks and recreation may serve notice upon such owner or occupant, directing him or her to cause such work to be done within thirty (30) days, and upon his or her failure to comply with the notice, the city may enter upon the premises and perform the work required and charge the cost thereof to the owner or occupant. The cost shall be charged in accordance with the provisions of the Charter relative to special assessments and pursuant to the provisions of chapter 33. 
(Code 1967, § 7-214)  
Sec. 38-15. - Removal of live trees from public places. 
Any person desiring to remove a live tree from any public place for the construction of walks, drives, buildings or any other structures for his or her own gain, shall deposit with the department of parks and recreation a sum equal to the value of the tree as determined by the director of parks and recreation. 
(Code 1967, § 7-215)  
Sec. 38-16. - Tree requirements for construction of new dwellings. 
Any person desiring a building permit for the construction of a new dwelling in the city shall deposit with the division of buildings and safety engineering the sum of two hundred dollars ($200.00) for each permit issued, which shall be used by the director of parks and recreation to purchase a tree to be placed in the public right-of-way in front of the dwelling. The director of parks and recreation shall have complete discretion as to the type of tree to be planted, the time of such planting, and shall supervise the planting of the tree. 
(Code 1967, § 7-216; Ord. No. 80-533, § 1, 4-28-98)  
Sec. 38-17. - Guaranty of trees planted by city. 
Any tree planted by the city under the supervision of the director of parks and recreation shall be guaranteed by the city for a period of two (2) years after the date of planting; provided, however, that the city will not be responsible for the replacement of trees which were damaged or destroyed by the acts or omissions of the abutting property owner. The director of parks and recreation shall have the sole authority to determine whether a tree was so damaged or destroyed by the abutting property owner. 
(Code 1967, § 7-217)  
Sec. 38-18. - Penalty. 
Except if there is an administrative hearings officer vacancy as described in chapter 2.5, section 2.5-4(d), the violation of a provision of this Chapter is a blight violation. The administrative hearings bureau shall punish a violator found responsible for a blight violation as provided in Warren Code of Ordinances, chapter 2.5, section 2.5-7. 
(Ord. No. 80-527, § 25, 1-13-98; Ord. No. 80-632, § 1, 3-28-06; Ord. No. 80-655, § 1, 5-8-07; Ord. No. 80-731, § 11, 8-11-15; Ord. No. 80-750, § 2, 2-14-17)  
ARTICLE III. - PLANNED NATURAL LANDSCAPING AREA[2] 
State Law reference— MCL 117.4q. 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Garbage and rubbish, Ch. 16; International Property Maintenance Code sections 302, 308, and 309 as adopted by Warren Code of Ordinances, §§ 28-1 and 28-2; Property maintenance generally, Ch. 28; and Zoning generally, Appendix A. 
 
Sec. 38-19. - Purpose. 
The purpose of this article is to encourage property owners to plant and maintain planned natural landscaping areas. Planned natural landscaping areas and planting native plants reduces greenhouse gasses and pollution, reduces water consumption, supports native songbirds, pollinators, insects, and species diversity, saves money on watering, reduces soil erosion, decreases the need for pesticides, naturally cools the city, filters contaminated storm water, and reduces the potential of sewer overflow and basement flooding. 
(Ord. No. 80-745, 11-22-16)  
Sec. 38-20. - Goals. 
The city will strive to plant native plants, greatly reduce mowed turf grass areas, increase tree canopy, water during the hours of darkness, and encourage property owners to do the same. The city will work toward creating a thirty (30) percent tree canopy over the city. 
(Ord. No. 80-745, 11-22-16)  
Sec. 38-21. - Planned natural landscaping area requirements. 
(a)  Property owners may maintain a planned natural landscaping area, if the property owner complies with all of the following: 
(1)  Registers the property with the department of property maintenance; 
(2)  Does not have planned natural landscaping in the right-of-ways; 
(3)  Does not grow or allow excessive growth of any non-native plant that was not previously growing on the property before first registering the property as a planned natural landscaping area; 
(4)  Does not grow or allow excessive growth of any plant; 
(5)  Abides by all other applicable laws and ordinances not listed in section 38-21(c), including property maintenance ordinances prohibiting collection of junk or rubbish, rodent infestations, sanitation, grading and drainage, and rodent or other pest harborage; and zoning ordinances relating to corner visibility; 
(6)  Maintains a three (3) foot low growth area setback from any side and rear lot lines; 
(7)  Maintains a three (3) foot low growth area setback and a six (6) foot medium growth area buffer zone from the front lot line; and 
(8)  Regularly maintains the planned natural landscaping area. 
(b)  Registration. 
(1)  The property owner shall register the property every two (2) years. 
(2)  If the property owner sells the property, the registration is automatically transferred to the next owner until such a time that the registration requires renewal. 
(3)  The registration application shall include the name of the person registering the property, the address and parcel number of the property to be registered, an affidavit swearing that the person registering the property owns the property, and a statement that the registered property owner agrees to abide by all neighborhood resolution and appeal committee determinations and orders. 
(c)  Registered planned natural landscaping areas that comply with this section are exempt from the following vegetation-related property maintenance ordinances: 
(1)  The portions of chapter 21, section 21-47 banning growth of weeds or grass higher than six (6) inches and accumulation of dead weeds, grass, or brush; and 
(2)  International Property Maintenance Code Section 302.4 as incorporated into the Code of Ordinances in chapter 28, article I, International Property Maintenance Code banning certain weeds and plant growth. 
(d)  Noncompliance. 
(1)  If the property owner fails to register a planned natural landscaping area as required by section 38-21(a)(i), the city may issue blight tickets for violations listed in section 38-21(c). 
(2)  If the property owner fails to abide by the requirements listed in section 38-21(a)(ii)-(vi), the director of public service or his designee may (1) issue blight tickets for violations listed in section 38-21(c); (2) revoke or not renew the property owner's planned natural landscaping area registration; or (3) do both. 
(3)  The property owner may appeal a revocation or refusal to renew his planned natural landscaping area registration to the neighborhood resolution and appeal committee as provided for in section 38-21(e). 
(e)  Disputes and appeal. 
(1)  The mayor shall appoint a five (5) member neighborhood resolution and appeal committee. The committee shall be made up of Warren residents. 
(2)  The committee is responsible for: 
a.  Conducting dispute and appeal hearings; and 
b.  Making a final determination on the dispute or appeal following the hearing. 
(3)  Hearings. 
a.  If a property owner or resident lives on the same city block (both sides of the street) or the city block directly behind the planned natural landscaping area and has a complaint about the planned natural landscaping area, he may submit a request for a dispute hearing. The request shall state the nature of the dispute. 
b.  If the director of public service or his designee revokes or refuses to renew his planned natural landscaping area registration, the property owner may submit a request for an appeal hearing. 
c.  A request for a hearing shall be in writing and be submitted to the property maintenance department. 
d.  The committee shall conduct a hearing. At the hearing, the person who requested the hearing and the registered property owner may both address the committee. 
(4)  Final determination. 
a.  Following the hearing, the committee will make a final determination and order. 
b.  The final determination and order is binding on all parties. 
(5)  Failure to comply with the final determination is a blight violation. The administrative hearings bureau shall punish a violator as provided in Warren Code of Ordinances, chapter 2.5, section 2.5-7. A blight violation is appealable to the circuit court. 
(Ord. No. 80-745, 11-22-16)  
Chapter 39 - VEHICLES FOR HIRE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference— Authority to regulate trades and occupations, § 3.1(b)(2)(a); authority to regulate vehicles for hire, § 3.1(b)(2)(e). 
Cross reference— Mobile homes and trailers, Ch. 20; railroads, Ch. 28; streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 34; traffic and motor vehicles, Ch. 37; wreckers, § 37-551 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 39-1. - Penalty. 
The violation of any provision of chapter 39 is a municipal civil infraction which shall result in the assessment of a fine of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) or not more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per violation, plus costs and other sanctions for each infraction. 
(Ord. No. 80-527, § 26, 1-13-98)  
Secs. 39-2—39-20. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - TAXICABS AND MINIBUSES  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 39-21. - Definitions. 
The following words and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them: 
License means the license issued by the city authorizing the holder thereof to conduct a taxicab business in the city. 
Meter means any instrument or device attached to a taxicab which measures mechanically the distance driven and the waiting time upon which the fare is based. 
Permit means the driver's permit granted by the city to a person to drive a taxicab on the streets of the city. 
Rate card means a card displayed by the holder of a license in each taxicab which contains the rates of fare then in force under the provisions of this article. 
Street includes any street, avenue, lane, court, public parking lot or public place in the city. 
Taxicab means a motor vehicle regularly engaged in the business of carrying passengers for hire and not operated on a fixed route. 
Waiting time means the time when a taxicab is not in motion from the time of acceptance of a passenger to the time of discharge, not including any time that the taxicab is not in motion due to any cause other than the request, act or fault of a passenger. 
(Code 1967, § 5-201) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 39-22. - Equipment and maintenance. 
(a)  Prior to the use and operation of any vehicle under the provisions of this article the vehicle shall be thoroughly examined and inspected by the police department for cleanliness, appearance, mechanical condition, and to determine that such vehicle complies with all requirements of this article. If any such vehicle shall be found to be unclean, unsanitary, unsightly, fail to comply with the provisions of this article or for any reason to be unsafe for the transportation of passengers for hire, the vehicle shall not be licensed for use as a taxicab. 
(b)  Every vehicle licensed and operating under this article shall be inspected by the police department every three (3) months after the first inspection and licensing of the vehicle to determine that the vehicle meets the foregoing requirements and if the vehicle fails to meet such requirements, the license of the vehicle shall be automatically revoked. 
(c)  Every vehicle licensed shall have a card carried in the vehicle at all times showing the make and motor and/or serial number of the vehicle, the date of original inspection and approval by the police department together with the date of expiration of each approval. A duplicate of the card shall be kept on file in the police department. It shall be a violation of this article to operate any unapproved vehicle or a vehicle upon which any approval has expired under any license issued pursuant to this article. 
(Code 1967, § 5-215)  
Sec. 39-23. - Insignia, color, etc. 
Every taxicab operated under any license issued pursuant to this article shall prominently display the word "taxi" or "taxicab" on the outside of the vehicle and shall prominently display the insignia of the licensee designated in the application. If any licensee shall have designated a color scheme in his or her application, every vehicle licensed to be used by the licensee shall be painted in accordance with such color scheme. 
(Code 1967, § 5-216)  
Sec. 39-24. - Taximeter required. 
All taxicabs operated under this article shall be equipped with a standard meter device of a type and make approved by the police commissioner at the time of the application and issuance of the license. All meters shall be fastened in the front of the taxicab in a location visible to any passengers and the face of the meter shall be illumined after sunset. Each meter shall have thereon a flag to denote when the vehicle is conveying any passenger, and it shall be the duty of the driver to show the flag of the meter in a nonrecording position at the termination of each trip. All meters shall be subject to inspection by the police department. Any officer of the department is authorized either on complaint of any person or without complaint, to inspect any meter and, upon discovery of any inaccuracy therein, to notify the driver operating the taxicab to cease operation. After such notice the taxicab shall not be used for transportation of passengers for hire until the meter is repaired and in proper working condition. 
(Code 1967, § 5-217)  
Sec. 39-25. - Rates of fare; display of rate card. 
(a)  No owner or driver of a taxicab shall charge a greater sum for the use of a taxicab than the schedule of rates approved by resolution of the city council. 
(b)  Every taxicab operated under this article shall have a rate card setting forth the authorized rates of fare displayed in such place as to be in view of the passenger. 
(Code 1967, § 5-218)  
Sec. 39-26. - Refusal to pay fare; receipts. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to refuse to pay the legal fare of any taxicab licensed under this article after having hired same. The driver of any taxicab shall upon demand by any passenger deliver to the passenger a receipt for the amount charged, either by a mechanically printed receipt or by a specially prepared receipt on which shall be the name of the licensee, license number of the taxicab, the name of the driver, amount of meter reading and/or charges and the date of the transaction. 
(Code 1967, § 5-219)  
Sec. 39-27. - Conduct of driver. 
It shall be unlawful for any taxicab driver to: 
(1)  Drink alcoholic liquors while on duty and engaged in the business of driving a taxicab; 
(2)  Solicit passengers except when sitting in the driver's seat of the taxicab or while standing immediately adjacent to the side of the taxicab. No driver shall solicit patronage in a loud or annoying tone of voice or by any sign or in a manner so as to annoy any person or to obstruct the movement of any person or to follow any person for the purpose of soliciting patronage; 
(3)  Permit more persons to be carried in a taxicab as passengers than the rated seated capacity of his or her taxicab. A child in arms shall not be counted as a passenger; 
(4)  Refuse or neglect to convey any orderly person, upon request, unless previously engaged; 
(5)  Engage in the selling of alcoholic liquors or solicit business for any house of ill repute, to use or permit the use of any taxicab for unlawful purposes, to procure or aid in procuring any person for unlawful purposes or to allow any person in any taxicab while the same is at any taxicab stand or on any street waiting for customers; or to use the taxicab for any other purpose than for the transporting of passengers for hire; 
(6)  Fail, neglect or refuse to turn in to the police department within twenty-four (24) hours any lost article found in the taxicab; 
(7)  Occupy any stand or any public street or public place except such as may be designated as a taxicab stand by the police commissioner; 
(8)  Fail to notify the police department within one (1) hour after any accident, giving the time and location of the accident, the name of any person injured, the character of the injuries as far as known, and in case of property damage, the nature and estimated amount of the damage and the name of the owner of the property damaged. 
(Code 1967, § 5-220)  
Sec. 39-28. - Taxicabs licensed in other municipalities. 
Nothing in this article shall be construed to prohibit any licensed suburban or City of Detroit taxicab from coming into the city to discharge passengers accepted for transportation outside the City of Warren. While the vehicle is in the city, no roof light or other special light shall be used to indicate that the vehicle is vacant or subject to hire, and a white card bearing the words "Not For Hire" printed in black letters not less than two (2) inches in height shall be displayed at the right front corner of the windshield of the vehicle, in such manner as not to obscure the vision of the driver. No person shall be solicited or accepted in the vehicle for transportation from any place within the City of Warren. 
(Code 1967, § 5-221)  
Sec. 39-29. - Minibuses, multi-passenger van express service to designated locations; flat rate fare card. 
All persons licensed to operate a taxicab in the city may operate a minibus or a multi-passenger van. These vehicles may transport passengers from a designated location in the city to other designated locations outside of the city for a flat fare as set by a resolution adopted by the city council. Every vehicle shall have a rate card setting forth the authorized rate and displayed in such a place as to be in view of the passengers. 
(Code 1967, § 5-222)  
Secs. 39-30—39-40. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - BUSINESS LICENSE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Licensing generally, Ch. 18. 
 
Sec. 39-41. - Required. 
No person shall operate or permit a taxicab owned or controlled by him or her to be operated as a vehicle for hire upon the streets of the city without first having obtained a license from the city therefor as provided in this division. 
(Code 1967, § 5-202)  
Sec. 39-42. - Application. 
Application for a license under this division shall be filed with the city clerk upon proper forms provided by him or her, and the application shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The name and address of the applicant and whether applicant is an individual, partnership, corporation or other legal entity; 
(2)  The experience of the applicant in the transportation of passengers for hire; 
(3)  The financial status of the applicant, including the amounts of any and all unpaid judgments against the applicant and the nature of the transaction or acts giving rise to such judgments; 
(4)  Any facts which the applicant believes tend to prove that the public convenience and necessity require the issuance of a license; 
(5)  The number of vehicles proposed to be operated by applicant together with a list of such vehicles including the name, year, motor and/or serial number and the seating capacity of such vehicles according to its trade rating; 
(6)  The color scheme and/or insignia to be used to designate the vehicle or vehicles of the applicant; 
(7)  The type and make of taximeter to be used; and 
(8)  Such further information as the city clerk may require. 
(Code 1967, § 5-203)  
Sec. 39-43. - Investigation; report. 
(a)  Upon the filing of an application for a license under this division, the city clerk shall refer the same to the police commissioner who shall make or cause to be made through the police department an investigation as to the good moral character as defined in section 18-8 and ability of the applicant to operate a taxicab business in the city, and the public convenience and necessity for the issuance of a license to the applicant. The applicant shall, upon the request of the police department, make available at the department any motor vehicle or vehicles proposed to be used in the taxicab business for inspection as to cleanliness, mechanical condition, appearance, and determination that such vehicle or vehicles are in a safe condition for the transportation of passengers for hire. 
(b)  Upon completion of the investigation and upon approval of the application by the police commissioner, the city clerk shall transmit the application and a report upon the condition of the vehicle or vehicles proposed to be used by applicant, together with his or her recommendation, to the city council. 
(Code 1967, § 5-204)  
Sec. 39-44. - Issuance or denial. 
(a)  Upon receipt of the application, together with the report and recommendation of the city clerk and police commissioner, if the city council shall find and determine that the applicant is a qualified person to operate a taxicab business in the city, that the vehicle or vehicles to be used are clean, in a good mechanical condition and safe for transportation of passengers for hire, and that the public convenience and necessity require the issuance of a license to the applicant, then the city council shall authorize the city clerk to issue a license to applicant upon the payment of the license fees and filing of policy of insurance; otherwise the application shall be denied. 
(b)  In making the above findings, the city council shall take into consideration the number of taxicabs in operation, whether existing transportation is adequate to meet the public need, the probable effect of increased service on local traffic, the moral character, experience and responsibility of the applicant, and the type and condition of the vehicle proposed to be used. 
(Code 1967, § 5-205)  
Sec. 39-45. - Fee. 
The fee for a license under this division shall be as prescribed in section 18-18. 
(Code 1967, § 5-206)  
Sec. 39-46. - Insurance required. 
No license shall be issued or continued under this division unless there is in full force and effect an insurance policy for each taxicab in an amount of not less than five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) for bodily injury to any one (1) person, and not less than five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) for bodily injuries to more than one (1) person, and not less than one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) property damage in any one (1) accident. The copies of insurance policies shall be filed in the office of the city clerk. The insurance policies shall be issued by an insurance company authorized to do business in the state. 
(Code 1967, § 5-207; Ord. No. 80-594, § 1, 4-8-03)  
Sec. 39-47. - Transfer. 
No license under this division shall be sold, assigned, mortgaged or otherwise transferred without the consent and approval of the city council. 
(Code 1967, § 5-208)  
Sec. 39-48. - Expiration; additional vehicles; substitution. 
The license under this division shall be in effect for an annual period from January first to December thirty-first of the same year and there shall be no prorating of the fees if a license shall be issued or a vehicle added by the licensee during the annual period. If any licensee shall add an additional vehicle, such fact shall be immediately reported to the city clerk in writing, giving the name, motor number and/or serial number and seating capacity of such vehicle and the license fee paid thereon. If any licensee shall substitute another vehicle for one on which the annual license fee shall have been paid, such fact shall be immediately reported to the city clerk in writing, giving the make, motor number and/or serial number and seating capacity of the motor vehicle discontinued and the motor vehicle substituted therefor, but no additional fee shall be required to be paid on any such substitution. 
(Code 1967, § 5-206)  
Secs. 39-49—39-60. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - DRIVER'S PERMIT 
 
Sec. 39-61. - Required. 
No person shall operate a taxicab for hire upon the streets of the city, and no person who owns or controls a taxicab shall permit it to be driven, and no taxicab licensed by the city shall be so driven at any time for hire, unless the driver of the taxicab shall have first obtained and shall have then in force a taxicab driver's permit issued under the provisions of this division. 
(Code 1967, § 5-210)  
Sec. 39-62. - Application. 
(a)  An application for a taxicab driver's permit shall be filed with the city clerk on forms provided by the city, and such application shall be verified under oath and shall contain information concerning the experience of the applicant in the transportation of passengers. 
(b)  Each application shall be accompanied by a certificate from a reputable physician of the city certifying that, in his or her opinion, the applicant is not afflicted with any disease or infirmity which might make him or her unsafe or an unsatisfactory driver. 
(Code 1967, § 5-211)  
Sec. 39-63. - Investigation; approval or denial. 
Upon receipt of any application for a driver's permit under this division, the city clerk shall refer the same to the police commissioner who shall make or cause to be made through the police department an investigation of the applicant, his or her good moral character as defined in section 18-8 and his or her motor vehicle violation and police record. Each applicant shall be required to present himself or herself at the police department in the city to give such information as may be required in such investigation and to show that applicant has a current vehicle chauffeur's license issued by the state and is competent to operate a taxicab. Upon completion of the investigation the police commissioner shall, upon consideration of the application, the facts disclosed by such investigation and the physician's certificate, approve or reject the application. If the application is rejected, no refund shall be made of the application fee but the applicant may request an opportunity to be heard by any license appeal board designated by the city council, and to offer evidence why his or her application should be granted. 
(Code 1967, § 5-212)  
Sec. 39-64. - Fee. 
The fee for a permit under this division shall be as prescribed in section 18-18. 
(Code 1967, §§ 5-211, 5-213)  
Sec. 39-65. - Issuance; display. 
Upon the approval of an application for a taxicab driver's permit, the police commissioner shall authorize and the city clerk shall issue a permit to the applicant which shall bear the name, address, color, age, signature and a photograph of the applicant, which photograph shall be furnished to the city clerk by the applicant at the time of issuance of the permit. Every taxicab driver shall post his or her driver's permit in such a place as to be in full view of all passengers while the driver is operating the taxicab. 
(Code 1967, § 5-213)  
Sec. 39-66. - Expiration. 
Every driver's permit issued pursuant to this division shall be in effect for an annual period from January first to December thirty-first of the same year and there shall be no prorating of any permit fee if the permit shall be granted during such annual period. 
(Code 1967, § 5-213)  
Secs. 39-67—39-90. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - TRAILERS[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference— Mobile homes and trailers generally, Ch. 20. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 39-91. - Definitions. 
The following words and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them: 
Trailer means all trailers, except tractor trailers, truck trailers, farm wagons and equipment. 
Trailer renters means all persons deemed to be in the business of renting trailers, and shall be designated as a trailer renter, who shall receive in return, compensation or reward for supplying, furnishing, leasing or renting a trailer to another, in any manner, except by sale; or who shall offer, furnish, lease, rent or supply a trailer or trailers to others in return for articles purchased, or services rendered; or who shall, directly or indirectly, receive any remuneration, reward or return for furnishing a trailer to another other than by a bona fide sale. 
(Code 1967, § 3-202) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 39-92. - Insignia required. 
No licensee shall rent any trailer to any person unless the trailer shall display on both sides thereof the name and address of the licensee in letters and figures at least three (3) inches in height and not less than one (1) inch in width. 
(Code 1967, § 3-208)  
Sec. 39-93. - Statement required. 
Before any licensee shall furnish or rent a trailer to another, he or she shall obtain from the person renting the trailer a signed statement which shall state the name and address of the person owning the articles or goods to be moved in the trailer, the date of the removal, and the address of the place from which and to which the removal is to be made. It shall be the duty of the licensee to obtain the above required information on the statement, and the signature and address of the person making the statement, before the trailer is delivered to the person renting same. 
(Code 1967, § 3-209)  
Sec. 39-94. - False statement prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person securing or renting a trailer to make or sign any false statement, or to give any fictitious name or address, or to aid or abet the making or signing of a false statement, or the giving of any fictitious name or address. 
(Code 1967, § 3-210)  
Sec. 39-95. - Premises. 
Each business hereafter established shall be on a lot, the area of which shall be not less than eight thousand (8,000) square feet, and which shall be used exclusively for the purpose of conducting a trailer rental business. The lot shall be maintained with a stable surface that will not retain water, treated so as to prevent the raising of dust or loose particles. Such surfacing may be constructed of crushed stone, slag, gravel, cinders, or any type of permanent surfacing with adequate drainage so as not to adversely affect any adjacent lot and street. The owner or operator of an area so used shall erect and maintain on such an area a permanent type building at least four hundred (400) square feet in area, for the purpose of servicing such equipment, and shall erect and maintain a barrier-type fence not less than four (4) feet in height, on the boundaries of such an area, with only such openings therein as may be necessary for ingress or egress. Adequate lighting facilities shall be provided and so arranged as to reflect light away from dwellings adjacent to the area. 
(Code 1967, § 3-211)  
Secs. 39-96—39-105. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE[4] 

Footnotes:

Cross reference— Licensing generally, Ch. 18. 
 
Sec. 39-106. - Required. 
No person shall hold himself or herself out as a renter of trailers or shall conduct, operate or carry on the business of renting trailers, without first having obtained a licensed as a trailer renter as provided in this division. 
(Code 1967, § 3-201)  
Sec. 39-107. - Application. 
Every person desiring to engage in the business of renting trailers, before holding himself or herself out as a trailer renter, shall make written application for a license to do so, to the city clerk, which application shall state the number and capacity (cubic feet) of each trailer that is proposed to be used in conducting the business, the name, address, telephone number of the applicant, and the period of time the applicant has been located at the address set forth in the application. No licensee shall operate such business under more than one (1) trade name. 
(Code 1967, § 3-204)  
Sec. 39-108. - Fee. 
The fee for a license under this division shall be as prescribed in section 18-18. 
(Code 1967, §§ 3-206, 3-207)  
Sec. 39-109. - Insurance required. 
Every applicant shall furnish satisfactory proof to the city clerk that the applicant does carry adequate public liability and property damage insurance up to an amount which shall not be less than two hundred fifty thousand dollars ($250,000.00) per person and five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) per occurrence public liability and one hundred thousand dollars ($100, 000.00) property damage for each trailer. Each applicant shall furnish with his or her application a prepaid policy or certificate of liability insurance showing the issuance of the insurance hereinbefore required, which prepaid policy or certificate of liability insurance shall be kept on file in the office of the city clerk, and no license shall be valid in the event of the cancellation of the insurance. Any insurance company issuing insurance as provided hereunder shall notify the city clerk ten (10) days prior to the cancellation of the insurance, or any part thereof. 
(Code 1967, § 3-205)  
Secs. 39-110—39-130. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - MOTORCYCLES  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 39-131. - Hours of operation. 
Businesses licensed under this article shall be operated between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 8.00 p.m. There shall be no rental or the returning of vehicles between the hours of 8:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m. 
(Code 1967, § 3-1606(g))  
Sec. 39-132. - Application to rent. 
All vehicles regulated by the provisions of this article may only be rented, leased or permitted to be used upon the filing with the licensee of a written application therefor which shall contain the following: 
(1)  Name, residence address, and age of applicant; 
(2)  Number and date of the applicant's valid drivers license; 
(3)  If the applicant is under eighteen (18) years of age, acknowledgment in writing, signed by either parent of the applicant or the applicant's legal guardian, in the presence of and witnessed by the licensee or his or her duly authorized agent, to the effect that permission is granted for the applicant to use the vehicle and that such parent or guardian assumes full responsibility for all acts or actions of the applicant in the use of the vehicle so rented or leased; 
(4)  The registered motor number of the vehicle rented or leased, together with other identifying data. 
(Code 1967, § 3-1607(a))  
Sec. 39-133. - Records. 
Any person licensed under this article, or any employee thereof, shall keep a complete and accurate file of all applications received, contracts or agreements of rental, description of vehicle rented or leased, date and hour of its rental, name and address of the person to whom the vehicle is rented or leased, the parent or guardian's written approval of a minor's application and his or her agreement to be responsible for the action of the minor in the use of the vehicle, and all other data as may be required by the traffic safety committee, all of which shall be made available for inspection by the traffic safety committee. 
(Code 1967, §§ 3-1606(a), 3-1607(h))  
Sec. 39-134. - Qualifications of lessees. 
No person shall rent a motorcycle under this article to persons: 
(1)  Under eighteen (18) years of age until receipt of acknowledgment in writing, signed by either parent of the applicant or the applicant's legal guardian, in the presence of and witnessed by the licensee or his or her duly authorized agent, to the effect that permission is granted for the applicant to use the vehicle and that such parent or guardian assumes full responsibility for all acts or actions of the applicant in the use of the vehicle so rented or leased; 
(2)  Who cannot show a valid motor vehicle operators license. 
(Code 1967, §§ 3-1606(b), (d), 3-1607(b))  
Sec. 39-135. - Vehicle operation hand-out. 
The licensee shall provide each lessee of a vehicle regulated by the provisions of this article, before permitting the vehicle to leave the premises, with an operating regulation hand-out as provided by the traffic safety committee. 
(Code 1967, § 3-1607(f))  
Sec. 39-136. - Use of helmets required. 
Motorcycles shall be rented under this article only if the driver and his or her passenger are wearing safety helmets. 
(Code 1967, § 3-1606(e))  
Sec. 39-137. - Maintenance and care of vehicles. 
(a)  Licensees under this article shall maintain all vehicles in a safe manner and provide each with all equipment required by law. 
(b)  Licensees under this article shall have only the number of vehicles on the premises as provided for in the application. 
(c)  All vehicles when not in use shall be stored within a building structure. 
(d)  All repairs and maintenance work shall be performed within a building structure. 
(e)  Vehicle motors shall not be permitted to be running while on the premises, except for necessary use in connection with ingress and egress from the premises; or when necessary, in order to repair or maintain the vehicle, and then only when the vehicle is within a building structure. 
(Code 1967, §§ 3-1606(f), (i), 3-1607(c), (d), (e))  
Sec. 39-138. - Sanitation and conduct of patrons on premises. 
(a)  Premises licensed under this article shall be maintained in a clean and sanitary condition, and the actions of the patrons shall be regulated and controlled so as to eliminate loud, boisterous or improper conduct upon the premises and the unnecessary emission of smoke, fumes, gases or noise from the operation of vehicles upon the premises. 
(b)  Unnecessary assembling of vehicles or drivers of vehicles upon the licensed premises shall be prohibited. 
(Code 1967, § 3-1607(g), (i))  
Secs. 39-139—39-150. - Reserved.

(1)  If an individual, the name and address of the individual; 
(2)  If a partnership, the name, residence and business address of each partner; 
(3)  If a corporation, the name, date and state under whose laws such corporation was organized, and if a foreign corporation, whether authorized to do business in the state; the names of the principal officers, directors and local representatives, their residences and business addresses; 
(4)  A plot plat of the premises to be used in the conduct of the business upon which shall be indicated the location and size of all building structures to be used thereon, and all vacant portions of the site together with means of ingress and egress; 
(5)  Provide a statement as to the number of vehicles to be rented or leased in the conduct of the business and the location of their storage (all vehicles are to be stored within a building structure when not in use), service facilities and location thereof, and number of employees to be engaged in the conduct of the business proposed to be licensed; 
(6)  Such other information which may be required by the city clerk in order to process the application. 
(Code 1967, § 3-1605)

(Code 1967, § 3-1604)
