(Code 1967, § 3-1608)  
Sec. 39-155. - Insurance required. 
Prior to issuance of a license under this division the applicant shall purchase a policy of insurance for every vehicle owned, rented or kept on the premises. The policy shall have a minimum coverage of two hundred fifty thousand dollars ($250,000.00) for only one (1) person injured and five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) for two (2) or more persons injured as the result of any one (1) occurrence or accident. 
(Code 1967, 3-1606(h))  
Sec. 39-156. - Tag. 
Persons licensed under this division shall attach a license tag provided by the city for each vehicle. 
(Code 1967, § 3-1606(c))  
Secs. 39-157—39-160. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - SNOW PLOW OPERATORS 
 
Sec. 39-161. - License—Required. 
No person, firm or corporation shall operate or cause to be operated any vehicle within any street, alley, sidewalk, right-of-way or public place of the city (unless it is contiguous to the person's, firms or corporation's property) for the purpose of moving, removing or plowing any snow or ice therefrom, without first having obtained a license as herein provided. 
(Ord. No. 80-370, § 1, 1-13-89)  
Sec. 39-162. - Same—Application; contents. 
Any person, firm or corporation desiring a license as required by section 39-161 shall file an application with the city clerk on a form as approved by the city clerk, which application shall contain the applicant's full name, address, and the number, make, model, license number, type and weight of vehicle which is to be used for the purposes as stated in section 39-161. The clerk shall refer the application to the director of public service who shall determine whether the type of equipment or vehicle and weight thereof would be detrimental or tend to be damaging to the public rights-of-way above mentioned in which the same is proposed to be used. Upon the favorable recommendation of the director of public service, or his designated agent, the city clerk shall issue a license upon payment of the fee and the filing of insurance in the amount provided for below. (Ord. No. 80-370, § 1, 1-13-89)  
Sec. 39-163. - Insurance requirements. 
Each applicant shall produce and file with the city clerk a certificate of an insurance carrier duly authorized to transact business in this state, certifying that it has insured the city in the minimum limits of liability with respect to bodily injury of twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) for each person and fifty thousand dollars ($50, 000.00) for each occurrence, and in respect to property damage twenty thousand dollars ($20,000.00), which certificate shall contain a provision to the effect that the insurance company shall notify the city at least ten (10) days prior to cancellation of insurance. 
(Ord. No. 80-370, § 1, 1-13-89)  
Sec. 39-164. - License fee. 
The license fee shall be as prescribed in section 18-18(2) of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 80-370, § 1, 1-13-89)  
Sec. 39-165. - License plate. 
For each such vehicle, vehicles or equipment for which a license fee has been paid, a license plate or decal shall be issued by the city clerk. Such license plate or decal shall have a number which shall correspond to the number assigned to such vehicle, vehicles or equipment by the city clerk. Such license plate or decal shall be affixed to such vehicle, vehicles or equipment in a position so as to be readily seen. 
(Ord. No. 80-370, § 1, 1-13-89)  
Sec. 39-166. - Safety equipment required. 
In addition to the equipment required by the Michigan Statutes, each such vehicle shall be equipped with a muffler approved by the director of public service and have attached to such vehicle lights which are mounted in a position as to be visible to any traffic and pedestrians, and any other safety devices as determined by the police commissioner, or his designated agent, to be necessary to prevent any possible accidents or property damage. Said lights and safety devices shall be on at all times during any snow plowing. 
(Ord. No. 80-370, § 1, 1-13-89)  
Sec. 39-167. - Expiration of license. 
All licenses issued pursuant to the provisions of this chapter shall expire on the 30th day of April of each year. 
(Ord. No. 80-370, § 1, 1-13-89)  
Chapter 40 - VENDING MACHINES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference— Authority to regulate trades and occupations, § 3.1(b)(2)(a). 
Cross reference— Amusement machines, § 6-226 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 40-1. - Definitions. 
The following words and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them: 
Gambling for purposes of this chapter shall mean the acceptance or payment of anything of value contingent upon the result of a race, contest, happening of an event not known to be certain or a game in which winning depends upon fortuitous or accidental circumstances beyond the control of the player. 
Merchandise vending machine means any mechanical device which, upon insertion of a coin, token or similar object, returns the value in merchandise of the sum thus inserted, or renders a service for same including shuffleboards and electronic dart boards. 
Person shall include the following: 
(1)  Any person, firm, corporation or association which owns any such machine; and 
(2)  The person, firm, corporation or association in whose place of business any such machine is placed for use by the public; and 
(3)  The person, firm, corporation or association having control over such machine. 
Redemption game means a single or multi-player mechanical, electronic or manual amusement device involving a game, the object of which is throwing, rolling, bowling, shooting, placing, propelling or stopping a ball or other object into, upon, or against a hole or other target. Redemption game does not include either of the following: 
(1)  Games such as roulette, beano, cards, dice, wheels of fortune, video poker, slot machines, or other games in which winning depends primarily upon fortuitous or accidental circumstances beyond the control of the player. 
(2)  A game that includes a mechanical or physical device which directly or indirectly impairs or thwarts the skill of the player. 
(Code 1967, § 3-506; Ord. No. 80-436, § 2, 8-10-93; Ord. No. 80-553, § 1, 3-28-00) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 40-2. - Electrical regulations. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person holding a license under this chapter to operate any machine as defined in section 40-1 which has not been approved and/or listed by a nationally recognized testing laboratory such as Underwriters Laboratory (U.L.) and/or Factory Mutual Research Corporation. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to electrically connect food and beverage vending machines by the use of extension cords. 
(c)  All electrical connections made by the flexible cord that supplies the machine shall be of the three-wire grounding type. Vending machines shall be arranged so as not to overload any existing circuit that they may be attached to. 
(d)  For the installation of these vending machines that require the installation of an electrical circuit or the extending of a circuit, an electrical permit and inspection is required. 
(e)  The installation of electrical circuits shall be made by an electrical contractor and with an electrical permit secured from the city offices. 
(f)  All electrical installations shall be in compliance with the National Electrical Code. 
(Code 1967, § 3-510(a), (b), (d)—(g)) 
Cross reference— Electrical code, § 9-36 et seq.  
Sec. 40-3. - Gambling devices prohibited. 
(a)  Nothing in this chapter shall in any way be construed to authorize, license or permit any gambling device whatsoever, or any mechanism that has been determined to be a gambling device, or in any way contrary to law. 
(b)  The determination of whether a device is a gambling device shall be based on application of the Michigan Penal Code, Chapter XLIV, entitled Gambling, MCL, 750.301 et seq., as amended, and all other applicable state and federal laws, as amended. 
(b)  Redemption game devices, as defined herein, that comply with all the following requirements are exempt from the prohibitions contained in subsection (a): 
(1)  The outcome of the game is determined through the application of an element of skill by the player. 
(2)  The award of the prize is based upon the player achieving the object of the game or otherwise upon the player's score. 
(3)  Prizes awarded are only non-cash prizes such as toys, novelties, coupons or other representations of value redeemable for non-cash prizes, toys or novelties. 
(4)  The wholesale value of a prize awarded for the successful single play of a game does not exceed three dollars and seventy-five cents ($3.75). 
(5)  The redemption value of coupons or other representations of value awarded for the successful single play of a game does not exceed fifteen (15) times the amount charged for a single play of the game or three dollars and seventy-five cents ($3.75), whichever is less. However, players may accumulate coupons or other representations of value for redemption for no-cash prizes not to exceed two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) wholesale value. 
(Code 1967, § 3-510(c); Ord. No. 80-553, § 1, 3-28-00) 
Cross reference— Gambling generally, § 22-138. 
State Law reference— Gambling, MCL 750.301 et seq.  
Sec. 40-4. - Tobacco products—Findings and purpose. 
The Warren City Council finds the U.S. Surgeon General and other medical authorities have linked the use of tobacco products to numerous and serious health problems, and state law prohibits the sale, giving or furnishing of tobacco products to minors. Yet, despite this prohibition, the availability of tobacco products to minors continues to be a major problem and tobacco product vending machines are often located in unattended and unmonitored areas allowing for the unlawful purchase of tobacco products by minors. Restricting tobacco product vending machines in the City of Warren to specified locations which are not generally accessible to minors will reduce the availability of tobacco products to minors and promote the public health, welfare and safety as a result. 
Therefore, the purpose of this chapter is to restrict tobacco product vending machines in the City of Warren to specified locations which are not generally accessible to minors. 
(Ord. No. 80-404, § 1, 1-28-92)  
Sec. 40-5. - Same—Definitions. 
(a)  Tobacco product. Any product made from the tobacco plant for the purpose of smoking, chewing, inhaling or other personal use including, but not limited to, cigars, cigarettes, chewing tobacco, pipe tobacco and snuff. 
(b)  Tobacco product vending machine. Any automated, self-service device which, upon insertion of money, tokens or any other form of payment, dispenses any type of tobacco product. 
(Ord. No. 80-404, § 1, 1-28-92)  
Sec. 40-6. - Same—Restrictions on tobacco product vending machines. 
It shall be unlawful for the owner, tenant, or proprietor of any premises in the City of Warren to offer or sell tobacco products through a tobacco product vending machine except in the following specified locations: 
(a)  Premises where access by minors prohibited. A tobacco product vending machine may be placed or located wholly within the premises, or portions thereof, to which access by minors is expressly prohibited either by law or by policy of the owner of the premises. 
(b)  Commercial and industrial buildings. A tobacco product vending machine may be placed or located wholly within a commercial building or industrial plant, or a portion thereof, where the general public is prohibited from entering by appropriate signs where the tobacco product vending machine is intended strictly for the use of employees, and where minor employees are not usually admitted. 
(c)  Unattended and unmonitored areas. Notwithstanding subsections (a) and (b) above, no tobacco product vending machine shall be placed or located closer than twenty (20) feet to any entrance or exit, or within a restroom, coat room, outer waiting area, unmonitored hallway or any other area which is not constantly supervised or monitored during the hours the tobacco product vending machine is available for use, nor shall a tobacco product vending machine be placed or located in an area where it may be accessible to the public when the premises where it is located are closed. 
(Ord. No. 80-404, § 1, 1-28-92)  
Sec. 40-7. - Same—Enforcement. 
Compliance with this chapter shall be enforced by the mayor, the city building department, the Macomb County Sheriff's Department, police officers of the City of Warren, and other enforement officers as the mayor may designate. 
(Ord. No. 80-404, § 1, 1-28-92)  
Sec. 40-8. - Same—Severability. 
Sections 40-4 through 40-10 and each article, section, subsection, paragraph, subparagraph, part, provision, sentence, word and portion thereof are hereby declared to be severable and if they or any of them are declared to be invalid or unenforceable for any reason by a court of competent jurisdiction, the remainder of these sections shall not be affected thereby. 
(Ord. No. 80-404, § 1, 1-28-92)  
Sec. 40-9. - Same—Penalty. 
All violations of sections 40-4 through 40-10 shall be misdemeanors, and upon conviction thereof shall be punishable by a sentence of not more than ninety (90) days of confinement to jail or by a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), or both, in the discretion of the court. 
(Ord. No. 80-404, § 1, 1-28-92)  
Sec. 40-10. - Same—Repeal. 
All regulatory provisions contained in other city ordinances, which are inconsistent with the provisions of sections 40-4 through 40-9, are hereby repealed. 
(Ord. No. 80-404, § 1, 1-28-92)  
Secs. 40-11—40-25. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - LICENSE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Licenses generally, Ch. 18. 
 
Sec. 40-26. - Required. 
Any person displaying for public patronage or keeping for operation any merchandise and/or service vending machine, shall be required to obtain a license from the city as provided in this article. 
(Code 1967, § 3-507(1))  
Sec. 40-27. - Application. 
Application for a license under this article shall be made to the city clerk on a form to be supplied for that purpose. The application for a merchandise or service vending machine license shall contain the following information: 
(1)  Name and address of the applicant, age, date and place of birth; 
(2)  Prior convictions of applicant, if any; 
(3)  Place where machine or device is to be displayed or operated and the business conducted at that place; 
(4)  Description of machine to be covered by the license, mechanical features, name of manufacturer, serial number. 
(Code 1967, § 3-507(1), 3-508(1))  
Sec. 40-28. - Age requirement. 
No license shall be issued under this article to any applicant unless he or she shall be over eighteen (18) years of age. 
(Code 1967, § 3-508(2))  
Sec. 40-29. - Investigation; issuance. 
(a)  Application for a merchandise or service vending machine license shall be made out in duplicate, one (1) copy being referred to the police commissioner and the other copy to the director of buildings and safety engineering. 
(b)  The police commissioner shall ascertain if the vending machine applicant is a person of good moral character, as defined in section 18-8, by an investigation to determine if he or she was guilty of any criminal offense, and based on the investigation either approve or disapprove the application in writing, stating his or her reasons. 
(c)  The director of buildings and safety engineering shall inspect his or her files to see if the commercial establishment wherein the licensed machine is located complies with the city ordinances, has a valid certificate of occupancy, and based upon this investigation either approve or disapprove the application in writing, stating his or her reasons. 
(d)  No license issued under this article shall be issued to any applicant unless approved by the police commissioner and the director of buildings and safety engineering. 
(Code 1967, §§ 3-508(3), 3-509(2))  
Sec. 40-30. - Fee. 
The fee for a license under this article shall be as prescribed in section 18-8. 
(Code 1967, § 3-509(1))  
Sec. 40-31. - Display. 
The license provided for in this article shall be posted permanently and conspicuously at the location of the machine in the premises where the device is to be operated or maintained to be operated. 
(Code 1967, § 3-507(2))  
Sec. 40-32. - Transfer. 
(a)  A license under this article may be transferred from one (1) machine or device to another similar machine upon application to the city clerk to such effect and the giving of a description and the serial number of the new machine or device. Not more than one (1) machine shall be operated under one (1) license and the applicant or licensee shall be required to secure a license for each and every machine displayed or operated by him or her. 
(b)  A license shall not be transferable from person to person, and shall be usable only at the place and by the person designated in the license. However, if the licensee shall move his or her place of business to another location within the city, the license may be transferred to such new location upon application to the city clerk, giving the street and number of the new location. The new location shall be approved by the police commissioner and the director of buildings and safety engineering in the same manner as provided for the original license. 
(Code 1967, § 3-507(3), (4))  
Sec. 40-33. - Expiration. 
A license issued under this article shall be valid for one (1) year, expiring annually on the thirty-first day of August. 
(Code 1967, § 3-508(4))  
Sec. 40-34. - Penalty. 
The violation of any provision of article II is a municipal civil infraction which shall result in the assessment of a fine of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) or not more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per infraction, plus costs and other sanctions for each infraction. 
(Ord. No. 80-527, § 27, 1-13-98)  
Chapter 41 - WATER AND SEWERS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference— Authority of department of public service relative to water and sewers, § 7.21; public utility services, Ch. 15. 
Cross reference— Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 9; plumbing code, § 9-126 et seq.; garbage and rubbish, Ch. 16; mobile homes and trailers, Ch. 20. nuisances, Ch. 21; streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 34; subdivision regulations, Ch. 35. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 41-1. - Penalty. 
(a)  The violation of any provision of this chapter, except as otherwise provided in subsection (b) of this section and section 41-169, is a municipal civil infraction which shall result in the assessment of a fine not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) or not more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per violation, plus costs and other sanctions for each infraction. 
(b)  In addition to section 41-169(b), the following violations of this chapter are a misdemeanor which shall, upon conviction, be punished by a fine not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisonment for a term not exceeding ninety (90) days, or both, plus costs and other sanctions for each violation: 
(1)  Meters. Tampering with meter, breaking the seal of meter, removing or changing location of meter or interfering with reading of meter. 
(2)  Equipment. No unauthorized person shall break, damage, destroy, uncover, deface or tamper with or alter, any structure, property, appurtenance, or any other equipment which is part of the water system. 
(3)  Any violation of section 41-21(a). 
(4)  Failure to allow access for repair, maintenance or installation after reasonable notice. 
(5)  Turning water service on without authorization by the city after the service was discontinued or disconnected by the city. 
(6)  Use of fire hydrant without permission from authorized city department. 
(Ord. No. 80-714, § 1, 1-14-14)  
Secs. 41-2—41-20. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - WATER[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Water service for moved buildings, § 9-342; water service for wrecked buildings, § 9-416; use of drinking fountains and plumbing fixtures in parks, § 23-12; public improvements for water supply in subdivisions, § 35-103. 
 
Sec. 41-21. - Connections; permit required. 
(a)  No person shall tap any water main or distribution pipe of the waterworks system, or insert therein any corporation cock, stop cock or any other fixture or appliance, or alter or disturb any service pipe, corporation stop, curb stop, gate valve, hydrant, water meter or any other attachment being a part of the waterworks system and attached thereto. 
(b)  Before any service connection shall be made to any part of the waterworks system or any work performed upon old or new connections, a permit shall be obtained from the department of public service. Such permit shall be issued upon written application on forms obtainable from the water division. Applicants for water service shall furnish, lay and install all that portion of the service not provided by the city at their own expense, subject, however, to the supervision and inspection of the city inspector. 
(Code 1967, §§ 7-501(1), 7-502)  
Sec. 41-22. - Permit required for service pipe connections. 
No person shall divert the water from any main or distribution pipe into any service pipe without a permit from the department of public service. 
(Code 1967, § 7-505)  
Sec. 41-23. - Tapping fees. 
Upon filing an application for a permit to connect with any water main or distribution pipe of the waterworks system, there shall be paid such tapping fee as shall be prescribed by the regulations governing the waterworks system. Such fees shall include all the costs of tapping the main, installing the corporation cock, furnishing and laying the service pipe to the property line and installing stop cock and shutoff box; all such materials to be and remain the property of the city water system. 
(Code 1967, § 7-503)  
Sec. 41-24. - Restrictions on use. 
The owner or occupant of any building or premises entitled to the use of water from the system shall not supply water to any other person except upon written permission of the department of public service, nor shall he or she permit unnecessary waste of water. 
(Code 1967, § 504)  
Sec. 41-25. - Regulation of service pipes. 
All service pipes connecting with the distribution mains of the waterworks system, from the city main to the stop inside the building, shall be laid under the supervision of the department of public service and in accordance with the regulations governing the waterworks system. 
(Code 1967, § 7-506)  
Sec. 41-26. - Discontinuance of service for violations; cost of resumption. 
Any premises may be disconnected from the distribution pipes of the city waterworks system and the supply of water withheld from such premises upon violation by the owner or occupant of the premises of any provision of this article or of the regulations adopted pursuant thereto. This includes, but is not limited to, failure to allow inspection, meter reading, maintenance/repair, installation, and/or replacement of water meters upon reasonable notice by the city. Whenever the water is turned off from any premises because of any such violation, it shall not be turned on again until the owner or occupant has paid the department of public service prior to commencement of the work a fee to cover the cost of labor as determined by city council resolution. 
(Code 1967, § 7-507; Ord. No. 80-714, § 2, 1-14-14)  
Sec. 41-27. - City not liable for disruption of service. 
The city shall not be liable for any failure or deficiency in the supply of water to consumers, whether occasioned by shutting off the water to make necessary repairs or connections or for any other cause. 
(Code 1967, § 7-508)  
Sec. 41-28. - Use of branch and stop cock for each user; supply to more than one lot. 
In all cases where water service is intended to supply more than one (1) shop, store or building, it shall be the duty of the person making the service connection, or causing the same to be made, to install a branch with a stop cock for each branch outside the line of the premises so to be supplied. The stop cock shall be suitably protected and marked as to be easily located. In no case shall one (1) service supply more than one (1) lot, unless occupied by a single building covering more than one (1) lot used for a single industry or enterprise. 
(Code 1967, § 7-509)  
Sec. 41-29. - Connections with street mains for fire prevention. 
The owner or occupant of any premises of any manufacturing establishment, lumber yard, warehouse, elevator, store, hotel, school or any public building desiring to install large pipes with hydrant and hose couplings to be used only in case of fire may make connection with the street main at his or her own expense upon application to the department of public service, and the applicant shall pay all charges as prescribed by the city council and the connection shall be made in accordance with the specifications of the department of public service. 
(Code 1967, § 7-510) 
Cross reference— Fire prevention and protection, Ch. 13.  
Sec. 41-30. - Access to premises by city employees. 
The inspector or any of his or her agents shall have power and authority at all reasonable hours to enter upon any premises where water is furnished from the city waterworks system, for the purpose of reading, installing, repairing and/or replacing water meters and/or the inspection of all pipes and fixtures connected with the waterworks system, and they shall have authority to require any defective pipes or fixtures to be repaired, removed or replaced where the same are not in compliance with the provisions of the regulations pertaining to the waterworks system. Any person refusing or neglecting to make such repairs when so ordered shall be deemed guilty of violation of this article and liable to prosecution therefor. 
(Code 1967, § 7-511; Ord. No. 80-714, § 3, 1-14-14)  
Sec. 41-31. - Water meters. 
(a)  "Water meter" or "meter." As used in this article, water meter or meter means the water meter and any equipment used for meter reading. 
(b)  The division of water supply shall install remote water meter reading devices on all buildings having a water line two (2) inches or smaller in diameter leading to the building. Except for the water meter replacement program associated with Meter Replacement Program, RFP W-7738, or determined by the water division superintendent, the meter reading devices shall be installed with the cost to the customer and shall remain the property of the division of water supply. Failure to allow installation of water meters equipped with automatic remote reading devices may result in discontinuance of water service. 
(c)  Water meter access/location. Water meters shall be placed in an accessible location and in a manner satisfactory to the water division superintendent. If the premises does not contain a basement or other suitable inside location, the meter may be installed at another location upon approval of the water division superintendent. The owner or occupant is prohibited from creating, allowing, or having any obstruction which would preclude access by the city to the water meter. Upon reasonable notice, the city shall have the right to shut off the supply of water to any premises where the city employee or agent is unable to obtain access to the meter. 
(d)  Water meters shall be installed upon any premises supplied with water, and any damage to the water meter resulting from the failure of the owner, lessee or occupant to properly protect same shall be assessed against such owner, lessee or occupant. No person shall tamper with or remove the water meter, or interfere with the reading thereof. If any water meter shall fail to register properly, the water division shall estimate the consumption on the basis of former consumption and bill accordingly. Any failure attributed to the water meter itself will be replaced at no cost to the owner. 
(e)  Meter testing. An owner or occupant may require that the water meter be tested. If the water meter is found defective it shall be repaired or replaced at no cost to the owner or occupant. If an owner or occupant disputes the water bill, the water division superintendent or his/her designee may review the matter for a determination as to whether the water meter is defective. 
(f)  Upon filing an application for a permit for water service, there shall be paid such charge for a water meter as prescribed by the regulations governing the waterworks system. All water meters remain the property of the City of Warren Water and Sewer System. 
(Code 1967, §§ 7-511.1, 7-512; Ord. No. 80-340, § 42, 6-9-87; Ord. No. 80-714, § 4, 1-14-14)  
Sec. 41-32. - Emergency conditions. 
Under emergency conditions, as determined by the proper authorities and upon notification in a manner as prescribed by such authorities, sprinkling or other nonessential use of water may be banned entirely, and any service may be restricted if the public health, safety or general welfare is endangered. 
(Code 1967, § 7-513)  
Sec. 41-33. - Cross connections. 
(a)  The city adopts by reference the Water Supply Cross Connection Rules of the Michigan Department of Public Health, being R 325.431 to R 325.440 of the Michigan Administrative Code. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of the division of water supply to cause inspections to be made of all properties served by the public water supply where cross connections with the public water supply are deemed possible. The frequency of inspections and reinspections based on potential health hazards involved shall be as established by the city and as approved by the state department of public health. 
(c)  The representative of the city division of water supply shall have the right to enter at any reasonable time any property served by a connection to the public water supply system of the city for the purpose of inspecting the piping system or systems thereof for cross connections. On request, the owner, lessees or occupants of any property so served shall furnish to the inspection agency any pertinent information regarding the piping system or systems on such property. The refusal of such information or refusal of access, when requested, shall be deemed evidence of the presence of cross connections. 
(d)  The division of water supply is hereby authorized and directed to discontinue water service after reasonable notice to any property wherein any connection in violation of this article exists, and to take such other precautionary measures deemed necessary to eliminate any danger of contamination of the public water supply system. Water service to such property shall not be restored until the cross connection has been eliminated in compliance with the provisions of this article. 
(e)  The potable water supply made available on the properties served by the public water supply shall be protected from possible contamination as specified by this article and by the state and city plumbing code. Any water outlet which could be used for potable or domestic purposes and which is not supplied by the potable system must be labeled in a conspicuous manner as: 
WATER UNSAFE 
FOR DRINKING 
(f)  This article does not supercede the state plumbing code and article IV of chapter 9, but is supplementary to them. 
(Code 1967, § 7-501(2)—(7))  
Secs. 41-34—41-55. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - SEWERS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 80-417, § 1, adopted Sept. 8, 1992, amended the provisions of former Art. III, relative to sewers, in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Art. III derived from Ord. No. 80-398, § 1, adopted Nov. 26, 1991. 
Cross reference— Sewer service for moved buildings, § 9-343; sewer service for wrecked buildings, § 9-417; public improvements for sanitary sewers in subdivisions, § 35-102. 
 
Sec. 41-56. - Purpose. 
(a)  This article is intended to regulate and control the use of public sewers and the POTW by specifying requirements for permit issuance, inspections, connections to sewers, specifications for pipe quality, downspout regulations, waste materials discharged into the POTW, water and sewer rates, permit fees, sewage disposal rates and charges, late charges and penalties, discharge sampling, pretreatment and containment of harmful wastes, installation of sump pumps and building drains, and provides for the regulation of contributors to the POTW through the issuance of permits to significant industrial users and through the enforcement of general requirements for all users of the POTW through monitoring, reporting and enforcement provisions, thereby allowing the city to comply with all applicable state and federal laws required by the Clean Water Act of 1977 and the General Pretreatment Regulations, 40 CFR part 403, as amended. 
(b)  The objectives of this article are: 
(1)  To prevent the introduction of pollutants into the POTW which will interfere with the normal operation of the system or contaminate the resulting municipal sludge; 
(2)  To prevent the introduction of pollutants into the POTW which do not receive adequate treatment in the POTW, are incompatible with the system, or which will pass through the system into receiving waters or the atmosphere; 
(3)  To improve the opportunity to recycle and reclaim wastewater and sludge from the system; 
(4)  To provide for the equitable distribution of the cost of the POTW; 
(5)  To comply with all applicable state and federal laws required by the Clean Water Act of 1977 and the General Pretreatment Regulations, 40 CFR part 403, as amended. 
(Ord. No. 80-417, § 1, 9-8-92; Ord. No. 80-497, § 1, 7-9-96)  
DIVISION 1. - DEFINITIONS 
 
Sec. 41-57. - Definitions. 
For the purposes of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings described in this section unless the context in which they are used specifically indicates otherwise: 
(1)  Act: The Federal Water Pollution Control Act, also known as the Clean Water Act (CWA), as amended, 33 U.S.C. 1251, et seq. 
(2)  Alternative discharge limit: A limit set by the city in lieu of the promulgated national categorical pretreatment standards for integrated facilities in accordance with the combined waste stream formula, as set by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency. 
(3)  Applicable pretreatment standard: The standard that applies to a user. When there is a conflict between the categorical pretreatment standard and the local discharge limit, then the more stringent standard shall be the applicable pretreatment standard. 
(4)  Approval authority: The director of the department of natural resources. 
(5)  Authorized representative of industrial use: An authorized representative of an industrial/commercial user may be: 
a.  A president, secretary, treasurer or vice president of the corporation in charge of a principle business function, or any other person who performs similar policy or decision making functions for the corporation; 
b.  A general partner or proprietor if the industrial user is a partnership or proprietorship, respectively; 
c.  The manager of one (1) or more manufacturing, production or operating facilities employing more than two hundred fifty (250) persons or having gross annual sales or expenditures exceeding twenty-five million dollars ($25,000,000.00), if authority to sign documents has been assigned or delegated to the manager in accordance with corporate procedures; 
d.  The duly authorized representative of the individual designated above if such representative of the individual is responsible for overall operation of the facilities from which the discharge originates or for environmental matters of the company. 
Authorization for this individual must be submitted to the city, in writing, by the individual designated in paragraph d. above. In addition, the duly authorized representative shall be designated by the industrial user on the user permit application. 
(5.5)  Best management practice (BMP): a practice or practices that prevent or reduce adverse effects of industrial water discharge, including, but not limited to, practices establishing: treatment requirements; operating, maintenance, and management procedures; controls on site runoff, spillage, and leaks; and controls on sludge or waste disposal, drainage, and material storage. 
(6)  Biochemical oxygen demand (BOD): The quantity of oxygen utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedure, for five (5) days at twenty (20) degrees centigrade expressed in terms of weight and concentration (milligrams per liter, mg/l). 
(7)  Building sanitary drain: That part of the horizontal piping of a sanitary system under the basement floor that receives sanitary waste from the plumbing system and conveys it to the building sewer which begins at a point five (5) feet outside the outer face of the building wall. 
(8)  Building sewer: The extension from the building sanitary drain to the sanitary sewer lead located in the public right-of-way or easement. 
(9)  Building storm drain: That part of the horizontal piping of a storm drainage system under the basement floor that receives the groundwater discharge from the footing drain tile and conveys it to the storm line. 
(10)  Bypass: The intentional diversion of wastestreams from any portion of an industrial user's treatment facility. 
(11)  Categorical standards: The national categorical pretreatment standards or pretreatment standard as promulgated under authority of the Clean Water Act which specifies the quantities or concentrations of pollutants or pollutant properties which may be discharged or introduced into the POTW by specific industrial dischargers. 
(12)  Chemical oxygen demand: The quantity of oxygen utilized in the chemical oxidation of inorganic and organic matter in wastewater, expressed in terms of weight and concentration (milligrams per liter, mg/l). 
(13)  City: City of Warren. 
(14)  Combined waste stream: The waste stream at industrial facilities where regulated process effluent is mixed with other wastewater, either regulated or unregulated, prior to or at the point of treatment. 
(15)  Combined waste stream formula: The combined waste stream formula found at 40 CFR 403.6(e) is the method which shall be used to calculate alternative pollutant limits at industrial facilities where regulated process effluent is mixed with other wastewaters prior to treatment. 
(16)  Compatible pollutant: Pollutants that can be effectively removed by the POTW treatment system to within acceptable levels for the POTW residuals and the receiving stream and that do not contribute to operational upsets or interference of the POTW. This includes but is not limited to conventional pollutants. Specifically excluded are heavy metals and/or incompatible organic and inorganic pollutants. 
(17)  Composite sample: A series of individual samples of equal volume or of flow proportioned volume taken over a specified time period at specified intervals which are combined into one (1) sample or the equivalent. The arrangement of the sample series shall be tailored to the specific circumstances of the waste stream being tested and shall reasonably reflect the characteristics of the waste stream at the time of each sample. 
(18)  Control manhole: A sampling location which provides for effectively isolating the discharge or flow of an industrial/commercial user. 
(19)  Control authority: A POTW that has received industrial pretreatment program approval in accordance with requirements set forth in 40 CFR 403.11. 
(20)  Cooling water: The water discharged from any use such as air conditioning, cooling or refrigeration, or to which the only pollutant is added is heat, shall be considered noncontact cooling water. The water, discharged from any use such as air conditioning, cooling or refrigeration, to which heat and other pollutants have been added, shall be considered contact cooling water. 
(21)  Direct discharge: The discharge of treated or untreated wastewater directly into the waters of the state. 
(22)  Domestic user: A source of waste emanating from a residence and resulting from the day to day activities usually carried on in a domicile. 
(23)  EPA: The United States Environmental Protection Agency, administrator or other duly authorized official. 
(24)  Equivalent limit: A mass per day limit or a concentration limit which is calculated to be equivalent to a federal categorical limit and applied as the local limit in place of the federal limit. 
(25)  Existing source: Any source which is not a new source as defined in subparagraph (45) of this section. 
(26)  Fats, oils or grease (FOG): Any hydrocarbons, fatty acids, soaps, fats, waxes, oils, and any other material of animal, vegetable or mineral origin that is extractable by solvent in accordance with standard methods. 
(27)  Footing drain tile: That piping system at the outside base of the basement wall receiving groundwater from the yard area. 
(27.5)  Fundamentally different factor variance: A variance from the local discharge limits that is permitted because the facility is fundamentally different than those facilities that local discharge limits are based on. 
(28)  Grab sample: A sample which is collected in less than fifteen ( 15) minutes without regard to flow in the waste stream and without consideration of time, but which reasonably reflects the characteristics of the waste stream at the time of sampling. 
(29)  Holding tank waste: Any waste from holding tanks such as, but not limited to, vessels, chemical toilets, campers, trailers, septic tanks, and vacuum-pump tank trucks. 
(30)  Incompatible pollutants: Any pollutant which is not a compatible pollutant. 
(31)  Indirect discharge: The discharge or the introduction of nondomestic pollutants into the POTW (including holding tank waste discharged into the system). 
(32)  Industrial pretreatment permit: Permit issued in accordance with Division 4 of this article. 
(33)  Industrial user: A source of discharge to the POTW which originates from, but is not limited to, facilities engaged in industry, manufacturing, business, trade or research, including the development, recovery or processing of natural products. Single and multiple family residential dwellings with discharges consistent with domestic waste characteristics are specifically excluded. 
(34)  Industrial wastes: The solid, liquid, gaseous waste or form of energy or any combination thereof, resulting from any industrial, manufacturing, trade, business or research process or from the development, recovery or processing of natural resources which is distinct from employee domestic waste or sanitary waste. 
(35)  Integrated facilities: Industrial facilities with combined waste streams. 
(36)  Interference: Discharge by a user which, alone or in conjunction with other discharges by other sources, inhibits or disrupts the POTW treatment processes or operations contributing to a violation of any requirement of the city's NPDES permit. The term includes prevention of sewage sludge use or disposal by the POTW in accordance with Section 405 of the Act (33 U.S.C. 1345), or any criteria, guidelines or regulations developed pursuant to the Solid Waste Disposal Act, the Clean Air Act, the Toxic Substances Control Act, or more stringent state criteria (including those contained in any state sludge management plan prepared pursuant to Title IV of the Solid Waste Disposal Act) applicable to the method of disposal or use employed by the POTW. 
(37)  Laboratory determinations: Are methods set forth in 40 CFR 136, " Guidelines For Establishing Test Procedures For Analysis of Pollutants" or the laboratory procedures set forth in the latest edition, at the time of analysis, of Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and Wastewater prepared and published jointly by the American Public Health Association, the American Water Works Association, and the Water Pollution Control Federation. Where these two (2) references are in disagreement, the methods given in 40 CFR 136 shall be followed. 
(38)  Matrix interference: Characteristics of the sample that interfere with the test method execution such that reliable data cannot be generated. 
(38.25)  Maximum allowable headworks loading: The total mass, including SAL allocations, of a pollutant that all users, septage receipts, along with POTW's safety factors may discharge without causing a pass through or interference. 
(38.75)  Maximum allowable industrial loading: The total mass, including SAL allocations, of a pollutant that all industrial users of a POTW may discharge without causing a pass through or interference. 
(39)  May or shall: Use of the word "may" is permissive whereas use of the word "shall" is mandatory. 
(40)  National categorical pretreatment standard: Any regulation containing pollutant discharge limits promulgated by the EPA in accordance with Section 307(b) and (c) of the Clean Water Act and applies to a specific category of users. 
(41)  National prohibitive discharge standard: Any regulation developed under the authority of 307(b) of the Act and 40 CFR, Section 403.5. 
(42)  New source: 
a.  Any building, structure, facility or installation from which there is or may be a discharge of pollutants, the construction of which commenced after the publication of proposed pretreatment standards under Section 307(c) of the Act which will be applicable to such source if such standards are thereafter promulgated in accordance with that section, provided that: 
1.  The building, structure, facility or installation is constructed at a site at which no other source is located; or 
2.  The building, structure, facility or installation totally replaces the process or production equipment that causes the discharge of pollutants at an existing source; or 
3.  The production or wastewater generating processes of the building, structure, facility or installation are substantially independent of an existing source at the same site. In determining whether these are substantially independent, factors such as the extent to which the new facility is integrated with the existing plant, and the extent to which the new facility is engaged in the same general type of activity as the existing source should be considered. 
b.  Construction on a site at which an existing source is located results in a modification rather than a new source if the construction does not create a new building, structure, facility or installation meeting the criteria of paragraphs (45)c.1.ii., or (45)c.1.iii. of this section but otherwise alters, replaces, or adds to existing process or production equipment. 
c.  Construction of a new source as defined under this paragraph has commenced if the owner or operator has: 
(1)  Begun, or caused to begin as part of a continuous on-site construction program: 
(i)  Any placement, assembly, or installation of facilities or equipment; or 
(ii)  Significant site preparation work including clearing, excavation, or removal of existing buildings, structures, or facilities which is necessary for the placement, assembly, or installation of new source facilities or equipment; or 
(2)  Entered into a binding contractual obligation for the purchase of facilities or equipment which are intended to be used in its operation within a reasonable time. Options to purchase or contracts which can be terminated or modified without substantial loss, and contracts for feasibility, engineering, and design studies do not constitute a contractual obligation under this paragraph. 
(43)  Nondomestic waste: Solid, liquid, or gaseous waste resulting from any industrial manufacturing, trade, or business process, or from the development, recovery or processing of natural resources. 
(44)  NPDES permit: National pollution discharge elimination system permit issued pursuant to Section 402 of the Clean Water Act for the discharge of wastewater into the surface waters of the state. 
(45)  Operation and maintenance: All work, materials, equipment, utilities and other effort required to operate and maintain the wastewater transportation and treatment system consistent with insuring adequate treatment of wastewater to produce an effluent in compliance with the NPDES permit and other applicable state and federal regulations, including the cost of replacement. 
(46)  Organic chemicals: Compounds composed of carbon and hydrogen or their derivatives which are manmade or by-products of manmade or natural substances which include, but are not limited to, synthetic fibers, plastics, rubber medicinals, solvents, surface-active agents, pesticides and other agricultural chemicals, lubricating oil additives or other petroleum derivatives. 
(47)  Pass through: A discharge which exits the POTW into waters of the United States in quantities or concentrations which, alone or in conjunction with a discharge or discharges from other sources, is a cause of a violation of any requirement of the POTW's NPDES permit, including an increase in the magnitude or duration of a violation. 
(48)  pH: The logarithm (base 10) of the reciprocal of the concentration of hydrogen ions expressed in gram equivalents per liter of solution on a scale of 0 to 14, with 7 being neutral. 
(49)  Pollutant: Any dredged spoil, solid waste incinerator residue, sewage, garbage, sewage sludge, munitions, chemical wastes, oils, biological materials, radioactive materials, heat, wrecked or discharged equipment, rock, sand, cellar dirt, including industrial, municipal, and agricultural waste discharged into the water. 
(50)  Pollution: The introduction of pollutant(s) that can or does result in the degradation or impairment of the chemical, physical, biological or radiological integrity of the water. 
(51)  POTW: Publicly owned treatment works as defined by Section 212 of the Clean Water Act. The term includes any devices and systems used by or for the city in the storage, treatment, recycling or reclamation of municipal sewage or industrial wastes of a liquid nature. It also includes sewers, pipes and other conveyances if they convey wastewater to the POTW treatment plant. 
(52)  POTW treatment plant: That portion of POTW designed to provide treatment to wastewater. 
(52.5)  Practical quantitation level: As defined by the MDEQ's Mich. Admin. Code, R 325.10107(f), is the lowest concentration that can be reliably achieved by well-operated laboratories within specified limits of precision and accuracy during routine laboratory operating conditions. 
(53)  Pretreatment: The reduction of the amount of pollutants, the elimination of pollutants, or the alteration of the nature of pollutants. 
(54)  Pretreatment requirements: Any substantive or procedural requirements related to pretreatment, other than a national pretreatment standard imposed on a user. 
(55)  Pretreatment standards: Includes all national categorical pretreatment standards, the general and specific prohibitions specified in 40 CFR 403.5, all state standards and the prohibitions or limits specified in this article. 
(56)  Public sanitary sewer lead: That part of a sanitary system which receives sanitary waste from the building sewer at the public right-of-way or easement and conveys it to the public sanitary sewer. 
(57)  Public sewer: A sewer of any type controlled by a government entity. 
(58)  Replacement: The replacement in whole or in part of any equipment, appurtenances and accessories in the wastewater transportation or treatment systems to insure continuous treatment of wastewater in accordance with the NPDES permit and other applicable state and federal regulations. 
(59)  Sanitary sewer: A pipe or system of pipes that convey wastewater from residences, commercial buildings, industrial plants, institutions or other structures as a part of the wastewater collection system. 
(60)  Severe property damage: Substantial physical damage to property, damage to the treatment facilities which causes them to become inoperable, or substantial and permanent loss of natural resources which cannot reasonably be expected to occur in the absence of a bypass. Severe property damage does not mean economic loss caused by delays in production. 
(61)  Sewage or wastewater: Is a combination of the water-carried wastes from residences, business buildings, institutions and industrial establishments, together with such ground, surface and stormwaters as may be present. 
(62)  Significant change: Any change in the discharger's effluent which either causes the flow or concentration of the discharge to change by twenty (20) percent or more over those reported on the discharger's permit application or periodic compliance report, including the addition of any new wastewater constituent or new wastestreams. 
(63)  Significant industrial user: Any industrial user of the POTW who (1) is subject to the Categorical Pretreatment Standards under 40 CFR Ch. I, Subch. N; (2) discharges an average of twenty-five thousand (25,000) gallons per day or more of process wastewater to the POTW (excluding sanitary, noncontact cooling and boiler blowdown wastewater) or contributes a process wastestream which makes up five (5) percent or more of the average dry weather hydraulic or organic capacity of the POTW treatment plant; or (3) is designated as such by the Control Authority as defined by 40 CFR 403.12(a) on the basis that the industrial user has a reasonable potential for adversely affecting the POTW's operation or for violating any pretreatment standard or requirement. 
(64)  Sludge: The accumulated solids separated from liquids during the treatment of wastewaters. 
(65)  Slug load: Any discharge of a non-routine, episodic nature, including but not limited to an accidental spill or non- customary batch discharge. 
(66)  Standard Industrial Classification (SIC): A classification pursuant to the standard industrial classification manual issued by the executive office of management and budget. 
(67)  Storm sewer: A sewer which carries storm and surface water and drainage, but excludes sewage and industrial wastes other than NPDES permitted discharges. 
(68)  Storm water: Includes storm water runoff, snow melt runoff, surface runoff and drainage. 
(69)  Sump pump: A device approved by the superintendent of the wastewater treatment plant that is designed to receive, lift, and discharge flow from the building storm drain to a point outside the basement walls of the building. 
(70)  Superintendent: The superintendent of the wastewater treatment plant or his designated representative. 
(71)  Surcharge: A charge assessed against the user to cover the costs of investigating, pumping or treating discharges in violation of this article, or to cover the added costs of treating discharges which contain compatible pollutants in excess of the amount set forth in section 41-161. 
(72)  Suspended solids: The total suspended matter that floats on the surface of, or is suspended in, water, wastewater or other liquids, and which is removable by laboratory filtering. 
(73)  Trade secret: The whole or any portion or phase of any secret manufacturing proprietary process or method not patented, which is useful in compounding an article of trade having a commercial value, and the secrecy of which the owner has taken reasonable measure to prevent from becoming available to persons other than those selected by the owner to have access for limited purposes. "Trade secret" shall not be construed, for purposes of these regulations, to include any information regarding the quantum or character of waste products or their constituents discharged or sought to be discharged into the treatment plant, the wastewater system tributary thereto, or the waters of the state. 
(74)  Toxic pollutant: Any pollutant or combination of pollutants listed as toxic in regulations promulgated by the Administrator of the EPA under the provisions of the Clean Water Act, Section 307(a), or other acts, or included in the Critical Materials Register promulgated by the Michigan Department of Natural Resources or other acts. 
(75)  Upset: An exceptional incident in which there is unintentional and temporary noncompliance with the effluent limits applicable to the user because of factors beyond the reasonable control of the user. An upset does not include noncompliance to the extent caused by operational error, improperly designed treatment facilities, inadequate treatment facilities, lack of preventive maintenance, or careless or improper operation. 
(76)  User: A user as defined in this article may be either: 
a.  Sanitary sewer user: Any person who contributes, causes or permits the contribution of wastewater into the POTW; 
b.  Storm sewer user: Any person who contributes, causes or permits discharge to the storm sewer system either indirectly over the surface, or through an internal drainage system connected to the public storm sewer system. 
(77)  Wastewater: The liquid and water-carried industrial or domestic wastes from dwellings, commercial buildings, industrial facilities and institutions, together with any incidental infiltration and inflow that may be present, whether treated or untreated, which is contributed to or permitted to enter the POTW. 
(78)  Wastewater treatment plant: The City of Warren Sewage Treatment Plant located at 32360 Warkop, Warren, Michigan. 
(79)  Watercourse: A channel in which a flow of water occurs, either continuously or intermittently. 
(80)  Waters of the state: All streams, lakes, ponds, marshes, watercourses, waterways, wells, springs, reservoirs, aquifers, irrigation systems, drainage systems and all other bodies or accumulations of water, surface or underground, natural or artificial, public or private, which are contained within, flow through, or border upon the state or any portion thereof. 
(Ord. No. 80-417, § 1, 9-8-92; Ord. No. 80-497, § 2, 7-9-96; Ord. No. 80-597, §§ 1, 2, 7-22-03; Ord. No. 80-744, § 1, 6-14-16)  
Sec. 41-58. - Abbreviations. 
The following abbreviations shall have the designated meanings: 
BMP—Best Management Practice 
BOD—Biochemical Oxygen Demand 
CFR—Code of Federal Regulations 
COD—Chemical Oxygen Demand 
CWA—Clean Water Act 
EPA—Environmental Protection Agency 
FOG—Fats, Oils or Grease 
L—Liter 
mg—Milligrams 
mg/l—Milligrams per liter 
MDNR—Michigan Department of Natural Resources 
NPDES—National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System 
O&M—Operation and Maintenance 
POTW—Publicly Owned Treatment Works 
PQL—Practical Quantitation Level 
RCRA—Resource Conservation and Recovery Act 
SAL—Specific Alternative Limit 
SIC—Standard Industrial Classification 
SIU—Significant Industrial User 
SWDA—Solid Waste Disposal Act, 42 U.S.C. 6901, et seq. 
T.P.—Total Phosphorus 
TSS—Total Suspended Solids 
USC—United States Code 
(Ord. No. 80-417, § 1, 9-8-92; Ord. No. 80-744, § 2, 6-14-16)  
DIVISION 2. - SEWER USE 
 
Sec. 41-59. - Regulation. 
The rules and regulations established in or pursuant to this chapter are established for the preservation of the public health, safety and welfare, to prevent pollution of the environment, and to fulfill the obligations of the city with respect to all state and federal laws and all rules and regulations adopted in conformance thereto. The discharge into the system of any substance which exceeds the limitations contained herein, or in any manner fails to conform to the provisions of this chapter, is hereby declared to be a public nuisance and a violation of the code, subject to enforcement action. 
(Ord. No. 80-417, § 1, 9-8-92)  
Sec. 41-60. - Illicit discharges. 
(a)  Sanitary sewers. Illicit discharges to any sanitary sewer include the prohibited discharges specified in section 41-74 of this article. Compliance with a permit shall not relieve the user of any liability relating to or from this discharge. 
(b)  Storm sewers. Illicit discharges to any storm sewer include any discharge that is not composed entirely of storm water, except discharges pursuant to a NPDES permit, discharges resulting from firefighting activities and the following uncontaminated discharges: water line flushing, landscape irrigation run off, diverted stream flows, rising ground water, pumped ground water, discharges from potable water sources, foundation drains, air conditioning condensation, irrigation water, springs, water from crawl space pumps, footing drains, lawn watering, non-commercial car washing, flows from riparian habitats and wetlands, residential swimming pool discharges and other dechlorinated swimming pool discharges and street wash water. compliance with a permit shall not relieve the user of any liability relating to or from this discharge. 
(Ord. No. 80-417, § 1, 9-8-92; Ord. No. 80-497, § 3, 7-9-96)  
Sec. 41-61. - Use of public sewers required. 
(a)  The owner of any house, building or property used for human occupancy, employment, recreation or similar purpose which is located in the city and has a public sanitary sewer lead located within two hundred (200) feet of the property line, is hereby required, at the owner's expense, to install suitable toilet facilities, and to connect those facilities directly to the proper public sanitary sewer in accordance with the provisions of this article within ninety (90) days of official notice to connect. Every single house or structure shall have a separate connection with the sewer main unless an exception is approved by the director of public service. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to construct any privy, privy vault, septic tank, cesspool, or other facility intended or used for the disposal of sewage without the approval of the director of public service. 
(Ord. No. 80-417, § 1, 9-8-92)  
Sec. 41-62. - Use of publicly owned treatment system. 
Any person who complies with the standards, rules and regulations established in or pursuant to this chapter, shall be permitted to discharge into the POTW system provided there exists adequate sewer service available for connection. 
(Ord. No. 80-417, § 1, 9-8-92)  
Sec. 41-63. - Sewer connection permit. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to make any sewer connection, sanitary or storm, without first having obtained a sewer connection permit. 
(b)  Application for a sewer connection permit shall be made to the division of buildings and safety engineering. The sewer connection permit fee shall be collected in accordance with the charges set forth in the Plumbing Code found at Chapter 9, Article IV. 
(Ord. No. 80-417, § 1, 9-8-92)  
Sec. 41-64. - Sewer connection inspections. 
All connections to any city sewer shall be inspected by the division of engineering. Such connections shall only be made after procurement of an engineering inspection permit from the division of engineering. 
The division of engineering shall inspect all sewer connections and related work which takes place in the city right-of-way. The division of engineering shall also inspect the complete installation of any sanitary sewer lead which will serve two or more residences, any sewer which is larger than six (6) inches in diameter, or any sewer which is required to have an Michigan Department of Natural Resources permit pursuant to ACT 98 P.A. 1913, as amended. 
(Ord. No. 80-417, § 1, 9-8-92)  
Sec. 41-65. - Illegal sewer connections. 
It is prohibited to have any residential, commercial or industrial downspout leading to any sanitary sewer or to have any sanitary sewer line leading to any storm sewer. Any person who owns or possesses a building or structure which is in violation of this provision shall comply, forthwith, at the owner's expense. 
(Ord. No. 80-417, § 1, 9-8-92; Ord. No. 80-497, § 4, 7-9-96)  
Sec. 41-66. - Trucked and hauled waste. 
Trucked and hauled waste shall not be discharged to the POTW except at discharge points designated by the POTW. 
(Ord. No. 80-497, § 4, 7-9-96) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 80-497, § 4, adopted July 9, 1996, deleted former § 14-66, relative to discharges to the storm sewer, and renumbered former § 14-67 as § 14-66. The provisions of former § 14-66 derived from Ord. No. 80-417, § 1, adopted Sept. 8, 1992. Provisions regarding discharge into storm sewers are currently set out under § 41-140 et seq.  
Secs. 41-67—41-70. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - INDUSTRIAL PRETREATMENT PROGRAM 
Part I. 
Regulations 
The purpose of this division is (a) the protection of the public health and safety; (b) the protection of the POTW and personnel; (c) the abatement and prevention of pollution; and (d) the POTW compliance with state and federal regulations. This purpose is accomplished through the regulation and control of the quantity and quality of wastes admitted to or discharged into the wastewater collection and treatment system under the jurisdiction of the city. 
(Ord. No. 80-417, § 1, 9-8-92) 
 
Sec. 41-71. - Pretreatment required. 
All users shall provide necessary wastewater treatment as required to comply with this ordinance and shall achieve compliance with all Federal Categorical Pretreatment Standards within the time limitations as specified by the Federal Pretreatment Regulations. Any facilities required to pretreat wastewater to a level acceptable to the city shall be provided, operated and maintained at the user's expense. Detailed plans showing the pretreatment facilities and operating procedures shall be submitted to the superintendent for review. No construction is to commence until the plans have received approval of the superintendent. The review of such plans and operating procedures in no way relieves the user from the responsibility of modifying the facility as necessary to produce an effluent acceptable to the city under the provisions of this chapter. Any subsequent changes in the pretreatment facilities or method of operation shall be reported to the city prior to the user's initiation of the changes. 
(Ord. No. 80-417, § 1, 9-8-92)  
Sec. 41-72. - National categorical and state pretreatment standards. 
(a)  The national categorical pretreatment standards defined in 40 CFR, Chapter I Subpart N, Parts 405-471, are hereby incorporated into this article and made a part hereof. A list of federal categories is included following this section. 
(b)  State or local discharge limits shall apply in any case where they are more stringent than federal requirements. 
(c)  When the limits of a federal categorical pretreatment standard are expressed only in terms of mass pollutant per unit of production, an equivalent mass per day or concentration based limit may be substituted as the superintendent deems appropriate for individual industrial user.

(Ord. No. 80-417, § 1, 9-8-92; Ord. No. 80-527, § 28, 1-13-98)  
Sec. 41-73. - Existing source and new source compliance. 
(a)  Existing sources: Compliance with categorical pretreatment standards by existing sources shall be achieved within three (3) years of the date the standard is effective unless a shorter compliance time is specified in the appropriate subpart of 40 CFR chapter I, subchapter N. Existing sources which become industrial users subject to promulgation of an applicable categorical pretreatment standard shall be considered existing industrial users except where such sources meet the definition of "new source," 40 CFR 403.3(k). 
(b)  New sources: Prior to discharging, all "new sources" as defined in Section 403.3(k) shall install, have in operating condition and start up all pollution control equipment required to meet applicable pretreatment standards. Within ninety (90) days all "new sources" must comply with all applicable pretreatment standards. 
(Ord. No. 80-417, § 1, 9-8-92)  
Sec. 41-74. - Prohibited contributions. 
No user shall contribute or cause to be contributed to the POTW, directly or indirectly, any pollutant or wastewater which will cause interference or pass-through. In addition, it shall be unlawful for users to discharge any of the substances listed below. These discharge prohibitions apply whether or not the user is subject to the national categorical pretreatment standards or any other national, state or local pretreatment standards or requirements. A user shall not contribute any of the following substances to the POTW: 
(1)  Any liquids, solids or gases which by reason of their nature or quantity are, or may be, sufficient either alone or by interaction with other substances to cause fire or explosion or be injurious in any other way to the POTW or to the operation of the POTW including but not limited to wastestreams with a closed cup flashpoint of less than one hundred forty (140) degrees Fahrenheit or sixty (60) degrees Celsius using the test methods specified in 40 CFR 261.21. Examples of these materials are, but are not limited to, gasoline, kerosene, naphtha, benzene, toluene, xylene, ethers, alcohols, ketones, aldehydes, peroxides, chlorates, perchlorates, bromates, carbides, hydrides and sulfides; 
(2)  Solid or viscous substances or inert suspended solids which may cause obstruction to the flow in a sewer or other interference with the operation of the wastewater treatment facilities such as, but not limited to: grease, garbage with particles greater than one-half inch in any dimension, animal guts or tissues, paunch manure, bones, hair, hides or fleshings, entrails, whole blood, feathers, ashes, cinders, sand, spent lime, lime slurries and lime residues, stone or marble dust, metal, glass, straw shavings, grass clippings, rags, spent grains, spent hops, wastepaper, wood, plastics, gas, tar, asphalt residues, residues from refining, or processing of fuel or lubricating oil, mud, or glass grinding or polishing wastes, Fullers earth, or dissolved solids such as sodium chloride and sodium sulfate in unusual concentrations; 
(3)  Any wastewater having a pH less than 6.5 or greater than 10.5, or wastewater having any other corrosive property capable of causing damage or hazard to structures, equipment, or personnel of the POTW; 
(4)  Any wastewater containing toxic pollutants in sufficient quantity, either singly or by interaction with other pollutants, to injure or interfere with any wastewater treatment process, constitute a hazard to humans or animals, create a toxic effect in the receiving waters of the POTW, or exceed the limitation set forth in a categorical pretreatment standard; 
(5)  Any discharge resulting in toxic gases, vapors or fumes within the POTW in a quantity that may cause acute worker health and safety problems; 
(6)  Petroleum oil, nonbiodegradable cutting oil, or products of mineral oil origin in amounts that will cause interference or pass through; 
(7)  Any noxious or malodorous liquids, gases, or solids which either singly or by interaction with other wastes are sufficient to create a public nuisance or hazard to life or are sufficient to prevent entry into the sewers for maintenance and repair; 
(8)  Any substance which may cause the POTW's effluent or any other product of the POTW such as ash residues, sludges, or scums, to be unsuitable for reclamation and reuse or to interfere with the reclamation process; 
(9)  Any substance which will cause the POTW to violate its NPDES permit, the receiving water quality standards, or the national air quality emissions standards; 
(10)  Any wastewater with objectionable color not removed in the treatment process, such as, but not limited to, dye wastes and vegetable tanning solutions; 
(11)  Any wastewater having a temperature which will inhibit biological activity in the POTW treatment plant resulting in interference (one hundred four (104) degrees Fahrenheit at the influent) but in no case wastewater with a temperature which exceeds sixty-six (66) degrees Celsius (one hundred fifty (150) degrees Fahrenheit) 
(12)  Any pollutants, (including oxygen demanding pollutants (BOD, etc.) released at a flow rate and/or pollutant concentration which will cause interference to the POTW; 
(13)  Any wastewater containing any radioactive wastes or isotopes of such half-life or concentration as may exceed applicable pretreatment standards; 
(14)  Any unpolluted water including, but not limited to, noncontact cooling water; 
(15)  Any discharge from roof downspouts, surface drains or other sources of surface runoff or groundwater to a building sewer or building drain which in turn is connected directly or indirectly to a public sanitary sewer. 
(Ord. No. 80-417, § 1, 9-8-92; Ord. No. 80-641, § 1, 11-14-06)  
Sec. 41-75. - Local discharge limits. 
(a)  Effluent limits. Unless, a written authorization from the city is obtained pursuant to subsection (e) of this section, an industrial user shall not discharge wastewater that exceeds the following concentrations: 
Arsenic 	0.33 mg/l 
Beryllium 	0.005 mg/l 
Cadmium 	0.29 mg/l 
Chromium (Total) 	7.0 mg/l 
Copper 	4.5 mg/l 
Lead 	0.6 mg/l 
Lithium 	0.83 mg/l 
Mercury 	See subsection (b) 
of this section 
Nickel 	4.1 mg/l 
Selenium 	0.21 mg/l 
Silver 	0.82 mg/l 
Thallium 	0.54 mg/l 
Zinc 	4.2 mg/l 
BOD (Biological Oxygen Demand) 	2100.0 mg/l 
TSS (Total Suspended Solids) 	1450.0 mg/l 
Phosphorus 	75.0 mg/l 
Ammonia-N or Total K Kjeldahl (TKN)* 	200.0 mg/l 
 
* If significant organic nitrogen is or may be present, Ammonia-N may be expressed as Total Kjeldahl Nitrogen (TKN). 
(b)  Mercury limits. Any mercury discharge at detectable levels is a violation of this article. The mercury discharge level is calculated by EPA Method 245.1 or an EPA-approved equivalent. The PQL shall be no higher than 0.0002 mg/l, unless a higher quantification level is appropriate because of demonstrated sample matrix interference. 
(c)  Effluent limits in grab sample. Unless, a written authorization from the city is obtained pursuant to subsection (e) of this section, an industrial user shall not discharge wastewater that exceeds the following concentrations in any grab sample: 
Chromium (Hexavalent) 	0.5 mg/l 
Cyanide (Available) 	0.5 mg/l 
Cyanide (Total) 	1.3 mg/l 
Total Phenolics 	0.67 mg/l 
Petroleum Based Fats, Oil and Grease 	150.0 mg/l 
Total Fats, Oil and Grease 	900.0 [mg]/l 
 
(d)  New limits. If the superintendent determines that an industrial user is contributing or proposes to contribute any substances to the POTW in a quality, quantity, or location that the superintendent determines is reasonably likely to adversely affect the POTW or the receiving stream, the superintendent may develop and enforce effluent limits that are specifically applicable to that substance, industrial user, or both. 
(e)  Specific alternative limit permits. 
(1)  Authority to grant. Subject to the requirements and restrictions listed in this subsection (e), the superintendent, at his sole discretion, may grant a specific alternative limit (SAL) or multiple specific alternative limits to an industrial user in an industrial pretreatment permit that allows discharges to the POTW that are different than the effluent limits listed in (a) and (c) of this section (SAL permit). 
(2)  Constituent. The superintendent shall only grant SAL permits for BOD, TSS, Phosphorus, and Ammonia-N/ Total K Kjeldahl (TKN) 
(3)  Maximum allowable headworks and industrial loadings. In determining a SAL, the superintendent may allocate a share of the maximum allowable headworks loading and maximum allowable industrial loading for BOD, TSS, Phosphorus, and Ammonia-N among one or more industrial users in amounts and on terms and conditions the superintendent deems appropriate and are in accordance with SAL procedures approved by the MDEQ. 
a.  The POTW plant headworks loadings shall not exceed the following levels: 
BOD (Biological Oxygen Demand) 	48,000 lb/day 
TSS (Total Suspended Solids) 	43,500 lb/day 
Phosphorus 	1,030 lb/day 
Ammonia-N 	4,500 lb/day 
 
b.  The POTW plant industrial loadings shall not exceed the following levels: 
BOD (Biological Oxygen Demand) 	27,500 lb/day 
TSS (Total Suspended Solids) 	18,350 lb/day 
Phosphorus 	402 lb/day 
Ammonia-N 	1,510 lb/day 
 
(4)  Fundamentally different factor variance. The superintendent shall not grant a SAL that is less stringent than the effluent limits listed in (a) and (c) of this section, unless the industrial user qualifies for a fundamentally different factor variance that allows the user to exceed the applicable effluent limits. If the superintendent grants a variance, the SAL shall not exceed the limits provided in the variance. 
(5)  Acknowledgement and acceptance. Before the superintendent grants a SAL permit, the industrial user shall sign an acknowledgement and acceptance of both the provisions of this subsection (e) and the specific SAL permit conditions or provisions. 
(6)  Additional conditions or provisions. The superintendent may include in a SAL permit any conditions or provisions that comply with this article and any other applicable city, state, or federal laws or regulations. 
(7)  Compensatory charge. The superintendent may include in a SAL permit a provision requiring that the industrial user pay a compensatory charge to the city. 
(8)  No additional rights created. The SAL permit does not create any rights or future expectations beyond the limited scope of the express language of the SAL permit. 
(9)  Termination or modification. At any time after granting the SAL permit, the superintendent may terminate or modify it without the industrial user's consent. 
(10)  Violation. Any violation of a SAL permit provision is a violation of this article. 
(Ord. No. 80-417, § 1, 9-8-92; Ord. No. 80-640, § 1, 11-14-06; Ord. No. 80-744, § 3, 6-14-16)  
Sec. 41-76. - Dilution of wastewater. 
No user shall ever increase the use of process water or in any way attempt to dilute a discharge as a partial or complete substitute for adequate treatment to achieve compliance with the national categorical pretreatment standards or any other pollutant specific standard developed by the city or state. 
(Ord. No. 80-417, § 1, 9-8-92)  
Sec. 41-77. - Grease, oil and sand interceptors. 
Grease, oil and sand interceptors shall be provided when they are necessary for the proper handling of liquid wastes containing grease in excessive amounts, or any flammable wastes, sand or other harmful ingredients. All interceptors shall be of a type and capacity approved by the superintendent and shall be located so as to be readily and easily accessible for cleaning and inspection. All interceptors shall be maintained and cleaned regularly to prevent grease, oil or sand from entering the public sewer system. 
(Ord. No. 80-417, § 1, 9-8-92)  
Sec. 41-78. - Spill containment requirements. 
Every nondomestic user that uses or stores liquid material or chemicals at its facility, shall provide a storage or containment area that is capable of containing the liquid material in the event of an accident. The containment area shall comply with the following requirements: 
(1)  All liquid polluting material, except salt, shall be diked, curbed or otherwise structurally enclosed so as to contain not less than one hundred fifty (150) percent of the liquid polluting material stored or used unless a lesser containment area or alternative control measures are approved by the superintendent.
