The area shall be so constructed that no liquid polluting material can escape therefrom by gravity through the building sewers, drains, or otherwise directly or indirectly into any sewer system, surface or ground waters of this state unless approved by the superintendent. 
(2)  The storage tank and/or diked area shall be maintained not more than twenty (20) percent full at all times and ready for accidental spillage or breakage of the solution thereto. 
(3)  There shall be no connections between harmful concentrated chemical solutions and the sewer systems or surface drainage systems if a simple mechanical or human failure would result in a prohibited contamination. 
(4)  Detailed plans showing facilities and operating procedures to provide this protection shall be submitted to the city for review. No construction is to be commenced until the plans have been reviewed by the city. 
(Ord. No. 80-417, § 1, 9-8-92) 
Part II. Reporting Requirements  
Sec. 41-79. - Notice of discharge change. 
All users shall promptly notify the superintendent, in advance, of any significant change in the volume or character of the pollutants in their discharge. 
(Ord. No. 80-417, § 1, 9-8-92)  
Sec. 41-80. - Notice of slug load and problem discharges. 
(a)  In the event of a discharge that is reasonably likely to adversely affect the POTW, including, but not limited to, a slug load, the industrial user shall immediately notify the POTW contact person by telephone of the discharge and potential problem. The industrial user shall comply with all notice and reporting requirements set forth in section 41-81 for operating upsets. 
(b)  On request of the superintendent, the industrial user shall submit a slug load discharge control plan as defined by 40 CFR 403.8(f)(2)(vi). 
(c)  An industrial user shall immediately notify the POTW of any changes at its facility that may affect the potential for a slug load discharge. 
(Ord. No. 80-417, § 1, 9-8-92; Ord. No. 80-744, § 4, 6-14-16)  
Sec. 41-81. - Operating upsets. 
(a)  Immediate notice. In the case of an operating upset, the industrial user shall immediately notify the POTW contact person by telephone of the incident. The notification shall include all of the following: the location of the discharge, type of waste, concentration level, volume, and corrective action taken. 
(b)  Five-day report. Within five (5) days after an operating upset, the industrial user shall submit to the superintendent a detailed written report describing all of the following: the cause of the discharge, the duration of noncompliance, including exact dates and times, the measures taken in response to the discharge, the impact of the discharge on the user's compliance status, and the measures to be taken by the user to prevent any future recurrence. 
(c)  Employee notice . An industrial user shall notify all appropriate employees of the required operating upset notification procedures. Additionally, in a prominent place at the industrial facility, the industrial user shall permanently post the name and telephone number of the contact person at the POTW in case of an operating upset or other problematic discharge. 
(Ord. No. 80-417, § 1, 9-8-92; Ord. No. 80-744, § 5, 6-14-16)  
Sec. 41-82. - Residual records. 
When required by the city, the user shall submit a record of all residuals generated, stored and hauled including copies of manifests where the material hauled is a hazardous waste. 
(Ord. No. 80-417, § 1, 9-8-92)  
Sec. 41-83. - Discharge information required. 
Any nondomestic user discharging water to the sewer or other watercourse, including industrial waste discharged to the sanitary sewer, shall upon request, submit to the superintendent of the wastewater treatment plant, the following information in units and terms appropriate for evaluation: 
(1)  Name, address and location of building. 
(2)  SIC number according to the most recent revision of the Standard Industrial Classification Manual, Bureau of the Budget. 
(3)  Wastewater constituents and characteristics including but not limited to those mentioned in section 41-75 as determined by a reliable analytical laboratory; sampling and analysis shall be performed in accordance with the procedures and methods detailed in 40 CFR part 136 and the amendments thereto. 
(4)  Time and duration of contribution. 
(5)  Average daily wastewater flow rates, including daily, monthly and seasonal variations, if any. 
(6)  Description of activities, facilities and plant processes on the premises including all materials which are or could be discharged. 
(7)  The nature and concentration of any pollutants in the discharge which are limited by any applicable pretreatment requirement, and a statement regarding whether or not the pretreatment requirements are being met on a consistent basis and if not, whether additional operation and maintenance and/or additional pretreatment is required by the user to meet applicable pretreatment requirements. 
(8)  If additional pretreatment and/or operation and maintenance are necessary to meet the pretreatment requirements, a schedule by which the user will provide for such additional pretreatment shall be submitted. The completion date in this schedule shall not be later than the compliance date established for the applicable pretreatment requirement. The following conditions shall apply to this schedule: 
(i)  The schedule shall contain increments of progress in the form of dates for the commencement and completion of major events leading to the construction and operation of additional pretreatment required for the user to meet the applicable pretreatment standards. 
(ii)  No increment referred to in subsection (a)(9)a. shall exceed nine (9) months. 
(iii)  Not later than fourteen (14) days following each date in the schedule and the final date for compliance, the user shall submit a progress report to the superintendent including, as a minimum whether or not it complied with the increment of progress to be met on such date and, if not, the date on which it expects to comply with this increment of progress, the reason for delay, and the steps being taken by the user to return the construction to the schedule established. In no event shall more than nine (9) months elapse between such progress reports to the superintendent. 
(9)  Each product produced by type, amount, process or processes and rate of production. 
(10)  Type and amount of raw materials processed and chemicals used, average and maximum per day. 
(11)  Number and type of employees, hours of operation of plant and proposed or actual hours of operation of pretreatment system. 
(12)  Any other information as may be deemed by the city to be necessary to evaluate the impact of the discharge on the POTW and the need for pretreatment. 
(13)  The disclosure form shall be signed by the authorized representative of the user and a qualified engineer. The city will evaluate the complete disclosure form and data furnished and may require additional information. Within ninety (90) days after full evaluation and acceptance of the data furnished, the city shall notify the user of the acceptance thereof. 
(Ord. No. 80-417, § 1, 9-8-92)  
Sec. 41-84. - Facility and pretreatment information. 
Upon request of the superintendent, the user shall submit the following information: 
(a)  Site plans, floor plans, mechanical and plumbing plans detailed to show all sewers, sewer connections and appurtenances by the size, location, and elevation. 
(b)  Detailed plans showing the pretreatment facilities and operating procedures. The city will review such plans and respond with approval or suggested modifications to the user within ninety (90) days following plan submittal. The review of such plans and operating procedures will in no way relieve the user from the responsibility of modifying the facility as necessary to produce an effluent acceptable to the city under the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 80-417, § 1, 9-8-92)  
Sec. 41-85. - Certification. 
All industrial user reports, including but not limited to: categorical pretreatment baseline reports, periodic compliance reports, categorical pretreatment deadline reports, and categorical process statements, shall include a certification statement as set forth below and signed by the authorized representative of the industrial user: 
I certify under penalty of law that this document and all attachments were prepared under my direction or supervision in accordance with a system designed to assure that qualified personnel properly gather and evaluate the information submitted. Based on my inquiry of the persons who manage the system, or those persons directly responsible for gathering the information, the information submitted is, to the best of my knowledge and belief, true, accurate and complete. I am aware that there are significant penalties for submitting false information, including the possibility of fine and imprisonment for known violations. 
(Ord. No. 80-417, § 1, 9-8-92)  
Sec. 41-86. - Confidential information. 
(a)  Information and data regarding a user obtained from reports, questionnaires, permit applications, permits, monitoring programs and from inspections shall be available to the public or other governmental agency without restriction unless the user specifically requests and is able to demonstrate to the satisfaction of the superintendent that the release of such information would divulge information, processes or methods of production entitled to protection as trade secrets of the user. 
(b)  When requested by the person furnishing a report, the portion of a report that might disclose trade secrets or secret processes shall not be made available for inspection by the public but shall be made available upon written request to governmental agencies for uses that are either related to this article, the NPDES permit, or the pretreatment program; provided, that the information shall be treated as confidential by the government agency, until such time as the information has been determined to be nonconfidential by the government agency. 
(c)  Information accepted by the city as confidential shall not be transmitted to any governmental agency or to the general public by the city until and unless a ten-day notification is given to the user. 
(d)  In accordance with 40 CFR 403.14(b) all effluent data shall be available to the public without restriction. 
(Ord. No. 80-417, § 1, 9-8-92)  
Sec. 41-87. - Records retention. 
(a)  Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, an industrial user shall retain, for a period of three (3) years, all records including books, documents, memoranda, reports, correspondence, and any summaries relating to monitoring, sampling, and chemical analysis, including BMP documentation made by or on behalf of a user in connection with its discharge. 
(b)  An industrial user shall retain all records that pertain to matters that are the subject of enforcement action, litigation, or administrative adjustment until all enforcement activities, periods of limitation, and appeals periods have expired. On request, an industrial user shall provide all such records to representatives of the EPA, state, or POTW for inspection and copying purposes. 
(Ord. No. 80-417, § 1, 9-8-92; Ord. No. 80-744, § 6, 6-14-16)  
Sec. 41-88. - Falsifying information. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly make any false statement, representation, or certification in any application, record, report, plan or other document filed or required to be maintained under this article or in any permit, or to falsify, tamper with, or knowingly render inaccurate any monitoring device or method required under this article. 
(Ord. No. 80-417, § 1, 9-8-92)  
Sec. 41-89. - Notification of hazardous waste discharge. 
(a)  All users shall, pursuant to 40 CFR 403.12(p), provide a one time notification for each listed or characteristic hazardous waste under 40 CFR part 261 discharged to the POTW. If a pollutant is already being reported to the POTW as part of a periodic compliance report, the pollutant is not subject to this reporting requirement. Further, users who discharge no more than fifteen (15) kilograms (kg) of hazardous wastes during a calendar month are exempt from the notification requirements set forth herein unless the wastes are acute hazardous wastes as specified in 40 CFR 261.30(d) and 40 CFR 261.33(e). The written notification shall include the following information: 
(1)  The name of the hazardous waste(s), the hazardous waste number as identified in 40 CFR 261 and the type of discharge. 
(2)  Certification that a program is in place to reduce the volume and toxicity of the wastes generated to the degree economically practicable. 
(3)  All users who discharge more than one hundred (100) kilograms (kg) of hazardous waste in a calendar month, shall also submit the following additional information: 
(i)  An estimation of the mass and concentration of hazardous waste constituents in the wastestream discharged during that calendar month. 
(ii)  An estimation of the mass of constituents in the wastestream expected to be discharged during the following twelve (12) months. 
(b)  In the event that a substantial change in volume or character of a user's discharge occurs, the user is required to provide further notification in accordance with the requirements set forth in 40 CIR 403.12(p). 
(c)  In the event new regulations are adopted under 40 CIR sections 260—261 which identify additional characteristics of hazardous waste or lists additional substances as a hazardous waste, all users discharging such substance shall comply with the notification requirements of this section within ninety (90) days of the effective date of the regulations. 
(d)  Notification as required in this section shall be provided in writing to the following hazardous waste authorities: 
Director, Waste Management Division 
U.S. Environmental Protection Agency- 
Region 5 
230 South Dearborn Street 
Chicago, Illinois 60604 
Chief, Technical Services Section 
Waste Management Division 
Division of Natural Resources 
Box 30028 
Lansing, Michigan 48909 
Director, Industrial Pretreatment Program 
Warren Wastewater Treatment Plant 
32360 Warkop Avenue 
Warren, Michigan 48093 
(Ord. No. 80-417, § 1, 9-8-92)  
Secs. 41-90—41-92. - Reserved. 
Part III. 
Monitoring and Inspection  
Sec. 41-93. - Authority of inspectors. 
Authorized representatives of the city shall be permitted ready access at all reasonable times to enter any user's premises for purposes of inspection, observation, measurement, documentation, records examination and copying, sampling and testing in connection with the performance of their duties and the administration of this article. Where a user has security measures in force that require proper identification and clearance before entry onto the premises, the user shall make necessary arrangements with security personnel so that upon presentation of proper identification, personnel from the city, state department of natural resources and EPA will be permitted to enter without delay. 
(Ord. No. 80-417, § 1, 9-8-92)  
Sec. 41-94. - Non-routine inspections. 
Under circumstances where an inspection of a nondomestic facility is necessary to investigate a problem discharge, authorized representatives of the city shall be permitted ready access to enter any user's premises for purposes of inspection, observation, measurement, sampling and testing. 
(Ord. No. 80-417, § 1, 9-8-92)  
Sec. 41-95. - Safety rules of user. 
While on the property of the user, the inspectors shall observe all safety rules applicable to the premises established by the company. 
(Ord. No. 80-417, § 1, 9-8-92)  
Sec. 41-96. - Other inspections. 
Inspections performed by state or federal representatives shall not relieve a user from inspection by city representatives and inspection by the city shall not relieve any user from compliance with lawful inspection by state and federal representatives. 
(Ord. No. 80-417, § 1, 9-8-92)  
Sec. 41-97. - Monitoring equipment; removal of samples and data. 
The city, through its authorized representatives shall have the right to set up monitoring equipment on the user's premises as needed for sampling and flow measurement, to take and remove samples of wastewater and pollutants from the user's discharge, and to make copies of other data and material inspected during an entry upon the user's property. If the city requests that the user make photocopies of documents, the city shall give the user at least twenty-four (24) hours notice to comply with such request, however, this notice requirement does not affect the right of the city during an inspection to immediately copy data or other materials. Upon the written request of the user, split samples will be provided. 
(Ord. No. 80-417, § 1, 9-8-92)  
Sec. 41-98. - Access refused. 
It shall be a violation of this article for any user to refuse an authorized representative of the city access to its premises; or to refuse to allow the representative to obtain, take, or remove samples; or to refuse access to records pertinent to this article. 
(Ord. No. 80-417, § 1, 9-8-92)  
Sec. 41-99. - Authority to require submission of samples. 
The city may require any user to submit one or more representative samples of it's wastewater discharged or proposed to be discharged to the POTW. 
(Ord. No. 80-417, § 1, 9-8-92)  
Sec. 41-100. - Monitoring activities; control manhole; flow meter. 
(a)  The city may require, at the user's expense, the user to provide a control manhole and/or flow metering equipment to facilitate inspection, sampling and flow measurement of the building sewer and/or internal drainage systems. The control manhole shall be located on the user's premises unless otherwise allowed under the provisions herein. At the expense of the user, the sampling facility and all sampling and monitoring equipment shall be maintained at all times in a safe and proper operating condition. Following notice to provide a control manhole and/or flow metering equipment, the user shall submit to the city, plans and specifications which shall comply with all applicable local construction standards and specifications. Construction shall be completed within ninety (90) days following written approval from the city of the plans and specifications. 
(b)  When the user demonstrates that the location of a control manhole on the user's premises is impractical or will cause undue hardship on the user, the city may allow the control manhole to be constructed on a public street or sidewalk area, provided the location meets the following conditions: 
(1)  The sampling manhole will not be obstructed by landscaping or parked vehicles; 
(2)  There is ample room in or near such sampling manhole to allow accurate sampling flow measurement and preparation of samples for analysis; and 
(3)  It will not create an obstruction or other hazard in the public way. 
(c)  If the city has not required the user to provide a control manhole, the nearest downstream manhole in the public sewer to the point at which the building sewer is connected shall be designated the access point or control manhole for the user. 
(d)  The city, in its discretion, may monitor a users discharge through an available control manhole or by utilizing a downstream manhole, whichever the circumstances warrant. 
(Ord. No. 80-417, § 1, 9-8-92)  
Sec. 41-101. - Self-monitoring. 
(a)  The city may require any user to perform self-monitoring of the wastewater discharge. Any required self-monitoring program may include designation of the sampling location, frequency of sampling, number of samples, types of samples, type of analysis required, standards for testing and increased reporting schedules. 
(b)  Industrial users who conduct self-monitoring shall notify the city within twenty-four (24) hours of becoming aware of a violation of any applicable discharge limit. The user shall repeat the sampling and analysis and submit the results to the city within thirty (30) days, unless the city notifies the user that it will perform the repeat sample and analysis. 
(Ord. No. 80-417, § 1, 9-8-92)  
Sec. 41-102. - Testing and analysis. 
(a)  Sampling methods. The industrial user or its designee shall carry out sampling by customarily accepted methods to reflect the effect of constituents on the POTW and to determine the existence of hazards to life, limb, and property. The superintendent will determine the type of sample to be taken depending on the specific analysis to be performed. The industrial user or its designee shall perform all sampling and analysis in accordance with 40 CFR Part 136, standard methods, or an alternative method as approved by the superintendent. 
(b)  Facilities. 
(1)  The industrial user or its designee shall properly operate, keep clean, and maintain in good working order its wastewater monitoring and flow measurement facilities. 
(2)  The industrial user's failure to keep its monitoring and flow measurement facilities in good working order is not grounds for claiming that sample results are unrepresentative of its discharge. 
(c)  Samples. 
(1)  The industrial user or its designee shall ensures wastewater samples are representative of the industrial user's discharge. 
(2)  Composite samples. For composite samples, the industrial user or its designee shall use a flow-proportional sampling technique, unless an alternative time-based or grab-based sampling technique is approved by the superintendent. An industrial user seeking an alternative sampling technique shall submit a written request and demonstrate that the alternative sampling technique will be representative of the discharge. The superintendent may only grant the use of an alternative sampling technique if the basis for granting the alternative sampling technique is documented in the city's file for that user. 
(3)  Grab samples. 
a.  The industrial user or its designee shall use grab samples for assessing oil and grease, temperature, pH, cyanide, total phenols, sulfides, and volatile organic compounds compliance. 
b.  For compliance reports, except ninety-day compliance reports and baseline monitoring reports, the industrial user or its designee shall use a minimum of four (4) daily grab samples for oil and grease, pH, cyanide, total phenols, sulfides, and volatile organic compounds. If historical sampling data is available, the superintendent may authorize a lower number of samples. 
c.  For ninety-day compliance and baseline monitoring reports, the industrial user or its designee may composite multiple grab samples prior to analysis, if they comply with all of the following: 
i.  They are collected during a twenty-four-hour period; 
ii.  They are composited using protocols (including appropriate preservation) specified in 40 CFR part 136 and appropriate EPA guidance; 
iii.  For cyanide, total phenols, and sulfides they are composited in the field or the laboratory; 
iv.  For volatile organics and oil and grease they are composited only in the laboratory; and 
v.  For other pollutants, they are composited as authorized by the superintendent. 
(Ord. No. 80-417, § 1, 9-8-92; Ord. No. 80-744, § 7, 6-14-16)  
Sec. 41-103. - Surcharge. 
There shall be a surcharge assessed to nondomestic users in order to cover the added costs of investigating, pumping or treating discharges in violation of this article, or to cover the added costs of treating discharges which contain compatible pollutants in excess of the amounts set forth in section 41-161. 
(Ord. No. 80-417, § 1, 9-8-92)  
Sec. 41-104. - Cost Recovery. 
In addition to service charges, the user shall be responsible for any additional costs incurred by the POTW due to the user's discharge or incurred by the POTW due to a violation of this article. Recoverable costs include, but are not limited to, expenses incurred due to additional monitoring, investigating, pumping or treating of discharges; damage or loss to the POTW; fines and penalties incurred by the city as a result of any user discharging in violation of this article. The user shall be notified of all charges assessed pursuant to this provision. 
(Ord. No. 80-417, § 1, 9-8-92)  
Secs. 41-105—41-109. - Reserved. 
Part IV. 
Noncompliance  
Sec. 41-110. - Prohibited bypass. 
It shall be unlawful for any user to intentionally bypass any portion of the treatment facility by discharging in violation of applicable effluent limits. Enforcement action shall be taken against a user for a bypass unless; 
(1)  The bypass was unavoidable to prevent loss of life, personal injury or severe property damage; 
(2)  There were no feasible alternatives to the bypass, however, if adequate back up equipment should have been installed in the exercise of reasonable engineering judgment to prevent a bypass which occurred during normal periods of equipment down time or preventative maintenance this exception shall not apply; and 
(3)  The user complies with the notice requirements set forth in section 41-112(a). 
(Ord. No. 80-417, § 1, 9-8-92)  
Sec. 41-111. - Allowable bypass. 
A user may be allowed to bypass the treatment facility only under the following conditions: 
(1)  The user complies with the notice requirements set forth in section 41-112(b); 
(2)  The bypass does not violate any pretreatment requirements; and 
(3)  The bypass is necessary for essential maintenance to assure efficient operation. 
(Ord. No. 80-417, § 1, 9-8-92)  
Sec. 41-112. - Bypass notice. 
(a)  Unanticipated bypass in violation of applicable pretreatment requirements. In the case of an unanticipated bypass violating applicable pretreatment limits, the user shall notify the POTW by telephone immediately upon knowledge of the bypass. A written report shall then be submitted within five (5) days thereof. The written report shall contain a description of the bypass and its cause; the duration of the bypass, including exact dates and times, and if the bypass has not been corrected, the anticipated time it is expected to continue; the steps taken or planned to reduce, eliminate, and prevent reoccurrence of the bypass. The superintendent may waive the written report requirement if a sufficient oral report was received within twenty-four (24) hours. 
(b)  Anticipated bypass. If a user knows in advance of the need to bypass within applicable pretreatment limits, it shall submit prior notice to the POTW, if possible, at least ten (10) days before the date of the bypass. 
(Ord. No. 80-417, § 1, 9-8-92)  
Sec. 41-113. - Significant noncompliance. 
An industrial user shall not be in significant noncompliance with the pretreatment regulations. An industrial user is in significant noncompliance if its violations meet one (1) or more of the following criteria: 
(1)  The industrial user has chronic violations of wastewater discharge limits. Chronic violations of wastewater discharge limits occur when sixty-six (66) percent or more of all of the measurements taken during a six-month period exceed (by any magnitude) the daily maximum limit: average or instantaneous limit for the same pollutant parameter; 
(2)  The industrial user has technical review criteria violations. Technical review criteria violations occur when thirty-three (33) percent or more of all of the measurements for any pollutant parameter taken during a six-month period equal or exceed the product of the daily maximum limit: average or instantaneous limit times the applicable TRC (TRC = 1.4 for BOD, TSS, fats, oil and grease, and 1.2 for all other pollutants except pH); 
(3)  The industrial user violated any other pretreatment effluent limit (daily maximum, longer-term average, or instantaneous limit) that the POTW determined caused, alone or in combination with other discharges, interference, pass through, or endangered the health of the POTW personnel or the general public; 
(4)  The industrial user discharged a pollutant that caused imminent endangerment to human health, welfare, or the environment; or resulted in the POTW's exercise of its emergency authority to halt or prevent such a discharge; 
(5)  Within ninety (90) days after the schedule date, the industrial user did not meet a compliance schedule date or a compliance schedule milestone for starting construction, completing construction, attaining final compliance, or any other date contained in an order; 
(6)  Within thirty (30) days after the due date, the industrial user did not provide required reports including all of the following: baseline monitoring reports, ninety-day compliance reports, periodic self-monitoring reports, and reports on compliance with compliance schedules; 
(7)  The industrial user did not accurately report noncompliance; or 
(8)  The violation or violations adversely affected the operation or implementation of the pretreatment program as determined by the superintendent. 
(Ord. No. 80-417, § 1, 9-8-92; Ord. No. 80-744, § 8, 6-14-16)  
Sec. 41-114. - Annual publication. 
The name of those users who are found to be in significant noncompliance as defined in section 41-113, during the period since the previous publication, shall be published annually in the local daily newspaper with the largest circulation. 
(Ord. No. 80-417, § 1, 9-8-92)  
Secs. 41-115—41-120. - Reserved. 
Part V. 
Industrial Pretreatment Permits  
Sec. 41-121. - Permit required. 
All significant industrial users and any other user as required by the superintendent, shall obtain an industrial pretreatment permit from the superintendent in order to discharge into the POTW. Obtaining an industrial pretreatment permit does not relieve a permittee of any obligation to obtain other permits required by federal, state, or local law. 
(Ord. No. 80-417, § 1, 9-8-92)  
Sec. 41-122. - Permit not required. 
Upon a finding that a noncategorical user has no reasonable potential for adversely effecting the POTW's operation or for violating any pretreatment standard or requirement, the control authority (POTW) may at any time, upon its own initiative or in response to a petition received from a noncategorical industrial user or POTW and with the consent of the approval authority, determine that such industrial user is not a significant industrial user to which the provisions of this article apply. Such determinations will be submitted to the approval authority and, unless objected to, shall become effective ninety (90) days from the date of submittal to the approval authority. 
(Ord. No. 80-417, § 1, 9-8-92)  
Sec. 41-123. - Permit application. 
All users required to obtain a permit shall make application on a form provided by the superintendent submitting the following information within sixty (60) days from receipt of notice to file application: 
(1)  Name, address and location of facility; 
(2)  A statement as to whether the user is a corporation, partnership, proprietorship or other type of entity and the name of the person(s) responsible for the discharge by the user; 
(3)  Standard Industrial Classification (SIC) code of both the industry and any processes for which federal categorical standards have been promulgated; 
(4)  Wastewater constituents and characteristics including pollutants in the discharge which are limited by any federal, state or local standards. Sampling and analysis shall be performed in accordance with procedures established in 40 CFR 136, as amended; 
(5)  Time and duration of discharges; 
(6)  Average daily and instantaneous peak discharge flow rates in gallons per day, including daily, monthly, and seasonal variations. All flows shall be measured unless verifiable techniques are approved by the superintendent. 
(7)  Site plans, floor plans, mechanical and plumbing plans detailed to show all sewers, sewer connections, inspection manholes, sampling chambers and appurtenances by size, location and elevation; 
(8)  Detailed plans showing the pretreatment facilities and operating procedures; 
(9)  A description of the activities, facilities and plant processes on the premises including a list of all raw materials and chemicals used at the facility which are or could be discharged to the POTW; 
(10)  Each product produced by type, amount, process(s) and rate of production; 
(11)  Type and amount of raw materials processed on the average and maximum per day; 
(12)  Number and title of all employees, hours of operation, and actual or proposed hours of operation of the pretreatment system; 
(13)  A list of all environmental control permits held by or for the user; 
(14)  Nature and concentration of any pollutants or materials in the discharge which are limited by city, state or federal pretreatment standards, together with a statement whether or not compliance is being achieved with the pretreatment standards on a consistent basis and if not, whether operation and maintenance activities and/or additional pretreatment is necessary for the user to comply with the applicable pretreatment standards; 
(15)  Where additional pretreatment and/or operation and maintenance is necessary to comply with the applicable pretreatment standards, the user shall provide a compliance time schedule indicating the shortest time period necessary to achieve compliance. The completion date in the schedule shall not be longer than the compliance date established for the applicable pretreatment standard. 
(i)  All compliance time schedules shall contain progress increments providing dates for the commencement and completion of major events necessary to achieve compliance, including but not limited to hiring an engineer, completing preliminary plans and final plans, executing contracts for major components, commencing construction, completing construction and commencing operation of the system. 
(ii)  Under no circumstances shall the city allow a time increment for any step directed toward compliance to exceed nine (9) months and no compliance period shall exceed a total of eighteen (18) months. 
(iii)  The user shall submit, within fourteen (14) days of the scheduled date for each progress increment, a progress report to the city stating whether or not it has complied with the increment of progress, the reason for any delay and the steps being taken to return to the compliance time schedule. In no event shall more than nine (9) months elapse between submittal of progress reports to the city. 
(16)  Any other information required to be submitted by the superintendent. 
(17)  All permit applications shall be signed by an authorized representative and certified as required in section 41-85. 
(Ord. No. 80-417, § 1, 9-8-92)  
Sec. 41-124. - Permit conditions. 
(a)  Industrial pretreatment permits shall include all of the following conditions: 
(1)  A statement of duration; 
(2)  A statement of nontransferability; 
(3)  Effluent limits for the average and maximum wastewater constituents and characteristics; 
(4)  Sampling, reporting notification, and recordkeeping requirements; and 
(5)  A statement that a violation of pretreatment standards and requirements may result in applicable civil and criminal penalties, as described in division 5 of this article. 
(b)  Additionally, if the superintendent determines it is necessary, industrial pretreatment permits may include any of the following conditions: 
(1)  A schedule of fees and charges; 
(2)  Limits on average and maximum rate and time of discharge, requirements for flow regulation and equalization, or both; 
(3)  Requirements for installation and maintenance of inspection and sampling facilities; 
(4)  Requirements for installations and operation of discharge flow monitors; 
(5)  Compliance schedules; 
(6)  Requirements for submission of technical reports, discharge reports, or both; 
(7)  Requirements for maintaining plant records relating to wastewater discharge as specified by the superintendent; 
(8)  Requirements for allowing the city or its agent to access any plant records; 
(9)  Requirements for notifying the city or its agent of any new introduction of wastewater constituents or any substantial change in the volume or character of the wastewater constituent introduced into the POTW; 
(10)  Requirements for notifying the city or its agent of accidental discharges, as required in section 41-80; 
(11)  Requirements for notifying the city or its agent of slug discharges; 
(12)  Requirements for controlling slug discharge; 
(13)  Requirements for BMPs; and 
(14)  Other conditions to ensure compliance with this division. 
(c)  Within fifteen (15) days of receiving a permit issued pursuant to section 41-121, a SIU may request reconsideration of the conditions contained in the permit. The SIU shall submit the request for consideration in writing and state the grounds supporting the request for reconsideration. 
(Ord. No. 80-417, § 1, 9-8-92; Ord. No. 80-744, § 9, 6-14-16)  
Sec. 41-125. - Permit modifications. 
(a)  The superintendent shall have the authority to amend any permit issued hereunder in order to: 
(1)  Assure compliance by the POTW with applicable laws, regulations, and the POTW NPDES permit; 
(2)  Account for substantial changes in discharges by the user; 
(3)  Account for new information concerning the pollutants discharged by the user; 
(4)  Reflect changes in federal or state laws and regulations or in City ordinances; 
(5)  In the event there are operational changes at the POTW that require revision of the permit; or 
(6)  Modify or terminate any special agreement provision contained in a permit. 
(7)  Changes in monitoring locations; 
(8)  Correction of typographical errors; or 
(9)  Incorporation of enforcement actions. 
(b)  The user shall be informed of any changes in the permit at least thirty (30) days prior to the effective date of change, unless a shorter time is necessary to meet applicable law or to protect human health or the environment. 
(Ord. No. 80-417, § 1, 9-8-92)  
Sec. 41-126. - Permit term. 
All industrial pretreatment user permits shall be issued for a specified time period not to exceed five (5) years. The user shall apply for a permit reissuance a minimum of one hundred eighty (180) days prior to the expiration of the user's existing permit. 
(Ord. No. 80-417, § 1, 9-8-92)  
Sec. 41-127. - Permit transfer. 
Industrial pretreatment permits are issued to a specific user for a specific operation and location. Industrial pretreatment permits are not transferable to another user or location without prior written approval of the superintendent. The superintendent may approve a permit transfer for the duration of the permit period under the following conditions: 
(1)  The transferee makes application to the superintendent for permit transfer at least sixty (60) days prior to the date of transfer and acknowledges full responsibility for complying with the existing permit; and 
(2)  The permittee has not violated any provision of the user permit or this article during the six-5 month period preceding the date of transfer; and 
(3)  As of the date of transfer, there are no unpaid charges or fees due to the city from the permittee related to the use of the POTW; and 
(4)  No significant change will be made to the operation, discharge, facilities and activities of the transferee and the application for the industrial pretreatment permit remains accurate for the transferee. 
(Ord. No. 80-417, § 1, 9-8-92)  
Sec. 41-128. - Interim permit. 
Interim permits may be issued by the superintendent for a period not to exceed ninety (90) days. The terms and conditions of the permit shall be established by the superintendent. 
(Ord. No. 80-417, § 1, 9-8-92)  
Sec. 41-129. - Permit fees. 
Users shall pay an industrial pretreatment permit fee to the city to reimburse the city for its cost of processing the application, issuing the permit, administering the permit, and processing renewal applications. 
(Ord. No. 80-417, § 1, 9-8-92)  
Sec. 41-130. - Revocation of industrial pretreatment permit. 
(a)  The city may revoke the industrial pretreatment permit during its term or deny renewal to any user who is found to have violated any one of the following conditions: 
(1)  The violation of any permit condition; 
(2)  The violation of any provision of this article; 
(3)  Failure to accurately report the wastewater constituents and characteristics of its discharge; 
(4)  Failure to report significant changes in its operations or wastewater constituents and characteristics; 
(5)  Failure to fully disclose all relevant facts or misrepresent any material fact; 
(6)  Refusal to provide reasonable access to the user's premises for the purpose of inspection, monitoring or sampling; 
(7)  Endangerment of human health or environment that can only be abated by revocation of the permit; 
(8)  The change in any condition which requires either a temporary or permanent reduction or elimination of the discharge. Upon revocation of its permit, the user shall terminate its discharge to the POTW. 
(b)  Upon revocation of its permit, the user shall terminate its discharge to the POTW. 
(Ord. No. 80-417, § 1, 9-8-92)  
Sec. 41-131. - Baseline monitoring reports for permittees and users subject to categorical pretreatment standards. 
(a)  All existing industrial users subject to the categorical pretreatment standards shall submit a report to the superintendent within one hundred eighty (180) days after the effective date of a categorical pretreatment standard or one hundred (100) days after the final administrative decision made upon a categorical determination submitted under 40 CFR 403.6(a)(4), whichever is later, containing the following information: 
(1)  The name, and address of the facility including the name of the operator and all owners. 
(2)  A list of any environmental control permits held by or for the facility. 
(3)  A description of the nature, average rate of production, and standard industrial classification of the operations carried out, including a schematic process diagram which indicates points of discharge to the POTW from the regulated processes. 
(4)  The amount of measured average and maximum daily flow, in gallons per day, to the POTW, for both the regulated process streams and other streams as necessary to use the combined waste stream formula provided in 40 CFR 403.6(e). 
(5)  Identify the pretreatment standards applicable to each regulated process as required by 40 CFR 403.12 (b)(5). 
(6)  The results of sampling and analysis which identify the nature (or mass where required) of regulated pollutants in the discharge from each regulated process. Procedures for sampling and analysis shall meet the requirements set forth at 40 CFR 403.12(b)(5)(iii) and (iv). 
(7)  Attach a statement signed by an authorized representative of the user and certified by a qualified representative stating whether the pretreatment standards are being met on a consistent basis, and if not, whether additional operation and maintenance and/or pretreatment is required for the user to meet the pretreatment standards. 
(8)  Where additional pretreatment and/or operation and maintenance are necessary to comply with applicable pretreatment standards, the user shall provide a declaration of the shortest schedule by which the user will provide the necessary changes. The completion date in the schedule shall not be longer than the compliance date established for the applicable pretreatment standard. 
(9)  When required by the city, the user shall submit a categorical process statement certifying whether or not a categorical process is performed at the user's facility and identifying all categorical processes which are performed. All categorical process statements must be certified as required in section 41-85 on certification. 
(b)  All "new sources" and sources that become industrial users subsequent to the promulgation of an applicable categorical standard shall submit a report to the superintendent, within 90 days prior to commencement of discharge, containing the following information: 
(1)  The name, and address of the facility including the name of the operator and all owners. 
(2)  A list of any environmental control permits held by or for the facility. 
(3)  A description of the nature, average rate of production, and standard industrial classification of the operations carried out, including a schematic process diagram which indicates points of discharge to the POTW from the regulated processes. 
(4)  An estimate of the amount of average and maximum daily flow, in gallons per day, to the POTW, for both the regulated process streams and other streams as necessary to use the combined waste stream formula provided in 40 CFR 403.6(e). 
(5)  Identify, by estimation if necessary, the pretreatment standards applicable to each regulated process as required by 40 CFR 403.12(b) (5). 
(6)  The results of sampling and analysis which identify the nature (or mass where required) of regulated pollutants in the discharge from each regulated process. Procedures for sampling and analysis shall meet the requirements set forth at 40 CFR 403.12(b)(5)(iii) and (iv). 
(7)  The method of pretreatment the source intends to use to meet applicable pretreatment standards. 
(8)  When required by the city, the user shall submit a categorical process statement certifying whether or not a categorical process is performed at the user's facility and identifying all categorical processes which are performed. All categorical process statements must be certified as required in section 41-85 on certification. 
(Ord. No. 80-417, § 1, 9-8-92)  
Sec. 41-132. - Permittee initial compliance reports. 
(a)  Within ninety (90) days following the date for final compliance with applicable categorical pretreatment standards or in case of a "new Source," following commencement of the introduction of wastewater into the POTW, or in the case of noncategorical industrial users, any industrial user subject to the pretreatment standards or local requirements shall submit to the superintendent a report containing the following information: 
(1)  The amount of measured average and maximum daily flow, in gallons per day, to the POTW, for both the regulated process streams and other streams as necessary to use the combined waste stream formula provided in 40 CFR 403.6(e). 
(2)  Identify the pretreatment standards applicable to each regulated process as required by 40 CFR 403.12(b) (5). 
(3)  Attach a statement signed by an authorized representative of the user and certified by a qualified representative stating whether the pretreatment standards are being met on a consistent basis, and if not, whether additional operation and maintenance and/or pretreatment is required for the user to meet the pretreatment standards. 
(b)  For industrial users subject to equivalent mass or concentration limits established according to 40 CFR 403.6(c), this report shall contain a reasonable measure of the user's long term production rate. For all other industrial users, this report shall include the user's actual production during the sampling period. 
(Ord. No. 80-417, § 1, 9-8-92)  
Sec. 41-133. - Permittee periodic compliance reports. 
(a)  Every June and December, a permittee or SIU shall submit a compliance report to the superintendent that indicates all of the following: 
(1)  The nature and concentration of pollutants in the effluent that are limited by the categorical pretreatment standards or local requirements; 
(2)  A record of measured or estimated average and maximum daily flows of the reporting period for the discharge. Upon request of the POTW, the user shall provide more detailed reporting of flow; and 
(3)  All monitoring results of any permitted wastewater constituents analyzed in accordance with approved 40 CFR 136 test methods. 
(b)  The reports shall be based on sampling and analysis performed in the period covered by the report and done in accordance with the techniques described in 40 CFR part 136. The POTW may require the user to submit periodic compliance reports more frequently than bi-annually. Further, the months that the periodic compliance reports are due may be altered at the discretion of the superintendent in consideration of local high or low flow rates, holidays, budget cycles, or other factors. 
(c)  If this division requires an industrial user to comply with a BMP, the industrial user shall submit documentation necessary for the superintendent to determine compliance with the requirement. 
(Ord. No. 80-417, § 1, 9-8-92; Ord. No. 80-744, § 10, 6-14-16)  
Sec. 41-134. - Significant industrial user submittal. 
All industries meeting the definition of significant industrial user, subject to the national categorical pretreatment standards or as otherwise required by the city, must submit the following information: 
(1)  Site plans, floor plans, mechanical and plumbing plans detailed to show all sewers, sewer connections and appurtenances by the size, location, and elevation. 
(2)  Detailed plans showing the pretreatment facilities and operating procedures. The city will review such plans and respond with approval or suggested modifications to the user within ninety (90) days following plan submittal. The review of such plans and operating procedures will in no way relieve the user from the responsibility of modifying the facility as necessary to produce an effluent acceptable to the city under the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 80-417, § 1, 9-8-92)  
Secs. 41-135—41-139. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - STORM SEWERS 
 
Sec. 41-140. - Discharge into storm sewers. 
(a)  Storm water and all other unpolluted drainage shall be discharged only to storm sewers or to a natural outlet approved by the state department of natural resources. Industrial cooling water or unpolluted process waters may only be discharged to a storm sewer or natural outlet pursuant to a valid NPDES permit. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to discharge or cause or allow any illicit discharge, dumping or disposing of materials other than natural precipitation, to discharge any sewage, industrial or commercial waste, or other fluid into any public storm sewer, drain or any sewer, drain or pipe connected with or emptying into any public storm sewer, except the following discharges: water line flushing, landscape irrigation run off, diverted stream flows, rising ground water, pumped ground water, discharges from potable water sources, foundation drains, air conditioning condensation, irrigation water, springs, water from crawl space pumps, footing drains, lawn watering, non-commercial car washing, flows from riparian habitats and wetlands, residential swimming pool discharges and other dechlorinated swimming pool discharges, and street wash water. 
(c)  No person shall connect or attach any downspout, pipe or drain or cause such a connection to any public storm sewer without first having obtained permission from the director of public service. Application for such connection shall be made in writing to the director of public service and shall state the location of the connection; the name and address of the owner and occupant of the premises; and shall be accompanied by sufficient plans and specifications as to enable the director of public service to determine whether the connection is done in accordance with standard practices and will not contribute any pollutants to the public storm sewers nor endanger the health, safety and welfare of pedestrians and others using public streets, alleys and other places. 
(Ord. No. 80-497, § 7, 7-9-96)  
Sec. 41-141. - Use of Best Management Practices. 
All users shall implement Best Management Practices as defined by 40 CFR 122.2 to minimize the contribution of pollutants to the public storm sewers to the maximum extent practicable. 
(Ord. No. 80-497, § 7, 7-9-96)  
Sec. 41-142. - Industrial storm water discharge. 
For purposes of enforcement of this division the director of public service or his designated representative shall have the authority to implement and manage an industrial storm water program regulating the quantity and quality of industrial storm water discharges. 
(Ord. No. 80-497, § 7, 7-9-96)  
Sec. 41-143. - Notice of NPDES permits. 
Any person who holds a National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System permit shall provide a copy of the permit to the director of public service or his designated representative within sixty (60) calendar days of the adoption of this Ordinance or if the permit is issued after the adoption of this Ordinance, within sixty (60) days of issuance of the permit. 
(Ord. No. 80-497, § 7, 7-9-96)  
Sec. 41-144. - Notification of spills, illicit discharges and dumping. 
(a)  Immediate notice. In the event that a user or other person becomes aware of a spill, illicit discharge to the storm sewer or the dumping of prohibited material, the user or person shall immediately telephone and notify the city through the director of public service or his designated representative of the incident. The notification shall include the location of the discharge, type of material discharged, concentration level, volume and corrective action taken. 
(b)  Five day report. Within five (5) days following a spill, illicit discharge or knowledge of a dump, a storm sewer user shall submit to the director of public service a detailed written report describing the cause of the spill, illicit discharge or dump, the measures taken to contain and clean up the discharge and the measures to be taken by the user to prevent any future recurrence. 
(c)  Employee notice. All industrial storm sewer users shall notify all employees of the notification procedures required in the event of a spill, illicit discharge or knowledge of a dump. A notice shall be permanently posted on the user's bulletin board or other prominent place stating the name and telephone number of the director of public service or his designated representative in the event of a spill, illicit discharge or knowledge of a dump. 
(Ord. No. 80-497, § 7, 7-9-96)  
Sec. 41-145. - Authority of inspectors. 
For the administration of this article, authorized representatives of the city shall be permitted ready access to a user's premises at any time a storm sewer user is in operation or has storm water discharge for purposes of inspection, observation, measurement, documentation, records examination and copying, sampling and testing. Where a user has security measures in force that require proper identification and clearance before entry onto the premises, the user shall make necessary arrangements with security personnel so that upon presentation of proper identification, personnel from the city, state department of natural resources and EPA will be permitted to enter without delay. 
(Ord. No. 80-497, § 7, 7-9-96)  
Sec. 41-146. - Non-routine inspections. 
Under circumstances where an inspection of a non-domestic facility is necessary to investigate a problem discharge, spill or suspected dumping, authorized representatives of the city shall be permitted ready access to enter any user's premises for purposes of inspection, observation, measurement, sampling and testing. 
(Ord. No. 80-497, § 7, 7-9-96)  
Sec. 41-147. - Other inspections. 
Inspections performed by state or federal representatives shall not relieve a user from inspection by city representatives, and inspection by the city shall not relieve any user from compliance with lawful inspection by state and federal representatives. 
(Ord. No. 80-497, § 7, 7-9-96)  
Sec. 41-148. - Monitoring equipment; removal of samples, data. 
The city, through its authorized representative, shall have the right to set up monitoring equipment on the user's premises as needed for sampling and flow measurement to take and remove samples of storm water and pollutants from the user's discharge, and to make copies of other data and material inspected during an entry upon the user's property. If the city requests that the user make photocopies of documents, the city shall give the user at least twenty-four (24) hours' notice to comply with such request, however, this notice requirement does not affect the right of the city during an inspection to immediately copy data or other materials. Upon the written request of the user, split samples will be provided. 
(Ord. No. 80-497, § 7, 7-9-96)  
Sec. 41-149. - Access refused. 
It shall be a violation of this article for any user to refuse an authorized representative of the city access to its premises; or to refuse to allow the representative to obtain, take, or remove samples; or to refuse access to records pertinent to this article. 
(Ord. No. 80-497, § 7, 7-9-96)  
Sec. 41-150. - Authority to require facility inspections, reports, discharge information and submission of samples. 
The city may require any user to perform facility inspections, discharge monitoring, submission of discharge information reports or submission of one or more representative samples of its storm water discharge. 
(Ord. No. 80-497, § 7, 7-9-96)  
Sec. 41-151. - Monitoring facilities; control manhole; flow meter. 
(a)  The city may require, at the user's expense, the user to provide a control manhole and/or flow metering equipment to facilitate inspection, sampling and flow measurement of the storm sewer and/or internal drainage systems. The control manhole shall be located on the user's premises unless otherwise allowed under the provisions herein. At the expense of the user, the sampling facility and all sampling and monitoring equipment shall be maintained at all times in a safe and proper operating condition. Following notice to provide a control manhole and/or flow metering equipment, the user shall submit to the city, plans and specifications which shall comply with all applicable local construction standards and specifications. The plans must be approved by the engineering division and any other division or department specified in the notice and all alternate permits shall be obtained. Construction shall be completed within ninety (90) days following written approval from the city of the plans and specifications. 
(b)  When the user demonstrates that the location of a control manhole on the user's premises is impractical or will cause undue hardship on the user, the city may allow the control manhole to be constructed on a public street or sidewalk area, provided the location meets the following conditions: 
(1)  The sampling manhole will not be obstructed by landscaping or parked vehicles; 
(2)  There is ample room in or near such sampling manhole to allow accurate sampling flow measurement and preparation of samples for analysis; and 
(3)  It will not create an obstruction or other hazard in the public way. 
(c)  If the city has not required the user to provide a control manhole, the nearest downstream manhole in the public storm sewer to which the user's premises is connected shall be designated the access point or control manhole for the user. 
(d)  The city, in its discretion, may monitor a users discharge through an available control manhole or by utilizing a downstream manhole, whichever the circumstances warrant. 
(Ord. No. 80-497, § 7, 7-9-96)  
Sec. 41-152. - Self-monitoring. 
(a)  The city may require any user to perform self-monitoring of the storm water discharge. Any required self-monitoring program may include designation of the sampling location, frequency of sampling, number of samples, types of samples, type of analysis required, standards for testing and increased reporting schedules. 
(b)  Industrial users who conduct self-monitoring shall notify the city within twenty-four (24) hours of becoming aware of a violation of any applicable discharge limit. The user shall repeat the sampling and analysis and submit the results to the city within thirty (30) days, unless the city notifies the user that it will perform the repeat sample and analysis. 
(Ord. No. 80-497, § 7, 7-9-96)  
Sec. 41-153. - Enforcement. 
The director of public service shall have the authority to implement the enforcement provisions enumerated in Division 5 of Article III, Chapter 41, against any storm sewer user in violation of any of the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 80-497, § 7, 7-9-96; Ord. No. 80-527, § 28, 1-13-98)  
Sec. 41-154. - Cost recovery. 
The user shall be responsible for any costs incurred by the city or damage to the sewer system due to the user's discharge in violation of this article. Recoverable costs include, but are not limited to, expenses incurred due to additional monitoring, analysis investigating, pumping or treating of discharges; containment, isolation, cleanup and disposal; damage or loss to the sewer system; fines and penalties incurred by the city as a result of any user discharging in violation of this article. The user shall be notified of all charges assessed pursuant to this provision. 
(Ord. No. 80-497, § 7, 7-9-96)  
Sec. 41-155. - Post-construction storm water runoff.[4] 
(a)  Purpose. The purpose of this section is to establish requirements and standards for discharging and treating storm water runoff in the City of Warren that comply with the Federal National Pollutant Discharge System (NPDES) storm water regulations, administered by the State of Michigan, pursuant to MCL 324.3103, for all new development or redevelopment projects. The City of Warren holds a State of Michigan issued jurisdictional general permit for discharges from a city municipal separate storm sewer system (MS4). The permit, incorporating state and federal rules and regulations, requires the city to manage post-construction storm water runoff from new development and redevelopment projects throughout the City of Warren. 
(b)  Definitions. 
(1)  Responsible party is the legal or equitable owner(s) of the property; or person(s) or entities with legal or equitable rights to develop the property. 
(2)  Post-construction storm water runoff is the storm water that flows from a project site after completion of a development or redevelopment project. 
(3)  The project site is any area on the development or redevelopment project where there is earth disturbance. 
(4)  The minimum treatment volume is the first inch of the post-construction storm water runoff. The minimum treatment volume is calculated by the formula listed in the Michigan Department of Environmental Quality (MDEQ) Post-Construction Storm Water Runoff Controls Program Compliance Assistance Document, as amended (SWCAD). 
(5)  Water quality treatment performance standard is removal of a minimum of eighty (80) percent of total suspended solids (TSS) as compared with uncontrolled runoff; or limiting TSS discharge concentrations to no more than eighty (80) milligrams per liter. 
(6)  Channel protection performance standard is maintaining post-construction storm water runoff and peak flow rate at or below the existing level for all storms up to the two-year, twenty-four-hour event. 
(7)  Existing level is the runoff volume and peak flow rate from the land use immediately preceding the development or redevelopment project. 
(8)  Earth disturbance is any activity which removes ground cover, changes the slope or contours of the land, or exposes the soil surface to the actions of wind and rain. It includes, but is not limited to, excavation, surface grading, filling, landscaping, or removal of vegetative roots. 
(9)  A development or redevelopment project is a construction project involving a public or private property where there is either: 
(i)  An earth disturbance of one (1) acre or more; or 
(ii)  an earth disturbance of less than one (1) acre, but that is part of a larger common plan of development or sale that would disturb one (1) acre or more. 
(c)  Applicability. 
(1)  This section applies to all development or redevelopment projects where post-construction storm water runoff flows into a MS4. 
(d)  Macomb County Public Works Office's Procedures and Design Standards for Storm Water Management (PDSSM). 
(1)  Unless otherwise provided, for purposes of this Section, all measurements or calculations are determined by the methods and definitions provided in the most recent version of the PDSSM; 
(e)  Requirements. Unless the City of Warren Engineering Division provides the responsible party a written exemption, the responsible party shall do all of the following: 
(1)  Before beginning construction, apply for and receive a construction permit from the City of Warren. 
(2)  The permit application shall include a site-specific tentative storm water management plan that complies with the storm water criteria, source controls, site controls, and storm water management practices listed in the most recent version of the PDSSM, including but not limited to all of the following: 
(i)  Post-development, site-specific structural and vegetative best management practices (BMPs) designed, installed, and maintained to: treat the minimum treatment volume to the water quality treatment performance standard; and achieve the channel protection performance standard; and 
(ii)  If the TSS concentrations in the minimum treatment volume do not exceed eighty (80) milligrams per liter, the responsible party shall provide site-specific documentation attesting to the TSS concentrations; 
(3)  Develop or redevelop in accordance to the approved storm water tentative management plan. 
(4)  After development or redevelopment, submit and receive approval for the final operation and maintenance plan that ensures maximum design performance. 
(5)  Develop and maintain the property in conformity with the final operation and maintenance plan including annual storm water maintenance reports. 
(f)  Enforcement. 
(1)  Final operation and maintenance plan compliance. To ensure final operation and maintenance plan compliance, the City of Warren may do any one (1) or more of the following: 
(i)  Have the city engineer stop construction on a project until the responsible party provides adequate assurances that the requirements of this section will be implemented; 
(ii)  Access the property for intermittent inspections by the building, engineering, waste water treatment, or other city department; 
(iii)  Require the responsible party to connect to the public storm sewer system; 
(iv)  Perform any necessary BMP maintenance or corrective actions that the responsible party neglects to perform; or 
(v)  Impose any other requirements necessary. 
(2)  Cost reimbursement. The City of Warren may require the responsible party to reimburse the city for costs associated with ensuring compliance with this section. 
(3)  Penalty. 
(i)  A violation of this section is a municipal civil infraction, punishable by a fine of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) but not more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per violation; and/or costs; assessments; and damages and expenses, as provided by MCL 600.8727(3). 
(ii)  A judge or magistrate may also order: 
a.  Corrective action to remedy the violation; 
b.  Reimbursement to the city for documented enforcement costs; and 
c.  Any other appropriate legal or equitable action. 
(Ord. No. 80-734, § 1, 11-24-15; Ord. No. 80-752, § 1, 2-28-17) 
Footnotes:

Secs. 41-156—41-160. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 5. - ENFORCEMENT 
 
Sec. 41-161. - Notification of violation. 
Upon discovery of a violation of these ordinances or a wastewater permit issued hereunder, the superintendent may serve a written notice of violation upon the user. The superintendent may require the user to submit an explanation of the violation and a plan for the satisfactory correction and prevention of the cause of the violation. Submission of an explanation or plan shall not relieve the user of any liability for prior or subsequent violations. 
(Ord. No. 80-417, § 1, 9-8-92; Ord. No. 80-497, § 6, 7-9-96)  
Sec. 41-162. - Administrative order of compliance. 
Upon discovery of a violation of these ordinances or a wastewater permit issued hereunder, the superintendent shall have the authority to issue an order of compliance upon the user directing the user to implement additional self-monitoring; additional management practices; operational techniques; install devices or other related appurtenances; or implement other requirements that may be necessary and appropriate to achieve compliance. Failure to comply with an order of compliance shall be grounds for termination of service. 
(Ord. No. 80-417, § 1, 9-8-92; Ord. No. 80-497, § 6, 7-9-96)  
Sec. 41-163. - Cease and desist order. 
Upon discovery of a violation or the continuance of a violation of these ordinances or a wastewater permit issued hereunder, the superintendent shall have the authority to issue a cease and desist order directing the user to cease all violations of this ordinance and comply forthwith. The cease and desist order may also require the user to take such appropriate remedial or preventive action as may be necessary to properly respond to the violation including but not limited to halting operations and terminating discharge. 
(Ord. No. 80-417, § 1, 9-8-92; Ord. No. 80-497, § 6, 7-9-96)  
Sec. 41-164. - Emergency suspension of service. 
(a)  In order to stop an actual or threatened discharge presenting or causing an imminent or substantial harm to the health or welfare of persons, the POTW, or the environment, the superintendent shall have the authority to suspend the wastewater treatment service or the user's wastewater permit. Upon the emergency suspension of service, the superintendent shall immediately notify the user of such suspension. 
(b)  Any user notified of a suspension of the wastewater service or the wastewater permit, shall immediately stop or eliminate its discharge. In the event of a user's failure to immediately comply voluntarily with the suspension order, the superintendent shall take steps necessary to prevent or minimize damage to the POTW, its receiving stream or individuals, including immediate severance of the sewer connection. Unless termination proceedings have been instituted, once the danger has passed the superintendent shall allow the user to recommence its discharge. 
(c)  Any user notified of a suspension of the wastewater service or the wastewater permit, shall submit to the superintendent, within fifteen (15) days, a detailed written report describing the cause of the harmful discharge, the duration of noncompliance including exact dates and times, the measures taken in response to the discharge and the measures to be taken by the user to prevent any future recurrence. 
(Ord. No. 80-417, § 1, 9-8-92; Ord. No. 80-497, § 6, 7-9-96)  
Sec. 41-165. - Termination of sewer use service. 
In the event that a user violates or continues to violate the provisions of this article, an order or a permit issued hereunder, the superintendent shall have the authority to direct the termination of the user's sewer use. Service will recommence only at the user's expense and after the user has demonstrated its ability to comply with the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 80-417, § 1, 9-8-92; Ord. No. 80-497, § 6, 7-9-96)  
Sec. 41-166. - Termination of water service. 
In the event that a user violates or continues to violate the provisions of this article, an order or a permit issued hereunder, the superintendent shall have the authority to direct the termination of the water service to the user. Service will recommence only at the user's expense and after the user has demonstrated its ability to comply with the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 80-417, § 1, 9-8-92; Ord. No. 80-497, § 6, 7-9-96)  
Sec. 41-167. - Public nuisance. 
Nothing contained in this article shall be construed as limiting in any manner the powers of the health officer, and if any unsanitary conditions exist, the same is hereby declared to be a public nuisance and shall be abated in accordance with the provisions of the Charter and this Code. 
(Ord. No. 80-417, § 1, 9-8-92; Ord. No. 80-497, § 6, 7-9-96) 
State Law reference— Nuisances generally, Ch. 21.  
Sec. 41-168. - Declaratory and equitable actions. 
If any person discharges waste into the POTW in violation of the provisions of this article, the city may institute an action in the appropriate court seeking declaratory and/or injunctive relief as required. 
(Ord. No. 80-417, § 1, 9-8-92; Ord. No. 80-497, § 6, 7-9-96)  
Sec. 41-169. - Penalty. 
(a)  The violation of any provision of chapter 41, except as otherwise provided in subsection (b), is a municipal civil infraction which shall result in the assessment of a fine of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) or not more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per violation, plus costs and other sanctions for each infraction. 
(b)  The following violations of this chapter are a misdemeanor which shall, upon conviction, be punished by a fine not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisonment for a term not exceeding ninety (90) days, or both, plus costs and other sanctions for each violation: 
(1)  Any person who at the time of a violation knew or should have known that a pollutant or substance was discharged contrary to any provision of this sewer use ordinance, or contrary to any notice, order, permit, decision or determination promulgated, issued or made by the POTW under the ordinance; 
(2)  Any person who intentionally makes a false statement, representation, or certification in an application for, or form pertaining to a permit, or in a notice, report, or record required by this sewer use ordinance, or in any other correspondence or communication, written or oral, with the POTW regarding matters regulated by this sewer use ordinance; or 
(3)  Any person who intentionally falsifies, tampers with, or renders inaccurate any sampling or monitoring device or record required to be maintained by this sewer use ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 80-417, § 1, 9-8-92; Ord. No. 80-497, § 6, 7-9-96; Ord. No. 80-527, § 28, 1-13-98)  
Sec. 41-170. - Hearings. 
(a)  Any user subject to termination of water or sewer service, revocation or nonrenewal of an industrial pretreatment permit, or enforcement action under the penalty provision of this article may, within ten (10) days of receipt of notification of the proposed action, request a hearing before the enforcement officer to demonstrate its ability to comply with the provisions of this article and otherwise establish why the proposed action should not be taken. 
(b)  The user and all witnesses shall be given thirty (30) days' notice of the scheduled hearing date. The hearing shall be conducted by the enforcement officer. Further, all testimony shall be taken under oath and recorded stenographically. Based on the evidence presented at the hearing, the enforcement officer shall provide a recommendation of action to the superintendent. The superintendent shall then take steps necessary to implement the enforcement officer's recommendation of action. 
(Ord. No. 80-417, § 1, 9-8-92; Ord. No. 80-497, § 6, 7-9-96)  
Secs. 41-171—41-180. - Reserved.

Suspended solids (SS): $0.3089 per pound in excess of three hundred fifty (350) mg/liter;

Nondomestic user cross-connection inspection charge: $0.1003 per one hundred (100) cubic feet. 
g.  The rates established here are to meet operations and shall not be excessive or produce profit over and above the requirements of the system or as required by law. 
(3)  Isolation of wholesale water costs, union contract wages and fringe benefits. The purpose of this section is to permit the automatic adjustment of retail rates to residential, commercial and industrial customers for changes in operating costs that are outside the direct control of the water and sewer system. 
a.  Wholesale water costs - the consumption-based retail water rate shall be adjusted to reflect changes in the wholesale cost of water purchases implemented by the City of Detroit during the current fiscal year. 
1.  Water purchase expense in the original adopted operating budget is calculated as the estimated water purchase volume times the wholesale rate in effect at the time of budget adoption. 
2.  When the City of Detroit Board of Water Commissioners approves a change in wholesale rate to be charged to the city, water purchase expense shall be recalculated as the actual year-to-date wholesale purchase cost plus estimated purchase volumes for the balance of the fiscal year times the revised wholesale rates. 
3.  The revised water purchase expense as determined above shall be compared to the original approved water and sewer system budget for water purchases. If the revised cost exceeds the original budget cost the resulting shortage shall be recoverable from retail customers through an increase in the water consumption rate for balance of the current fiscal year. If the revised cost is less than the original budget cost the surplus shall be rebated to retail customers through a decrease in the water consumption rate for the balance of the current fiscal year. 
The adjustment to the water consumption rate shall be determined by dividing the anticipated cost change by the projected sales volume for the balance of the current fiscal year. 
b.  Reserved. 
c.  Reserved. 
d.  Reserved. 
e.  These adjustments of water and sewer rates shall occur by operation of this ordinance under authority granted under sections 6.1 of the city charter, as if specifically adopted by city council. 
f.  Any changes in rates shall be published at least once in a newspaper of general circulation with the city. Supporting schedules shall be filed with the city clerk for public inspection and transmitted to the city council for information and review. 
g.  Nothing in this section shall, in any way, limit the power of the city council to adjust water and sewer rates by resolution or ordinance amendment independent of the operation of this ordinance.
